PETITION.TITLE: El Salvador

PARA.TAB: The Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:

There is widespread concern and outrage in the international community about the Salvadoran government's treatment of its returning refugee and internally displaced population. Since the signing of the San Jose Agreement on Human Rights by the Salvadoran government and the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front under the mediation of the United Nations, we have been hopeful for an improvement in the Salvadoran government's treatment of its civilian population, particularly those in the repatriate communities and the social movement. Every Article of the Agreement under Section 1. Respect for and Guarantee of Human Rights, has been violated by the Salvadoran government and its armed forces. The international community is aware more than ever before of the systematic intimidation and harassment including capture, torture, rape and murder of members of repatriate communities and the social movement by the Salvadoran armed forces.

We can only conclude that the Salvadoran government's lack of control of its armed forces is indicative of its own lack of real commitment to a negotiated peaceful solution to the civil war. It appears, furthermore, that the Salvadoran government is unwilling to honour Agreements to which it is signatory, including international Conventions on Human Rights, and in doing so places itself above international law.

The international community, including the Australian government, has a common interest in the peaceful resolution to the conflict and the initiation of a genuine free democratic process in El Salvador. We therefore call upon the Australian government to:

PETITION.PARA: 1.Use all diplomatic channels available to urge the Salvadoran government to:

PARA.TAB: a.respect the rights of returning refugees, internally displaced people's and community organisations,
b.order the armed forces to comply with the San Jose Agreement.

PETITION.PARA: 2.Urge the US Administration to convert all military and associated aid to humanitarian development processes.
3.Involve itself in direct support for the UN Verification Commission (ONUSAL).
4.Provide a special fund for Australian non-government organisations working with social movements and repatriate communities in El Salvador.

PARA.TAB: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Child-care Relief Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and the Senators in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the two-tiered child care fee relief scheme to be introduced by the Federal Government from 1 January 1992 will discriminate against families needing child care for "non-work related" reasons.
That fees for these families will rise to such an extent that thousands of parents will not be able to afford access to child care services.

That as a result the viability of many child care centres and services will be significantly affected causing increases in fees for families who need access to child care services for "work related" reasons.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Senate should disallow the Federal Government's new two tiered child care fee relief scheme.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Monarchy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that Australia, under its constitutional system based on the Monarchy, is one of the world's most successful democracies. The petitioners note particularly that:

PARA.TAB: Australia is one of the world's oldest democracies
Australia has led the world in many democratic reforms

PETITION.PARA: Our constitution, based on the Monarchy, has:

PARA.TAB: ensured national independence
maintained national unity in a federation
provided constitutional stability
protected our liberties and freedoms

PETITION.PARA: Australia should remain a constitutional Monarchy with Her Majesty The Queen of Australia as our head of State and as in duty bound will ever pray. God save The Queen.

PETITION.TITLE: AIDEX Exhibition
PETITION.PARA: To the Hon. the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled, the Petition of the undersigned showeth:

PARA.TAB: That the Australian Government is making Australia an active participant in the international arms trade by its official support for the Australian International Defence Exhibition (Aidex 91) to be held in November 1991.
Your Petitioners ask that the Senate should—
request the Government to withdraw all official support and participation from Aidex to regain our international standing as an advocate of disarmament and arms control.

PETITION.TITLE: FM Radio Service

PARA.TAB: To the honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PETITION.PARA: We, the undersigned, request that you urge the Minister for Transport and Communications, the Honourable Kim Beazley, MP to exercise the authority vested in him by the Broadcasting Act 1942 to :

PARA.TAB: (a) recognise that the townships of Bullfinch, Marvel Loch and Southern Cross, in the State of Western Australia, have no access to an FM radio service; and
(b) acknowledge that these townships lie outside existing service areas; and

(c) rectify this situation by directing the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal to develop appropriate licence conditions to provide for the creation of a service area and the grant of a licence to ensure that the townships of Bullfinch, Marvel Loch and Southern Cross have access to an FM radio service.

PETITION.PARA: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPINDLER

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave —I present to the Senate the following petition from 46 petitioners which is not in conformity with the Standing Orders, as it is not in the correct form:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: A humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Philippines respectfully showeth:
Attention is drawn to Australia's increasing role in the militarisation of the Pacific region and in particular to the current Government-led arms export drive.

The arms trade is not only detrimental to Australians affected by the diversion of public money away from socially beneficial areas—for example, health, education and social welfare—but is an integral factor in the oppression and poverty of the people of the Third World.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will:
Cease all military aid and training to governments engaged in repression of their own people.
Direct all Federal and State Government Departments and instrumentalities to withdraw from participation in and support for AIDEX and similar arms fairs in Australia and overseas.
Close down AIDEX 1991.
Establish a register of all applications for arms transfers and offset agreements which would be subject to public scrutiny.
Redirect all monies currently being used to promote the arms industry to socially useful research, development and production.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—If I may ask the Manager of Government Business (Senator McMullan) a question relating to today's program for the Senate, now that the Australian people have been advised that the Australian Labor Party is to change its Leader, the Prime Minister, at 6.30 tonight, the question immediately comes to mind as to what will happen to the Senate sittings. We are due to sit until 10.30 tonight. Is it the Government's intention that that continue to be so? Will it still be so if the Prime Minister is changed at 6.30? Will he, as I presume will be the case, then immediately proceed to Yarralumla to tender his resignation? Will the Government be intending to pursue business in the Senate tonight under a new Prime Minister? In effect, what will happen?

PARA.TAB: It is illuminating that the message Mr Hawke has put out this morning is that this is necessary; it is in the interests of the Party and the Government. There is no mention at all of whether it is in the interests of the nation of Australia or of the one million unemployed. It is just another demonstration that all this is really about is the power play within the Labor Party rather than any concern for the national interest at all. We are now being dragged into it. It seems that the Government wants us to sit, and to continue to sit, in this farcical environment. The Manager of Government Business might also tell us, when he advises us whether we will sit tonight, what will happen to the legislation that we are dealing with tonight. I assume that the House of Representatives will not sit tonight.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps they should call an election.

—An election would be what the Australian people would want, but it will not be what this Government would want, as it knows what would happen. Is there any point in dealing with legislation in the Senate tonight, even if the question of the leadership of the Party and the Government can be sorted out, if the House of Representatives is not to sit?

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—All that fervent hypothesising is a waste of time. Had we any intention of changing the sitting schedule, I would have moved a motion at the placing of business, and I did not.

I remind honourable senators that we are back here to deal with matters moving between the two Houses. If the House of Representatives is not to sit tonight, what is the purpose of the Senate's sitting tonight? I think that the Senate is at least entitled to know that.
—Who says it isn't?
—Well, you tell us. Will the House sit tonight?

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—There have been several attempts over the past few weeks to start a major debate about the sitting schedule of the House of Representatives, but each and every one has been an absolute waste of time, as this one is. TALK.START.PARA: —Papers are tabled in accordance with the list circulated to honourable senators. With the concurrence of the Senate, I ask that the list be incorporated in Hansard.
—Is leave granted?

—by leave—I wish to make one brief remark, as Senator Vanstone did yesterday when she pointed out that 37 documents were tabled yesterday to be dealt with in half an hour. Some of them were very important matters. Today we have not 37 but 41 documents, including such important ones as the Commissioner of Taxation annual report and the report under the Members of Parliament (Staff) Act 1984, which outlines the consultants engaged under that Act. Other documents include taxation statistics for 1989-90, the Department of the Treasury annual report, and reports on Australia and the World Bank, the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and the Australian Securities Commission. There is an enormous volume of very important material.

PARA.TAB: The reason I raise this, pointing out that it is grossly unsatisfactory for us to be hit with these on the last day of sitting and given only half an hour to talk about all 41, is that many of these reports were in draft form and available at Senate Estimates committee hearings. Some of us in the Opposition were very grateful for the existence of these reports in draft form at those hearings and thanked the departments for going to the trouble of doing so. It is particularly distressing to see the extraordinary amount of time between the preparation of the draft reports and the final presentation of the reports to the Parliament. It is simply unsatisfactory; it is unfair; and it prevents proper discussion of these matters of some substance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have they been sitting on Ministers' desks?

—Senator Tambling asks whether they have been sitting on Ministers' desks. Where have these reports been all this time? One often notices, as I did yesterday looking through these reports, a very substantial time gap between the date of the Auditor-General's report on particular documents and the date of submission to this chamber. This is not a new phenomenon. It appears every year. It is untenable; it is unacceptable; and it is about time this Government allowed the Senate the courtesy of being able to examine in proper detail these important matters.
—A cover-up.

—The presentation of almost 80 reports from major government bodies in the last two days of sitting appears to be, as Senator Tambling says, a cover-up, a concerted attempt simply to meet the formal requirements of reporting without providing proper scrutiny of these reports in this forum. Surely the Government can do better than this—unless it simply does not want these documents discussed in detail in this forum.

—by leave—I would also like to express my dismay not so much about the number of documents being tabled today but about the time being made available for us to debate and discuss those documents. We have 30 minutes this afternoon in which to cover 40-odd documents. As has been said, a large percentage of those documents deal with areas of great concern and interest to honourable senators around this chamber. They include Australia and the World Bank; the operations of the IMF and World Bank; the Health Insurance Commission; the Australian Industrial Relations Commission; the Australian Broadcasting Corporation; the Australian Institute of Health; and the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research. That latter body has been of particular interest to me for some time. All of these documents need to be thoroughly discussed by this chamber.

PARA.TAB: If any honourable senator at any committee I am on, or in this chamber, suggests that the mere existence of a provision in legislation that a particular statutory authority or government department reports to the Parliament by providing the Parliament with its annual report gives the Senate and the Parliament adequate audit and control over that particular statutory authority, I will not believe him because it is not so. I have never believed that it is so. This matter came up recently at a committee hearing when it was said that a particular organisation could make an annual report to the Parliament, as though that discharges our audit and control functions over that body. It does not. This is becoming a farce. I give fair warning to anybody who might suggest that this is a way of dealing with particular matters that I will certainly be opposing that suggestion and quoting what has happened in the last two days in support of my concern.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I am entirely sympathetic with the remarks made by Senator Michael Baume and Senator Harradine, and indeed with, although we will give some thought to it, the notice of motion Senator Kernot gave on a similar matter. It is intolerable that on the last day of sitting of the Senate we have so many reports put down by the Government. At one stage the Senate was scheduled to rise last Thursday. Is the Government seriously putting the view, by its action in tabling these reports today, that these reports would not have been tabled had the Senate risen according to schedule last Thursday?

PARA.TAB: I believe that we need a new discipline, that is, that all such reports be tabled at least one week before the scheduled last day of sitting of the Senate and that the consideration of those reports be able to be systematically covered in the remaining sitting days of the Senate; that is, in half-hour periods or, if necessary, one-hour periods. As Senator Harradine has rightly put it, the Senate would not only be seen to be monitoring such reports and carrying out its functions properly, but actually doing it.

Secondly, I reiterate that the time has come for us to have, in each of the two six-month sessions of the Senate, a published program for the last three sitting weeks scheduled for the Senate to sit, agreed to by the Whips and of which the Manager of Government Business has full cognisance. The remaining business of the Senate could be sensibly set out and we could see how the final three weeks of sitting could be determined in an orderly way. That schedule should also make allowance for urgency debates and other political matters that will inevitably take up a proportion—say, 30 per cent—of that last three weeks.

We have already moved to the point where we have what we call the Senator Macklin motion that no new business can be passed by the Senate after a certain date—about three weeks before the end of sitting. We ought to space our business from that date so that things are done in a sensible way and the Senate is not only seen to be doing its job but is actually doing it.
Leave granted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs on the adequacy of the existing legislative controls in the Trade Practices Act 1974 over mergers, monopolies and acquisitions, together with the transcript of evidence.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I will take a little time on this matter, if I may. This report is the result of a reference by the Senate to the Committee, in the terms that are set out at the commencement of the report. If the inspiration for it can be placed at anyone's door, it would be at the door of Senator Spindler, who urged that this matter be taken up, and in the light of his representations it was taken up. It has been an interesting time working on this report. I think it would be fair to say that at the commencement of proceedings the majority of those on the Committee thought along a particular line, and had they been asked to decide the issue at that point of time they would have come down in a way that was different from the end report. I think that has been brought about due to the evidence that was put before the Committee.

PARA.TAB: It has been a hard working committee in respect of this report. It is a good, hard working committee in respect of all the work that it does. In talking about the report presently before us, I want to thank the members of the Committee, starting with the Deputy Chair, Senator Vanstone, who, I think, is a classic example of how evidence put before the Committee can persuade people who are on it. She certainly acted on this occasion as a parliamentarian on a parliamentary committee. The same can be said for Senator Giles, whose contribution is always great and perhaps never adequately recognised. Senator Kemp put in a dissenting report on one of the main points, and I think that dissenting report indicates the balance that the Committee had to struggle with. Senator Kemp came down in respect of the recommendations on section 50 in a particular way, whereas the rest of the Committee came down in another way. In looking at the dissenting report of Senator Kemp, one can see that it has intellectual integrity, although the conclusions that he reaches are different.

There was also a dissenting report on another issue that was raised, namely, the issue of divestiture. That dissenting report was put in by Senator Spindler and Senator Schacht. Again, I think the argument that was used for that has intellectual rigour. It is my contention that the report itself has intellectual rigour and that the conclusions that the majority reached, are, on balance, the correct ones. I have mentioned Senator Schacht and Senator Spindler, and I also mention Senator O'Chee, and, of course, the redoubtable Senator Peter Walsh, who needs no introduction. I also want to thank another honourable senator, who was not on the Committee but who brought material to the Committee and made submissions to it, which in the end proved quite crucial: in this context I mention Senator Boswell, who has helped the Committee and whose contribution has been considerable indeed. I hope that he is moved to make some comments on the report.

I now want to say quickly that perhaps the most weighty matter that the Committee considered was what to do with section 50 of the Trade Practices Act, whether to leave it as it was, which, in effect, to use some jargon here, was to leave the dominance test, as it is presently set out in that section, or to move to a test which required that there be no merger or acquisition if there was a substantial lessening of competition in a substantial market for goods and services. The Committee has moved to the second test. In this, it has moved away from the recommendations that were made by the Griffiths committee, a most considerable committee chaired by the Hon. Alan Griffiths, Minister for Resources. It was the majority view of the Committee that it was desirable to take on the new test.

The Committee has made other significant recommendations. For example, it has recommended—this may be controversial—that section 52A, which refers to unconscionable conduct, be repealed and that the common law be relied upon. It is the view of the Committee that the common law does give people generally—not only consumers but also small business and, indeed, big business if the occasion arises—an ability to go before the courts if the conduct that has been carried out is so unconscionable that some interference should occur. In taking away and repealing that section, the Committee has recommended that the Trade Practices Commission be given the ability to bring actions on behalf of anyone for whom it considers it appropriate to do so, and that proper finance be made available to it.

I thank the members of the Committee and also Senator Boswell. It is only right that I do so. I also record thanks to the secretariat, led by Mr Frank Tallarita, the Secretary, who was very ably assisted by Mr James Warmenhoven. I seek leave to incorporate a tabling statement in Hansard.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: The report sets out the findings of the inquiry by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs into the adequacy of existing legislative controls over mergers, monopolies and acquisitions as well as the regulation of unconscionable conduct in commercial transactions.
The terms of reference of the inquiry required the Committee to have particular reference to:
.the appropriate test that should apply in s50;
.whether compulsory pre-merger notification should be introduced;
.whether, in situations of existing market dominance, the Trade Practices Commission should be able to examine conduct in addition to that already covered by s46;
.the extension of s52A (which deals with unconscionable conduct) to all commercial dealings;
.any other matters.
The Committee has made 21 recommendations of a wide ranging nature.
The appropriate test in section 50

The Committee found the economic material concerning the effects of acquisitions and mergers, presented to the inquiry, was illative rather than definitive. The evidence that mergers yield productive efficiencies remains equivocal. Nor is it clear that such efficiencies as have occurred have in fact improved the international competitiveness of Australian firms or resulted in demonstrable benefits to consumers.

A body of economic research now suggests that international competitiveness, both in large and small nations, is achieved not by encouraging companies to merge but by encouraging them to compete. The Competitive Advantage of Nations by Professor Michael Porter was frequently cited before the Committee. While his work does not deal directly with Australia, it was generally treated with considerable respect by those who made submissions to the Committee. The thrust of Professor Porter's work supports a change to section 50.

With respect to what section 50 of the Trade Practices Act 1974 should set out as the appropriate test, the Committee, by a majority, has recommended that it be amended to prohibit mergers which would have the effect or likely effect of substantially lessening competition in a substantial market for goods and services.

Authorisation is a process unique to Australia among those countries which regulate trade practices. The Committee views authorisation as a necessary and appropriate mechanism for balancing the need for competition and the need for the public to benefit; for example by Australia developing economies of scale to compete successfully in world markets.

The Committee sympathises with business concerns that the law governing mergers be certain and predictable. The dominance threshold has been in operation since 1977, and the courts have made a number of decisions setting precedents as to its meaning.

The Committee considers that any uncertainty changes to the test might bring can be reduced significantly by the incorporation into the Act of statutory guidelines, for example along the lines of the Canadian model.

The Committee emphasises that change should not be introduced lightly. Amendments to the Trade Practices Act may bring about uncertainty and this should not be readily risked. On the other hand, if reform is needed, it should be made unless the harm caused by it outweighs the good obtained. The Committee considers that change is needed to s.50 of the Trade Practices Act and that the benefit likely to flow from it will clearly outweigh any detriment that may arise.

Different submissions treat particular mergers and acquisitions that have taken place in varying ways. However there is a substantial body of material before the Committee expressing concern about those such as that of The Herald and Weekly Times by News Limited, that of Berger and British Paints by ICI (Dulux), that of McPherson's Steel by Tubemakers, and the joining together of Coles and Myer. The Committee observes there is a significant number of responsible people and organisations with as much disquiet about mergers and acquisitions that have taken place in the last few years. It seems appropriate to the Committee that ones of a similar nature should be closely examined in the future.
Significantly, the dominance test where applicable internationally is often accompanied by a presumption of dominance at market shares of around 25% or 33%.

The thrust of the submissions the Committee received from small business and from farmers was generally in the one direction. They argued for a change in section 50. Proper regard must be had for their proposition.
Material put before the Committee giving a consumer's perspective on section 50 sought a change in it. This must be given due weight.

The Griffiths Report which was tabled in May 1989 was one of high standard. The majority recommended that no change be made to section 50 of the Trade Practices Act. The Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs has great respect for the Report. However, it had to decide the issues before it on the material available to it. Further, since the tabling of the Griffiths Report there has been a considerable shift towards increasing competition in the marketplace as a means of giving Australia a better economic outlook. An amendment to section 50 in the terms suggested by the Committee is a means towards that end.

Those countries having most in common with Australia have legislation similar to the Trade Practices Act. A goodly proportion of them operate under the `lessening of competition' test. Australia would be bringing itself into line with them were it to adopt that test.

Section 50 deals with the structure of corporations. The rest of Part IV of the Trade Practices Act deals with conduct. The sections dealing with conduct impose more rigorous limitations on it than does section 50 on structures. There would be more consistency in the Act were structure and conduct dealt with generally in the same way.
The Committee has also recommended that, to make clear the ambit of the new test, guidelines be incorporated in the Trade Practices Act 1974. The guidelines should contain criteria including:
the level of concentration in the market;
the likely level of foreign competition in the market;
the availability of product substitutes;
barriers to entry;
whether one party to the merger is a failing firm;
the likelihood that the proposed merger would remove a vigorous and effective competitor;
the extent to which effective competition remains or would remain in the market;
change and innovation in the market;
the ability to significantly increase prices following a merger; and
any other factors relevant to competition in a market.

The Committee has recommended that where a proposed merger fails to meet the test including the guidelines the Trade Practices Commission should nevertheless have the power to authorise it when it is for the benefit of the public.
Compulsory pre-merger notification

Australia has operated an informal system of pre-merger notification for some years. While this system is a useful one, the Committee accepts that the TPC does not receive sufficient notice of impending mergers and at times encounters difficulty in giving them detailed and prompt consideration. There are a number of countries similar to Australia which require pre-merger notification. The OECD has suggested to its members that they should follow suit.

The Committee has recommended that it be obligatory for a notice to be given to the TPC where mergers or acquisitions of a substantial nature are proposed. What is a matter of a substantial nature should be defined in the Act. The contents required should be limited so that undue burden is not cast on those who must provide them. The Committee has recommended that the details of the scheme be drawn up by the Attorney-General's Department and released for public comment.
Compulsory notification and sensitive industries

The Committee accepts that certain industries need to be dealt with by taking into account factors in addition to economic ones. These currently include the media. The Committee notes that some `sensitive' industries such as insurance and banking are currently governed by specific legislation.

The Committee notes that issues such as social and cultural ones are outside the ambit of the Trade Practices Act and should be dealt with in discrete legislation. The Trade Practices Act should remain concerned specifically with fair competition in the market place and the protection of consumers. Accordingly, the Committee has recommended that section 50 continue to confine its operation to protecting competition. Where there are other than economic issues involved in industry structure or ownership, they may be dealt with in specific legislation.
Pre-notification, authorisation and the Trade Practices Tribunal

The Committee has recommended that parties proposing to merge continue to have the ability to approach the TPC seeking authorisation (with a right of appeal to the Trade Practices Tribunal) or alternatively to have the option of directly approaching the Tribunal. The Committee has recommended that strict time limits be imposed on both processes.
The Committee has recommended that adequate funding be made available to the Commission and the Tribunal to enable this to be done.
Misuse of market power: s46
The Committee accepts that the proof of purpose under section 46 poses considerable difficulties for the TPC and other litigants.
Proposals to extend the section by the incorporation of an effects test would undoubtedly encourage its greater use by litigants.
However, the Committee accepts that in a provision directed explicitly at misuse of market power it is appropriate that a distinction between purpose and consequence be retained.

The Committee accepts that effective competition involves engaging in conduct the potential effect of which may be to produce the very ends proscribed in section 46. To better enable purpose to be established under section 46, the Committee has recommended that it be amended to provide that although the TPC has the overall onus of proving a breach of that section when it has brought forward evidence which makes it as likely as not that one has occurred then one will be taken to have occurred unless the corporation in question shows otherwise. This recommendation should facilitate the proof of purpose.
The Committee has recommended, by a majority, that serious and persistent abuses of market power should be dealt with by serious increased monetary penalties and not through a remedy of divestiture.
Unconscionable conduct: s52A
The Committee has considered the possible extension of the unconscionable conduct provisions in s52A to commercial dealings.
The Committee accepts that any attempt to confine a statutory prohibition against commercial conduct to small business would be arbitrary, artificial and productive of uncertainty.

Since its introduction, s52A has been used rarely as a remedy. It does not enhance the protection afforded by the common law. The Committee considers that the common law provides sufficient remedies for people who have suffered through unconscionable conduct, particularly as the courts in Australia have shown a willingness to develop to meet new situations.

The Committee considers it would be better for those who suffer from the unconscionable conduct of others were their remedies left to the common law, and were the TPC to be given the power of bringing actions on their behalf and of bearing the burden of costs. Accordingly, the Committee has recommended that s52A be repealed and that legislation be introduced giving the TPC the ability to bring proceedings on behalf of a person who has a right at common law and to pay the costs involved.

This proposal will allow the TPC to assist a significantly wider range of persons and will give them relief as to costs. In making this recommendation, many of the disadvantages discussed during the inquiry should be avoided. The continuing development of equitable principles will remain unaffected. Any development of voluntary industry codes of conduct will remain unaffected.
The repeal of s52A, although removing a statutory entitlement, will not reduce consumer rights and protection as the existing remedies under common law will remain.
Related matters: remedies

The Committee considers that penalties should be commensurate with those for anti-competitive conduct applicable internationally. It has recommended that the pecuniary penalties for breaches of Part IV and Part V be increased substantially.

The Committee has recommended against the reintroduction of a private right to injunctive relief in relation to mergers. The Committee believes that the TPC is in the best position to protect the interests of the community against mergers.
The Committee has recommended that the Act be amended to provide remedies for breaches of undertakings made between the TPC and another person or persons.

The Committee considers that the issue of broad and flexible remedies for breaches of Part IV deserves further consideration and has recommended that the Attorney-General give consideration to introducing a range of appropriate remedies for such breaches.

Finally, the Committee has recommended that the details of any proposed amendments to the Act be developed by the Attorney-General's Department following consultation with all relevant parties and released by way of Exposure Draft Bill for public comment. Public comment should occur over a reasonable time of not less than three months.

The Committee thanks all interested individuals and organisations for their contribution and assistance during the inquiry, both in making submissions to the inquiry and for their attendance at its public hearings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to comment briefly on two aspects of the report tabled today by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs called Mergers, Monopolies and Acquisitions. In particular, I wish to address section 50 and the recommendation of the Committee that the criterion used for determining whether an acquisition or merger can proceed should be changed from dominance of a market, as it is currently, to the likely effect such a merger or acquisition will have of substantially lessening competition in a substantial market for goods and services.

PARA.TAB: The Committee received many submissions on that particular aspect of the matter. It is true to say, as the Chairman of the Committee, Senator Cooney, has said, that the Committee finally decided on a judgment of the balance between the various views put forward. In the past, the lesser test was supported very much because it was thought that it eliminated inefficient industries and companies and that it also increased the international competitive capacity of Australian enterprises by giving them additional size and therefore the ability to utilise economies of scale.

The detriment that would be part of any such acquisitions and mergers—namely, the creation of a monopoly or duopoly—was considered as being secondary to those first two considerations. However, we have seen substantial changes in our industrial capacity and the view has been reached that economies of scale are not necessarily the main factor in achieving international competitive capacity.

The Committee has heard considerable evidence, including the seminal work by Professor Porter, The Competitive Advantage of Nations, which indicated not only that the factor of economies of scale is now of a secondary nature with a higher degree of technology being utilised but also that to achieve international competitiveness it is essential to expose companies to competition in the domestic market so that they may hone their capacity to compete abroad. The advantage of that course of action is that Australian consumers and small businesses are able to benefit from the higher level of competition that such a policy would create.

This particular change had its beginnings in an amendment that I moved to the Trade Practices Amendment Bill on 16 May this year. While the Government at that stage was not prepared to accept these arguments, it is with a great deal of pleasure that I now acknowledge that, following the acceptance by the Government of the terms of reference from the Government and the Opposition, we now have this recommendation of the Committee.

I note that Senator Cooney, the Chairman of the Committee, was gracious to acknowledge the beginnings of this reference. I wish to acknowledge the patience, tolerance, diligence and incisive legal mind that Senator Cooney, as Chairman of this Committee, has brought to this particular inquiry. In initiating the inquiry, I was conscious of the fact that the Committee was in fact overloaded with work. I appreciated all the more the assiduous work that was done not only by the Chairman but also by every member of the Committee.

I would be remiss if I did not pay tribute also to the secretariat—Mr Frank Tallarita, Mr James Warmenhoven and Ms Fiona Matthews—who very ably supported the work of the Committee and without whose assistance this inquiry would not have been possible to pursue. I believe the inquiry turned out to be rather more massive and rather more far-reaching than we thought at the beginning. There will be more opportunity later on to debate the very important issues that this report has placed on record.

I turn briefly to the dissenting report which I am glad to say I share with Senator Chris Schacht. That goes to the question of divestiture. We believe that there is a need for the remedy of divestiture in the case of serious and persistent misuse of market power. Section 46 does deal with the misuse of market power and prohibits corporations with a substantial degree of market power from taking advantage of that power for certain purposes. These purposes are eliminating or substantially damaging competitors, preventing new entrants into a market, or deterring or preventing others from engaging in competitive conduct.

The Attorney-General's Department believes that such breaches of section 46 should be addressed through increased monetary penalties. However, they are hardly sufficient to rectify a situation once we have on record persistent and serious misuse of market power. I quote from Professor Baxt's evidence. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . unless you have a remedy, like the Americans, the Canadians and the Europeans have which enables their courts to say, `You have to divest certain parts of your operations', then you are not going to be able to get to the heart of the problem in these situations.

We therefore believe that divestiture should be available as a remedy in such cases. It has been suggested that no situations have so far arisen in Australia where divestiture would have been warranted. Whether or not this is so, I consider that, given the high levels of industry concentration in Australia, particularly in the current wave of deregulation and privatisation, it is likely that such a situation could arise in the future. The Trade Practices Act should provide remedies capable of dealing with such situations effectively.

PARA.TAB: One should stress that one does not see divestiture as a remedy which would be commonly and often used. The Committee has been told that it is a rarely and reluctantly used remedy in those jurisdictions where it is available. But the fact that it is available and can be used by courts in appropriate circumstances and has not been withdrawn, despite agitation by interest groups, remains a telling factor in evaluating its appropriateness.

We have just witnessed another step in the continuing concentration of media ownership in Australia. This must be one of the major concerns that we face when we talk of misuse of market power. We are addressing an area which can affect the very fibre of our democratic system. It is with more than a sidelong glance at those developments that I believe this dissenting report calling for divestiture as a remedy should be noted by the Senate and the Government. I trust that this dissenting report by Senator Schacht and myself will be the start of another battle which ultimately will have to be won.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the tabling of the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs entitled Mergers, Monopolies and Acquisitions; Adequacy of Existing Legislative Controls. I will speak briefly in view of the pressure of other business. When the Trade Practices Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991 comes back to be debated, there will be opportunities for honourable senators to speak.

PARA.TAB: The main reason I wish to speak is that, together with Senator Spindler, I have put in a dissenting report on one aspect of the legislation, namely, divestiture. Firstly, I congratulate Senator Cooney and all the other members of the Committee for their work on this piece of legislation, and the seriousness with which they went about the work of dealing with an extremely complex piece of legislation that has an impact way beyond that of most pieces of legislation in our community. In this legislation we are dealing with, as we would say, the top end of town, the big picture and so on. This legislation can have dramatic effects on the lives of many ordinary Australian citizens, and the Committee accepted that responsibility.

I am delighted that the Committee unanimously recommended a change in the test for mergers and acquisitions from dominance of the market to a substantial lessening of competition. That is an excellent step forward. I trust that the Government and the Opposition will take this report and its recommendations very seriously. I already suspect that the Leader of the National Party in this place is enthusiastic for that test. It is a big step forward for the old agrarian socialists who come on board. I hope that the debate in the broader political process on this issue will start from this report. I also hope that some time in the near future the Government can bring forward legislation to accept the unanimous report on this section.

I am of the view that in the trade practices area we are really dealing with the way in which Australia sees its future role in international competition. Once one moves away from a mercantilist view of world trade and international competition and sees that we need an internationally competitive economy, one, therefore, has to put in place mechanisms that guarantee that that competition is effective for our community.

It seems to me that, in a more deregulated and internationally competitive economy, we will have investments from many major corporations from overseas which, with their large financial resources, may be able literally to buy up an Australian industry. It seems to me that we have to put in place mechanisms to control and take action where the marketplace is adversely affected, against the interests of the public.

The present test for dominance of the market is too soft and limited. I know that there will be arguments from lawyers about what the substantial lessening of competition means. I suspect that whatever we put forward in this Bill will mean big employment opportunities for lawyers, but that is unavoidable and I cannot think of a way around it. If I could, I would have put in a further dissenting report. Nevertheless, a substantial lessening of competition, on all the evidence we received, is clearly a tougher test to be met. Therefore, it is an excellent part of our report.

I now turn to divestiture powers. If we are to have an internationally competitive economy and encourage more efficient industry in Australia, we will need a sanction in the business sector that companies which persistently and wilfully misuse their power in the marketplace will have to pay the ultimate penalty of divestiture of part of their operations. The fact that that power is there will mean that some people will be more careful than they are now; they will always be looking over their shoulder if this power is sitting in the legislation. I do not believe that it would be often used in Australia, but I agree with Senator Spindler that, with the way the world economy is developing and the way that multinational and transnational companies are establishing worldwide operations, it is more likely to be a possibility in the future that such a test and such a power will be used.

A very strong test to be applied to a total divestiture power is that it must be in the national interest. If the Trade Practices Commission told an operation in Australia that it had to divest because it had wilfully misused its power, there would be a public process via a hearing and court cases. If people argued that, no, it is in the national interest that this company maintains its operations, then governments, consumer groups and other groups in the community could put their views. It would be a public, transparent process which would be very good for the public process and the public interest.

There are many cases where a monopoly in Australia can be justified. For example, the steel industry is basically run by BHP. In my view, it would be bonkers to suggest that it should divest several of its steelworks because it dominates the market. In the last decade, the Australian Government introduced and operated a steel plant—to which the taxpayers contributed several hundred million dollars—to revamp the steel industry so that it would not collapse. That money overwhelmingly went to BHP. It seems to me that it is in the national interest to argue that that dominance should be allowed to continue as far as the size of its share of the market is concerned.

If BHP misuses its power in providing steel to customers, the remedies are already there: it can be forced to provide steel at reasonable prices; and action can be taken against it for predatory pricing. I must say that, in the end, if BHP acted in such a way over a long period and did not respond to previous decisions of the Trade Practices Commission, it would run the risk of being forced to divest something. But part of that process would have to be done publicly, with government arguing one way or the other, and everyone would have an opportunity to participate.

I emphasise, as did Senator Spindler, that divestiture is an action of last resort, but unless there is that action of last resort, the other penalties are inadequate. Fines of millions of dollars are peanuts for an industry that has a revenue base of billions of dollars. But if companies were told that they would have to lose part of their operations—which is worth $500m, and would affect their profits—that risk would make them think twice.
I draw attention to an example of this approach which is mentioned at page 139 of the dissenting report as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: For example, should either Australian Airlines or Ansett Australia refuse to supply Compass with adequate airport leasing space, and if such a refusal amounted to a misuse of market power, then the court should be able to order the `divestment' of a portion of the existing lease space to Compass, or even order a reduction in the term of the leases held by Australian or Ansett.

Today we have newspaper reports that Compass is in serious financial difficulty. One of the arguments being put is that it does not get decent access to the existing gateway facilities in all the Australian terminals which, I understand, have 20-year leases signed. It seems clear to me that this is one case where divestiture is a reasonable power with which to threaten the airlines. I am sure the threat of it would make Ansett and Australian Airlines much more reasonable in the negotiations. It would seem to me that, if this is one of the reasons why Compass runs into difficulty and goes out of existence, it proves the need for divestiture power to be in the Act as a last resort.

PARA.TAB: Therefore, I commend the dissenting report. I of course point out to the Senate that I am a member of the Government party. There will be debate within the Government about these amendments and so on, and I will have my say in those forums as well. Naturally, as a loyal member of the Government, if the Government decides not to accept all of my views, that is my tough luck. I will of course be supporting the Government's final position. But I think the debate has started and I do not think there is an intransigent view on any side of politics that this matter is black and white or all or nothing. I congratulate Senator Cooney and the other members of the Committee for beginning what I think will be an excellent debate which, in the long run, will enhance the operation of competition in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received this report on mergers, monopolies and acquisitions only in the last 10 minutes. Therefore, I have not been able to go into the whole report; I have looked only briefly at the recommendations on the first couple of pages.

PARA.TAB: I am very pleased with the recommendations that this report has brought down. I, too, would like to pass on my congratulations to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. I think one of the main problems facing business in Australia today is the market domination that has been allowed to aggregate and to force small business to take lesser prices for its production and its manufacturing products. It has been going on for some time. Eighty per cent of the grocery trade in Australia is owned by overseas companies and the aggregations in the grocery trade have been going along at a very rapid pace. This Committee report addresses some of these problems.

It may be said that it is like shutting the gate after the horse has bolted, but we have to make a start somewhere. The Committee has taken on the problems and it has looked at the difference between the two tests: the lessening of competition in a substantial market for goods and services and the present market domination test. I can understand why, in 1977, the Government at the time opted for the market domination test in order to get huge economies of scale so that we could be more competitive in international markets. But the fact is that it simply has not worked. We are no great export power and what has happened is that we have lost efficiencies in our smaller domestic productions.

For any market to take on exports it must have a very solid domestic market, and 99 per cent of manufacturers and food processors who export require a very solid domestic market. Unless that domestic market returns a profit and can give guarantees that the company will be profitable, then it has very little base upon which to build a competitive overseas export market. The report addresses this matter and I think Senator Cooney has done a magnificent job as Chairman of this Committee. Quite frankly, I think small business in Australia—and I include the manufacturing and smaller retail sector, primary industry, the farmers, and their processing companies such as Golden Circle, Berri, Letona, Ardmona and SPC—will welcome this report with open arms. It is what it has been seeking for the last five or six years, or even longer.

I can talk with some knowledge about this subject because before I came into this place I was a merchant and I experienced personally the market domination that was rampant in 1983. From my questioning of industry at the moment, it seems that it has only got worse between 1983 and 1991. Manufacturers have said to me, `I can cop high interest rates, I can cop union demands and I can cop lower demand caused by the recession, but one thing I cannot cop is 80 per cent of my business going to four or five customers. If I lose one of those customers I lose 25 per cent of my throughput through my factory'.

So, when a manufacturer is faced with that throughput or percentage of his market going to one customer, that customer has huge purchase leverage to drive the prices down—sometimes under the cost of manufacturing. The processor or the manufacturer has to make a decision as to whether he will accept the lower prices, manufacture under cost and hold his market share; or, if he loses that particular customer by not lowering his prices, whether he can run his factory when he loses the benefits of the economies of scale.

In my time, I have seen promotional discounts, settlement terms and corporate discounts demanded—a plethora of demands from retailers—which are screwing the prices down, sometimes, as I mentioned before, way under the cost of production. Therefore, I look forward to the time when this report becomes legislation. I am sure it will be very popular. It certainly will be popular in the cattle industry, where we have seen amalgamations and aggregations of abattoirs and where there are fewer buyers in the ring to bid for stock—and when there are fewer buyers in the ring there is less competition. That will not give a true price to a rural producer and it will not give him prices which are driven by market forces.

I think all of us in this Parliament would believe sincerely that if an economy is to be driven by market forces we cannot keep pulling market forces out of the economy by amalgamations and takeovers until there are no market forces left to work. That is what is happening at the moment and we are getting artificial prices. Many of the discounts that are demanded—such as corporate discounts and advertising discounts—are not being passed on to the customers; they are being held by the mega-corporations. So this report goes a long way to solving those problems. Of course, we have to see the report accepted by the Government and it then has to pass into legislation.
The other section that attracts me in this report is that the Committee recommends that section 52A of the Trade Practices Act be repealed. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: It recommends that legislation be introduced giving the Trade Practices Commission the ability to bring proceedings of behalf of a person who has a right of action at common law arising from the unconscionable conduct of another.

That has always been extended to consumers. This report now suggests that it will be passed on to farmers and small business. That will also be very much welcomed in the small business community, where there have been cases of unconscionable conduct that has led in some circumstances to penalties being imposed on the smaller entrepreneur. Now it gives him access to a law that will give him some equity. Many small businesses just cannot afford to go to court or pay the legal costs and take on the mega-corporations.

PARA.TAB: This report has given small business and primary industry a great Christmas present. We would be churlish if we did not thank Senator Spindler for setting up the Committee and Senator Cooney for his stewardship in bringing this report to fruition.
Debate (on motion by Senator Brownhill) adjourned.
Debate resumed from 18 November, on motion by Senator Collins:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: upon which Senator Chapman had moved by way of amendment:

PARA.TAB: At end of motion, add ", but the Senate condemns the Government for entering into an agreement with the States which is flawed in that it fails to provide for;
(a)a thorough review of all inputs, taxes and charges paid by the road transport industry; and
(b)an investigation of the current level of efficiency of road construction and maintenance practices;

PROCTEXT.PARA: and notes that the Senate will now have to rectify these omissions by referring the matter to a Senate Legislative and General Purpose Standing Committee for inquiry and report".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Today the Senate is debating the National Road Transport Commission Bill, a very contentious piece of legislation. I am pleased to say that the National and Liberal parties strenuously oppose this legislation. At a time of economic recession, this Government legislation will increase registration costs in Australia by 300 or 400 per cent on heavy vehicles that carry 80 per cent of the domestic freight in Australia—that is, vehicles over 4 1/2 tonnes. The transport industry employs 400,000 people indirectly and employs 100,000 people directly in road transport. Road transport accounts for 9 per cent of the gross domestic product.

PARA.TAB: If this Bill goes through, its repercussions will be felt all over Australia. There will be job shedding in the transport industry as already hard-pressed trucking operators will be unable to pay the increased cost of registration or pass those costs on to already strapped primary producers and other manufacturing industries. They will have to lay off staff, who will join the other one million people on the dole queue.

Nowhere will this legislation impact harder than on rural Australia, where every farm input, every tin of sheep dip, every wool bale, every piece of machinery, and all the groceries that have to be transported out into the bush, mainly on road transport at the moment, will be hit with increased registration charges that will drive up the costs to rural dwellers and rural producers.

Primary industry gets hit with a double whammy when it has to transport its commodities from the farm gate to the abattoirs or the silos and then to the domestic market or to the ships which export our rural products overseas to earn much needed export dollars. An increase of 300 to 400 per cent in registration charges would further add to costs and cripple our export industries and make them less competitive at a time when we need every dollar we can earn in export income. It is ironic that the Government is putting this Bill through a day after the announcement was made that farm incomes have dropped 75 per cent on last year, which was at an all-time low base. This is further proof, if any was needed, that this Government does not care about Australian farmers or regional dwellers.

The National Road Transport Commission will implement the agreement reached between the Commonwealth and the States at the Special Premiers Conference, and the ACT will also join, on uniform road regulations and road charges on heavy vehicles of 4 1/2 tonnes and over.

This Bill has been on a long journey. In 1989 the Inter-State Commission report was succeeded by a report from the Department of Land Transport consultant, Mr Ted Butcher. In October last year the Special Premiers Conference looked at this report and decided to set up a working group with three reporting bodies—a regulation committee, a road funding committee and a charging committee. The working group has set the figures which I, as well as industry bodies, believe will be implemented by the National Road Transport Commission.

This Bill does not establish the charges or the uniform rules but gives the power to the newly appointed Commission. That technically may be correct, but the new National Road Transport Commission is strictly controlled by the guidelines that are in the Bill and were in the Special Premiers Conference agreement signed by all the Premiers. The decisions the newly appointed Commission makes must be endorsed by a majority decision of the ministerial council, which consists of all transport Ministers and the Minister from the ACT and is chaired by the Federal Minister, Mr Brown. The Northern Territory has refused to be a signatory to the agreement establishing the National Road Transport Commission. The Northern Territory Government has researched the new charges and is of the opinion that the increased registration charges would increase the CPI in the Territory by between one and 2 per cent and increase transport costs by 10 to 15 per cent.

This legislation does not set up the National Road Transport Commission as a fearless, independent body able to stand up and make rational judgments based on research, fact and information, as asserted by the Government. That is simply not true. The newly appointed Commission under this legislation is bound to endorse the agreement signed at the Special Premiers Conference. In fact, the formula and the methodology agreed to at the Special Premiers Conference are exactly as set out in the Bill. Clause 20 of the Bill is a direct lift-out from the Special Premiers Conference. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard clause 20(3) of the Bill. I have discussed this with the Minister.
Leave granted.

(3) The National Commission in recommending Road Charges, and a Road Use Charge to the Ministerial Council shall ensure that by no later than 1 July 1995 the charges it recommends comply with the Charging Principles, and recover fully the road costs of all Vehicles based on average annual distances travelled except for road trains, which are to receive concessions of up to 50% of full cost recovery Mass-distance Charges. Road train charges should achieve full cost recovery by 1 July 2000 at the latest. In arriving at its recommended charges the Commission is to:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)use PAYGO for determining what expenditure is to be recovered until an improved method of cost recovery becomes available;

(b)use a common methodology, initially based on the model employed by the Inter-State Commission in its 1990 Report but enhanced with further research currently being undertaken by the Australian Road Research Board;
(c)initially adopt the expenditure allocation template to be endorsed by AUSTROADS in the PAYGO process; and
(d)make use of the Australian Bureau of Statistics Survey on Motor Vehicle Use road task data (with appropriate upgrading) as the source of this data.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Clause 20(3) requires that the National Commission, in recommending road charges and road use charges to the ministerial council, shall ensure that by no later than 1 July 1995 the charges it recommends will comply with the charging principles and recover fully the road costs of all vehicles, based on average annual distance travelled, except for road trains, which are to receive concessions of up to 50 per cent of full cost recovery mass-distance charges. In arriving at its recommended charges, the Bill says that the Commission is to use—it does not say it may or it will consider; the wording in the Bill is very definite—a PAYGO system for determining what expenditure is to be recovered.

PARA.TAB: This supposedly independent Commission is emasculated by the very legislation that proclaims its existence. It cannot make inde- pendent decisions on costs. It must refer decisions to the ministerial council for approval. At any time, two or more States can veto any decision the Commission makes—the exact agreement the Special Premiers Conference reached on road charges. Any-

SPEECH.PARA: thing that the National Road Transport Commission decides can be vetoed by only two Ministers. The formula in the Special Premiers Conference agreements, repeated in this legislation, will increase road charges by 300 per cent and, in some cases, 400 per cent. It is the same formula used by the working group that established the scale of charges for heavy road use. I seek leave to have a table incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: [THE TABLE IS OMITTED FROM THE DATABASE, SEE HARD COPY PAGE 5022]

TALK.START.PARA: —This table comprises the working group's figures that must be recommended by March 1992, to apply by no later than 1 January 1993, with full cost recovery phased in by July 1995, and by 1 July 2000 for road trains. In the Senate on 15 October, when I asked Senator Collins whether there would be only one charge, he replied that the National Road Transport Commission would recommend charges by March 1992 to apply by no later than 1 January 1993, that full cost recovery would be phased in by 1995, and by 1 July 2000 for road trains. What Senator Collins told the Senate is exactly what was agreed at the Special Premiers Conference and what is in the Bill. Senator Collins has agreed with the Special Premiers Conference and with the method in this legislation. It again confirms that the National Road Transport Commission has no option but to increase charges to those in the working group's figures that I have incorporated.

PARA.TAB: At a Senate inquiry last Wednesday we were told by officers of the Department that the charges were not set—it was up to the National Road Transport Commission to set the charges. Senator Collins also said that there were no charges set at present. The Government has never been prepared to tell the truth about increasing road charges. For 2 1/2 years we have lived with a smokescreen surrounding this, with no-one prepared to tell what the charges will be. Everyone in the industry is well aware that the charges will be those set out in the working group's table that I have incorporated.

On 7 November the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown) told the House that total charges for the increased registration would be $7,000 to $8,000. I believe this is only the first charge to be introduced in 1993 for a six-axle articulated vehicle of 42 tonnes. Mr Brown has not told the House that those charges will increase to full cost recovery by 1995 and will be $14,100. The Minister representing Mr Brown in the Senate has said that no charges have been set; the Minister for Land Transport has said that the total charges for six-axle articulated vehicles will be $7,000 to $8,000; while the working group has responded to a formula of total cost recovery as laid down in the Special Premiers Conference agreement and as repeated in this Bill. The inescapable conclusion is that initial charges from January 1993 will be $7,750 for a six-axle articulated vehicle of 42 tonnes and full cost recovery by July 1995 will amount to $14,100.

There is confusion, I believe, amongst Government members but certainly not amongst the people involved in the industry. Last Wednesday night the Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure took evidence from concerned industry groups and unionists. The witnesses told the Committee exactly how those increased charges would affect the industries and their members. Submissions were made by the National Farmers Federation, the National Transport Forum, Australian Livestock Transport, the National Transport Federation, the New South Wales Road Transport Association and the New South Wales Branch of the Transport Workers Union of Australia.

As I said, there is no confusion amongst these people because they know exactly where they are going. Every one of those groups believes that the new National Road Transport Commission would have no option other than to charge the working group's recommended figures because of the prescribed formula set down in clause 20(3) in this legislation.

There are two parts to the heavy vehicle charge. The first component is the increased registration charges that we have just been through. The second is a charge equal to the part of the diesel fuel tax levied by the Commonwealth for road building and maintenance. The figure bandied around by those in the know is that around 15.6c a litre would be allocated to road spending. That is certainly an improvement on the 6c a litre that is presently being spent on road maintenance. When this Government came to power in 1983, excise was 9.4c a litre, of which 6c was spent on roads. Due to automatic indexing, the excise has risen to 26c a litre, yet the Government has only allocated the same 6c a litre to road charges, siphoning off $2.5 billion to Consolidated Revenue.

The coalition's position is that all excise will be removed from the transport industry as well as sales tax on semitrailers, prime movers, batteries, tyres, parts and all other accessories that go to make up the components of a semitrailer and a prime mover.

TALK.START.PARA: —No excise tax—sales tax.
—There is no excise, but there is sales tax. Will the Minister concede there is sales tax?
—You just put another tax on instead. That is what you will do.

—He will concede that. I thank him. This will mean a saving in cost to the transport industry—I hope that Senator Button listens to this because he may learn something—of 10 per cent by the removal of excise and 6 per cent by the removal of sales tax. That is a massive 16 per cent that will be removed from the costs of the transport industry. These figures have been given to me by responsible members of the transport industry. If Senator Button thinks that the Fightback package will not be popular with the transport industry, I have to inform him that he is very much mistaken.

PARA.TAB: This Government will keep excise and sales taxes, and then will increase road charges by a massive 300 per cent to 400 per cent. This is just another example—if any more were needed—of the philosophical differences between the National and Liberal parties and the Labor Party. This package is not one of economic reform. It increases charges to a sector of Australia—the trucking industry and rural Australia—that cannot afford one more cent added to its budget. Micro-economic reform is about lowering costs, not increasing fees by 300 per cent to 400 per cent.

This Government has taken no account of the burden that the transport industry bears. The Inter-State Commission has assessed that the road transport industry pays on average 3 1/2 times more indirect tax than do other industries, but this has been ignored in all of the calculations. There are no improvements in the Bill. No uniformity is achieved by the

SPEECH.PARA: Bill. There are two zones, A and B. One Territory Government will not sign the agreement and, if any transport Minister wants to absolve his State from any part of the agreement, that Minister can issue an application order and absolve that State from the uniform rules. What sort of uniformity is that? What sort of federalism is that? There is absolutely no unity. It is a package of compromise. Its only achievement will be increased freight charges; more truckies losing their livelihood, their jobs, their homes and their rigs; more cost to our export markets; and more country towns being destroyed. That is what the package will give. To get an agreement from all States to be part of the national road transport system, the Government was forced into accepting—

TALK.START.PARA: —You are becoming an agitator.
—I will be very pleased to hear Senator Button's contribution because I am sure that it will be interesting to the people of rural Australia.
—Senator Boswell has been an agitator for a long time. You have only recently become an agitator. I would not interject, if I were you.

—I know that Senator O'Chee is particularly interested in this speech because he is concerned about rural Australia. The Government was forced into accepting a two-zone system because the Premiers of Western Australia, Queensland and South Australia were not prepared to accept the higher zone A charges. New South Wales, Victoria, Tasmania and the ACT will pay higher charges. The scheme has not even got off the ground and it is already in disarray because of the two-zone system.

PARA.TAB: It is ironic that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) talks about new federalism, yet we are already seeing differences between the States. We will see trucks from the Northern Territory and the lower zone States stopped at the border and asked to pay higher fees to enter a zone. It was mentioned in the Committee that trucks may even be forced to pay the higher registration fees if they ply their trade in the higher zones. We could even see the reintroduction of the old tick gates on the border where one has to get a permit to cross the border. That may be Senator Button's idea of new federalism, but it is certainly not mine. We will turn the clock back 90-odd years to when we had customs posts at the border. That is how stupid it is. No-one has any idea of how it will work. Even Mr Brown concedes that it is a farce. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Frankly we needed to incorporate zones into the Special Premiers Conference to get everyone aboard—
that is just another compromise—
but I continue to have considerable reservations about the efficiency of this approach in terms of its administration, enforcement and equity.

Mr Brown does not have a clue as to how the extra charges will be made on vehicles moving between the States, from one zone to another—and nor does anyone else, if they are perfectly honest. It will be passed over to the National Road Transport Commission and there will be one hell of a fight when the Premiers meet and make a decision.

PARA.TAB: We are told that permits will have to be issued at the border, which will create tension in the industry. We are also told that there will be a reduction in charges between the low cost zone and the high cost zone. In fact, the legislation sets out under clause 20 that the charges will be uniform. Mr Goss, the Queensland Premier, has never come out and told Queenslanders what the registration charges will be in Queensland and what the savings are in zone B, or the differences in savings between zone A and zone B. There is a complete contradiction in terms between the new federalism and that presently being proposed in this Bill. There will be chaos.

The Government is bringing in legislation, with the support of the Australian Democrats, which will increase road charges by 300 per cent to 400 per cent by 1995. The formula is set in this Bill; it is set in a Special Premiers Conference; and it has been worked out by the working group. The Commission has nowhere to go. The legislation that sets up the Commission in effect also sets up the charges. The Democrats may oppose the supplementary legislation that sets up the charges or, hopefully, they will amend it.

The legislation does not take into consideration any impact on regional and rural Australia. In March this year at a rural and remote transport conference at Alice Springs, the Government commissioned a study by the Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics and the Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics into the regional impact of the proposed changes embodied in the Special Premiers Conference agreement.

That report will not be ready until March or April next year and, therefore, will have no impact or influence over the charges. The National Road Transport Commission is required by this legislation to recommend charges by March 1992 to apply no later than January 1993. That report was commissioned seven months ago and has not been seen—it probably will not been seen until February or March next year—yet under this legislation the newly appointed Commission is required to set the charges by 1992. It is another example to show regional and rural Australia just what contempt this Government has for country people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on, Senator; you were going to be nice today.

—Senator Button knows that it is true. I am being provoked. I was given an impact study done by the Shepparton, Kyabram and Rodney regional development corporation on the effects of the Special Premiers Conference agreement. I have incorporated the figures of that working group in my speech. The study would be typical of country districts in Australia, but because of Victoria's smallness or compactness the results would be more disastrous for the bigger States, particularly for my State of Queensland. The study found that it would cost an additional $6.8m to register the 650 articulated vehicles in the district; that it would push up livestock transport by between 8c and 50c a kilometre; that the transporting of hay would increase by $10 a tonne; and that the cost of transporting fruit would increase by between $1 and $5 a tonne. The Goulburn Valley's economic viability would be devastated. The results show that 140 jobs would be lost in the road transport industry and 520 jobs would be lost in other industries.

PARA.TAB: In my State of Queensland it will cost an additional $15 to transport a beast from Mount Isa, Julia Creek and Hughenden to Toowoomba or Roma, the main selling points, and an additional $40 a tonne in freight. We have to ask: what sort of crazy, harebrained scheme is this which will add cost to export industries and put more lead in the saddle of primary producers and further depopulate country areas? The Government has produced a recipe to devastate rural Australia. The Government has a hide to bring this legislation in without any impact statement. The Democrats should follow the example of the National Party and the Liberal Party and also reject the legislation.

The present position is that the Democrats, while supporting the National Road Transport Commission Bill, have stated that they will not guarantee to pass further road transport legislation which sets up the new charges. The whole matter has been referred to a Senate committee which will report on 11 September 1992.
