The result of that inquiry will determine the attitude that the Democrats will take to passing any legislation which will increase the charges.

Let us look at the politics of the matter. The committee report will go to the Senate on 11 September 1992 and the new charging legislation, if it takes into consideration the Senate inquiry, could not be introduced into the Parliament until at least October. By then, the election date will be looming in the minds of the Government and the Democrats.

TALK.START.PARA: —Small minds.

—Some of them are small-minded. Would they be prepared to increase charges on the eve of an election? That is a big question. If the National Road Transport Commission is to be set up, it will require complementary legislation in the State parliaments. It will be difficult for the New South Wales Government to muster the numbers in Parliament, as all of the Independents and the Labor Party state that they will not support a Bill with two charging zones. The National and Liberal parties are making noises in Western Australia. They will not support a Bill; it will be knocked off in the upper House. The South Australian Government is rapidly losing enthusiasm and interest for this particular Bill.

PARA.TAB: The flawed concept of a national road transport commission that has no other option than to increase charges to full cost recovery by 1995 under a formula which will raise registration by 300 per cent to 400 per cent looks to be sailing into very heavy weather and could sink with all hands. It would be of great benefit to rural Australia and primary industry if it did. If the Government is to ignore the warnings and proceed with the increased charges after the Senate inquiry on 11 September 1992, it will lose even more seats—it has already lost government now.

The trucking industry and rural and regional Australia have won a reprieve, but they cannot be complacent. The Democrats will not support the legislation that increases charges until the Senate committee reports on 11 September 1992. The coalition will not support this legislation or have a bar of it at any price.

In conclusion, I am very proud to oppose this legislation. It is ill conceived and ill thought out. It would cripple industry, including primary industry, and regional and rural Australia. It would kill our country towns and ruin our export markets. This Bill deserves no support at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have great pleasure in following and supporting my colleague and leader Senator Boswell. This Bill, as Senator Boswell said, would destroy remote and regional towns in this country and do untold damage to our primary industries—and to our other exports around this nation. The fact is that 90 per cent of our freight is carried on the roads; and, irrespective of what changes we make to the rail network, at the end of the decade 90 per cent of our transport will still be carried on the roads. So any attempt to increase road registration charges is nothing but an increase in the cost of freight from one part of this country to the other.

PARA.TAB: One would have thought that a nation the size of Australia, with its tiny population, would be doing everything in its power to reduce the cost of road transport in this country. But not this Government. This Government's view of micro-economic reform is not to reduce costs to industry but to increase them—because that is the effect of this Bill. This Bill sets up a Commission which is locked into recommending higher road user charges. This Bill sets up a commission which is locked into imposing greater costs on people who live in regional areas of Australia and on industries in regional areas of Australia. The Government is locked into a false and myopic view of micro-economic reform that will do nothing but inhibit our exporters, rather than assist them in becoming more competitive throughout the rest of the world.

It is very important that we look at the genesis of this Bill, that we look at the genesis of this loopy proposal that the Government has brought before us. It was in May last year that the aptly named Butcher report came out, recommending these increases in road user charges. I have great pleasure in saying that it was my colleague Senator Boswell who, with me, took some members of the Commission around regional Queensland and actually showed them, for the first time, what life was like outside the capital cities, what it was like when one got further west than Toowoomba. We showed them the effect that their plans would have on people in remote and regional Australia—because they had not been there.

The National Party fought this measure tooth and nail—in New South Wales where my colleague Senator Brownhill comes from, in Queensland and in Victoria. Later came the efforts of our friends the Liberals in Western Australia, and I acknowledge the work of Senator Panizza in that regard. It was that work that forced the Government to back down on the original proposal to introduce this charge on 1 July this year. That was the original proposal: 1 July 1991 was D-day for the road transport industry as this Government set about increasing the charges. We fought it to a standstill.

The Government still has this crazy notion that it needs to increase the road user charges. This is not about improving the funding to the roads. Honourable senators know perfectly well that the Government gets enough money to fund the roads four times over. This is the Government that gets $6.5 billion in fuel taxation and returns $1.5 billion to the road network. Yet Government members come into this chamber and talk about full cost recovery. They have full cost recovery; they have full cost overrecovery.

Under this Government's taxing regime, we even have the absurd situation where cruise boat operators pay a fuel tax that is supposed to support the roads. The Government is getting money willy-nilly—and it wants more. It is like some cancer that has got out of control, feeding on the money of others, in this case the money of the road transport industry. It is not as though the road transport industry does not pay its way. Even if we leave out the fourfold taxation that is inherent in the fuel charges, we should look at the other taxes the Government imposes on the road transport industry—the 20 per cent sales tax on parts and on the trucks; the existing registration charges; the provisional tax; and, if they are lucky enough to make a dollar, the income tax on top of that.

If we put all the taxes that truckies pay on one side of a set of scales and put the small amount they take home to their wives and kids on the other side of that set of scales, we would see that the truck drivers, the transport operators, do not own their industry; the Government owns their industry because the Government owns the profits of their industry. The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, and his colleagues on the other side know this very well because that is exactly what they want to do. We on this side of the chamber in the National and Liberal parties represent a completely different attitude to business and to the road transport industry. We say, `What you need is not more taxation but less taxation'. We stand for less taxation on business and, particularly, less taxation on the road transport industry.

I can talk about the road transport industry: 20 years ago my father got out of that industry because he was not making a buck. Road transport operators who thought they were having it hard in 1971, if they are still around in 1991, would say that it was a breeze 20 years ago. In the intervening period costs have gone up something like tenfold while the actual charges have gone up only threefold. The road transport industry is the most competitive and most cost efficient in this country. Under the guise of perpetrating micro-economic reform, this Government would throw out the window and destroy the only truly efficient service industry we have. That is what it wants to do.

There is no way that we in the National Party will support this Bill. In bringing this Bill before the Senate, the Government asks the Senate to sign a blank cheque. It asks the Senate to set up a commission that is locked into the higher charges without our knowing what those higher charges are—and there is more and worse besides. As Senator Boswell has said, this Commission will make its recommendations in March 1992 for charges that are due to come into effect on 1 January 1993. But what has happened to the report on the effect on remote and regional Australia? Where is that? Will that be tabled so that the National Road Transport Commission can have a look at it and take it into consideration when making its recommendations? Of course not. It will not be on the table. It may not come out until after the National Road Transport Commission has finished its work in March 1992.

That shows how shallow and hypocritical is this Government's commitment to the people of remote and regional Australia; how shallow and hypocritical is its commitment when it sets up a body to make a report and makes sure that it heads off with the proposals before that report can be made public. That is what the Government wanted to do with the Butcher report, and we stopped it. We intend to do everything we can to stop it again this time, because it is wholly unsatisfactory. We have a Senate committee of inquiry that will report on 11 September 1992—six months after the Commission recommends its charges. That is the truth. That is what this Government wants to do. It does not care about the effect, so long as it can get its hands on more taxpayers' money. That is all this proposal is about.

I have severe doubts as to whether some of the things that are proposed by the Government are constitutional. I doubt whether the discriminatory charging regime, the discriminatory taxes that will be imposed by virtue of the different rates inherent in the registration charges, is constitutional with respect to section 51 of the Constitution. Unless every single cent of that road user charge is returned to the roads, it is not a user charge but a tax, and it is not possible to have taxes that discriminate between States. I suggest that the Government and the Minister give serious consideration to this matter because they are setting up a taxing regime that will discriminate between one State and another in regard to trade. For example, trade going between New South Wales and South Australia would be taxed at a higher rate than trade going between South Australia and Western Australia. That is what this Government will do. I have severe doubts about whether it is at all constitutional.

I suppose I ought to talk about the effect this measure will have on industry in this country, because that is what is of major concern to me. It is surprising, of course, that Bob Hawke, in his attempt to save his leadership, had the indecency—I use the word `indecency' carefully—to accuse the coalition, which is opposing this Bill, of planning to introduce these charges which his own Government thought up, brought up and introduced.

How much more hypocritical or cynical could a Prime Minister become than to mislead the Australian populace in such a disgraceful and disgusting way? The truth is—and let the whole Australian population know it—that we on this side of the chamber oppose this Bill, the principles behind it and this Government's attempts to increase charges for the road transport industry. Let the people know it because we believe they ought to know it. This is not a coalition of people intent on higher taxation, as this Government and the Democrats are, but we are a group of people intent on lower taxation. Will Mr Hawke, if he remains Prime Minister after 6.30 tonight, have the decency to go to the Australian people and say, `I misled you; I did not tell you the truth. I did not tell you that it was my Government's idea.'? Of course he will not do that. Will Minister Button be shouting it from the rooftops?

TALK.START.PARA: —What about ex-Treasurer Keating?

—Will the ex-Treasurer, maybe the next Prime Minister of Australia, be shouting it from the rooftops? Will he be saying that the previous incumbent told the Australian population a grave untruth? Of course not. They do not want people to know what they are doing. But we want them to know, because we will not tolerate what this Government plans to do to the road transport industry.

PARA.TAB: Let me talk about the effect on other industries and on other people. For example, I refer to potato growers on the Atherton Tableland. Currently they earn about $8 a bag for potatoes that come off the tableland and are sold in Sydney. The problem is that the cost of getting those potatoes from the Atherton Tableland to Sydney is $5.50 a bag. If there is a 20 per cent increase in road user charges, which is what is expected to result from this Bill, it will add another $1.10 to the price of a bag of potatoes. As it is, those potato growers are already losing money by taking the potatoes out of the ground and shipping them down to Sydney. Effectively, there will be little opportunity for the potato industry in the Atherton Tableland if this Bill goes through.

Let us look, for example, at the effect the Bill will have on the sugar industry. That industry is a big user of gypsum, which it spreads over the soil. Currently it costs $15 a tonne to buy gypsum in Brisbane, but in Bundaberg the cost of gypsum is $50 a tonne. In other words, there is a $35 a tonne freight component on that gypsum from Brisbane to Bundaberg. If one adds another 20 per cent to that—another $7—instead of that gypsum costing $50 a tonne, exorbitant as it is, it would cost $57 a tonne. The cost to the sugar industry will be quite dreadful. That industry needs gypsum to ensure that the soil is fertile and that the industry gets a good return, yet this Government intends to add to the industry's input costs. We believe that that is despicable.

Another industry that would suffer would be the dairy industry, which is a major user of road transport in shipping milk from the producer to the dairy and from the dairy to the consumers. One only needs to look, for example, at the dairy cooperative on the Atherton Tableland to see what effect that would have. The effect is quite frightening. That dairy cooperative would be faced with hundreds of thousands of dollars of extra registration fees just on the trucks it owns itself, let alone on the transport charges it pays to other operators. It involves hundreds of thousands of dollars in higher registration charges on the trucks that it owns.

These are things that this Government does, yet it tells us that this is micro-economic reform. It is nothing short of micro-economic destruction for this Government to increase the charges to industry in the way it has. It will be nothing short of destructive of the efforts of that dairy cooperative to export dairy produce into South East Asia if this Government gets its way. This Government is likely to get its way because its friends, the Democrats, will support it. The Democrats pretend that they are friends of the bush and the friends of anybody else they happen to meet, but they are the same people who shamefully support an increase in road user charges. This is being done in the same manner in which the Democrats have shamefully refused to support any attempt by the coalition to reduce the cost of diesel and petrol through the abolition of the fuel tax. That is a disgusting and disgraceful public position and one that will be remembered for a long time.

I conclude by saying that the Australian people should know who are the authors of this proposal. Let them know who are the supporters of this proposal, and who will knife industry in the back through this Bill. What is for sure is that it will not be the National and Liberal parties because we oppose these provisions now and will oppose them while this Government continues to tax industry in the way in which it does.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Liberal and National parties have proposed an amendment to the National Road Transport Commission Bill 1991 which I would urge the Government seriously to consider and, in the interests of Australia, adopt as the policy of the Parliament and the Government. My colleagues in the Liberal and National parties have spoken at some length on the effects of the Bill and what it would do to Australia, and it is important for us to understand the concept of this Bill and the industry's concerns.

PARA.TAB: The Bill on a cursory reading is innocuous. It simply sets up the National Road Transport Commission, which seems to be not such a bad idea. However, one of the benefits of the Senate committee system is that it enables senators and the public at large to look in greater depth and detail at what the Bill really means and what lies behind the words and sentiments of what the Government proposes. I do not think many people would object to the broad thrust of the sentiments of the Bill, but when one looks at the Bill closely and understands what the industry says about it, one has real concerns as to what the Bill will do for transport in Australia.

I am particularly concerned about road transport of any nature. I live, and always have done, in the far north of Queensland where we exist because of transport—road transport, rail transport and air transport. It is particularly pleasing to find that Dr Hewson in his Fightback package has recognised the role that road freight and freight generally play in the lives and living standards of those of us who live remote from the capital cities. To that end, Dr Hewson has introduced a package of reforms which will make road transport much more cost-effective. The wholesale sales tax will be completely removed from all business inputs, but particularly the road transport industry. The 20 per cent wholesale sales tax on rigs, trucks, tyres, windscreens and repairs will go. In addition, the 26c a litre fuel and diesel excise which currently applies will be completely removed.

The cascading effect of that will have a massive impact on the lives of those of us who live in areas remote from the capital cities because we depend so much on road, rail and air transport and on our own cars and the fuel that is used in them. That more than anything is one of the most significant reforms that have been proposed in this country, I venture to say, this century because it will mean so much in terms of the costs of shipping things by road.

Yesterday, when travelling with Dr Hewson in north and central Queensland, we talked to truckies. We received their enthusiastic support for the Fightback package because they recognise just what it will do not only for remote and regional Australia but also for Australia in general. The trucking industry as a whole significantly supports and enthusiastically endorses the Fightback package because of what it will do for remote and regional Australia and for the cost of transport.

I digress slightly to mention another aspect of transport in the area I come from. It is a very sad day in the annals of the transport industry in far north Queensland and northern Australia when we see the reports today that Compass Airlines is struggling. Compass has made an enormous impact on far north Queensland and really boosted the area's tourist industry at a time when—because of this Government's actions with the pilots strike, the recession we had to have and huge interest rates—the tourist industry in far north Queensland was on its knees. It is my opinion that the significant event of Compass coming along, more than anything, saved the tourist industry in far north Queensland and really boosted it to a stage where it is now one of the most progressive industries in the world.

I read with some sadness today that Compass Airlines is struggling. Compass in its first seven months of operation—in the words of its balance sheet—paid some $22m to various government coffers, and of that $22m some $2.4m went in sales tax and almost $1m went in payroll tax in that period. If the Government had the courage to adopt the Fightback package, Compass Airlines would be better off today by $3.5m. That is just one aspect of it. The flow-on effect of all of the other reductions of taxes on businesses would be enormous.

TALK.START.PARA: —You'd add 15 per cent to every ticket!

—They would even help people in Senator Tate's area. I am sure that the people of Tasmania would love to have Dr Hewson's Fightback package because of what it would do to transport in his area. In the figures of Compass, the $3.5m which went into government coffers would not be there under Dr Hewson's Fightback package. The industry understands that and the tourist industry generally accepts that. It is a sad day. I certainly hope that Compass can continue running because the airline is very important to the freight and transport areas of our nation.

PARA.TAB: I mentioned that yesterday I was in central and north Queensland talking with truckies about the Fightback package and other things, including the National Road Transport Commission Bill. Some of the truckies showed to us press releases that had been issued by the Australian Democrats pretending that they are the truckies' friend.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a joke!

—That is right; what a joke. I do not have to get up in Parliament here and point out to Australians the hypocrisy of the Democrats and their policy on transport because the industry is doing it for me. The industry is throwing around these press releases from the Australian Democrats and wondering how a political party that was established to keep the bastards honest can be so hypocritical and have such a deleterious effect on the national road transport industry. Senator Kernot, who has taken some interest in this and who issues these press releases around the countryside, should really wake up to herself. It would be far better that she said nothing than issue these sorts of press releases, which make the Democrats the laughing stock of the transport industry. They are scorned, and rightly so, by those people who need assistance, who want assistance, who understand that our package will give assistance but who realise that our efforts are being thwarted by the combined force of the Government, with its Right, Left and Centre Left factions, and its far left faction in the Australian Democrats. People in the industry do understand that.

PARA.TAB: Time is short because we have a deal of legislation to get through on the day the Senate rises. We have been asked to keep our speeches short, which is difficult on a matter as important as this, but I want briefly to mention some of the things that happened at the inquiry held by the Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure on this particular Bill. I am privileged to be a member of that Committee along with my Liberal Party colleagues Senators Chapman and Panizza. We spent a great number of hours listening to people make submissions on that Bill. These people had come from all over Australia at short notice because they had a very great concern about the Bill and they wanted us, as parliamentarians, to understand their concerns. As I said previously, I am particularly grateful that they came because they made me more aware of what was happening.

Had the Government had some members there, it might also have learned and realised that the Bill requires substantial further investigation. Senator Foreman sat through the hearing, so he would understand the submissions made, but none of his colleagues bothered to attend and the Australian Democrats did not even bother to show up. They did not even have the courtesy to listen to the submissions made by those people.

I have read what Senator Coulter said about Senator Powell not being available, and I can understand that. But Senator Kernot used to be on that Committee. She understands the matter and has the carriage of it in the chamber. She could easily have been there. Senator Coulter said that after speaking to members of the industry between 7.40 and 7.50 he suddenly understood all of their concerns. In 10 minutes he was able to achieve, so he says, what those witnesses took some four, five or six hours to explain to and be questioned on by the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —He's pretty bright.

—If I were Senator Tate, I would not interject because his Party had four people on that Committee and only one of them, the Chairman, bothered to turn up. It is an absolute disgrace for the Government to come along and put some proposal to this Parliament by the majority of that Committee—the Labor Party and the Democrats—when they were not even there to hear the arguments. How would they know and be able to understand what it was all about? How could they appreciate the real problems that the people in the trucking industry had with the Bill?

PARA.TAB: I will just mention some of the concerns expressed by witnesses from the trucking industry. They were concerned about the independence not of the commissioners but of the Commission itself because its jurisdiction was wrong and the rules under which it was to operate were not appropriate. They were concerned that the Commission was being directed by the Labor Party in a certain area and that it would not be an independent body looking at all aspects of the road transport industry to properly consider this Bill.

There was also a concern that the Bill was being rushed through. There was a plea by nearly all of the witnesses—which the Liberal Party members on the Committee took up—for further time to investigate the concerns of the industry, to give the Commission some power to look into things, to estimate the level at which the road freight charges might have to be and then to determine the impact of that on the people of Australia. There was a real concern that sufficient time was not being given to investigate those matters.

There was also a concern about the two zones that are being proposed. I remember some time ago when my State Premier, Mr Goss, in a blaze of publicity and in an attempt to hoodwink the people of Queensland, came back as the tough boy from one of these Premiers Conferences and said, `I'm not agreeing to that road freight thing. I have a special deal for Queensland. We are going to have a different say in it. It'll be beaut for Queensland'. Foolishly, I, like a lot of other Queenslanders, thought that sounded like a good idea because we would get some favoured treatment. But, after attending the Committee and hearing the concerns of the people who have investigated it fully and understand it, it is quite obvious that there is a real concern with a two-zonal system. I would not have been aware of that concern if I had not been able to get the in-depth advice and submissions from people in the industry and people who understand what this is all about.

It is most important that the social and economic impact of the proposed new road user charges are investigated before, or at least at the same time as, recommendations are made for the new charges. The Government seems to have overlooked this. It has quite petulantly refused to allow that to happen. Why a full investigation cannot be allowed and what the Government has to fear from these sorts of things I do not know. However, this is certainly something that I urge honourable senators to consider when voting. I mention very briefly that many of the witnesses had a real concern with clause 20(3) of the agreement between the States, and that related to the possible non-independence of the Commission. I again urge the Government to look at the matter.

I also urge the Government, in addressing these issues, to consider the submissions of the Northern Territory Government and to take on board the concerns of the industry, the concerns of the people who really know how this will affect road transport generally, the concerns about rushing this through without proper and adequate investigation. Those people made a significant effort to come and explain that to us, to point out the flaws in the Bill, to point out what the Parliament should do with the measure. I hope the Senate will take on board those submissions and arguments put to the Committee and adopt the amendment Senator Chapman has moved on behalf of the Liberal and National parties. I urge the Senate to support the amendment and so give the trucking industry in Australia a fair go, a chance to serve the people they look after.

TALK.START.PARA: —Time is short and I will not take very long speaking to the National Road Transport Commission Bill. I compliment the previous speakers on this side for putting the Opposition's position so clearly and so lucidly. We have a number of concerns about this Bill: the fact that the taxes and charges already being paid are not taken into account, and the whole business of not being able to look at the roads that are provided for the industry to run on and make an assessment of how economically they are being funded and maintained. That is a great disability.

PARA.TAB: I want to talk briefly as a primary producer, one of the very few in this Senate, because the Bill has a major impact on rural Australia.One of the major propositions is that heavy transport will operate on a user pays basis. As all honourable senators would know, I have marked reservations about user pays. It is something that is very glibly trotted out. Very few people seem to understand that there are many ramifications in adopting the user pays concept. It is one of the worst legacies the Whitlam Government left us. If we are to have a user pays doctrine, as I have said on numerous occasions, particularly in relation to aviation, I think there is a good case to get away from personal income tax, because we are paying twice for a lot of things under the user pays concept.

If we are going to have a user pays doctrine, I want to be consulted on how my money is expended by government departments. Certainly half the bureaucrats in them I would not feed; I would take them off the payroll. I find that in the aviation field there is very little consultation with me as to what expenditures are run up in my name, and I suspect that it will be much the same with respect to transport. We will have a bureaucratic determination of what the `true cost' is for this service and it will be levied against the industry.

Everything that goes onto a property and everything that comes off moves by road. It is very much in the national interest that we make that as cheap a service as it is possible for it to be. As Senator Macdonald was saying, that is one of the great benefits of the GST proposal, which cleans out all the on-costs to transport in this country and makes them a deductible business expense. That is why rural Australia has embraced the GST so emphatically. It has been one of the great breakthroughs towards reducing costs that rural Australia has faced.

One of the difficulties is that most of the people in the Department of Transport and Communications have never been out in the field. There is great concern from these people about how the heavy transports are breaking up the roads. If transports are properly designed they do not break up roads. What happens is that people overload transports, and it is not uncommon, whether they are hauling freight between Sydney and Melbourne or wheat off a property in the Darling Downs, to load those vehicles up to two or even three times their designed all-up weight. When that happens the effect on the road paving is catastrophic and very expensive repairs are required.

The solution to the problem is not to attack the industry and say that operators will be charged $20,000 or $30,000—some figures are up to $70,000 or $80,000—a year to register heavy equipment. The correct approach is to enforce, through the State police forces and the traffic authorities, the design loading of the trucks. If that happens, then except in extremes of wet weather, when the paving is undermined to some degree and the stabilisation is reduced, there are no harmful effects to the road surface.

I shall close with those few remarks. I support fully the position of the Opposition on this measure. The move to a National Road Transport Commission has some virtues but, like everything else the Government has done in recent times, it has not been thought through. The Bill is not a coherent document and, as it stands, it will only add very significantly to costs and frustrations in the transport industry, and it will certainly not work in the way the Government intends it to work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Many of my colleagues have drawn attention to particular problems and concerns with the National Road Transport Commission Bill. My major concern is to draw attention to some of the problems this Bill will cause in my home State of Victoria. Senator Macdonald, Senator Boswell and Senator O'Chee have very effectively put to the chamber the very great concerns about the Bill that exist amongst people in the transport industry in their State. These concerns are shared equally by many in the transport industry in Victoria.

PARA.TAB: To provide examples of our concern, I draw on a study undertaken by the Shepparton-Kyabram-Rodney Development Corporation. A review was conducted by the National Transport Federation on the effects of this Bill on the transport industry in Shepparton. I believe that the study is important. All through this process the Government has claimed that the changes to road charges that will be determined by the National Road Transport Commission will have a negligible impact on rural and remote areas. This claim by the Government is significant, in the light of the fact that, to my knowledge, no real study on the impact of this Bill has been undertaken by the Government. This is despite the fact that an interim commission has been set up to begin work on these issues.

The study I referred to by the Shepparton Development Corporation, which based its findings on recommendations from the Government working parties to heads of governments in July 1991, delivers some major findings and raises some very serious questions, which I wish to bring before this chamber. It is significant because it is the first report of this kind to examine the impact of the proposals for road funding by the Government on regional areas in Victoria, and I believe its findings can be applied literally to hundreds of regional centres throughout the country.

The report found, among other things, that the road transport industry is vital to the Shepparton region. It found that articulated vehicles play a larger role than the local lighter delivery trucks. In effect, this means that regions such as Shepparton, which rely more heavily on larger vehicles, will be particularly adversely affected. Another finding of the report was—and I am sure that it can be confirmed by many honourable senators in this chamber—that the road transport industry operates on very slim margins, around 3 to 4 per cent of turnover, and any further increases in road charges could not be easily absorbed, if they could be absorbed at all, by the industry.

This report is sending a clear message to the Government that its plan to heap additional charges over and above those already incurred by the industry would have a disastrous impact, not just on the road transport industry but on the Shepparton region as a whole. The report goes on to examine closely the financial impact decisions that the proposed National Road Transport Commission may have if the recommendations of the government working parties to the heads of government were adopted.

It found that employment in the Shepparton region directly from the road transport industry amounted to some 1,400 jobs; that some 60 per cent of employment in the region was generated by or heavily reliant on the road transport industry; and that the industry generated a turnover in the region of some $67m. But it is important to recall that the profit margin here is only around 3 or 4 per cent of this total. In other words, the report found that whilst the road transport industry survives on a very low margin, its survival is vital for the Shepparton region as a whole as it generates such a vast amount of income. The National Transport Federation has concluded in its review of the Shepparton Development Corporation's report that:

SPEECH.PARA: It appears that the proponents (of the increases in registration) have not taken significant account of the regional road transport industries and the effects any increase on charges will have on the industry and consequently the regional economy.
The report went on to say:

For items that require freighting through various stages of production, the cost increases will be passed on at each stage. Two of the Goulburn Valley's major industries—dairying and the fruit industry—fall into this category. They are also staple consumer products and provide valuable export earnings to the Goulburn Valley and Australia.
Commenting on the Government's two-tier registration fee proposal, the NTF concluded:

If either a fixed cost registration fee or a variable charge. . . is levied on the industry, virtually all the articulated transport industry in this region will become unviable (given the) marginal return to the operator is (currently) between 3-4%.

I believe it is incumbent on the Minister to rise today to respond to these findings. Nothing less than the jobs of hundreds in the Shepparton region alone depends on his response. I know that you, Mr Acting Deputy President, with your long background in the trade union movement and the very proper concern that you show about levels of unemployment in this country—and I wish they were shared by the leaders in your Party—would also be particularly concerned about the adverse impact on jobs that this Bill will certainly have.

PARA.TAB: In case the Minister doubts the severity of the situation, he might consider the example provided in the NTF's response to one of Shepparton's largest transport companies. This company operates 65 articulated vehicles. It estimates that the impact of the registration and user charges would be as follows: registration fees would blow out by some $684,125 to the staggering amount of around $936,000; user charges, based on a per kilometre levy of 10c per kilometre, and estimating a yearly distance per vehicle of some 250,000 kilometres, would amount to a charge of $25,000 per vehicle or a total of $1,625,000—an increase of more than $1.3m over current charges. That is a very heavy burden indeed to be borne by a company.

On a regional basis, of the companies in the Development Corporation's survey, the new charges would take nearly $3m directly off the bottom line—and I stress that this is in the Shepparton region alone. Three out of four livestock transporters believe the Government's measures will add costs of $2 per head of stock; hay carting may increase by $10 per tonne; grain freight increases could vary between $1 to $12 per tonne: and freighting stock feed, bagged, up to 30c per tonne. Fruit transporting could increase from $1 to $5 per tonne. That is a very heavy additional burden to be borne by these industries.

Dr Hewson made it clear at the launch of the Fightback package that reform of the transport industry is of major importance. Yet the coalition believes that any reform must be fair and equitable. The study by the Shepparton Development Corporation raises very serious questions, not only for that region but for the whole of regional Australia, and suggests that the Government's proposals are neither fair nor equitable. The lack of consultation by the Government is of serious concern, and Senator Macdonald drew our attention very effectively to this matter. It is very poor indeed that this Government has rushed through this measure in the hope of giving some credibility to Mr Hawke's much vaunted new federalism foray.

The coalition's Fightback package details the coalition's commitment to remove all the current taxes applicable in the area before examining the issue of road user charges. The principal initiatives of the visionary Fightback package which would have a positive impact directly on the road transport industry are: firstly, the abolition of the wholesale sales tax; secondly, the abolition of fuel excise duty; and thirdly, the abolition of payroll tax. Fourthly, the package will investigate possible savings to be made by improving the efficiency of road construction and maintenance.

The principal concern of the coalition with this Bill is that the NRTC does not have the power, under its terms of reference, to review the existing level of taxation on road transport, nor the need to look at the efficiency of road construction and maintenance. The Government seems quite prepared to put additional charges on road transport, on top of existing taxes. This will increase transport costs and decrease Australia's competitiveness.

We on this side of the chamber believe micro-reform is about reducing costs and increasing competitiveness. It is clear that, by bringing before the Senate today proposals for the NRTC which will have the opposite effect to genuine micro-reform, the Government has shown contempt for the road transport industry and has underlined again, as it does ceaselessly with its confused policies, its lack of commitment to real micro-economic reform.

In conclusion, I have frequently argued in this chamber that the Australian Democrats, in many of their policies, have adopted an anti-rural approach. If there are any who doubt this claim, I invite them to examine the Democrats' alternative budget brought down by Senator Spindler and never, as far as I am aware, rejected by their current Treasury spokesperson, Senator Kernot. This alternative budget raises over $6.4 billion in additional taxes. They should also examine the Democrats' environmental policies and rural policies, which seem designed in a number of areas to bring much of our primary industry to a grinding halt.

I hope that in the Democrats' consideration of this Bill they will support the sensible amendments proposed by my colleague Senator Chapman so that at least some constructive changes can be made to a Bill which, as so many speakers have noted in their contributions to this chamber today, will have such an adverse effect on our transport industry in particular, and the rural sector in general.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to speak to the National Road Transport Commission Bill 1991, I wish firstly to support the comments of my colleagues. I do not wish to go over the ground that they have covered, but I wish to comment on some aspects of this Bill about which I have some concern.

PARA.TAB: I believe that, in terms of making our transport industry in this country internationally competitive, it is important that we have a fair and equitable system. The question we must ask about this Bill is: is it fair between the States and is it equitable between operators and consumers? I believe that it is not. I believe that it has the potential to force operators to put costs up and lose road transport tasks to the rail system. I am not opposed to the rail system winning tasks by being competitive through improving its act, but I am opposed to its winning tasks or carrying operations by forcing the road transport industry into a situation where it is non-competitive. I believe that the Bill before us, and the one that will be coming before us relating to the rail industry, will not have the potential to maximise the efficiency that is required in our transport industry.

The transport industry in this country is the artery of the nation. I find it absolutely unacceptable that we have a transport industry in this country which is bedevilled by taxes and charges. The road transport industry is the most highly taxed industry in this country. I want to cover some points concerning that and why, when carrying out the tasks required on behalf of Australian consumers, residents and industry, it is internationallly non-competitive.

Firstly, I want to deal with the current situation. This Bill will lead to a new system of user pays road charging in terms of the agreements that have been put in place between the States and the Commonwealth. For example, a rig costing $257,000 in the first year would cost $38,850—very close to $40,000—in wholesale sales tax on a prime mover, trailer and tyres, required to do some 250,000 kilometres. That figure does not include any replacement parts in that year.

A further element of the taxes on the road transport industry is import duties. The average import duty on commercial vehicles being brought into this country is of the order of 25 per cent. The national average is around 9 per cent. Once again, in this arena we find that the heavy haulage industry is significantly disadvantaged. Further, currently, fuel excise is in the order of 26c a litre and only 6c a litre of that goes back into the road system. Once again, the road transport system is making an enormous contribution to general revenue to fund other government programs. Of course, this makes our transport industry in Australia very expensive.

I want now to deal with our approach to the road transport industry, as opposed to that of the Government. We are looking at the impact of payroll tax and other taxes that road transport users have to pay, such as licences and State taxes.

Our approach, through the Fightback package, is to get rid of the wholesale sales tax and the fuel excise, and the payroll taxes which impact very heavily on transport, particularly in my State of Western Australia, which is very large. The agricultural and mineral industries in particular rely very much on the road transport industry to carry out many of the tasks that are required in shifting products around my State. This applies not only to the agricultural and mining industries, but also to the movement of everybody's goods and services. To have such an important industry—which, as I said, is the artery of communications in the movement of goods in this country—so heavily taxed is unacceptable.

I want to dwell briefly on our amendments currently before the chamber. The first concerns a thorough review of all input taxes and charges paid by the road transport industry. In respect of that amendment, it is absolutely essential, having highlighted some of the taxes and charges which already exist, not to have the threat of another tax or charge on top of them. We have had no clear indication from the Government as to its position on this issue. Will it transfer into general revenue the whole fuel excise that is collected?

This Bill deals with the user pays concept and states that it is important that the user pays for road usage. I would spell out quite vigorously that the road transport industry is already paying more in taxes than is required for the maintenance and construction of the road system in this country, and the industries of this nation are put at a very significant disadvantage because it is an extra cost that they have to bear. The Government should spell out very clearly its future position, which it has not done. Part (a) of our amendment seeks to establish precisely the taxes and charges and their impact.

There have already been a number of reports on this issue in the transport industry, including the Inter-State Commission report. I believe that the only way to go is to wipe the slate clean, get rid of the taxes I mentioned—the wholesale sales tax, fuel excise, payroll tax, the training levy and all these existing costs—and then look at licensing systems charges and fuel charges in the States so that the road transport industry has a very clear indication of what it is looking at. Currently, that situation is not clear.
The other point I want to raise concerns part (b) of our amendment, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . an investigation of the current level of efficiency of road construction and maintenance practices;

We know that in this country we have all sorts of problems regarding work practices in many industries. I want to give a couple of examples of the way that road maintenance operates, of which I am fully aware.

PARA.TAB: I am sure that nobody in this chamber, and very few people in Australia, would not have driven along roads and seen maintenance gangs working on them. The thing that always strikes one is the number of people who are standing around or sitting down alongside a truck—in other words, not being very usefully engaged in their employment. Occasionally one comes across a road operation where that is not the case.

I want to highlight what has happened in the Shire of Ravensthorpe in Western Australia, where I live. It was decided a number of years ago to introduce competition into the operation of road maintenance and various services of the shire. Much of the road work that was being done was contracted out, especially the main tasks. What did we see then? We saw trucks and graders that started early in the morning, worked until late in the evening, worked double shifts and got the job done. We never used to drive past them seeing people standing around with no tasks. We never used to find on a Monday morning that people did not arrive at work until lunchtime and knocked off at Friday lunchtime to go home.

The second part of our amendment is also very important because I believe the level of efficiency and productivity demonstrated in the maintenance work on our roads is very poor indeed. Usually, the quality of the construction and the work that is done is quite satisfactory, but the capital for the vehicles, graders, rollers and a whole host of machinery that is used for the maintenance and building of our roads is very poorly applied and utilised. Of course, that is paid for, fundamentally, out of charges that come back onto the road users.

As I pointed out in my earlier comments, the road transport industry is very heavily taxed indeed. The Government should start by having the courage to implement those aspects of the Fightback package—and the other aspects I referred to—which remove the wholesale sales tax and other aspects of the charges, including the fuel excise. It should start a clean sheet in terms of charging. In conclusion, an investigation of the efficiency and improvements in efficiency and the utilisation of the capitalisation and work practices must be an integral part of a national road transport system.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like my colleagues, I am very concerned about the National Road Transport Commission Bill 1991. I have been pleased to hear today the contributions of my colleagues, from both the National Party and the Liberal Party, because I think they have highlighted most of the concerns I have.

PARA.TAB: We must remember that the road transport system employs some 400,000 people around Australia. I am reminded of how important road transport is when I think back to a parliamentary delegation, of which I was a member, which visited the Soviet Union last year. That, too, is a vast country and one of the major reasons it is having so many problems at the moment is that it has a failed transport system. The bureaucracy has failed it; it does not have the infrastructure or the private enterprise system we have in Australia.

I believe one of the big success stories of our road transport system has been the fact that it is driven by private enterprise. Yet this Bill, which is being forced through this House today with great urgency before Christmas, seeks to set up another bureaucracy. The framework of the Bill is really asking the road transport industry to buy a pig in a poke, because it does not know what it will cost or what the impact will be on the industry and the people of Australia. Here we are today being forced to pass this Bill through the Senate as a matter of urgency, yet we do not know the answers to the issues that will affect every man, woman and child in this country. We do not know what the impact will be on freight costs and all of those other things associated with it.

As I said, one of the major problems I can see facing the USSR is its failed transport system. I believe this Bill and all of the bureaucracy that goes with it will not improve our system but detract from it. I am not the only one who thinks that. This has also been highlighted by the road transport organisations around Australia. When we look at the proposition that has been put to us today and which we are debating, it is interesting to note that all major groups in the road transport industry have opposed strongly the Special Premiers Conference agreement. For the life of me, I cannot understand why the Tasmanian Premier would agree to put Tasmania in the high cost zone.
Debate interrupted.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Burns)—Order! The time being 12.45 p.m., we will now move to matters of public interest.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take the opportunity in this discussion on matters of public interest today to raise certain issues with regard to the administration of the office of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission in Tennant Creek. In early September this year, I put on notice with a Senate Estimates committee a question about the performance of the Anyinginyi Health Congress in Tennant Creek. I pursued that matter further in Estimates committee hearings on 12 September and I made a number of points about the need to undertake accountability, auditing and a health performance review.

PARA.TAB: At that time, in early and mid-September, I also had confidential discussions with both the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Tickner) and the chief executive officer of ATSIC in this regard. It concerns me that it took some two months for the inquiry into Anyinginyi to get under way and for the Minister to, in effect, respond to me with the terms of reference of the inquiry in a letter dated 13 November. I have still heard nothing about the results of any inquiries into the matter. I feel that whilst the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission has an important, independent and proper function in any of these areas, given the fact that all of these organisations are funded principally by taxpayers' money, the Minister must accept the proper political accountability and give due courtesies and proper reporting in relation to service delivery to Aboriginal people in health areas, such as the Anyinginyi Congress. This issue must be addressed. The procrastination and delays associated with this project, which have gone on now for almost three months, are a major concern.

In early November, I raised in the Senate a matter arising from those Estimates committee hearings but which also concerned the misappropriation of more than $1m with regard to the operation of the Jurnkurakurr Out-station Resource Centre, also based in Tennant Creek. It was acknowledged that the events that took place in the several days after that revealed that there was evidence of gross mismanagement and totally inadequate supervision and that, in effect, more than $1m in funds—which had been dedicated for Aboriginal service delivery purposes—had dissipated and disappeared.

Whilst the Minister did make available to me an initial report of the inquiry by a firm of chartered accountants, Pannell Kerr Forster, and this then flowed on to the Tennant Creek community, it is a matter of concern that we have not been able to ascertain any further details. I am aware that the ongoing service delivery required by Aboriginal people in the Barkly and Tennant Creek areas of the Northern Territory is of major concern. But it is also of concern to the commercial interests of the traders of Tennant Creek who, in this instance of which I am aware, have been caught for more than $300,000 in debts arising from this project.

At the same time, I also called for further information with regard to other ATSIC administered programs, principally certain community development and employment programs, and I highlighted a number of them. ATSIC subsequently reported to me that a couple of the projects had clean sheets, and I acknowledge that, particularly with regard to Robinson River and Lake Nash. However, I have heard nothing further with regard to the problems that are supposed to affect the project at Nicholson River and also with regard to the functions of a housing association at Borroloola and a community service delivery agency in Elliott.

None of this information has come back, despite representations having been made in this place in early November and also directly to the Minister and to ATSIC. I find it a matter of concern, as we rise now for the summer recess, that the Minister has not taken the opportunity to report through Senator Collins, as ought to have happened in this place, in proper and due time. Therefore, we will not be able, as we properly ought, to ascertain and obtain the information before the end of February 1992, a further three months—in effect, six months from when the issue was first ascertained. I hope that the Minister will address this matter quickly and promptly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise as a matter of public interest the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's treatment of children's radio programs and specifically the way in which it has dealt with certain educational programs for children. According to the Australian Bureau of Statistics, there are some 2,475,300 children in Australia between the ages of nought and nine years. The Australian Broadcasting Corporation's radio division denies the very existence of these children. Last year the ABC axed its internationally acclaimed children's radio service and took away the right of these children to listen to any radio programs of their own. One could easily imagine the public outcry if, instead, the ABC had axed all of its radio programs for adults. With an annual budget of just over $500m, it is indefensible for the ABC not to allocate funds to restore radio programs for children.

PARA.TAB: Only recently the ABC ran its 8c a day campaign yet again. This means that children up to nine years old are effectively contributing over $72.27m to the ABC, out of which no money is returned to make radio programs for children. It is incomprehensible that the ABC's Board, together with its radio management, is not prepared to allocate any funds to ensure its own future existence. If today's children are not given the opportunity to enjoy and be stimulated by radio, they will never appreciate the value of the ABC or become its future audience.

Previously the ABC had taken positive steps to cater for children by providing radio serials and a 10-minute program for young children called Ticklepot. Commenting on the early success of Ticklepot, the then Chairman of the ABC, Mr Somervaille, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it brought home to me the absolute necessity to see that our programming for young children, rather novel it seems, goes from success to success.

Ticklepot brought fun and laughter to thousands of children across Australia, but since the axing of Ticklepot the word appears to create terror amongst some ABC executives. They hoped it would go away, but only recently, after being mentioned in a replay of the TV program PGR on the ABC, they received many inquiries about the program again.

PARA.TAB: In defending its action to axe Ticklepot, the ABC has come up with a barrage of varied excuses. First, those responsible for this decision did not know the duration of the program nor the true cost. The Green Guide quoted Mr Roger Grant, Controller of Radio National, as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: Ticklepot costs $1m a year and runs for only seven minutes a day.

By the next day it had come down to a quarter of a million and he said he was misquoted. But even that figure was misleading and ignored important facts. I am sure that, if the ABC costed other radio programs in the same way, it would find that they were even more expensive to make.

PARA.TAB: The Managing Director of the ABC, Mr David Hill, gave a unique insight to the ABC by stating that Ticklepot was axed because `the program Offspring wished it to be removed from its program'. Even the listeners were well aware of the attitude of the then presenter towards Ticklepot. Surely there is more accountability for ABC program decisions than axing a program because another program did not want it to follow it.

David Hill then went on to say that Ticklepot was not viewed as being central to the mission of Radio National or the charter of the ABC. If children's educational programs were not part of the charter of the ABC, then why has it established such a fine tradition in providing programs for children? David Hill then showed his complete ignorance of radio by stating:

SPEECH.PARA: You may be assured the needs of preschoolers will not be neglected by the ABC with a discontinuation of Ticklepot. ABC Television screens twice each day programs such as Sesame Street and Play School.

PARA.TAB: Radio and television are completely different media and television cannot replace radio. This excuse also overlooks the fact that Ticklepot received many letters from families where the parents had made a conscious decision to encourage their children not to watch television but to listen to the radio, and these children were now denied their own program.
Responding to further criticism over the axing of Ticklepot, David Hill then gave another unbelievable reason when he wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: The ABC charter states that the Corporation is to provide `programs of an educational nature' and it does not specify that these programs are to be for children. A great many programs broadcast by the ABC are educational, and this will continue to be the case.

What sort of excuse is that? Using Hill's own argument, the ABC should have axed all its popular educational programs for adults, because the charter does not say that the educational programs have to be for adults.

PARA.TAB: It was no coincidence that once a `Save Ticklepot' concert was organised, Ticklepot was taken off air. Despite its being programmed for all of 1990, management altered the program schedule and with one day's notice axed the program. In fact, the ABC completely ignored its young audience and other listeners by not telling them that it had taken the program off air.

The ABC action is indefensible. No money was saved by taking the program off air. In fact, four weeks of programs had been produced and have never gone to air and most of the 410 programs produced had already had repeat rights paid for.

The ABC continued to cover its tracks over axing Ticklepot. After it had mentioned the success of Ticklepot for two years in its annual report, why was no mention made of Ticklepot in the literacy and education section of last year's annual report to the Minister for Communications? The ABC even took steps to stop the producer of Ticklepot receiving a literacy achievement award for outstanding contributions to literacy.

In deciding to axe Ticklepot, the ABC glossed over the success of Ticklepot and the need for children's radio. It was the only non-educational children's radio program in Australia and was widely appreciated across Australia, especially in the country and remote areas, and in preschools, day care centres and schools and at home. Normal audience surveys did not reflect the true audience Ticklepot had. However, two separate surveys by the ABC proved how popular it was and called upon the ABC to extend the duration of Ticklepot and to repeat the program. In one survey, it was found that more children listened to each Ticklepot program than watched Play School.

I know that Ticklepot received more than 25,000 letters and drawings in response to the program, a fact that ABC management has refused to accept. In just 12 months, the program established a fan club of more than 5,000 members. Ticklepot became so popular that a stage performance was created. Twenty-six sell-out concerts were held in South Australia and Victoria and over 13,000 attended. It has also won Australian and international awards, including the gold medal for educational-children's programs at the International Festival of New York in 1989, followed by the bronze award in 1990. The first children's radio programs the BBC ever bought were episodes of Ticklepot.
The ABC cannot say that there is no need to provide children's radio programs, because it definitely falls within the objectives of ABC's radio corporate plan 1991-94 to:

SPEECH.PARA: reach most Australians with a range of programs that cater for specialist and minority interests.

PARA.TAB: provide programs which pioneer and challenge, engage and entertain.

SPEECH.PARA: retain capable, creative and committed staff in all areas of ABC Radio.

PARA.TAB: Despite the radio corporate plan objectives, the ABC charter and the fact that the ABC maintains five radio networks broadcasting 24 hours a day, the ABC still chooses to provide no opportunity for children to enjoy their own programs, whereas the BBC has expanded its service to now provide over 35 hours of children's radio per week.

If the ABC makes program decisions based on financial cost without taking into account its overall program responsibility, one must question its program making process. Surely, programs are produced because of their value and need and if any income were generated by the program it would become a bonus for the ABC.

When questioned on Radio University 5UV, the Controller of Radio National, Roger Grant, stated, `The Ticklepot program earned precisely zero revenue for ABC Radio, but what it earned for ABC Enterprises, I don't know'. But we are talking about the one ABC, where it has been conservatively estimated that products of ABC Enterprises, produced from radio programs by the Children's Unit in South Australia, have generated more than $660,000 income for the ABC. Further income was generated through the sale of episodes of Ticklepot and five children's radio serials to the BBC, and they have a tremendous potential to continue to raise funds for the ABC.

There is much more that could be said about this saga. The ABC's intransigent management has refused to bow to public and press criticism over the axing of Ticklepot. It seems that by their decisions and actions a couple of managers can impose their views and ignore the views of children, parents, politicians, the press and more than 1,300 people who signed petitions calling for the ABC to re-establish children's radio.

If David Hill is genuinely interested in the welfare of children, other than campaigning against the effect of tobacco advertising on children, why does he not divert some of his energies into re-establishing children's radio to ensure that ABC Radio will always have a future audience? If David Hill continues to allow the ABC to discriminate against children by not providing them with their own radio programs, he has failed in his responsibilities as a managing director.

I recall that when the ABC received its budget this year, the Minister for Transport and Communications, Mr Beazley, said that the ABC would be free to apply the efficiency dividend to programming expansion and improvement. If the ABC is to use the efficiency dividend money for program expansion, there is no reason why the ABC cannot reintroduce children's programs.

In raising this issue today, I hope the ABC will not continue to put up a smokescreen of excuses but will take immediate and positive steps to provide children with their own radio programs. After all, the ABC was on a winner with this program in the first place. The ABC still employs the talented staff associated with children's radio and could easily return its now idle production studios in Adelaide to the worthwhile task of producing children's radio programs.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: North Australian Development Unit: Interim National Child-Care Accreditation Council

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Alston, I presume this will be a birthday speech.
—I will try to celebrate some other matters, Mr Acting Deputy President.

PARA.TAB: The first matter is to associate myself with remarks made late last night by Senator Tambling in relation to the North Australian Development Unit (NADU). I had the pleasure of visiting the Unit within the last 12 months. I was very impressed with the quality of its work, which I think is unique in many respects. It is certainly not able to be readily achieved by the Department of Social Security in Canberra or in the other capital cities. For that reason the Unit was established in Darwin and allowed to prosper, although, as it would seem, for only a brief period.

What concerns me most of all about the recent Government announcement is that it is nothing more than a transparent marginal seat election strategy dressed up as a social justice strategy. It is designed simply to take the Unit to pieces, to transfer it to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, and to abolish completely the work of all those researchers who have been producing very high quality outcomes. That is a great disappointment.

It is yet another example of what Senator Richardson does when he is confronted with a choice between policies and politics. As a result, we will presumably get only broad statements made about the benefits to northern Australia that can flow from Senator Richardson's largess, rather than considered, thought-provoking reports. The reports at times have been at odds with the Department but, from discussions I have had, they have been within the bounds of tolerance. Therefore, one can only describe this outcome as politically motivated.

I turn to another matter which I view even more seriously. It is the establishment of an interim national child-care accreditation council. Senator Tate may have had some involvement in this and if he has—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, not recently. I remember the Bill.

—The honourable senator will be aware that this matter has been on the Government's agenda since the last election. The Government has wanted to establish an accreditation system as part of the trade-off with the ACTU for allowing fee relief to be extended to the private sector. No bones were made about that; the ACTU was always bitterly opposed to fee relief to the commercial sector, and this was part of the deal.

PARA.TAB: There has never been any justification provided for accreditation, given that there are regulations operating in each State. Sometimes the regulations vary. For example, the staff to child ratio may vary. It can make a considerable difference. But no-one would argue that one cannot rationalise the system via ministerial councils and the like, or indeed that there is necessarily a need to have uniformity throughout the system.

Accreditation is simply the ultimate self-indulgence. I have been critical of it from the outset, and I was very pleased when Senator Tate, in an Estimates committee hearing towards the end of last year, finally de-linked accreditation from the extension of fee relief to the private sector. There was then some confidence that maybe the Government would rethink its approach to accreditation. Well, it has not; it has gone even further and established what is really a travesty of community involvement and representation.

We all accept in this place that policies should not be made in isolation from the community, that politicians should get out there and consult, and that when there is a need to establish an advisory group it makes good sense to appoint people from the community who have some direct experience of the issues. But what we have here is nothing but a charade. Seventeen people have been appointed to an interim accreditation council, yet only two have had any direct experience in dealing with children. The rest are theorists or unionists.

It is clear that this is nothing but an attempt to justify dramatic increases in conditions and entitlements for child-care workers and an attempt to pander to the self-delusions of the early childhood lobby, who consistently fail to come up with any credible research to demonstrate that one can show a difference in terms of quality outcomes between children who have had the privilege of having access to formal child-care and those who have not.

The fact is, of course, that fewer than 10 per cent of children under the age of 12 are actually able to be placed in formal child-care centres, including family day care. Quite often it has a lot to do with the cost of the service but the fact remains that it is a small and relatively privileged group that this sort of outfit wants to extend to the wider community.

It is almost an ideological obsession. People say with a straight face that child-care is too important to be left to parents. Now we are told by the likes of the people who are on this committee that one cannot put a price on quality. That is an absolute disaster in policy terms. Not only that, but it is an insult to the parents, who are abysmally unrepresented on this committee, and an insult to the consumers, who have virtually no say at all. Certainly the taxpayers' interests are almost totally neglected, with a couple of honourable exceptions. We have on the committee representatives from the Australian Federation of Child-Care Associations and the Federation of Parents of Children in Day Care. Apart from those two groups the rest consist of simply a parade of vested interests. Anne Black, for example, the ACTU child-care officer, is there on the basis that she worked as a nurse before becoming active in the union movement. She became concerned with child-care following the birth of her own children.

That can be said about almost every parent in Australia, I would have thought. Yet not only do we find the ACTU child-care officer on board—and clearly her charter in representing her members is to boost terms and conditions of employment—but we have also someone put forward as a ministerial nominee by the Lady Gowrie Child Centre in Melbourne who is the immediate past ACTU child-care policy officer.

It is clear not only that this is one-sided representation but also that it is almost exclusively designed to serve the interests of those who stand to gain from working in the industry or from pontificating about it. I find it disappointing in the extreme, not only because it will not be addressing issues of affordability—which is absolutely paramount in access to child-care services—but because it will not even address the real issues of quality. It pretends, based on US experience which I would have thought makes it very clear that one just cannot identify quality because it is such a subjective concept, that the best way to go is to set minimum standards. That is what the State regulations do, by and large. One has inspectors to ensure that they are enforced. One can have random visits, and one can have whistle-blowers; one can have a whole range of people to ensure that children are not neglected, that the child-care workers are carrying out their duties and that there is no exploitation in the system.

By and large, there are very few complaints. Yet we have this persistent push to jack up the rates somehow. That is what it is all about—to go on arguing for over-award payments and overstaffing of centres. There are some absolutely scandalous examples of the unnecessary employment of people in child-care centres—almost always community based centres. This is a recession-proof industry. While every other small business in the country either is going broke or is on the verge and is having to cut back—and doing that in terms of labour, unfortunately—the child-care sector just pretends that somehow labour is sacrosanct, that it simply cannot address its cost structures, and it puts out its hand for more government assistance. This sort of charade will just perpetuate that problem.

So $1m was set aside in the last Budget to fund a totally unnecessary accreditation system. We are now told in the Wangman report—which the Government studiously refuses to release to the public because it is obviously terrified that it will be taken to pieces—that it will cost $1m in the first year alone, and in year 2 probably up to $3m. All this is to fund trips around Australia by 17 self-indulgent pontificators. They will not achieve a single thing. What they hope ultimately to do is to have groups visiting child-care centres and giving them ticks—giving them star ratings, in effect. One does not have to be very smart to realise that if one goes there on a good day one can make a judgment that will be totally irrelevant; if one goes back a few weeks later there may have been staff turnover or a change in attitude on the part of the director, or turnover in the quality or the types of parents using the service. In other words, it is a self-perpetuating indulgence, for one would need to be constantly doing the rounds and spending as much money as possible—totally unnecessarily. If there is money to spare in the system, it ought to be going to ensuring that parents have access to affordable and good quality child-care as measured by the regulations. Yet this sort of council will no doubt be pushing for staff-child ratios such as prevail in the smaller States. If we are to bring Victoria and New South Wales into line with those States, it will cost about another $100m. There is not a scintilla of evidence to demonstrate that children are better off between the ages of three and five if they have ratios of 5 : 1 rather than 15 : 1. There is absolutely no evidence that such an outcome will result.

I challenge this council to do something worth while, not simply to travel around Australia and waste taxpayers' funds on trying to persuade others that they ought to boost wages and conditions. I challenge it to commission some sensible research to demonstrate that we can measure the quality of child-care by outcomes and not inputs.

If we keep on going down this cul-de-sac, all we will succeed in doing is putting child-care beyond the reach of the very parents that these people profess to be concerned about. It is nothing more than a disaster that there is no sensible consumer representation, that the interests of parents are almost totally neglected, and that this will simply serve the interests of a very small clique. I hope that Minister Staples will come to his senses and will realise that this is an extravagant waste of public resources and that there are much better ways of assisting parents in getting access to child-care services in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer as a matter of public interest to the administration of the Insurance and Superannuation Commission. I made some remarks last week in relation to the Commission's report, but I want to cover a few more issues which are upsetting, in particular, taxpayers and people who need to deal with the Insurance and Superannuation Commission in the outlying States, especially Tasmania, Western Australia and Queensland.

PARA.TAB: I have received a number of inquiries from constituents about this over the last six or eight months.
