They seem to be getting more and more terse and it is well and truly time that this Parliament turned its attention towards solving the administration and resource problems of the Insurance and Superannuation Commission.

The Select Committee which Senator Sherry chairs is looking into superannuation and that may be a vehicle for looking into the Insurance and Superannuation Commission administration problems. I will be having a look at the circular that Senator Sherry provided to honourable senators earlier this week, which outlined the terms of reference of that inquiry, to see whether they cover the matters I raise today and whether those terms of reference need to be widened or expanded to look into this matter.

To be more specific about some of the problems which confront taxpayers, particularly in Western Australia in relation to the ISC: first, there is the matter of there not being a representative of the ISC in Western Australia, with the result that my constituents have to try to phone through to the ISC in Melbourne. On many occasions—and I have also tried to ring just to see whether these constituents are being fair dinkum—it is impossible to get through for hours and hours if not days at a time.

It is a terrible service. This matter of trying to get through to the ISC to get information about reasonable benefits limits, about interim determinations and determinations on superannuation, was raised at the Estimates Committee by Senator Watson from Tasmania. The ISC there said, in summary, that it was severely under-resourced and that its telephone switchboard was just not able to cope with the load. The ISC reported how many calls it took per day, which was an enormous number. One could only assume that for every call that got through, there were probably five or 10 that did not.

The important and sad thing about this is that under this new system, where the ISC has taken control of the reasonable benefits limit and determinations and interim determinations on superannuation away from the Tax Office, the maladministration and what seems to be an under-resourcing of this Commission are leaving people without the information they require to make sensible decisions about their own provision for superannuation. One of the cases I referred to last week showed that that particular constituent of mine had lost some tens of thousands of dollars because he had been given wrong advice as to when to resign from his position. That is one sad case which has cost that person a lot of money and cost his family a lifestyle they should have been able to enjoy. There are probably many other cases similar to that.

So my first point concerns the lack of access of the Australian taxpayers to this service to which they are entitled. Clearly, there is a need to have officers of the ISC in each of the States and capital cities. Of course, that is a resourcing question and a matter which I ask the Government to look at.

Secondly, also in relation to services, the chartered accountant from Abbott MF Cooper and Company who wrote to me has also written to Mr Free, the Minister assisting the Treasurer, and asked him to do something about it. The company has written many letters and has received only one reply in the past 12 months in relation to some of these questions. The Government also seems not to have any policy in relation to the standing of tax agents who make submissions or write letters on behalf of clients to the ISC. Apparently, there is no procedure to recognise tax agents as being able to deal with the Commission, although that is the procedure for people dealing with the Tax Office.

The other matter is that one of this company's clients had received six different determinations in the past year, all of which have been totally incorrect. In other words, they are being overburdened. The value and the quality of their work and the accuracy of their determinations are very questionable. If there are six determinations and not one of them is correct, you really wonder how many people around Australia are getting incorrect determinations.

Lastly, another specific example is that this particular accountancy practice had sought about 41 determinations on behalf of its clients in the past six or so months. Out of those 41 determinations, only one was correct. All the others required alterations. And, of course, as soon as there is an incorrect determination, people have to go back through the process of trying to get through on the phone, trying to get letters responded to, and so on.

From the constituents' queries that I have been getting, it seems that we have a disastrous administration of this Insurance and Superannuation Commission on our hands. It seems to be under-resourced. It seems to be badly administered. The Government should give close attention to these matters, if it is not doing so already. Clearly, the Government is distracted at the moment with considerations here on Capital Hill, but once those are out of the way, and once we find out who are to be the new Treasurer, Prime Minister and Minister assisting the Prime Minister, this should be one of the first matters that the new Labor Government—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad you didn't say `new Minister for Justice'.

—Let us hope there is not a new Minister for Justice, Senator Tate; you cannot always back the right horse. But this is a serious matter. On behalf of my constituents, I will seek to have Senator Sherry's committee spend some time on this. Through Senator Tate, I ask the Government to have a close look at a problem which I am sure is being channelled through to many senators' and members' offices. I ask the Government to resolve this problem as quickly as possible.

PARA.TAB: These taxpayers pay their taxes to get the sort of service that they deserve from these commissions. Clearly, at the moment they have to mess around for six or eight or 10 months to get a wrong determination, and then mess around for even longer to get a correct determination, and in the meantime they cannot put in their tax return and thus comply with the tax laws. So we have a disaster on our hands. I urge the Government to take action to solve these problems.
Motion (by Senator Tate) agreed to:
That the sitting of the Senate be suspended till 2 p.m.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Leadership of Australian Labor Party: Prime Minister

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, at least for this afternoon. I refer the Minister to the imminent ballot for the leadership of the Australian Labor Party and the Prime Minister of Australia.
—You won't get a vote.

—I would not want a vote. What advantages would there be for Australia in the election of the architect of the recession, Mr Keating? In the event of Mr Keating's success, what transitional arrangements have been made to govern this country, particularly bearing in mind the plight of almost one million unemployed Australians?

—Ever since I have been here with this Opposition it has asked questions about what the Budget forecasts are for next year and what will happen next month. My position on all these things has always been that the Government will do what is necessary and announce any decisions it makes at an appropriate time. That will follow in respect of Senator Hill's question, as well as anything else he asks.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. What is the Government's response to a recent attack by the HCF in a letter to contributors on the National Health Strategy's Issues Paper No. 2—Hospital Services in Australia: Access and Financing—and the push by HCF for tax rebates for private health insurance contributions?

—The Minister to whom Senator West refers has seen a copy of HCF's recent health report and the accompanying letter to contributors. To be quite frank, it is a travesty of misrepresentation. It misrepresents all the options being presented for public discussion in the particular issues paper referred to by Senator West. All options that are discussed in that paper aim to extend the overall level of choice available to hospital patients. The question of choice is absolutely paramount. The importance of patients being able to choose their own doctor is emphasised by the National Health Strategy and all options presented enhance choice in this regard. That is exactly what we would anticipate.

PARA.TAB: It is therefore a blatant misrepresentation for HCF to claim—I will use its words—`that if this strategy were adopted, Canberra could decide not only which doctor would treat you, where you could be treated and when, but even whether you would be treated at all'. That is just scaremongering and blatant misrepresentation, and no credit attaches to HCF for the publication of this misrepresentation.

What have been put together in Issues Paper No. 2 are simply options. They have been presented for public debate, and any assertions with respect to future Government policy are therefore highly premature. HCF's actions simply amount to a cynical attempt to scare people into taking out private health insurance. By pushing the concept of Government subsidy through tax rebates, HCF is attempting to subvert further sensible public debate on the options in order to protect its own vested interests in the current arrangements.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer the Minister to the call by the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development, Dr Blewett, to the Prime Minister to contact European leaders requesting that they strengthen their resolve on the Uruguay Round of talks. Can the Minister assure the Senate that the Government will not accept a Uruguay Round outcome that does not give a real and substantial reduction in agricultural protection?

—The Uruguay Round negotiations have reached a very sensitive and important stage, with major discussions and possible conclusions being reached at meetings tomorrow, hopefully. In the second part of the question Senator Panizza asks whether the Government will decline to accept an unfavourable outcome for the Uruguay Round. This Government has been diligent in pursuing the Uruguay Round, particularly in the interests of the primary producers of this country, and levels of agricultural subsidy and protection. Though we have been diligent in that, the question suggests a misunderstanding of Australia's position. We have been diligent in doing that through the Cairns Group, for example.

PARA.TAB: I cannot see any point in saying that we will not accept the outcome of the Uruguay Round, whatever it is. Australia is not quite in the position of saying, `We will accept this' or `We will not accept that'. As Senator Panizza knows, the great vice in the agricultural trade throughout the world is subsidies in Europe and North America. The essential negotiations involve an agreement between Europe and North America in relation to subsidies, and to a lesser extent Japan in relation to protection of agricultural products such as rice.

It is proper to say that, though we as a government have done everything that is available to us and will continue to do so, it is not a question in the totality of the Uruguay Round of saying that Australia will accept this or Australia will not accept that. If the outcome of discussions tomorrow and over the next few weeks is unsatisfactory, then of course the Australian Government will pursue further talks. If that is the intention of Senator Panizza's question, that is an undertaking I can give him.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Can the Minister advise the Senate of the outcome of the third review conference of the Biological Weapons Convention which was held in Geneva during September?

—The recent third review conference of the Biological Weapons Convention made very real progress towards strengthening the treaty. It was a conference in which, I am happy to say, Australia played a prominent part. The BWC is a major multilateral disarmament agreement concluded in 1972 to outlaw biological weapons. Membership of the BWC now totals 118 countries, including Australia, while a further 21 countries have signed the convention but not yet ratified it.

PARA.TAB: The major measures agreed by the conference to strengthen the treaty included agreement on the establishment of an ad hoc group of government experts to examine verification mechanisms. The group will meet for the first time in March-April 1992 and report to the states parties by the end of 1993. There was clarification that the scope of the convention included biological agents relevant to plants and animals, not just human beings.

There was agreement on additional confidence building measures, as well as reaffirmation of existing confidence building measures. New measures agreed included the declaration of past biological weapons research and development programs, both offensive and defensive, and the declaration of human vaccine production facilities. At the conference Australia played a leading role in forging agreement, but any transfers of relevance to the BWC should be authorised only when the intended use is for purposes not prohibited under the convention, and worked successfully to have the conference call on developed countries to adopt positive measures to promote technological transfers to the developed world.

In conclusion, the group is an informal alliance of 22 Western countries looking at this issue, formed by Australia in the mid-1980s, which introduced controls on the export of chemicals that had potential use in the manufacturing of chemical weapons. The group meets regularly under Australia's chairmanship to discuss chemical and biological weapons issues and to harmonise and review export controls.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. I refer to the various press reports concerning the apparently precarious financial position of Compass Airlines. I ask the Minister to explain to the Senate and to the tens of thousands of Australian families which have pre-paid their air fares for travel over the Christmas period: how many passengers are involved? Has the matter of a financial bail-out of Compass Airlines been discussed between the Government and Compass? What is the Government's position in relation to bailing out Compass or any other airline? Finally, given that the Government and the Opposition have created the deregulated aviation environment that will allow airlines to fail, at massive cost to the Australian economy, is not the predicament of Compass Airlines and its passengers simply the inevitable outcome of deregulation in a very small market?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will answer the three parts of Senator Kernot's question before I make a general statement about the current situation. In respect of the first part of the question, as to the number of passengers, Compass management has advised me that approximately 125,000 passengers have prepaid bookings with Compass over the next six weeks. The majority of those are return bookings; in other words, Christmas travel. Secondly, yes, it is true that we had a meeting with Compass Airlines which put some requests to the Government. I do not think it is relevant, nor do I think it is proper for Compass, which is a private company, to discuss the details of that meeting. I certainly have no hesitation in saying that the Government will not be purchasing significant blocks of prepaid tickets from any airline, nor will it be providing personal loans to any airline. We deregulated the airline industry deliberately to remove ourselves from that situation.

PARA.TAB: In respect of the last part of Senator Kernot's question, honourable senators may or may not have noticed that I have been taking a consistently cautious line on deregulation for precisely the reasons that Senator Kernot has advanced; that is, the very small size of the Australian market. Honourable senators in here would know that I have been saying this in Question Time for months. In fact, I think I can probably find one of my answers.

Only a week or so ago, when attacking the Opposition's ridiculous aviation policy in its goods and services tax package—I remind honourable senators it involves dumping large numbers of international flight seats and reducing prices—I indicated that prices could not possibly get any lower than they are at the moment. I was seriously concerned—I have been saying this for six months—about the depth of the discounting that was being offered by the airlines. They were offering seats for significantly less than the cost of producing them. That is a matter for the commercial judgment of the airlines concerned.

Last night Compass Airlines was in dispute with the owners of the aircraft. Regrettably, that dispute resulted in delays in the departure of some Compass flights. Potentially it involved the stranding of a very large number of passengers, particularly at Sydney and Melbourne airports. Fortunately that was averted last night by discussions between the airline and representatives of the owners of the aircraft. Compass has advised me that all passengers were carried last night. I might add that we stood ready, through the Federal Airports Corporation management at the airports, to provide emergency assistance in the form of food, sleeping arrangements and so on for passengers, should it have been required. Fortunately, it was not. As I said, Compass is a private company. The responsibility for its operations and, in particular, its passengers resides properly with Compass. Obviously we are concerned about these events and we are closely monitoring the situation.

I will conclude by advising the Senate of the most recent developments. I think it is important that people know this. This morning on Perth radio an officer of Compass Airlines, the Vice-President, Customer Service, said:

ANSWER.PARA: The situation is that we are taking bookings and ticketing people today and tomorrow. Beyond that we are not ticketing people but we are taking bookings. Now that has been put out to all of our staff and that's the instructions under which all of our staff are operating on.

The last advice I have is that legal action commenced at 12.30 this afternoon in the Federal Court of Australia in Sydney. The matter has been adjourned for further consideration by the court at 9.30 a.m. on Monday next.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer. I just want to refer to the last part of my question and I ask, because we will end up paying for it in the long term: what could be the long term cost of this failure in terms of how much Compass has borrowed both onshore and offshore to set itself up in the first instance?

—As I have already explained, Compass is a private company and is entitled to work out its own affairs in a commercial manner. I cannot answer that question. The company is currently in a legal dispute with the owners of the aircraft. That matter is currently being adjudicated upon in the courts. As I have said, the hearing has now been listed for 9.30 on Monday morning.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. As a result of the end of the 30-year war between Eritrea and Ethiopia in May of this year, can the Minister provide details of the assistance Australia is providing to Eritrea? Can the Minister also provide details on the prospects for a plebiscite in Eritrea to determine its future status?
—I thank Senator Schacht for this question. I am sure he will know how to spell my name when I am chasing the Nobel prize later.

PARA.TAB: I did have minor notice of this question from Senator Schacht. In response to the suffering experienced throughout Ethiopia as a result of the famine and civil war, Australia provided significant refugee relief in an emergency assistance package in 1991. This included assistance amounting to $3.8m for Eritrea.

Even though the fighting has ended the suffering continues. With this in mind consideration is currently being given to a similar package of assistance for 1991-92 which will be made up of Australian sourced food aid and funding for the airlifting of relief food, agricultural rehabilitation and health services. Assistance will continue to be channelled through Australian non-government organisations. Provision has been made in the 1991-92 country program budget for a contribution of $270,000 for an eye lens factory to be established in Eritrea. Some additional assistance for this factory is envisaged.

It is also expected that a small number of in Australia training awards will be made available to Eritrea in 1991-92. Following the fall of the Mengistu Government in June of this year the Eritrean People's Liberation Front established a provisional government in Eritrea. It was subsequently agreed between the transitional government of Ethiopia and the provisional government of Eritrea that a referendum on the future relationship between those two countries would be held within two years. No firm date has yet been set for that referendum. The Australian Government is not aware of any plans by the provisional government of Eritrea to hold any elections in advance of that referendum.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. Why has the Health Insurance Commission seen fit to further waste taxpayers' money by sending a kit listing the new schedules of fees to each individual doctor in Australia and to every one of their locations of practice? What was the cost of this gross and unnecessary exercise? Why did the Health Insurance Commission send 10 or 20 books to each practice? Finally, is waste such as this the reason that the co-payment was introduced in the first place and, having wasted the money, will the Government led by either Mr Hawke or Mr Keating now remove the co-payment?

—I do not have any knowledge of the kit that has apparently been distributed to doctors and to those who require to know the schedule of benefits—I take it Senator Knowles is talking about the Medicare benefits schedule. Of course, it is extremely important and has been a subject of comment in this chamber from time to time that this sort of information be made available to practices in a readily accessible and easily readable form as soon as is possible. There have been complaints from time to time in this chamber about that information not being made available.

PARA.TAB: Of course, the Opposition will overcome any problem about having to notify the doctors' and general practitioners' surgeries and health care providers of the Medicare schedules. All those opposite will have to do is to rely on the AMA to circulate the schedules. That will become the benchmark, the fee, which every person who enters a doctor's surgery in Australia for primary health care will have to pay because of the deal that the Opposition has engineered between the AMA and the private health funds so that, through insurance, when Australians present themselves at a surgery for a consultation they will have to provide the fee charged by the AMA: $31 per consultation.

That is what the Opposition has in mind. Those opposite will simply have to rely on the AMA to distribute the schedule. That will be their answer. As to co-payments—Senator Knowles made the error of speaking about a co-payment; in fact, there are two co-payments, depending on whether the GP bulkbills—the Opposition, as disciples of choice, will forbid, not permit, a GP to bulkbill patients unless they are pensioners or card holders. The Opposition will take away that choice from GPs. Those opposite will say that GPs are not allowed to bulkbill Australians as they present themselves for consultation at the doctors' surgeries. Those opposite will take away that choice. Senator Knowles even had the premise of her question wrong. There are in fact two co-payments, depending on bulkbilling. That is a choice which many doctors want to continue to make, and those opposite will forbid their making that choice.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister to answer the question: what was the cost of sending this information to every doctor at every surgery that they have, and in some cases sending 10 or 20 books to each practice? Why was it done? More importantly, what was the cost?

—I am quite happy to find out what the cost was. The cost of providing this sort of information would obviously be a part of providing necessary information to doctors in their practice. That is a cost which doctors would expect to be undertaken by government in the provision of this very important information.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer to my question of 9 September last with respect to New Zealand shearers working in the Australian wool industry. Is the Minister aware of continuing concerns being expressed regarding the employment of New Zealand shearers in the Australian wool industry? What was the outcome of the proposed random inspections—referred to in the answer of 9 September—to ensure that the conditions of the Federal shearing award are properly observed?

—Senator Maguire is referring to a practice, apparently promoted by the NFF, to employ shearers on false or contrived contracts below the legal rate of the shearing award. It appears that the shearers used in this circumstance are recruited not from Australia but from New Zealand—which, of course, is a Third World economy these days. The New Zealand shearers are being used illegally to break down the living standards of Australian shearers and, coincidentally, to afflict considerable damage on the rural economies in some country towns where shearers make up a reasonable percentage of the population.

PARA.TAB: Senator Maguire asked what has happened within my Department to deal with this problem. My Department has advised me that there have been discussions between the Australian Workers Union, the Shearing Contractors Association, my office and the Department of Industrial Relations in order to identify who the potential or suspected offenders are and to establish a strategy to apprehend and prosecute them for breach of a lawful award. The awards management branch of my Department, which would be the responsible branch, will conduct random sweeps in areas where it is believed that these shearers are employed and ensure compliance with the lawful terms of the award. It will commence reasonably shortly.

In the discussions that we have had, other questions have been raised which affect other Ministers. For example, questions of taxation evasion and social security fraud have been raised as well. I am writing to my colleague the Minister for Social Security about the social security aspects of this and my colleague the Treasurer to see what can be done to prevent any derogation from lawful standards in Australia, not only in industrial relations but also in social security and tax payment.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. On 9 September, 101 days ago, on 17 October, 63 days ago, and on 12 November, 37 days ago, the Minister said that he was preparing a statement in answer to my accusations that on 9, 10 and 11 September and on 17 October he misled the Senate when he took an inaccurate brief from his mates in the Seamen's Union of Australia and attacked the export award winning Robe River. When is the Minister going to have the courage to acknowledge his errors and apologise to the Senate and Robe River?

—Senator Winston Crane has a bee in his bonnet about this matter. For the record, I repeat once again—although I do not think there is a need to say it once again—that I have not misled the Senate in any way. I made two assertions. First, I asserted that Robe River is a rotten employer. I still hold that view; I do not mislead the Senate about the consciousness with which I hold that view. I think it is entirely appropriate for me to be able to make that statement. This Government has not shirked the task of identifying rotten unions when they have arisen. In fact, the Government moved to deregister the BLF, because it thought that the union's activities were beyond the pale, and we did so. I can say, with some degree of respect for the Government's position, that when employers conduct themselves in an anti-social way they, too, should not escape condemnation.

PARA.TAB: The second assertion that I have made, upon which I do not mislead the Senate, is that Robe River is a vexatious litigant with respect to industrial relations law. I have no better example than the one that I have given where, after several appeals on frivolous and minor matters in the main—some were substantial—a wholly owned subsidiary of Robe River, a company employing seamen, went into voluntary liquidation and a new company was created in order to get the contract and thus set at nought all of the rights of the employees of the wholly owned subsidiary. I consciously regard that—I mislead you not—as vexatious litigation by Robe River in order to avoid dealing with the issue of proper industrial relations in its company.

I am offended by some of the remarks which spokespersons for this company have made about their intentions in the conduct of good industrial relations in this country. The Government has been supporting a cooperative approach in the Australian workplace between employers and workers to generate higher productivity. On several occasions in this chamber I have cited agreements where that type of them and us, boss and worker, employer and employee relationship has been broken down and a team approach has been substituted, willingly, by all.

What does Robe River do? It says that unions should be excluded from the workplace. Robe River says—I have the text of a speech here—that people should come to work every day frightened that they will be fired. That is a direct quote from a speech by the Chief Executive of this company. He said that they should come to work every day frightened that they will be fired; only then will they act in the workplace in a responsible manner. That is a shocking indictment of the type of attitude that this authoritarian company has to its greatest asset—the people who work for it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs will be aware of the recognition of the Lotus Glen Correctional Centre by the Human Rights Commission as a Queensland prison administration dedicated to fully implementing the recommendations of the Royal Commission of Inquiry into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. In view of the tragic death yesterday of the second member of an Aboriginal family to die in custody in Geraldton, can the Minister report on efforts to have all State Ministers fully account for their policies in upgrading conditions and personal security for Aboriginal prisoners? Is the Attorney-General's Department initiating any coordination of a national approach to this responsibility?

—It is always a terrible tragedy when there is a death in custody, whether it is of an Aboriginal or non-Aboriginal Australian. I express the sympathy of all members of the Senate to the family of the Aboriginal who died in custody yesterday. That is a matter which causes all of us to reflect on the way in which Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders are represented in our prison cells, police cells and prison populations, which is out of all proportion to the numbers in the general Australian community.

PARA.TAB: If methods can be found to divert such persons from that type of incarceration, then those methods should be pursued most vigorously. I believe that, as a result of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, those sorts of measures are being undertaken in a very cooperative way by the Commonwealth with the States. In fact, only a couple of days ago the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Robert Tickner, was able to announce funding of some $6.5m for various projects submitted by the States with a view to reducing the incidence of such deaths in custody. Such projects may be simply to do with the design of police cells in some outback areas or provincial cities, as I believe is the case with the New South Wales submission. Others relate to the fundamental social and cultural causes of the incarceration of so many Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders.

I think all of the States have shown goodwill and good faith in these matters. I think Senator Reynolds also adverted to the fact that already the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission has found it possible to make an award to a prison near Cairns, the name of which escapes me for the moment. That particular prison, because of the regime that operates there—which relies on the inmates taking responsibility for much of their own care—is regarded as a model for the way incarceration should occur. I believe that that particular prison, having received that award from the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, certainly does provide a model—not merely for other Australian prisons and police cell situations but also possibly for international significance. So much is happening in this field, and one would hope that it can reduce the incidence of deaths in custody.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer. In view of his response, will the Minister ask the Attorney-General to report to the Senate on whether his Department has responded to the unanimous resolution of the Senate last month urging State prison authorities to regard Lotus Glen as a model in incorporating Aboriginal culture into its rehabilitation programs, and also to report to the Senate on how that intention of the Senate is being implemented?

—I will certainly seek that information from the Attorney-General, but it is even more important to observe that the resolution passed by the Senate expressed a view which coincides with the assessment made by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and led to the award being made. I believe that, in that way, one has the independent verification outside of government circles of what a worthwhile project that has been and what a model it provides for the situation where Aboriginals or Torres Strait Islanders find themselves either in police cells or prison custody.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to the depreciation changes in the industry statement of 12 March and the lack of supporting legislation for now over nine months. Is the Minister not concerned about problems relating to corporations balancing on 31 December this year—a balance date in lieu of 30 June—in view of the lack of a legislative base? What steps does the Government propose, or what advice can the Minister give, for December balancing corporations which now must make an instalment deduction in January 1992? Further, has the Minister's Department, DITAC, had the opportunity of reviewing such legislation in its draft or final form? Can the Senate be assured that the inconsistencies revealed in the joint Treasury-DITAC statement regarding the effective life of an asset will be removed from the legislation?

—I thought Senator Watson might have been kinder to me on the last day of sitting before Christmas than to ask me a question about tax. That is diligent of him. I will, of course, have to direct a number of the matters in his question to the Treasurer. The legislation to which the honourable senator referred was introduced into the House of Representatives today, I understand, and that will give the honourable senator an opportunity to look at it. To the extent that there were some detailed questions directed to me, I will direct them to the Treasurer. Certainly my Department did have some opportunity to have an input into the draft legislation. As soon as I get an answer from the Treasurer, I will give it to Senator Watson.

—Is the Minister for Industrial Relations aware that on or about 14 November Australia Post implemented a set of guidelines for the conduct of surveillance of employees in relation to claims for compensation made under the Commonwealth Employees Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988 and that these guidelines were lodged with the Privacy Commission? Were these guidelines drawn up in consultation with Comcare and, if not, why not? If the guidelines were drawn up with the assistance or knowledge of Comcare, are they consistent with any guidelines adopted by Comcare and, if not, what action will the Minister now initiate to ensure consistency as required under the CERC Act? Are the Australia Post guidelines consistent with the operation and intention of the CERC Act? Does the Minister regard the action and conduct of Australia Post in using surveillance practices to gather information to be used against people claiming compensation as a legitimate practice consistent with the intention of the CERC Act?
—I point out to honourable senators that I think that some of these questions from both sides are too long.

—I agree the question is too long, and if there were fewer questions I would answer them more quickly. I thank Senator Bell for giving me notice of his question—but then not asking it and asking a slightly different one. I am aware of guidelines for surveillance in Australia Post and Telecom, and I am aware that the guidelines used by both those enterprises and the guidelines used by Comcare itself have been developed in consultation with the Privacy Commissioner. That matter was referred to in one part of the question. The second round of consultative processes with the Privacy Commissioner, I am advised, has recently been completed. The guidelines specific to Australia Post and Telecom include provisions in relation to a code of ethics applicable to investigators. I am advised that in the general field of workers compensation investigation there is a code of ethics for private investigators used by insurance companies in order to see that ethical behaviour is properly observed in investigations.

PARA.TAB: But these guidelines for Australia Post and Telecom have an in-built code of ethics for investigators that ensures confidentiality of information, physical security of relevant records and the physical destruction of those records once the particular matter under investigation has been resolved. With regard to Comcare, the guidelines contain the same provisions as those for Australia Post and Telecom. I am advised that the current practice is that surveillance is used only in the most limited of circumstances, and then only with the express agreement of Comcare's Chief Executive Officer or Deputy Chief Executive Officer.

In the field of workers compensation investigation, the manner in which investigations are conducted is a very sensitive matter. I personally know of cases in the private sector where techniques of investigation have been used which abuse the privacy of the individual, and in fact involve attempted entrapment of the individual as well. I also know of cases of the extraction of statements when a worker is in an injured state or a state of shock and recovering from the immediate incident giving rise to an injury. All of those things are deplorable.

From a Government point of view, however, we take the view that it is naive and wrong to assume that every case is somehow not worthy of fuller investigation. Some cases are, because the sad truth is that some people do try to manipulate workers compensation. It is nowhere near the number that is often pretended to be the case, but there is a small element where that is true, and we need to safeguard against that. But, as a general rule, surveillance is not availed of, and where it is, in that minority of cases, I think the proper safeguards are in place to ensure that it is done appropriately.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Prime Minister and Treasurer. As Australia continues to wallow in the recession that we had to have, with unemployment at its worst level for 60 years, what hope can the Minister give the one million jobless, plus the emerging school leavers, for their prospects over the next 12 months?
—This is another attempt to derive emotional and political benefit, and is a cheapskate question.

—I raise a point of order, Mr President. The Minister is improperly reflecting on the motive of the honourable senator who asked the question. I submit that he should be asked to withdraw that reflection.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—If the honourable senator had been sitting here day after day, he would know that we have a serious and tragic unemployment problem in this country. Before Christmas those opposite are seeking to derive as much political comfort as they can from that situation.
—Mr President, will you rule on Senator Crichton-Browne's point of order?
—I have ruled on the point of order. I said that there was not a point of order.

—Let me give this answer, because if those opposite ask political questions, they will get political answers. The political answer to this is that, in terms of this Christmas, the outlook for many people is very sad and difficult. In terms of Christmas 1992, the outlook will be better. If those opposite get into power in 1993, then at Christmas 1993 the outlook will be worse and worse and worse, as is admitted by the Leader of the Liberal Party, Dr Hewson, who has more intellectual honesty than the rest of those opposite put together. Dr Hewson has admitted that if his so-called package was introduced, unemployment would get worse; he has admitted that. That is the political reality which those opposite have to front up to, instead of asking these pathetic questions in trying to derive some comfort from the situation before Christmas.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I note the Minister's answer that the outlook will be better. What is the difference between the failed policies and strategies which brought about the recession we had to have and the current policies espoused by either the temporary Prime Minister or the Prime Minister in waiting?

—On numerous occasions I have answered questions about policies and responsibilities for a very difficult recession. Senator Parer either was not listening— he was probably yelling his head off at Question Time—or alternatively was dozing; it was one or the other. I have answered questions about these policy issues time and again. I have said time and again that this Government in respect of the application of monetary policy in 1990 and early 1991 accepts responsibility for a substantial part of this recession. But there are other factors involved in this recession as well. There are factors such as the huge rural crisis that we have in this country.

PARA.TAB: I suppose Senator Parer would say that the wool crisis was in some way the responsibility of this Government. I tell Senator Parer that it was not. There are a number of other factors which have contributed to this recession in Australia. People like Senator Parer could be asking the same questions in the Parliament of the United Kingdom, in the United States Congress and in the Canadian Parliament. Let us not forget that. This could have been done anywhere. It is no good those opposite muttering away in their beards. That is a fact which they have to face up to.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. Will the Government accept the recommendation in the Wangman report on child-care accreditation to spend an ongoing $3m per annum to fund this extra tier of supervision and regulation, or will it use the $3m for enhanced fee relief to parents who need it?
—I understand that the Wangman report has been released. It was commissioned by the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services.
—It hasn't been released.

—Senator Alston suggests that it has not been released publicly; I am not sure of that. Certainly the intention is that that report simply become one of the working documents for the interim accreditation council. There is no intention by the Government to accept holus bolus any recommendations in the report without the benefit of the advice of that council. There will not be an immediate response, and there will not be an immediate implementation of any recommendations within the Wangman report. It will become a working document of the interim accreditation council. It is on the basis of the recommendations from that council that the Government will make its decision.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security and Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Why was the $6.2m disability reform marketing strategy contract awarded over three months prior to the necessary legislation being passed by either House of Parliament? Why was $412,500 paid to the winning tenderer, Corporate Impacts, 24 days prior to the legislation being passed by the Parliament? Why was an additional $368,644.29 paid to the same company prior to this legislation receiving royal assent?

—I shall find out the information for Senator Patterson. I can only point out that the disability reform package was being generally supported here. We were not locked in mortal combat. It is a massive change which affects the lives of people who are dependent on an income provided by the Government. Obviously there is a need for preparation to be undertaken early. But I will obtain some specific answers to the honourable senator's question and try to give them to her next year.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I would like to know when the Minister intends to give the answers other than just next year. Can he assure the Senate that all due processes were followed in the letting of this tender? Is there any requirement or moral obligation of members of the working committee of the ministerial council awarding the tender to declare any conflict of personal interest in the matter, such as personal friendships with one of the tenderers and, if not, why not?

—I am not on that committee. I do not think that it would be possible to say that no-one on the committee would ever have met anyone in an agency. I will make an inquiry of the committee and find out. I was not present; so I do not know. As to when I will give the answer: normally I would give the answer tomorrow. I suspect, however, that we will not be sitting then, so I will not be doing that. I will endeavour to give it to Senator Patterson early in the new year. I will be away for a few weeks, but by the end of January certainly.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I refer to an article in the Adelaide News on Monday which claimed that insurance companies were importing inferior replacement car parts and panels from Malaysia and Taiwan, which could affect tens of thousands of South Australian jobs and elsewhere. It was also mentioned that this practice concerned unions and manufacturers because many of these parts did not meet the same standards as Australian products. Can the Minister inform the Senate as to the accuracy of these claims? Is the Government worried about this practice from an employment and safety perspective?

—I am not aware of the details of the case which Senator Foreman asked me about. From time to time, allegations of a similar kind emerge—usually from third parties—claiming that imported vehicle parts are unsafe. Of course, the primary issue in respect of these things has to be one of safety. The Australian design rules set down a comprehensive range of performance and design requirements for motor vehicle safety. The design rules cover a range of safety requirements such as vehicle impact testing, side door strength, steering systems and other features to improve occupant protection.

PARA.TAB: The Australian design rules take force nationally under the provisions of the Federal Motor Vehicle Standards Act 1989 which is administered by the Federal Office of Road Safety. The Federal Office of Road Safety provides a mechanism by which alleged safety defects are investigated. If Senator Foreman wishes to provide evidence of the safety problem—I certainly do not say that it does not exist—I would be pleased to forward it to the appropriate authorities in the Department of Transport and Communications which administer the Motor Vehicle Standards Act. I hope that Senator Foreman will do that.

From time to time one receives complaints of this kind and it is always worth while following them up. Recently I received complaints about compliance with safety standards in respect of imported cranes and lifting platforms predominantly used on building sites and in warehouses. The arrangement with the Federal Government has been that Customs would report any shipments of cranes or lifting platforms imported from overseas, and the State authorities in each case would inspect them and make sure that they satisfied Australian safety requirements.

My inquiries, as a result of the recent complaint, revealed that, in most cases, that has not been done by the State authorities. I am chasing that up at the present time. It is very important from the point of view of the use of this equipment that, if the regulations are not going to be complied with, those people who import this equipment ought to know that the Government will consider banning them again. We do not want to do that. We think that that is economically unsound. But they should comply with the safety requirements of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the present Prime Minister and concerns the Uruguay Round of GATT negotiations. I understand that the agricultural negotiations end tomorrow. Firstly, during the last six months, why has not the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, been able to find time to ring the leaders of foreign countries—in particular, of the United States, France and Germany—in support of Minister Blewett's negotiations, but waited until Minister Blewett rang him up to request him to do so? Secondly, has the Minister seen the comments by visiting Professor Chalmers Johnson that GATT is dead, in effect, because of the end of the Cold War? He suggests that the GATT arrangements are dead because they were, he says—
—This is another very long question, Senator Lewis.

—I will not read out the professor's comments, but I hope that Senator Button has read them. Does the Minister agree with the professor's prediction that GATT is dead and that the world is now entering an age of managed trade in which countries negotiate market shares directly with one another?
—As far as the first part of the question is concerned, it is true that it is hoped that the Uruguay Round in respect of the agricultural negotiations will reach at least a seminal point tomorrow.

PARA.TAB: I have not seen the suggestion by Dr Blewett that the Prime Minister should ring the appropriate officials, presidents or prime ministers in the US, France and Germany. I would be very surprised if the Prime Minister has not spoken to the President of the United States about this matter during this year, but I will investigate and obtain an answer for Senator Lewis. There is probably no tremendous point in the Prime Minister taking action to speak with the French authorities. They are well aware of their position and they are well aware of ours because it has been made clear to them on numerous occasions. I think the United States is also under no illusions about our position on farm subsidies.

I have not read the current comments by Professor Chalmers Johnson. I have read previous publications of his about international business and I must say they have a fair degree of hyperbole and sensationalism about them. `GATT is dead' is perhaps a good slogan for selling a book but it is probably far from the reality.

As far as managed trade between blocs is concerned, there has been a fair degree of managed trade between countries going on. For example, the heads of ASEAN meet in January to look at the question not of a trade bloc but a common external tariff for ASEAN countries. Those sorts of things are happening there as well as in North America, Central America and perhaps in parts of Europe.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where does that leave us?

—That leaves Senator Crichton-Browne sitting in front of Senator Lewis, whose question I am answering. The point is that even within a changed GATT regime arising from the Uruguay Round there will be a degree of managed trade going on. The lesser the better, but I think that will be likely to happen.

—I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to an answer he gave to Senator Walsh on 5 December regarding the wholesale sales tax treatment of road transport. In that question the Minister referred to the impact on transport costs as being 2.8 per cent for road, 0.8 per cent for rail and 1.1 per cent for air. Firstly, could the Minister inform the Senate where he got those figures from? Secondly, could he inform the Senate whether he considers the cascading effect of the high incidence of sales tax and fuel excise on road transport is one example of Australia's uncompetitive business tax system? Thirdly, does he agree that the distortion between road, rail, sea and air places a disproportionate burden on the cost of grocery items—
—Chapter 3.

—Answers given by Senator Collins are so long that I think I can ask a detailed question of the Minister. Does the Minister agree that the distortion between road, rail, sea and air places a disproportionate burden on the cost of grocery items, because most of them are transported on large articulated vehicles? Lastly, will the Minister inform the Senate whether the Government is currently considering specific proposals to reform these inequities in the wholesale sales tax treatment of road transport, or is the policy the same as usual—if it moves, tax it and if it keeps moving, tax it even harder?

—That is a very long and detailed question to which I will obtain a detailed answer. In respect of the figures which Senator Campbell asked about, my recollection is that they were obtained from a Treasury briefing on that matter. The answer as to where I got the figures from is there.

PARA.TAB: I was asked whether I recognise the cascading effect of a wholesale sales tax. The answer to that question is, of course, yes. Any business tax that exists is a burden on business. People say that payroll tax is a uniquely Australian burden on business but it is not uniquely Australian. For example, all European employers pay a social services levy which is at least equivalent to the effect of the payroll tax on Australian businesses. Arrangements vary from one country to another with the kinds of taxes which are imposed.

Regarding the cascading effect on groceries, I understand Senator Campbell's sensitivity about this because the Opposition's GST taxes necessities for every Australian—it taxes food; it taxes groceries; it taxes clothing; it taxes footwear; it taxes funerals; it taxes legal services; and it taxes all those things which are burdens on ordinary families in Australia. I cannot precisely answer that part of the question now, but I think the burden of the wholesale sales tax in respect of groceries would be considerably less than the burden of a 15 per cent goods and services tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I thank the Minister for saying that he received his figure from a Treasury paper. I ask the Minister: is he aware of the Treasury paper prepared for Dr Rick Charlesworth's Caucus economic industrial relations committee on 26 November, which showed that the 2 per cent figure he used actually refers to fixed rigid trucks; that the rate of WST incidence for transport is between 4 and 4.5 per cent on articulated vehicles; and, further, that the amount of average tonne kilometres for rigid trucks is only $57,000 and the rate for articulated trucks is $1.2m? Would the Minister agree that his using figures that do not apply shows something like a $1 billion to $1.5 billion hole in the argument he used on 5 December in reply to Senator Walsh's question?
—Mr President, because of interjections from both sides of the Senate I did not fully hear Senator Campbell's question.
—I can repeat it.
—Do not bother. Because of the detail in it, I would do better to read the Hansard over the vacation period. I assure the honourable senator that I will do that avidly.

PARA.TAB: While I am on my feet, I would like to send my best wishes for Christmas to Jessica Bailey and her family, who live near Young in New South Wales.
I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, by leave, I wanted to ask you a question relating to an undertaking Senator Button gave to you yesterday, but, in light of the comment he just made, the question I want to ask I think also relates to that. It will take just a moment.
—I will ask the Ministers to give their further answers to questions without notice first, which is the normal procedure.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 4 December 1991 Senator Patterson asked me a question in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services. I have now been provided with an additional answer to that question and I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

ANSWER.PARA: The facts refute Senator Patterson's suggestion that people with disabilities will be worse off under SkillShare in the future:
their access to the program is greater than ever before and will increase in 1992
all of the group-focused Skillshare projects that service people with disabilities in 1991 are being refunded in 1992, and the total funds going to these projects will be increased
in 1991, the Government introduced Disability Access Support Units (DASUs), providing $2.5 million for 10 such units throughout Australia.

PARA.TAB: these units provide specialist advice and resources to ensure that ALL Skillshares can properly cater for people with disabilities.

ANSWER.PARA: the number of Community Outreach modules focusing on people with disabilities which will be provided to SkillShare projects in 1992 will be more than double the number provided in 1991 (at an additional cost of $375,000)

PARA.TAB: hence the Government's approach is in line with the recommendation in the draft strategy paper on providing SkillShare for people with disabilities

ANSWER.PARA: the participation in SkillShare of people with disabilities is increasing

PARA.TAB: I don't know where Senator Patterson got her information from about the proportion of people with disabilities using SkillShare, but the figures taken from SNIPS (Skillshare National Information Processing System) are as follows:

TAB.TAB: in 1990, people with disabilities comprised just over 6% of SkillShare participants, an unacceptably low figure and one which has prompted the development of an approach focusing on all Skillshare projects and not a just a few of them
in 1991, the figure has increased to 8.4%

PARA.TAB: Senator Patterson complains that the target figures from the strategy paper are not included in the 1992 Skillshare Guidelines, but there would be little point given that the target figure in the paper for the end of 1992 was 8% and we have already passed that by the end of 1991.

ANSWER.PARA: The Guidelines for SkillShare were extensively revised for 1992 to reflect the introduction of the Disabilities Reform Package, Newstart, and a range of other initiatives and developments affecting the program.
as I indicated in my earlier answer, the revised Guidelines extend the capacity of the entire SkillShare network to service people with disabilities
However we obviously have no intention of closing down or forcing undesirable changes on successful Skillshare projects
hence the new Guidelines do not exclude support for "group-focused" projects, even though that term is not used in the document
funding has been maintained for the existing group-focused projects in 1992

the Minister has met ACROD and the Disabled Peoples International (DPI) and personally assured them that the Government has no intention of forcing change on these projects if they are successfully meeting the needs of their clients

over time, of course, as the impact of various policy initiatives have their effect on the capacity of all SkillShare projects to properly cater for people with disabilities, it is probable that the group-focused projects will deal with a broader range of clients
the Minister has asked DEET to ensure that its State and Area offices are advised of this position so that this is clearly understood.

Senator Patterson has read out to the Senate the recommendation from the draft strategy paper that "individual SkillShare projects would be able to negotiate with Area Directors for a reduction in their contracted requirements in relation to the number of clients they would assist

this process of consultation has taken place and, for example, the Minister advises me that he has received a letter from the Executive Director of the sponsor of one of the group-focused projects (who incidentally is a member of the National Executive of ACROD) thanking him for the way the department had negotiated the contract with her agency, and that she repeated this in the meeting with ACROD
The draft strategy paper referred to by Senator Patterson is just that, a DRAFT
the paper has been prepared by consultants, but has not been approved by the Minister
the Minister advises that while he believes the strategy is a very good basis for how Skillshare should cater for people with disabilities

PARA.TAB: he wants to receive the comments of affected groups, such as ACROD and DPI before finalising it
there are some aspects of the strategy paper which need to be amended before he approves it:

TAB.TAB: in particular the draft is not clear in explaining how the benefits which group-focused and specialised projects may bring will be ensured in the future

ANSWER.PARA: While the strategy paper is only a draft, there is no conflict between the paper and the 1992 Guidelines
the strategy paper is some 38 pages long

PARA.TAB: the guidelines are intended to cover all aspects of Skillshare,and thus only 3 pages are devoted to the broad arrangements for people with disabilities
there is no conflict between the two documents, and in fact much of the relevant section in the Guidelines is simply an extract from the strategy paper.

ANSWER.PARA: Finally, if SkillShare was to base its strategy on specialist and group-focused projects, this would be very costly and very cost-ineffective
extra expenditure on SkillShare is contrary to your own party's policy for the program

while Dr Hewson is now telling everyone that your former policy to abolish SkillShare was a mistake, your new policy is to encourage Skillshare projects to be totally self-funding by the end of the decade,

PARA.TAB: that of course is only a euphemism for the Commonwealth funding of SkillShare to stop.

ANSWER.PARA: you've still got the same policy, except you are telling people you are going to take longer to do it.

PARA.TAB: of course if you ever got in and the holes in your package were exposed (already over $4 billion is obvious), the decade would be brought forward very quickly.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the course of AIDEX and soon after it I received a number of questions in the chamber and outside about police actions at the site, as for example from Senator Reynolds. I also met a delegation comprising Senator Childs, Senator Spindler, Senator Vallentine and two representatives of the AIDEX demonstrators. Several of the allegations raised with me concerned purported actions by the police, and I undertook to report to the Senate on those allegations. I have received a report from the chief police officer and have provided a copy of my answer to the relevant senators. Because of its length, I seek leave to incorporate the answer in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—

ANSWER.PARA: 1.An ambulance was prevented from entering the protesters' camp.
2.Police prevented portable toilets from being emptied.
3.Police prevented water tanks from being filled. Report

Superintendent Colin Rowley, AFP Forward Commander at AIDEX, has advised that he is not aware of any incidents involving the prevention of ambulances or any other service vehicles from entering the protesters' camp. At no time were directions given to AFP members to restrict the entry or exit of any vehicle or person to the camping area used by the AIDEX protesters. Furthermore, the AFP, where necessary, assisted those vehicles to gain entry to or exit from the camping site. However, until such time as all specific complaints have been investigated by internal investigation division, the possibility that a member independently exercised a decision to refuse a call for attendance or denied entry cannot be categorically ruled out.

Superintendent John McLaren, ACT Ambulance Service, was present at the AIDEX demonstration and he has advised that he is unaware of any incident where an ambulance was prevented from entering the protesters camp. At the request of the AFP, a unit from the ACT ambulance was placed on standby inside the National Exhibition Centre (NATEX), to treat any person who was injured as a result of the ongoing violent situation. Superintendent McLaren also stationed a second unit outside NATEX, on Northbourne Avenue, to respond to any requests for an ambulance by protesters. He had instructed this ambulance not to enter the camp without obtaining his express approval.

The ambulance on Northbourne Avenue was utilised on approximately four occasions. On one occasion, the unit was approached by protesters with a request that it enter the camp and examine a protester who was ill. The ambulance officers manning the unit advised the protesters that they could only enter the camp with Superintendent McLaren's permission. This was duly obtained, the ambulance entered the camp site, and one person was conveyed to hospital.

During the AIDEX demonstrations a number of hoax calls for ambulances were received. As a result, Superintendent McLaren asked that callers place their requests for ambulances through police operations. This action reduced the number of hoax calls being received.

The ACT ambulance service was not at any time under AFP control. Superintendent McLaren, OIC Ambulance Service at AIDEX, made his own assessments as to whether or not a unit should attend at the camp site, and never, at any time, refused a call for attendance.

AFP inquiries have established that five portable toilets were hired by the protesters from GKN Rentals at Fyshwick. A pump out service was also ordered for 27 November 1991, and a refill of water and service of the portable toilets on 28 November 1991.

Statements obtained from employees of GKN Rentals disclose that on 26 November 1991, five portable toilets were emptied. On 28 November 1991, five toilets were serviced but the employee decided not to empty these as the units were only partially full. The toilets were to be returned the following day.
Both employees have stated that at no time was their access to the toilets impeded by anyone and in fact, they were assisted by the AFP to leave due to the crowds located at the exit location.
AFP inquiries have been unable to ascertain from where the water tank used by the protesters was obtained.

Five contractors (four listed and one unlisted) have been contacted by the AFP. These contractors were not involved in the provision of a water tank to the protesters. The Australian National University also has no knowledge concerning the provision of a water tank.

The AFP has been unable to contact three contractors (one listed and two unlisted) I am advised that they are not currently in the ACT but engaged on large commercial contractual projects and would almost certainly not be involved with a small job such as the AIDEX demonstration.
The AFP suspects that the provision of a water tank to protesters was a private arrangement.
