QWN.TITLE: ADDITIONAL RESPONSES TO QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —During Question Time, I was asked a question by Senator Winston Crane concerning Robe River and his allegation was that I had, in some form or way, misled the Senate.
—Well, you have.

—Well, Mr President, I have not misled the Senate. I wish to add to my answer by now tabling a document which is a history of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission's appeal cases by Cape Lambert Services since June 1989 and which lists by `C number' each of those cases under the headings, `Case No of Proceeding', `Nature and Subject Matter of Proceedings', `Statements by Senator Crane Hansard 10/10/ 91' and `Outcome'.

PARA.TAB: I also want to table a statement which is a history of these cases. There is also a set of remarks that I would make which go to the facts of these particular cases. It is a longer document. In deference to your rulings about the Senate, I would not propose at this stage to read it, but I may wish to at some other time. I seek leave to have these documents incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The documents read as follows—

ANSWER.PARA: [THE DOCUMENT IS OMITTED FROM THE DATABASE, SEE HARD COPY PAGE 5065]

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the additional information.

SPEECH.PARA: This is an incredible situation. A few minutes before the end of Question Time Senator Crane gave notice to Senator Cook that he intended to move to censure him. He gave notice because it is the proper courtesy which we follow. He gave notice that he was going to censure him for misleading the Senate in answers to questions on 9, 10 and 11 September and 17 October. Senator Crane reminded the Senate today that the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) has been promising the Senate that he will put down a full statement explaining the answers that he gave, which Senator Crane has constantly said were factually incorrect. He first said he would put that statement down 101 days ago, and on several occasions since he has repeated his promise to put down that statement. He has not done so.

PARA.TAB: It now seems that he has been sitting on that information and did not intend to put it down because Senator Crane again asked him today whether he would do so and all he answered with was another attack reflecting a personal prejudice on this Australian company, Robe River Ltd. That is not relevant at all to the questions that Senator Crane has been asking, which related to whether or not Senator Cook had made errors in fact on a number of occasions in defence of the original brief that he received from the Seamen's Union. So, having been given notice that he was about to be censured, suddenly Senator Cook decided he had no choice other than to put down information that he has been sitting on. That is an incredible way to do business.

I remind you also, Mr President, that time and time again Senator Cook from the Government benches has said to Senator Crane, `I dare you to censure me. Come on, go on with it. Censure me if you've got the information'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Put up or shut up!

—Put up or shut up. With great patience, Senator Crane has been coming back about once every month and, as an alternative to the Minister, has been saying, `On the face of this evidence, you have misled the Senate. The factual information that you have put before the Senate is wrong. I give you the opportunity to correct the record. Correct the record. Apologise to the company and apologise to the Senate'. But the Minister would not do that. He was hoping that this matter would go away, that Senator Crane would eventually find that it was too much trouble to continue with. He had no intention of putting before the Senate the information that he has now been forced to put before it, because the alternative was that he would have to admit an error and apologise, which he is not prepared to do.

PARA.TAB: Senator Crane will take the sensible course of action now and not pursue the censure motion at this time. He will first peruse the documents that the Minister has belatedly put down. But it is not a good way to do business. It demonstrates this Minister's prejudice and the extent to which he will go to protect his prejudice

TALK.START.PARA: —And his lack of bona fides.

—And, as my colleague says, his lack of bona fides. It does him and the standing of his Government no good. It is interesting on this day, when the new Prime Minister will probably be choosing a new set of Ministers, that the Minister again demonstrates his prejudice and incompetence. This Minister has already been censured by the Senate on two separate occasions. This would have been a third occasion, which is almost unprecedented. It is a poor standard of behaviour from a Minister and an insult to the Senate and Robe River. He still ought to get up and apologise for the way in which he has conducted his business in this regard.

—I would like to make some comments on this matter. When I first listened to the answer of the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) I was sceptical about its accuracy. I took certain actions to obtain a list of decisions in this matter from the Arbitration Commission, and it will be interesting to compare that list with the Minister's list to see whether they coincide.

PARA.TAB: I have given the Minister four opportunities in the Senate to make a statement so that the record is correct and accurate. The issue is not whether Robe River or the union is correct but whether the information that was put down in this chamber was accurate and reflected the true situation. That is what it is about. It is absolutely despicable, deceitful and unforgivable that, after again asking the Minister today, he could not set out the information he had until after procedural matters had been dealt with. He did not miss the procedural matters today because he was not aware of what was going on; he missed them because he was down the other end of the chamber talking to the Australian Democrats. That is why he missed them.

It is absolutely despicable that we now have this situation before us. I certainly reserve my right to continue with this matter. I will look with interest at those documents. More than three months ago I gave the Minister the opportunity of making sure that this accusation about a company in Western Australia—which today he once again criticised—was right. Perhaps some of that criticism is justified, but that is not the point. The point is that in looking at these issues, there must be even-handedness in the approach of the Minister to his responsibility. In this case there has not been even-handedness in the approach. I believe that the Minister today, in bringing in that information after Question Time and putting it on the table, has denigrated Question Time and the processes of this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very briefly, I was provided with some information through Senator Hill last evening in anticipation of a censure motion today. On perusal of the information, it seemed to me that there was substantial evidence that the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) had misled the Senate in respect of answers to questions.

PARA.TAB: The brief tete-a-tete I have just had with the Minister, to which Senator Crane referred a moment ago, involved the Minister saying to me that there was other evidence which he sought to put before us. I am pleased to note that the Opposition is not proceeding at this time with a censure motion because it is only fair that we have an opportunity to look at both lots of documentation to see just where the truth of this matter really lies.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should say a couple of things on this issue by way of threshold remarks before I go to the substance of it. The first is an allegation by Senator Hill—he repeated it a couple of times—that I had no intention of correcting the record. On the many occasions that I have been asked questions on this matter, I have on almost all of them, except for today because I got sick of needless repetition, said that I would correct the record in due course. This is not a matter of great substance—it is certainly not a matter high on my list of priorities—because nothing in the record derogates from the two conclusions that are the central propositions of my case.

PARA.TAB: The central propositions of my case are, firstly, that Robe River is a rotten employer and, secondly, that Robe River is a vexatious litigant on matters of industrial relations. Nothing here that is now before the Senate derogates in any way from those contentions. I believe that what is now on the record of the Senate supports them strongly.

To the point, though, that I had no intention of correcting the record, I did have an intention. I would have fulfilled it by speaking, as it was in my mind to do, in an adjournment debate so that I could take the time to go through the record case by case. I would have spoken on the adjournment because I need a full half hour and I did not wish to detain the Senate by dealing with these allegations during the consideration of business. It is wrong and reprehensible for any backbencher to rise and make an allegation, no matter how well- or ill-founded, and then expect the whole ship of government to stop so that some allegation can be dealt with. So it was my intention to speak in an adjournment debate and not detain the business of the Senate and the normal conduct of that business.

The second point is that there are a number of cases involved. Indeed, for anyone to make the allegation as I have—an allegation by which I stand—that a particular company is a vexatious litigant requires a history of litigation, and there is. A whole number of cases have gone through the Byzantine coils of appeal at various levels of the Industrial Relations Commission and the courts in this country. There have been different outcomes at different levels of appeal. In order to establish a factual outcome on the record based on what occurred is by no means a short matter; it is a long matter and requires clearly set out documentation. I have not proceeded thus far with an adjournment speech to do this, but it is still my clear intention to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do it tonight.

—I do not intend to do it tonight because I happen to have some other things to worry about. This is not the highest matter on my list of priorities, but it will be dealt with. As to the first question raised by Senator Hill that I had no intention of correcting the record, I make those comments as commitments to the Senate which I will fulfil.

PARA.TAB: The second question is this allegation of misleading the Senate. Senator Crane obviously got his name in the newspaper by making an allegation. I happen to take my responsibilities as a Minister of the Crown in this country seriously. The allegation of misleading is a formal allegation in the Westminster system that carries with it considerable penalty for anyone who does it. I do not think that it is one that simply should be traded freely across the chamber by way of interjection or allegation unless there is some substantial weight to it and unless people are prepared to act on their words.

I accept that Senator Crane is now prepared to act on his words because, as Senator Hill has said, I have certainly invited him to do so. I am pleased that he has now brought this matter to this point. Maybe we can resolve this matter one way or another; if not now—it is probably not appropriate that it be done now—then certainly some time soon during the next sitting period.

My two essential contentions here are: firstly, that Robe River is a rotten company; and, secondly, that Robe River is a vexatious litigant. In relation to the first point, my reasons for making that assertion are very many in number. The examples of why I have come to that conclusion are—if not picturesque—examples of a company taking an attitude about its work force which I think is frankly reprehensible. I hold to that assertion and I continue to make that assertion, irrespective of anything that might have come to pass from the Opposition.

But I have not come to that conclusion because a union has asked me to come to that conclusion, or because the Seamens Union, which is the aggrieved party here, has asked me to. I come to that conclusion independently of it, based on a survey of all of the evidence. This Government has reserved the right to criticise unions and take actions against unions. There are two examples of this. We regarded the Builders Labourers Federation as a reprehensible organisation which behaved itself in a disgraceful and unlawful way. We deregistered that union by legislation on two occasions. We believed the AFAP—the pilots federation—behaved in an improper way in an industrial matter, in terms of the pilots dispute two years ago, and, as a government, we took action against it.

I think a government—as opposed to an opposition—has a responsibility to be fair and even-handed. If it is dishing out punishment on one side when on the other side of the industrial relations fence there is misbehaviour, it is bound in all conscience to speak out and identify that as unacceptable behaviour. That is what I have done in the Robe case and the particular evidence that I have adduced is now before the Senate.

The second matter, about a vexatious litigant, goes to the extent to which the company has used the law to evade responsibility. There is a question of law and justice here. The law can be used by smart lawyers to delay the application of justice. Where the law, by resort to technical means, is used in such a way, it can in fact delay a proper outcome. I believe that to be so in this particular case, and I think the record supports me. The record supports what is not only my view but what would also be the view of any fair, independent person inspecting the record impartially in order to come to a similar conclusion.

I therefore conclude my remarks on the point that the Senate take note of my answer. If the Senate is of a mind to debate—and in some respects, I look forward to this debate—the merit of those claims and go to the facts and the detail, I am happy, in fact not only happy but also dripping with anticipation, to do that. But I do not think it is an appropriate thing to do today. Should the Senate be of that mind, I will be delighted to oblige by making a fuller explanation in an adjournment speech early in the next sitting period.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask that the Minister for Industrial Relations table the documents to which he referred in answering my question during Question Time today.
—I table the documents requested of me by Senator Bell.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I wish to make a personal explanation. I did not actually hear Senator Bishop read into the record a letter from a constituent, but she has kindly allowed me to look at a copy of the letter. The first part of that letter is quite congratulatory of Senator Bishop's performance, so I will not go into that. But I am really disappointed that, without even checking with me, Senator Bishop read the second part of the letter into the record. It says:

PARA.TAB: Had an unnecessary experience with Mr Ray—

SPEECH.PARA: meaning me—

when I was scrutineering in Manly many years ago, was cracked over the knuckles, when I was not familiar with some papers on the counting table, which I should not have touched. (The ruler really hurt).

PARA.TAB: A Headmaster at the table reprimanded him, on the spot. I belong to the Newport Branch . . .

SPEECH.PARA: And the letter continues. The first thing I have to say about that, having searched through my memory, is that I have never been to Manly in my life. I am sure it is a lovely spot. Secondly, I have never scrutineered outside Victoria and, thirdly, I have never used a ruler—not even in the classroom—to hit anyone over the knuckles; nor would I. I take the expansive view of scrutineering that what everyone in the room wants is the right result and a quick assessment of it. I always encourage cooperation, not hostility.

PARA.TAB: So, unfortunately, I have to say that Ms Gwen Jolliffe Page, in writing this letter to Senator Bishop, is a malicious liar.

TALK.START.PARA: —She says `Mr' Ray.

—No; earlier in the letter she talks about both Senator Evans and me. She is a malicious liar. There is no truth to her comments. I am disappointed that Senator Bishop put the letter forward without checking with me; but I am not surprised.
—Do you approve of malicious lies?
—Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. There was an interjection from Senator Tate to Senator Walters that she was a malicious liar. I ask the Minister to withdraw that.
—Mr Deputy President, of course I did not call Senator Walters a malicious liar. I said, `Do you agree with malicious lying?', or words to that effect. It was a question.

—Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I do understand that the sensitivities of Government members are very great on a day like today, before 6.30 pm. But I do think it is going over the top to call a correspondent a `malicious liar' when the Minister has no knowledge of whether or not intent was meant. I think it is quite clear that she may have thought it was the wrong Mr Ray.
—Why did you put it into the record?

—We went through that earlier when the Minister was not in the chamber. I think it is over the top to draw that conclusion about a constituent. I accept that Senator Ray can say the correspondent was under a misapprehension or was in error, or that it was a different Mr Ray. One can draw any of those conclusions; but to imply `malicious' I think is right over the top. If he were serious about it he would rephrase his objection, which I would accept. However, it is a matter for the Minister. But I do understand the touchiness associated with today.
—Order! That is a comment; that is not a point of order.
—I am happy to accommodate Senator Bishop. I will refer to her constituent as an absent-minded mendacious person. I do not think that has to be withdrawn.
—Order! The first comment did not have to be withdrawn either.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: In the first place, I note that the annual report for 1991 of the Economic Planning Advisory Council contains a comment which I would like to draw to the Senate's attention. That is the comment that the director in 1991 was Mr Fred Argy, OBE, and that Mr Argy retired in September 1991 after serving for five years in the position. I know I am reflecting the views of all members of the Opposition when I say we would like to place on record our appreciation of his work in that role and, as Opposition members, we acknowledge his contribution to EPAC.

PARA.TAB: However, it is disappointing that this slim volume, which is simply a report of proceedings and does not involve any detailed or substantial accounting requirements or anything like that, has only come into this chamber on our last day of sitting late in December, for a year that ended in June. This simply is not good enough. EPAC could perhaps look to its own forecasting of its timing and presentation of annual reports when it is looking at other weighty matters.

Even though EPAC's role is to advise the Government on a whole range of economic matters, it cannot be blamed for the mess that this Government has got us into. It is clear that in many instances the Government simply ignored what was evident in many EPAC reports, or advice that was presented to it via EPAC.

One would think that with the variety of expert advice available to the Government, it should not have made the incredible mess of the economy that took place under Mr Keating's careful stewardship, when he engineered the recession we had to have which produced one million unemployed, with the prospects of even greater increases in the level of unemployment in the new year. The objectives of EPAC are:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)to provide a broadly based source and channel of information on economic matters to assist the Commonwealth Government in making decisions relating to economic policy . . .
(b)to provide a forum for the participation of the community in the development and formulation of the economic policy of the Commonwealth Government; and
(c)to facilitate the development and consideration by the Commonwealth Government of medium and longer term economic assessments and policy requirements.
EPAC's functions are:
(a)to act as a major forum for discussions between the Commonwealth Government—
and other governments—
(b)to advise the Commonwealth Government on feasible and desirable goals and targets for the Australian economy;
(c)to develop assessments for the Commonwealth Government on the medium and longer term economic outlook;
(d)to advise the Commonwealth Government on policies that would help to achieve the optimum growth of the Australian economy; and
(e)to advise the Commonwealth Government on policies that might assist the achievement of sustained economic growth.

Despite all this advice, input and so on, this Government has managed to make a magnificent, incredible mess of things. If there is a clear relationship between the quality of advice and the outcomes, it would seem that that relationship is an inverse one rather than a direct one. There is no doubt that quite a lot of the advice that came through EPAC seemed quite rational. The report states:

EPAC papers made a significant contribution to public debate on economic issues. . . including such questions as competitiveness, inflation, urban and regional issues, taxation, federalism and productivity.
Let us hope that whichever government is in power next year, the people of Australia will have the opportunity of determining that.

PARA.TAB: In the current financial year the Council is discussing private debt and prudential regulation, Australia's unemployment problem, the current account deficit, investment and the cost of capital on Australia's productivity performance. All these matters are carefully and clearly addressed in the Opposition's Fightback program, which this Government is refusing to accept; which it is spending all its time seeking to destroy rather than getting ahead with the sorts of programs which will resolve these problems which EPAC has so properly identified in its report, and which it will be addressing in the current financial year.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to say a few words about the EPAC annual report for 1991. I join my colleague Senator Baume in words of congratulations to Fred Argy for the work that he did as the Director of EPAC over a period of five years prior to his retirement from that position two or three months ago. I am glad to see that the Government has since appointed Mr Argy to other duties within the public sector. He is a man of great experience, he is a very good economist and has made a major contribution over many years to economic thinking in Australia within the public sector. I have known him for many years and have had the pleasure of being a working colleague of his for many years. I am glad to see that he will be continuing to make a contribution.

PARA.TAB: The EPAC annual report is, as Senator Baume said, a fairly skinny document. That is one of the criticisms I have of it. One of the favourable comments I have about it is that EPAC is one of the nine major bodies which conduct research and advise the Government on economic policy. The taxpayers spend about $130m each year on the Government's economic research and advisory bodies, the largest of which is the Industry Commission. There are other very large ones, including ABARE. Of that $130m, the cost of running EPAC last year was pretty small; it cost $1.86m. That compares with the Industry Commission at $15.3m; ABARE, $15.3m; the Resource Assessment Commission, $6.2m; the Bureau of Transport Economics, $3.9m; and the BIE, $2.5m. When one looks at the reports that EPAC publishes, one would have to say that it is a cost efficient organisation.

There has been a growth in government advisory and policy bodies, particularly in the area of the economy generally and industry policy. They have grown like Topsy over the years; $130m is a lot of taxpayers' money to be spending on these organisations. In the coalition's Fightback proposals we have announced that in government we would undertake a major review and streamlining of those bodies so that we could get better value for taxpayers' money.

I think there is a much greater scope for the Government to contract out research work rather than do it in-house to the extent that it is now done. EPAC is a good example of the use of outside consultants and the contracting out that we think ought to be done more than it is now. Appendix 3 of the report lists the consultants that were used in 1990-91. It is an impressive range of consultants. The prices charged by them seem to me to be fairly reasonable for what was obtained and the work that has been done.

Page 6 of the report lists the work of the Council in 1990-91. It shows some of the major items that have been looked at by EPAC in that 12 months: investment and savings, inflation, competitiveness and productivity are amongst the most important. It is regrettable that the Government has not taken more account of the advice provided in those documents because they are very supportive of the need for greater competition, greater competitiveness, greater productivity, more control of inflation and a more balanced approach to economic policy—all the things that the coalition is saying need to be done and which are contained in our Fightback proposals. They are all things which this Government has been very bad at. They are the reasons why, to a large degree, we have the amount of concern and despair in the economy that we have today.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The annual report of the Treasury for 1990-91 is fairly comprehensive. It gives an interesting commentary on economic conditions during the 12-month period. There is much in this report that warrants very careful study and consideration. In five minutes it is impossible even to scratch at the surface of that report. I will just make a few comments in relation to the Treasury and its role.

PARA.TAB: First of all, I join in the tributes that have been made to Dr Chris Higgins, who was the Secretary to the Treasury for the first six months of 1990-91, prior to his very sudden tragic death almost exactly a year ago. I am pleased to see that the first page of the report pays tribute to the work of Chris Higgins, who was an outstanding public servant.

The Treasury has suffered from the fact that it has had no fewer than three Treasurers in the past seven months. We have had Mr Keating, Mr Kerin and now Mr Willis. Shortly after a vote at 6.30 tonight on the prime ministership, the Treasury seems set to have its fourth Treasurer in seven months.

TALK.START.PARA: —Joe Dawkins.

—My betting would be Mr Dawkins. I think Mr Keating owes him a lot of favours from the past and Mr Dawkins is obviously desperately anxious to be the new Treasurer. God help Australia if that happens. Mr Dawkins would probably be amongst the most unreconstructed socialists and expansionist Keynesians in Federal Parliament when it comes to economic policy. I believe we will have an even greater problem with Mr Dawkins as Treasurer in the incoming Keating Government than we have at the moment. The report sets out as part of the Treasury's central objectives for 1990-91:

SPEECH.PARA: .to provide high quality policy advice to the Treasurer;
.to elevate the level of economic debate more generally; and
.to assess and develop better organisational practices.

So far as the first objective is concerned—providing high quality policy advice to the Treasurer—it is not clear from the annual report the extent to which that was done. Looking at the performance of the economy over 1990-91, if that performance resulted from the Government acting on the advice provided to it by the Treasury, one would have to say that the Treasury was an absolute disaster in 1990-91. I do not necessarily say that because I think the Government did not on all occasions act on the advice of the Treasury and, indeed, on some important occasions acted contrary to that advice.

PARA.TAB: The net result is that, in 1990-91 and since, we have had the build-up of the deepest, most cruel, most protracted recession in this country for 60 years. It is a recession that was deliberately engineered. It did not happen because of external factors impinging on Australia. It was a totally home grown recession which has left almost one million people officially unemployed and another half million-plus underemployed and unable to find the amount of work necessary to provide a satisfactory working situation. One and a half million people in Australia are either unemployed or underemployed as a result of the very deliberate policy decisions of this Government.

I hope the Treasury, when the appropriate time comes—it cannot come soon enough—will be able to set the record straight as to the advice it has given to the Government over that time. I find it hard to believe that the advice coming from the Treasury would have been in line with the policy decisions that have been taken by this Government. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with Senator Short in commending the Treasury for including at the commencement of the annual report a tribute to Dr Chris Higgins, the Secretary to the Treasury, who died so tragically a year ago. I also commend the Treasury for pointing out in its quiet way why the Government has, in its view, gone off the rails economically. Page 3 of the report states:

PARA.TAB: During 1990-91 the Australian economy was in recession. Through a combination of factors—some domestic, some international—the recession proved to be deeper than expected both here and in a number of other countries. Not least amongst the reasons for this in Australia was the unwinding of what had been the sharpest asset price boom since at least WWII and possibly longer.

SPEECH.PARA: We can see the reason for the price boom. It was a set of political responses in terms of monetary policy that this Government undertook at an absolutely inappropriate time, which fuelled that boom and which we warned about at the time. Senator Short was in the forefront of the sensible commentators pointing out that the Government's policy approach was absolutely dreadful.

PARA.TAB: On page 4 the report goes on:

The sharp deflation of asset prices led to business failures which resulted in several financial institutions experiencing a marked increase in the doubtful and non-performing assets in their portfolios.

SPEECH.PARA: There is not a mention of the huge increases in interest rates which were forced on financial managers in Australia. The failure to use fiscal policy was the reason for this collapse. It was pure, simple, uncomplicated governmental incompetence that resulted in this excessive reliance on interest rates to resolve problems that should properly have been dealt with by other financial measures.

PARA.TAB: I am having to rush through this in five minutes; it is one of the 41 reports we have to deal with in half an hour, but it happens to be a very important one. However, another point is made in the report:

The recession weakened the Commonwealth Budget. While the cyclical effects have been allowed to take their course, the policy challenge has been to protect the structural position of the Budget so that the underlying integrity of fiscal policy remained intact.

SPEECH.PARA: What is happening to that underlying integrity now? We are getting statements from the Treasurer (Mr Willis) that something will have to be done because economic growth is not as hoped for. There is a clear indication coming from this Government that that `underlying integrity of fiscal policy' will be destroyed by a desperate government which is panicking into finding ways of softening the blow to the one million unemployed Australians in the recession that was engineered by the former Treasurer.

PARA.TAB: I also notice that the Treasury glosses over the $6.2 billion mistake made in the last Budget—the biggest ever budgeting mistake, to my knowledge, in Australia's history. A forecast $8.2 billion surplus ended up at $1.9 billion, missing its target by $6.2 billion. In dollar terms, nothing approaches that level of error. In the annual report I notice that the Treasury does not mention that; it simply says:

SPEECH.PARA: The. . . surplus fell from $8.0 billion . . .
The decline in the budget surplus reflected the operation of the automatic stabilisers on both expenditure and revenue—
Then it says:
the failure of certain proposals to be passed by Parliament (for example, the proposed sale of the Sydney-Moomba pipeline) . . .

I can assure the Treasury that the failure to sell the Sydney-Moomba pipeline would not have made a massive dent in the $6.2 billion in that year. I think it is simply a political debating point to try to run that line, particularly when that sale involved a massive breach of contract which I expect would have resulted in some legal action. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Operations of the IMF and World Bank

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The annual report on the Operations of the IMF and World Bank and, indeed, the report we have just deferred consideration of, the annual report on Australia and the World Bank, are very important documents. I hope that the Senate will find time at some point in the not too distant future, when we return next year, to debate more fully these reports and the matters relating to them; namely, Australia's position within the international economic arena. We have had some discussion on that with Senator McMullan in the past. It was arranged that we would try to have such a debate. I would welcome that.

PARA.TAB: These reports underscore Australia's links to, dependence on and interdependence with, the world economy. Australia is very heavily in debt to overseas lenders or owners. Our capacity for independent policy adjustment is therefore limited to that extent. If we had had less dependence on overseas debt and overseas equity in recent years, the problems confronting this nation would be very much fewer than they are now. Because we are so heavily indebted to the rest of the world, we now have a dangerous situation. In contrast to 20 years ago, or even 10 years ago, capital, knowledge and people—in other words, resources generally, particularly financial resources—are very mobile. They have the ability to move very quickly to the location which is most attractive for investment; equally, they have the ability to move very quickly from that location. The mood against a location can change. It means that Australia is essentially in competition with the rest of the world, not only in the market for goods and services but also, as importantly, in terms of being a favourable investment location.

That has enormous implications for this Government; it has enormous implications for Australia. It has particular implications in the weeks ahead. In recent days we have seen statements from the Treasurer (Mr Willis), under pressure from the left wing of the Labor Party and of the Government, in an attempt to out-Keating Keating on an interventionist, expansionist, economic policy by the Government. All the indications of recent days suggest that next year we will see a major loosening of an already loose economic situation.

If Mr Keating is elevated to the prime ministership or—if he does not make it—if the Hawke Government feels that it has to bow to the pressures of the Left, we will see ourselves in a very dangerous situation indeed. The first impact of that would be to increase dramatically the current account deficit, which is already running at $17 billion a year and which is costing something like 25c in every export dollar simply to service the debt, let alone repay it. We have an enormous external account problem.

If we do the U-turn which is now being indicated by the Government, the problems that we already have—the problems of the 1 1/2 million people, to whom I have just referred, who are underemployed or unemployed in Australia; the problem of falling investment, falling savings and falling production; and unsatisfactory productivity growth—will be compounded. All of the hurt, all of the hardship of the last couple of years of the deepest recession that we have had in 60 years will be for nought because we will have changed none of the fundamental, underlying problems which are affecting the economy.

These reports are very important in this regard. They make us realise the interdependence which Australia has with the rest of the world. I hope that the reports will provide a forum for continuing debate in this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: Medibank Private had an overall operating loss of $43.1m in 1990-91. Medibank Private's failure to increase its membership share in the eight years it has had the sole control of the Medicare program is one of the strongest arguments yet against nationalising health care financing in Australia. The fact that the overwhelming majority of Australians have stayed with their own health funds is all the more significant, given the fact that Medibank Private has had a monopoly over Medicare. This has meant that more than 70 per cent of insured people have had to go to a Medicare office to receive their medical benefit payment and then, as an act of free choice, they have gone to a second place—their own health fund. One should also be reminded that Medibank Private's figures suggest that it has been artificially holding its contribution rates down—one assumes to maintain market share.

PARA.TAB: The Macklin report has floated the idea of replacing the existing competitive network of health funds with a single national insurer, presumably the Health Insurance Commission; yet more than 70 per cent of Australians have shown that when they have a choice they do not want their business conducted by a government fund. This is quite obviously because Australians like to have freedom of choice and do not like government trading corporations telling them what they have to do. Clearly, if the Government attempted to embrace the nationalisation proposals which Macklin has put forward, it would be flying in the face of the wishes of more than 70 per cent of the insured population.

One area of particular concern is the extent to which the taxpayer may be called on to support the operations of Medibank Private. It is a matter of concern that many of the assets of the Commission appear to be held in the name of Medibank Private and Medicare is required to pay rent to it. I understand that this is to be looked at by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. I wish the Committee well in its deliberations.

The survival of the health care system in this country is dependent on an active private sector, often at the forefront of technology. The salvation of the health care system will come with the policy of the coalition.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on its inquiry into Australia's relations with Papua New Guinea, and I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a tabling statement.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: REPORT ON AUSTRALIA'S RELATIONS WITH PAPUA NEW GUINEA

I am pleased to present to the Senate the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on Australia's relations with Papua New Guinea. This is the second report in a series that the Foreign Affairs Sub-Committee is making on Australia's relations with its immediate region. In 1989 the Sub-Committee reported on Australia's Relations with the South Pacific and next year the Sub-Committee expects to complete an inquiry into Australia's relations with Indonesia.

This is by far the most comprehensive and wide ranging inquiry into Australia's relations with Papua New Guinea ever undertaken by an Australian parliamentary committee. The recommendations, if adopted, would have the effect of greatly transforming our nation's relations with Papua New Guinea, leading to a substantial broadening and strengthening of those relations.

Inquiries such as these into the basis of a whole relationship are of necessity wide ranging and complex and this inquiry into Australia's relations with Papua New Guinea has been a long one, interrupted by the election of May 1990. The terms of reference covered economic issues, including trade, investment and aid; political, strategic, social and cultural issues. Experts and interested parties from all these areas spoke to the Committee in over 18 public hearings conducted all over Australia. The report takes into consideration the often divergent views of its many witnesses and tries to set them into an historical context.
The Committee's report is based on the following overall historical assessment:

Australia's relationship with Papua New Guinea is governed by the fact that we obtained it as a colony in a burst of strategic nervousness just as we ourselves were seeking decolonisation. We were therefore diffident colonisers who governed with casual practicality and who departed with alacrity and too little care. The strategic concern, which motivated the acquisition of the colony in 1883, remains a constant factor in the relationship, coming as it does from our geographic proximity. A lingering sense of responsibility, bred of our rapid departure, governs our commitment to aid. Over the last fifteen years we have developed many formal ties and arrangements. Officially the relationship is given top priority and it has worked smoothly, albeit with questions arising now about the processes involved in aid and defence co-operation. Australia's major concerns are about the effectiveness of our aid in supporting Papua New Guinea's nationbuilding, a process that has slowed, and the instability of Papua New Guinea, evident in the secessionist movement on Bougainville or the political, social and economic disruptions of crime and corruption. Unofficially, at an institutional and personal level, the relationship has been weakened by time. Here, there is scope for strengthening it, for rehumanising it.

Certain issues consumed much of the Committee's attention. These were Australia's position and role as a major aid supplier to Papua New Guinea and the Defence Cooperation Program and the strategic considerations which prompt this program. Furthermore, the problems on Bougainville were of grave concern to the Committee. The Committee believes that these are central issues to the relationship and that they are issues that need to be addressed. In the case of Bougainville, there is a need for urgent resolution.

Given the current delicate stage of Papua New Guinea's economic and social development, the Committee believes that it would be wrong to withdraw too hastily from our aid obligations in support of PNG. These are obligations that extend from the days of colonial administration and particularly from the failure of successive Australian Governments to prepare Papua New Guinea sufficiently for independence. Low standards of education and health remain as a legacy to that neglect and one that continues to retard Papua New Guinea's development.

The Committee therefore believes that Papua New Guinea is in a crucial stage of its development and that the next ten to fifteen years will be vital in seeing the benefits of the rich resources of the country successfully applied to infrastructure and other developments. For this reason the Committee believes that aid must be maintained at nominal levels for the next five years. Furthermore, there should be no automatic formula for the reduction of aid by the year 2005 and only significantly higher than expected returns from resources should alter such an arrangement. Furthermore, no such no changes should occur without adequate consultation with PNG or planning time.

The Committee received a large number of recommendations urging changes to the Development Cooperation Program. The Government has already initiated some changes but the Committee believes that the current proposals should be modified. The key recommendations on aid are as follows:
The Committee recommends that budget support should be replaced by program aid, supported where necessary by project aid.

The move from budget support to program and project aid should be undertaken as a matter of urgency, commencing in 1993 or as soon as possible thereafter. During the transition there should be a mix of budget support and program and project aid, with the former being phased out by the end of 1998.

Given that negotiating projects and programs involves great administrative complexity and absorbs large amounts of scarce, high level managerial capacity, the Committee recognises that there may be delays in the implementation of this recommendation. If that occurs, the total level of aid should be maintained through continuing budget support.
The choice of program areas (designated programs) should be based on sound long term economic and social policies and be determined after close consultation between Australia and Papua New Guinea.

It is important to explain what we mean by this system of program aid. If aid is to be maintained, it should also be targeted more efficiently to areas of need. Present negotiations seem set to convert the existing budget support into project aid. The Committee does not believe that it is realistic to maintain nominal aid levels and at the same time convert this successfully into projects. Projects have a long lead time, are administratively complex and require high level managerial capacity. The Committee instead supports a system of program aid. Program aid is defined as the funding of a sector such as the education sector with a view to meeting predetermined objectives in a given period of time. It is a form of aid that would have definite goals; that would be monitored each year; that would involve Non-government Organisations; that might encompass projects within the target area; and that would involve long term funding commitment additional to and not a substitute for normal Papua New Guinea funding of the sector in question. The Committee believes that this last factor is most important if there are to be improvements in Papua New Guinea's infrastructure. The process of consultation between the Papua New Guinea and Australian Governments will also be a vital factor in the success of this system, particularly in ensuring that the targets are met and that the process remains within the power of the PNG Government.

Much media attention is given to security issues in Papua New Guinea. The evidence put before the inquiry certainly confirmed that the problem is serious. It is a twofold issue. There is lawlessness and violence in the towns and villages which creates fear and inhibits development and there is the movement on Bougainville for secession, perhaps the most destabilising and intractable problem Papua New Guinea faces. Both these problems have focused attention on the weaknesses within the defence and police forces—the need for better training, more discipline, an understanding of the need to protect human rights in dealing with civil disorder or disputes. These questions have prompted a review of expenditure on defence generally. The Committee understands the decision of the Papua New Guinea Government to rationalise its expenditure on security through joint training, joint logistics and more cooperative arrangements for the use of personnel. There is the difficulty a small nation has in finding adequate funding for the training and equipment of two separate forces. However, there are dangers in the merging of the two functions of domestic policing and external defence and the Committee believes that these dangers need to be addressed by the Defence Cooperation Program. There is scope within the training offered by Australia for some stress on humanitarian law and civic duties.

Bougainville, in particular, has revealed the problems Papua New Guinea faces in the future —problems of maintaining national integrity, problems of the recognition and satisfaction of the nationalist aspirations of groups within the country, problems of investment and resource development, problems of land ownership and compensation. The isolation of Bougainville has gone on too long. Too little is known about the real cost in terms of human suffering and loss of life over the last two years. Too little effort seems to have been made to find a solution, to get talks started and to stop the blockade. The Committee believes the Australian Government could and must do more despite the reservations expressed by various witnesses who saw Australian involvement precluded by its defence arrangements and commercial interests.
The report also argues strongly that the time has come to pay closer attention to the cultural and social aspects of the relationship which have become sadly neglected.

It is paradoxical that a neighbour so geographically close to Australia, whose historical connections with Australia have been so vital, should be so little known by the majority of Australians. There is scope for a vast improvement in the cultural, educational and sporting exchanges between the two countries and for the development and `normalisation' of the relationship beyond one tinged by the dependency of aid. In this report the Committee recommends a strengthening of the people to people arrangements and believes that this will have a beneficial effect on both countries. Since World War 11 Australia has discovered the worth of cultural enrichment from the immigration program. Our relationship with Papua New Guinea offers us the opportunity to share in the development of a diverse and dynamic people.

In conclusion, this report recognises the many strengths that exist in the relationship between Australia and Papua New Guinea—a formal relationship government to government that rests on regular consultation and review. However, there is scope for an expansion of the informal connections, the educational, cultural and social exchanges. We are urging a wholesale transformation of the aid relationship and many other things. In all there are 56 recommendations.

I am extremely gratified by the fact that, with the exception of one minor dissent, this report has been unanimously adopted by both the Foreign Affairs Sub-Committee and the full committee of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, representing all parties. I would strongly urge the Government to move towards implementing the key recommendations as soon as possible. The report contains a large amount of important information about the situation in Papua New Guinea and Australia's responses to it. The efforts of the Secretariat, especially Margaret Swieringa and Judy Middlebrook have been magnificent and I wish to thank them, our consultants, Rowan Callick and Matthew Neuhaus, very much. Finally, let me thank my colleagues on the Foreign Affairs Committee for the many hours they put into this report and for their cooperation in reaching agreement on the critical issues concerning our relationship with our closest neighbour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: This matter is not listed on the Order of Business for the Senate that has been distributed. Presumably, therefore, people are not aware that this matter is to be debated today. I became aware of it because I happened to hear that it was debated in the House of Representatives and I made some inquiries of the officials here. They indicated to me that it was a mere misprint.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was not a deliberate conspiracy.

—No, it was a mere misprint—an omission from the Order of Business. I simply refer to that fact. Obviously, other senators may not be aware that this matter is coming before us. I make that point because I know that a considerable number of members of parliament are very interested in the issue of Australia's relationship with Papua New Guinea. After all, I believe that that is a, if not the, most crucial relationship of all of our foreign affairs interests. I note that, at point 5 on page xxvi, the Committee says:

SPEECH.PARA: Central to the argument of this report is the view that the relationship between Australia and Papua New Guinea has weakened over time, especially at the individual level, and that the understanding the people of each country have of the other is not as deep or as thorough as it should be for such close neighbours. It is a cultural trade imbalance. Papua New Guineans know much more of us than we know of them. The fault lies particularly with Australians. Apart from those people whose connections with PNG go back to pre-independence days and the small group of officials who deal with the relationship at an official level, there are few in Australia who know or understand PNG well. Papua New Guinea does not figure in Australian school curricula, there are few cultural, sporting or tourist links and the media in Australia present a narrow and sensationalised view of Papua New Guinea as a violent and disintegrating society.
The Committee says further that it believes:
. . . there must be vast improvement in these links from the Australian side.

I agree entirely. It is a pivotal relationship. It is a relationship which must be worked on, as every successful relationship must be. Constant and consistent attention must be given to it. It is true that the press in Australia does sensationalise the situations that occur in PNG. The image of PNG amongst Australians, therefore, has become somewhat tarnished. That is unfair. It is unfair to the vast majority of Papua New Guineans, to those of us who have a great deal of respect for that nation, and to those of us who regard that nation as of pivotal importance to Australia.

PARA.TAB: Not only that, but we believe that we have a very important obligation to our nearest neighbour, Papua New Guinea. It is obvious that, on this last day of sitting this year, time does not permit the discussion that this report demands. I have had the report for only a very short while. But I must express some reservations about some matters in the report, because I believe that the Committee has made certain recommendations based on assumptions that were not tested. I think that is unfair and unfortunate. Let me refer to those recommendations which I have just described as unfair and unfortunate. I refer to recommendation 4 on page 41 and to recommendation 10. Those two recommendations, in so far as they refer to family planning, appear to the uninformed reader to be harmless enough. However, there is little or no evidence in the report of the Committee that the Committee questioned the basic premises or adopted a prudent or cautious approach in respect of these matters. For example, recommendation 4 says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that Australia offer a specific project to the family planning associations of Papua New Guinea in order that they might develop and promote comprehensive services on birth control. This aid could be delivered either through an expansion of current Non-government Organisation (NGO) services or through an AIDAB health project. We should also encourage the United National Family Planning Association to be involved.

The report does so after having said at paragraph 3.2.4 that a certain group of people whom the Committee indicated it saw in Port Moresby thought that population control needed to be made a priority of government with programs directed at reducing the high maternal and infant mortality rates. The report goes on to say in paragraph 3.2.5:

Already Papua New Guinea has not been able to expand its education system or its employment opportunities at a rate that keeps pace with population growth. Therefore, continued growth in the population at a rate higher than economic growth is potentially very serious. It puts pressure on the land; it stretches the capacity of the education and health systems; it worsens the unemployment situation; and it creates problems of lawlessness in the towns and in the highlands.

I will come back to that aspect in a moment because it is a ludicrous statement. The assumption made unfairly blames the fertility of the poor women in Papua New Guinea for a whole range of problems, and is a totally untested assumption.

PARA.TAB: I said that the Committee appeared to have accepted certain basic premises without having adopted a prudent and cautious approach. Let me give certain examples. Was the Committee aware of the unfortunate track record of UNFPA when it recommended its involvement in future Australian aid activities? Did the Committee examine the question of UNFPA support for the scandalous Depo-Provera based population control program in Papua New Guinea? Did it examine AIDAB's involvement therein? Did it examine AIDAB's involvement together with IPPF—International Planned Parenting Foundation—and UNFPA in the process of institutional strengthening of elites in Papua New Guinea to the detriment of the ordinary people of Papua New Guinea?

If it did not examine this question of the use of Depo-Provera in Papua New Guinea, why did it not do so? Why is there no mention of it in this report? Here is a drug upon which the UNFPA project is placing great reliance in its population control program in Papua New Guinea. In fact, Depo-Provera accounts for 63.3 per cent of the total funds to be spent on contraceptive purchases for women by UNFPA for the PNG project. This indicates that UNFPA has decided that approximately six out of every 10 `targeted' women will use Depo-Provera. This is despite the fact that Depo-Provera is not recommended in Australia for use. In fact, it is not authorised in Australia for contraceptive purposes. Although it is not approved for use in Australia for contraceptive purposes, presumably it is considered by UNFPA and others as suitable for PNG.

That is a real issue, and why did not the Committee ask questions about that? Does that not smack of some sort of colonial attitude—that something that is not approved for a particular purpose in Australia can be used as the flagship, as it were, of the population control program funded by UNFPA and supported by AIDAB; our taxpayers' money? I believe that the Committee should have examined those sorts of things.

Did the Committee have regard to the possible conflict between the social and religious attitudes of Papua New Guineans and the methods which the family planning bureaucrats attempt to impose on their client states? After all, the Committee quotes at paragraph 1.5.17 from a submission wherein it is stated that `Papua New Guineans are amongst the most religious people on earth. . . ' Yet those who call the tune internationally on population control are pushing women in particular and families into situations which are quite contrary to their cultural and religious convictions. There is no mention of this in the Committee's report. I think that is a failing and should be mentioned.
There is also room for potential conflict in the area of human rights. In recommendation 49 the Committee very sensibly states that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Australian Government should explore ways in which Australian aid to Papua New Guinea might be used to enhance safeguards for human rights protection.

But it is precisely in the area of family planning that gross violations of human rights can occur. Witness, for example, the gross violations of human rights in this area that occur in China and in a number of other countries.

PARA.TAB: I have been informed that already in PNG tubal ligations have been performed on women without their full understanding of what was involved and the general irreversible nature of the operation. Why were not questions asked about that? Here we have a situation where internationally driven population control organisations are attempting to impose their view on Papua New Guinea.

I am disappointed that the focus of the report has been on the quick-fix approach of the family planning salesmen from New York, Washington, and now from Canberra, many of whose methods do not accord with local customs, religious or cultural values, while there appears to have been little or no attention given to the genuine needs for better and more widespread medical attention at birth deliveries. That has been the biggest correctable cause of maternal mortality, not the number of children a woman has.

I return to paragraph 3.2.5 which I read earlier. It underlines the fact that already PNG has been unable to expand its education system or employment opportunities at a rate that keeps pace with population growth. It says that continued growth in the population at a rate higher than economic growth is potentially very serious. It puts pressure on the land, stretches the capacity of the education and health systems, worsens the unemployment situation and creates problems of lawlessness in the towns and in the highlands.

Those assertions are made, but there is not one attempt to back them up or discuss them. I am very disappointed about that because we could be regarded as, and called, colonialists in trying to impose our views of the world on Papua New Guinea. The report talks about pressure on land. People with knowledge of PNG know that it is a fertile land. Properly managed, there need be no pressure on the land. In fact, one of the causes of the downturn in employment is the severe decline in agricultural prices. As the Committee says on page xxvii, point 7:

SPEECH.PARA: In agriculture, however, a sector where most of the population is employed, there has been a severe decline in prices.

If there is a severe decline in prices, clearly the producers do not have the ability to make the necessary profit which, of course, has an effect on employment. It is not a question of there being too many people. The Committee's report then goes on to say:

Even the improvement in productivity that has been achieved in agriculture has not offset this decline in prices, nor has there been a successful movement into value-added manufacturing, linked to commodities.

That is what the thrust should be. I acknowledge that it is being suggested in certain sections of the report that more attention should be given to value adding. It is clear that PNG, as an exporter in the agricultural area, is suffering because of the decline in prices.

PARA.TAB: Why is that assertion about increasing pressure on land put in the report? Is the Committee suggesting that PNG is not sufficiently fertile even to meet its own demands in the area of basic commodities? That is not an argument for the imposition of a dictatorial population control program. Many countries in the world with very large and very prosperous populations do not have sufficient fertile land to produce their own food: for example, Singapore, Hong Kong and Japan, which make their money in other ways. Why is this assertion about increased pressure on land in the report?

Another point concerns stretching the capacity of the education and health system. An increased population, of course, does challenge those who are responsible for the delivery of health and education to ensure that those services are indeed delivered. What is the implication here? Is it to say, `Because the population has increased we will not concentrate on making sure that health services and education becomes a priority'? As I indicated before, to overcome the key problem of maternal mortality, far better and more widespread medical attention have to be given at birth deliveries. These are the areas that need to be supported.

The last point made by the Committee is that the population growth is creating problems of lawlessness in the towns and in the highlands. Does this mean that this problem of lawlessness is caused by the increases in population? I again quote the Committee against itself from page xxvi in point 4:

Of particular concern to the government and people of Papua New Guinea is the level of violence that exists in the country. A tradition of tribal warfare has long existed in the highlands but today `raskol' gangs belie the mischievousness of their name and spread real fear throughout the towns. It is a development that destroys the order and peace of the lives of local inhabitants, mars Papua New Guinea's reputation and threatens seriously to inhibit economic development. Worst of all, it has the potential to infiltrate and corrupt the political process.

SPEECH.PARA: Here the Committee is not saying that violence is a result of increased population growth. It is clearly putting violence in the context of certain gangs adopting mischievous activities and virtually blaming them on old tribal warfare traditions. It will not be overcome by throwing the pill or injecting women with Depo-Provera.

PARA.TAB: It is time that people had a look at some of these assumptions and examined them more thoughtfully, because there are many people who dishonestly peddle these prejudiced notions to serve their own vested interests. Organisations such as UNFPA and IPPF are spending enormous amounts of money indoctrinating people in developing countries with their prejudices. I have proof that it is happening in Papua New Guinea. It would have been interesting for the Committee to obtain some of that proof and ask questions of witnesses as to whether this was their own agenda or whether it was as a result of the indoctrination which has taken place by those with a vested interest. There are many people in those organisations who dishonestly peddle those prejudices, but there are many other well-meaning people who are preyed upon by that type of gravy train elite and who are force-fed that nonsense.

The report does not show that slowing the pace of the population growth will make any difference whatsoever. Let me give an example in my own State. Is the report suggesting that there should be no population growth over the next, say, 15 years? In my State there has been a 10 per cent drop in the number of people between the ages of 0 and 19 in the last 15 years, yet unemployment is going through the roof. We have experienced a drop in the population in that age bracket. Prescribing the pill or injecting women with Depo-Provera is not an answer to unemployment, and certainly the Committee has not said how its recommendation will seriously tackle that problem.

The Committee should not put the blame for the problems in Papua New Guinea, as it has done, on the fertility of the poor women in that country. As I said in a speech that I delivered to AIDAB on 25 July this year:

SPEECH.PARA: Enabling the true human development of each individual can be seen as the main objective of society, and therefore of political and economic systems.

Individuals and families are the core of society. Their well being is therefore central to the political and economic processes which seek to promote development. There is no sound and authentic development of a society unless priority is given to the needs of the individuals and families within that society. To the extent that any action taken is not in the real interests of individuals and families, then it is not contributing to true human development.

The totalitarian ideologies of fascist and communist States sought to develop societies at the expense of the rights of individuals and families. They failed to acknowledge that the family is the natural and fundamental group unit of society with pre-eminent rights and functions. They have been condemned by their victims and by history. Only by respecting the rights and values of the subjects of development can a solid framework for economic and social development assistance be laid.

I believe that the assumptions that are made by the Committee for its recommendation in the family planning area reflect a totalitarian ideology. They reflect a situation which could end in the ordinary Papua New Guineans rightly accusing us of cultural imperialism and returning to colonial domination in this particular area.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to notice and on behalf of relevant Ministers, I move:

PARA.TAB: That the following Bills be introduced: a Bill for an Act to establish a Construction Industry Development Council and a Construction Industry Reform Agency for the purposes of promoting and facilitating development and reform of the construction industry in Australia, and for related purposes; a Bill to amend the Migration Act 1958; and a Bill to amend the Trade Practices Act 1974 to provide for the compensation of persons who suffer loss caused by defective goods.
