SPEECH.PARA: CONSTRUCTION INDUSTRY REFORM AND DEVELOPMENT BILL 1991
This Bill represents an important part of the Government's construction industry reform strategy. This is an essential element of the Government's micro-economic reform agenda.

The reform and development of the construction industry is vital to the national economy. The construction industry is one of this country's largest industries. It has an annual expenditure in excess of $40 billion, it employs more than 500,000 people and accounts for over 60% of Australia's gross fixed capital expenditure.

The Government's reform strategy is directed at substantial improvements in productivity and efficiency in the industry. Because of the links the construction industry has with other key sectors—particularly mining, transport and tourism— reforms achieved in the construction industry will flow on through the economy generally.

The purpose of the Bill is to establish the Construction Industry Reform Agency, which will be the catalyst for change and development in the industry. The Construction Industry Development Council will also be established to be a broad based national consultative and advisory forum for the industry.

The construction industry reform strategy was launched by the Prime Minister on 3 December 1991. Its objective is to develop a reliable and internationally competitive industry through real and tangible improvements in performance standards.
The reform strategy specifically addresses the significant and intractable problems that have impeded the development of this industry to date.

The strategy is broadly-based, covering workplace reform, industry development and building regulation. The strategy is unique and innovative. It is the first time such a comprehensive national approach has been attempted for the industry in this country.

The development of the strategy has been undertaken in consultation with the major parties, in line with this Government's cooperative approach to industrial relations and industry development. In this process it has become apparent that the industry considers that a strong and active role by government is an essential prerequisite to achieving substantial reforms in the industry.

The Government has responded by approving a comprehensive industry reform and development strategy. It has also agreed to commit funding of $10.8m over the next 3 1/2 years to facilitate the implementation of the strategy.

However, the Government believes the industry itself must make a fundamental contribution to the reform process. Accordingly the Government has sought, at the outset, a genuine commitment on behalf of the parties to the achievement of reform.

As part of this commitment the industry is being asked to contribute to funding for the strategy through financial and resource contributions. This could possibly include making experienced staff available to the reform agency on secondment.
A significant indication of commitment to the strategy has been the signing of the In-Principle Reform and Development Agreement by the major industry parties.
The In-Principle Agreement commits the parties to improve the performance of the industry to world class practices and standards.

It identifies specific areas where improved efficiency and productivity can be achieved. This is to be pursued primarily through the development of performance standards, improved contractual arrangements and related improvements in project management. Priority is given to the need for improvements in training and skill levels for managers, professional staff and workers and to the enhancement of the industry's export performance.

The Agreement also commits the parties to rationalisation of industry bodies and industry awards. It contains specific measures to resolve restrictive practices and the incidence of lost time on sites. It gives priority to implementation of award restructuring in particular to the adoption of the proposed new classification structure and associated skill related career paths and training.

It is very significant that all major national industry bodies have signed the Agreement, including the Australian Federation of Construction Contractors, the MTIA/National Construction Council, the Master Builders'—Construction and Housing Association of Australia, the Building Owners and Managers Association of Australia and the Building Industry Specialist Contractors Organisation of Australia. Every major national industry trade union, along with the ACTU, have also signed the Agreement.

In addition, the governments of Victoria, South Australia and the Australian Capital Territory have signed, whilst Western Australia is to sign the Agreement on 23 December. It is likely that other governments will sign the Agreement shortly.

In an industry that has been characterised by counter-productive conflict and internal dissension, this strategy represents an unparalleled approach to reform. All major stakeholders are committed to its success.

It is on the basis of this ambitious and comprehensive strategy, together with the overwhelming support of all key sectors of the industry, that the Government now proposes to proceed with this legislation.

The main functions of the Agency will be to promote and implement the reform strategy. The Agency is to have primary responsibility for ensuring that the parties adhere to the commitments contained in the In-Principle Agreement.

The Agency will also be responsible for developing an industry code of practice, which is to be the basis for encouraging best practice standards in the industry. The Government has decided that it will commence to apply a code of practice for major Commonwealth public works construction projects from 1 July 1992.

The code of practice will contain arrangements for ratings systems for those companies seeking to participate in major construction projects. This will involve the development and implementation of a range of performance standards covering such important areas as quality assurance, research and export performance, financial performance, time performance, safety record and labour relations.
The aim of this code will be to enhance performance standards and delivery through a transparent and objective process.

In carrying out its responsibilities it will be essential for the Agency to liaise closely with the key national industry and union bodies and with State and Territory governments. The proposed Construction Industry Development Council will provide one suitable forum for such consultation.

The Government believes that reform must, and can, be achieved within the next 2-3 years. It therefore considers that the Agency should only be established for a strictly limited period. This will ensure that the momentum for change is maintained.

Accordingly the Bill provides that the Agency is to cease operations on 1 July 1995. Because of the urgency to press ahead with these reforms, the Agency has been established on an interim basis pending the enactment of this legislation.
It is essential to the success of the strategy that the Agency is strongly supported by the industry itself and is able to attract experienced and skilled people from the industry.

The Bill, therefore, constitutes a Board of the Agency that will enable people from the industry who have a proven record, and enjoy a high reputation in the industry, to be appointed to it. It is not intended to establish the Board in a manner that simply represents existing industry bodies.
The Prime Minister has announced that Mr Ern Macdonald, former chair of Civil and Civic, is to be the Chief Executive Officer of the Agency.
The Bill permits the Agency to employ staff, or engage or second people from the industry to undertake specific projects.
The Bill also establishes the Construction Industry Development Council. The Council will constitute an on-going forum for the industry to consider ways of improving its performance and standards.

The Bill provides that the Council will be chaired jointly by the Minister for Industrial Relations and the Minister for Small Business and Customs, thereby giving Council members direct access to the key Commonwealth Ministers responsible for the reform strategy.
The Council will advise the Government on issues affecting the industry and will liaise with the Reform Agency and other industry organisations and with State and Territory governments.

The Council's membership will include representatives from all major national industry bodies and unions. To reflect their key role, each State and Territory government is to be represented on the Council.

The Government is confident that the high level of support that has been demonstrated by all sections of the industry for the reform strategy will provide a sound basis for these two new bodies to make significant and durable contributions to the development of this vital industry.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
MIGRATION AMENDMENT BILL (NO 4) 1991

This Bill makes changes to the merits review system established as part of the major amendments to the Migration Act in 1989. The changes are designed to enhance the position of applicants for review. The Bill also increases penalties in the Act in line with Commonwealth criminal law policy and makes a number of other minor amendments.

The Government, in 1989, established a two-tier merits review system of certain decisions under the Migration Act. The first tier is the Migration Internal Review Office (MIRO). The second tier is the Immigration Review Tribunal (IRT) which is an independent external review agency. The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs noted in the House of Representatives on 17 April 1991 that the objectives of the review system continue to be achieved. That is to say, the review system provides independent review which is fair, just, economical, informal and quick. Further legislative changes have been made to enhance the review system and I refer Honourable Senators to the Migration Amendment Act 1991 which introduced a number of important changes.

This Bill will make two further changes to the review system. Firstly, the Bill will clarify the matters which may be considered by MIRO or the IRT when reviewing an assessment under Section 30 of the Act. Section 30 provides for an applicant for some visas, including concessional family visas, to be given points for certain prescribed factors such as employment qualifications, age, language skills and family relationships. The points awarded for each factor are prescribed in the Migration Regulations. It is a criterion for the grant of these visas that the applicant receive more than a specified number of points when assessed under section 30. At present the Act does not indicate whether MIRO or the IRT are required to consider changes to the Migration Regulations which occur subsequent to the original decision on the application. It is possible that the points awarded for a particular factor may increase or decrease in the period between the original decision and the review stage. The Bill will insert a new section 121A into the Act which will provide that points under section 30 are to be assessed by MIRO and the IRT in accordance with the regulations in force at the time of the original decision. However, if the regulations which are in force at the time of the review will lead to a more favourable outcome for the applicant, those regulations will apply instead.

The second change to the review system which will be effected by this Bill is a technical amendment to ensure that illegal entrants who may be invited by the IRT to lodge an application for an entry permit under section 121 are not prevented from doing so by section 37. Section 37 is designed to prevent illegal entrants from delaying their departure from Australia by lodging a sequence of applications for entry permits. That section was not intended, contrary to what one construction of the language might indicate, to prevent illegal entrants from lodging an application when invited to do so by a review authority. Section 37 will therefore be amended accordingly.

I turn now to the issue of the level of penalties provided for offences created by the Act. Honourable Senators will appreciate that the Migration Act creates a number of criminal offences dealing with such matters as illegal entry to Australia, obstruction of officers, and escaping from custody. In line with the Government's determination to reduce the number of illegal entrants in Australia, the penalties provided in the Act have recently been reviewed. The pecuniary penalties, provided as an alternative to imprisonment, were found to be below the levels now considered appropriate in terms of Commonwealth criminal law policy. That policy is expressed in section 4B(2) of the Crimes Act 1914 and provides that maximum pecuniary penalties are to be determined in accordance with a formula whereby 6 months of imprisonment equates to three thousand dollars. For example, the offence of escaping from custody in section 171 of the Act currently has a penalty of five thousand dollars or imprisonment for two years or both. These are, of course, the maximum penalties which a court may impose. Under the proposed amendment the penalty set out in the Migration Act will be two years imprisonment. However, application of the formula in section 4B(2) of the Crimes Act (three thousand dollars per six months of imprisonment) will increase the maximum pecuniary penalty from five thousand dollars to twelve thousand dollars.

The offences in the Migration Act which will not be subject to the formula in section 4B(2) of the Crimes Act are those where no imprisonment option is provided. The majority of those penalties will also be increased to maintain relativity with the penalties derived under section 4B(2). In addition I should mention those offences relating to the arranging of non-genuine relationships for the purpose of securing permanent residence in Australia. Persons who arrange contrived relationships to defeat Australia's migration laws will risk penalties of $100 000 or ten years imprisonment or both. These penalties were introduced recently in the Migration Amendment Act (No 2) 1991 and reflect the need for a more substantial deterrent in this area than would be provided by the application of the section 4B(2) formula.
The Bill will also introduce a number of other less significant, but nonetheless important, amendments to the Migration Act to which I will make brief reference.

References to powers of arrest will be removed from sections 92 and 93 and from a number of related sections to ensure that no confusion arises between the powers under the Act to take persons into what might be termed `migration custody' and the power to arrest persons for criminal offences. Officers who exercise powers under the Migration Act to take persons into custody do so for specific purposes under the Migration Act related to migration processing and/or removal from Australia. Those powers are, therefore, not subject to the restrictions set out in the Crimes Act 1914 which apply to the power to arrest persons for criminal offences. However, to make this distinction absolutely clear the term `arrest' has been removed from a number of sections of the Act and replaced with the term `detain in custody'.

I will now deal with the proposed amendment to section 20 of the Act. Section 20 identifies a number of matters which would result in a person becoming an illegal entrant unless those matters are disclosed in a notice under section 20. For example a person suffering from a prescribed disease or a prescribed physical or mental condition must disclose that fact in a section 20 notice. If a visa or entry permit is subsequently granted to the person who has made the required disclosure that visa or entry permit must be endorsed with a statement that the person is recognised to be a person to whom section 20 applies. In other words a person who has, for example, a prescribed disease, must have that fact acknowledged on their visa or entry permit. The Migration Regulations currently permit the endorsement to be in the form of a code recognisable only by departmental officers. Despite this, the requirement for an endorsement can cause embarrassment or offence to some persons. The proposed amendment will provide that the obligation to endorse the visa or entry permit will be satisfied if the information is recorded in a departmental database.
Finally, a number of other minor technical amendments will be made by the Bill and these are explained adequately in the Explanatory Memorandum to the Bill.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
TRADE PRACTICES AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1991

Mr President, it is with some sense of occasion that I today bring before the Senate a Bill to implement the Government's foreshadowed reform of product liability. The Bill represents the most significant legislative development in the reform of consumer protection in recent times, continuing this Government's commitment to promote the interests of consumers as part of an efficient economy.

The sorry state of Australia's existing product liability laws has been the subject of reports from the National Consumer Affairs Advisory Council, the Australian Law Reform Commission and the Industry Commission. All accept that an irresistible case exists for updating and simplifying the existing law. We need a system which promotes economic efficiency and provides justice to victims who suffer loss caused by defective products.

Internationally too, the need to make a manufacturer strictly liable for its defective products has been recognised in the development and implementation in the European Community of a Directive on product liability.

The Bill I bring before the Senate today follows the 1985 EC Product Liability Directive in all important respects. The EC Directive has proven to be a generally acceptable model to both business and community groups, and the introduction in Australia of a regime consistent with the Directive will ensure that no undue impediments to trade are imposed.

Indeed, the EC Directive appears in fact to be the emerging international standard for product liability legislation. I understand that, in our own region, the Governments of Japan, South Korea and Taiwan are also showing a clear interest in introducing legislation based on the Directive.

Australian manufacturers will be required to produce goods which meet these standards for export markets if they are to achieve international competitiveness. I also believe that Australian consumers are entitled to the same level of protection as is available to consumers abroad.
Features of the Bill
The key features of the Bill are as follows.

A manufacturer or importer of goods is to be strictly liable for defects in those goods. Goods are defective when they do not provide the degree of safety which persons generally are entitled to expect, taking into account all the circumstances including the way the goods were marketed or labelled, and the likely uses to which the goods will be put. This is an objective test: it is the objective knowledge and expectations of the community which determine whether a product is defective, not the subjective knowledge and expectations of the claimant.

A product will not be held to be defective simply because a better, safer product is subsequently put into circulation. This should ensure that the regime does not stifle product development or innovation.

Where a defect in a product results in someone being killed or injured, or where an individual's personal property is damaged as a result of a defect in goods, the manufacturer or importer is liable to pay compensation for that loss without the need for the person to prove that the manufacturer was negligent.

The claimant will have to prove that the product was defective, and that the defect in the product was the cause of the loss. But, as I have said, the claimant will not have to prove negligence. The difficulty in proving negligence is one of the factors identified in existing law which can lead to injustice.

In considering the evidence before it, the Bill calls for the courts to adopt a common sense approach to the onus of proof upon the claimant, and not to become embroiled in overly legalistic interpretations. If the evidence adduced by the claimant and all the circumstances of the case are such that it is reasonable to infer that loss was caused by a defect in goods, then that inference is to be made.

In practical terms, this should mean that where, in the view of the court, the circumstances of the case merit the drawing of the inference, the claimant will not be liable to be struck out or "no cased" on the ground of paucity of evidence.

In short, where the circumstances allow a reasonable inference that the defect caused the injury or damage to be drawn, the question will be a live issue, meriting the adjudication of the court. But, at the end of the day, the question for the court will continue to be: has this plaintiff shown, on the balance of probabilities, that a defect in the product caused the injury or damage?

This provision should clarify the position for potential claimants in what I would call `common sense claims'—that is, cases where the basic equity of a plaintiff's claim appeals to the common sense of ordinary Australians—cases which, to use the vernacular, are entitled to a `fair go'.

The Bill provides a number of defences. Manufacturers will not be liable if they can show that the existence of the defect was incapable of being ascertained by any means (the "state of the art" defence), or where the defect came into existence after the product left the manufacturer's control. A component manufacturer can escape liability if it can show that the component was only "defective" because of the design, markings, instructions or warnings of the product in which the component was incorporated.

The manufacturer will also not be liable where the product was defective only because it complied with a mandatory standard imposed by a government. Where the sole cause of a defect was compliance with a mandatory standard imposed by the Commonwealth Government, the Commonwealth will be liable to compensate the claimant for the loss.
In line with the EC Directive and the recommendations of the Industry Commission, compensation can be reduced to take account of any acts of the claimant which contributed to the loss.

The Trade Practices Commission will be empowered to take representative actions on behalf of one or more consumers who have a product liability claim. However, the Commission will be required to obtain the prior consent in writing of those claimants who it is to represent.
Public Consultation

While product liability has been the subject of a number of public inquiries over the past few years, industry and consumer groups have not had the opportunity to consider and comment on the specific terms of this Bill. I therefore propose to undertake a process of consultation once interested parties have had the opportunity to examine this Bill, and will carefully consider any views put to me. I would encourage all those with an interest in product liability, whether from an industry or consumer perspective, to carefully read this Bill and its supporting materials and to raise with me any of their comments or concerns.

In this regard, I want to point out that the Explanatory Memorandum prepared by my Department is somewhat more descriptive of the purpose and effect of the Bill than is normally the case with such documents. It has been prepared to assist and promote informed discussion on the Bill, and I commend it both to the Senate and the public at large as a useful document when considering the Bill.
Financial Impact Statement

The Bill primarily confers legal rights upon individuals to institute legal proceedings. No direct increase in public expenditure is required to administer the regime. There may be a need to consider increased funding for the Federal Court and the Trade Practices Commission if product liability becomes a significant part of their workload, but this is not likely to occur for some considerable time.

There may be costs arising from the imposition of Commonwealth liability for products which are defective solely because they complied with a mandatory standard imposed by the Commonwealth. The impact of Commonwealth liability for defective standards, however, is not expected to be great.

The Bill will ensure that it is the person who was responsible for putting the defective goods into circulation who will be liable to compensate those people who are injured because of the goods. This will benefit the whole community. There will eventually be some increased cost to business as a result of the new law; however, European experience under a very similar regime has shown that this cost will be almost imperceptible in the initial years and very gradual after that. The Bill will also undoubtedly encourage improved design, evaluation and enhanced quality control.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the brief time that I had before the luncheon adjournment I was pointing out that in dealing with the National Road Transport Commission Bill we must recognise the significant road transport system that we have in Australia that is provided by private enterprise. I drew an analogy with the failed transport system of the USSR, which I observed last year to be a total shambles. We, on this side of the House, are very concerned about the way that this Bill has been rushed into the Parliament, with no costing and no evidence as to the effects it will have on the transport system in Australia.

PARA.TAB: The bureaucracy that exists in the USSR seems to be working in a similar way to this particular Bill. The National Road Transport Commission will have at least 21 committees set up by Austroads, a group of all road transport authorities whose work bears directly on the Commission. These committees alone will immediately occupy about 10 per cent of the total staff time available to the Commission. The industry finds it bad enough now keeping up with the bureaucracy, but with another 21 committees it will find it almost impossible to do so.

In addition, the National Road Transport Commission will need to act as a secretariat to the Australian Transport Advisory Council, and this may take up to half the Commission's staff time. Serious questions should be asked about the level of bureaucracy that is involved with this Bill. The coalition has certainly endorsed transport reform, but we have always said it must be fair and equitable, and we have persisted with calls for an economic impact study to be carried out before any charges are implemented. The amendment moved by Senator Chapman highlights that. Certainly, it is going to a committee, but it seems to be a question of the horse following the cart.

We know that there has been a lot of comment from the industry. The National Transport Federation has said that the Bill is flawed on technical, democratic and economic grounds, and will lead to results that are contrary to the stated aims of land transport reform. The National Transport Federation is the largest representative organisation of long distance transport in Australia and is a member of the Road Transport Forum, so I think it should know what it is talking about. It said in a comment I read that it supports the reform process as a means of improving the effective freight movement in Australia, and it certainly supports the formation of a commission as an expert body to independently develop a better and fairer regulatory environment to our industry in an ongoing manner. However, it certainly does not support the current terms within the Bill which bind the Commission to the terms of reference and agreements signed by heads of government. There is no need to go into all of that, but I will quote from a statement that the Federation made, which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Along with our Federation and the Road Transport Forum, these groups believe that whilst reform is necessary and able to achieve real cost reductions in land transport, the current process is unjustified and will lead to higher costs, which is contrary to the aims of reform and against the interest of our nation.
Governments have not done their homework. The Bill and what it will lead to are flawed.

I turn briefly to the effect the Bill may have on my own State of Tasmania. This morning I noted that Senator Boswell was commenting about the effects he sees the Bill will have on remote Australia. As far as remoteness is concerned, when we are referring to freight, Tasmania is probably the most remote area in Australia. Tasmania has suffered for many years with the problem of shipping in Bass Strait and the like. Of course, there have also been airline strikes.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that at the moment a vast majority of our freight comes into the north of the State and has to be transferred south to the capital city. The concerns that have been raised, particularly by Tasmanian operators, are questions of which the Government should take note. The question that comes to mind is: given that Tasmania is already struggling to maintain a viable economy, why is this process being pursued? I mentioned this morning that I am quite concerned at the fact that the Tasmanian Government agreed to place Tasmania in the high charge zone along with Victoria and New South Wales. I would like to know the basis on which this decision was made and what further impact it will have on our crumbling economy. These are some of the questions that should have been answered before this Bill came into this place.

I also query what charges the Government will force particularly on road transport, and possibly cars, from 1 January 1993. Senator Boswell mentioned some figures this morning. He was talking about 45-tonne vehicles having an increased cost of $8,000, moving to $14,000 by 1995. All these added costs come on top of an industry already paying three and a half times the taxes that other businesses in Australia pay. That is quite alarming when we all rely so much on our transport system. We know that the Government started investigating the possibility of increased charges in 1985, but we still do not have the answers.

A letter was sent to me yesterday from the Secretary of the Tasmanian Truck Owners and Operators Association. I do not intend to read it all. The letter points out one particular difference between trucking in Tasmania and the rest of Australia. Tasmania's cart/carrier licensing system ensures that the remote communities in the State are placed on an equal footing with more populated areas. As you would understand, Mr Deputy President, some country routes tend to be less profitable than principal routes, but the cart/carrier licensing system we have in Tasmania certainly helps to even that out. The Secretary of the Tasmanian Truck Owners and Operators Association said in the letter:

SPEECH.PARA: If the Federal Government is successful in dismantling the licensing system in Tasmania and displacing smaller Operators from the Industry, the Country and more remote communities will suffer.

Some large Transport Operators who generally operate between Ports and use principal routes are promoting excessively high Taxes & Charges with the knowledge that some existing Operators will be forced from the Industry. It is their belief that all increases will be passed on to the consumer.

So we have the situation now where this extra charge on transport will cause quite significant increases in freight. We know that the stated intention of the Government is to use this road tax to improve our road system. If the Government had been fair dinkum about the excise it has been taking out of fuel for the last few years by putting that back into the roads where it should have been spent, we certainly would not be in the position we are in now.

PARA.TAB: One only has to look at the chart I have here entitled, `Real Excise Collections and Road Funding', from 1975 through to 1992. The amount spent on road funding is pretty level across the graph, but the excise collected is way above the amount spent. It was said this morning that the amount spent on roads was a bit over $1 billion, yet the Government is receiving between four and a half and five billion dollars in excise collections.

As we know and as has been said by my colleagues, under our Fightback package proposals, fuel excise, wholesale sales tax, tariffs and payroll tax will be removed from the road transport industry and will have a very significant effect on the costs and charges to all Australians. We are about removing fuel taxes; we are about removing wholesale sales taxes; we are about abolishing payroll tax; and we are about getting rid of tariffs. We are not about putting on extra road taxes and charges to make the cost of freight to all Australians more expensive.

It goes without saying that road transport operators, road users and, for that matter, the rail system are overjoyed by our package. They see that our future government is prepared to get rid of the shackles of government taxation on inputs and let them be truly competitive. There is no doubt that under the Fightback proposals road transport will be a big winner. In addition, road funding will not be reduced. That has been made quite clear by our Leader. The package that we are proposing will mean that transport in this country will be cheaper. As a Tasmanian, I am pleased to say to all my Tasmanian constituents that I believe that the State of Tasmania will probably get the best benefit from this particular package. At the present time, many of the shipping companies that travel across Bass Strait are paying quite high fuel excise which increases freight costs.

In conclusion, this Bill, this pig in a poke, came in here without any costing, without any investigation into the impact that it will have on Australia. For whatever reason—I do not know—it is being pushed through this place prior to the Christmas break. Given the belief that the Democrats will support the Government and push this Bill through, a framework will be set up, and I suppose it is anybody's guess the sorts of charges and regulations we will see next year further down the track.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to detain the Senate for long for the simple reason—and I want to be consistent about this—that I was a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs that introduced the new procedure referring legislation to standing committees of the Parliament for the alleged purpose of restraining unnecessarily repetitious debate in the chamber. That Committee sat from 8 p.m. until 2 a.m. the following day. All the arguments we have heard here in the chamber this afternoon were exhausted—I use that word advisedly—during that previous debate. Indeed, nothing new was added to what we have heard here this afternoon.

PARA.TAB: I interpolate that if at the conclusion of my remarks Senator Coulter seeks leave to speak, I will be perfectly happy—and I am sure that it would be in order—to give him leave to do so, so that he is not denied that opportunity.

Once again, I was intrigued to hear what has become conventional over the years with National Party politicians. Certainly in every election in which I have campaigned they have run the same line. They are perfectly happy to support, when it is politically necessary to do so, the line that is run in the town by their Liberal colleagues, but they are also perfectly happy to run a totally different line in the bush. We heard an example of that once again this afternoon.

The interesting thing about it is that in terms of the concerns that were expressed about any increases in road charges by this new national regime, which I might add is a very welcome reform initiative for which the Commonwealth cannot take sole responsibility because we are equal partners in this with the States and the ACT—

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the Northern Territory Government?

—I should not be disorderly enough to respond to interjections, but on this one I will. The Northern Territory Government has some concerns about what I think Mr Finch described during that Committee as a 5 per cent component—that was his word—of the charging, but fully supports and has committed itself to introduce parallel legislation with all other aspects of this package. This package will provide for the first time in our nation's history a national regime of operation for heavy vehicles in this country, which is so vital to our transport sector. It will remove the horrendous commercial inequities and inefficiencies in the operation of road transport that currently exist with trucks having to travel from State to State. As was pointed out by witnesses, departmental officers and myself at that Committee, very significant charges currently apply in the States for trucks that are registered elsewhere but are operating in those States.

PARA.TAB: The point I want to make is that the National Party is supporting the GST package. The GST package emphatically, and to a degree about which I protest and disagree with, talks about the unilateral imposition of a user pays system and fully supports it. At the same time—and I have pointed out this nonsense to the Senate before—it proposes the removal of fuel excise, which currently funds a significant proportion of those costs. That means by logical implication that if the coalition introduces a true user pays system—and that is what it says it will do in its GST document—some other method must be introduced to replace that component of revenue raising for road funding that it will remove. The only way I can see of doing it is by some system of mass distance charging, because the current revenue raiser will be removed with the full support of the National Party.

I repeat that National Party members always support the Liberal coalition line when they are in town and then tell another story to their constituents when they go bush. I had recent experience of this in the transport area. Tim Fischer was touring northern Australia not so long ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Tim Fischer.

—Mr Tim Fischer; absolutely. He needs all the help he can get. I am happy to put `Mr' in front of his name. Mr Tim Fischer was cruising Queensland and while he was there quite happily committed the coalition to providing $1 billion in additional Federal funding for Queensland roads alone. He then floated across to the Northern Territory on the same trip and committed the coalition to the construction of the Alice Springs to Darwin railway, involving another $1 billion.
—He was consistent.

—Absolutely. So in the space of two days the Leader of the National rump of the coalition had committed his Party to the expenditure of $2 billion while travelling from Queensland to the Northern Territory. I have to put that incident in context. When I was retailing that story to a journalist from the Press Gallery, he said, `Oh, well, I suppose that if it was anyone else but Tim Fischer perhaps it would matter'. I guess that, for accuracy, I would have to agree with that comment. Nevertheless, that is the traditional performance of members of the National Party, previously known as the Country Party. Their behaviour has not changed over the years, and I have grown very used to it. They consistently support their coalition partners in savaging public spending, cutting government services, chopping this off, chopping that off, and then going out to their electorates and promising the world with massive additional Federal Government spending for people in the bush—never actually delivering it, of course.
—Senator Collins, you should have Liberal Party conferences where they insist on cutting taxes and increasing expenditure.

—Absolutely. I was also intrigued, in terms of the GST package and the consistency of the Queensland Liberal Party with the Nationals on this issue, to see a number of resolutions passed at the recent State conference of the Liberal Party in Queensland. One resolution fully supported the application of a whopping 15 per cent retail tax on every motel bed, every restaurant meal, every souvenir purchased, every bus trip taken, every tourist package purchased, every trip to Magnetic Island. There would be a 15 per cent tax on the lot. At the same Liberal conference coalition members decried and protested against any further impost of government charges on the important tourist industry for Queensland. They are not particularly consistent, yet we heard the same line run in here by our National Party representatives today in respect of this legislation.

PARA.TAB: I want to make one general philosophical point concerning the continual sneering references by Opposition speakers during the debate to the great Federal initiatives of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). This is a hobby horse of mine, and I concede it. I was a delegate to two constitutional conventions. I can remember discussing this matter with former Senator Macklin, for whom I had, and still have, enormous respect. We got together at the last conference and both decided that we would never attend another one. Having conceded that constitutional reform to remove these inefficiencies in our transport system would be impossible because of the conservative approach we have to changing our Constitution, this kind of initiative is the only approach we can possibly use to succeed. I must say that to refer continually to it in this disparaging way by public figures who have a responsibility, in my view, to help bring this nation together rather than tear it apart does not do them any credit.

I make that point because this piece of legislation is not a creature of the Commonwealth Government; nor is it something which the Commonwealth Government is forcing—or can, under the provisions of the Act, force—down the throats of reluctant States. It is a legislative framework which incorporates the heads of agreement which was reached between the heads of government of the States, the ACT, the Northern Territory, in principle, with the exception of the charging, and the Commonwealth, in which the Commonwealth is an equal partner. We get one vote on the Ministerial Council, along with the rest. In conclusion, the fundamental point I want to make is that we have had a long debate here this afternoon, which—Senator Coulter will not be surprised to hear—was a complete reiteration of the six hours of continuous debate we had about charging at the Committee hearing.

The fact is that this legislation which is in front of us today has nothing whatever to do with that. It simply sets up the framework for the organisation which will make recommendations, and that is what they are, to the people who actually have the executive responsibility for making a decision: that is, the Ministerial Council, on which the Commonwealth has an equal vote along with the States. The fundamental point which appears to be utterly lost on members of the Opposition—I think they choose to ignore it—is that we are not in a better position. Let us take the theoretical example which I gave at the Committee hearing. Should the Commission go berserk—which it will not—and propose some horrendous rate of charges which would be iniquitous, inequitable and unfair, any head of government or any representative on that Ministerial Council who has the final decision-making power could not agree with that decision, and it would not proceed in that State.

This entire exercise depends—not simply in its genesis but in its execution—on continued cooperation between the State governments and the Federal Government. For the first time in our history, we will have a national regime—I must say it is to the great relief of the entire transport industry—encompassing our regulatory regime and charging regime for moving freight across this country by road. It was welcomed by the States, quite rightly, and it is welcomed by the Federal Government. But we are equal partners in this enterprise. All this legislation does is set up the organisation that will do it.

As this Senate knows full well, the Government supported happily the initiatives of the Australian Democrats to have further matters referred to the Standing Committee next year. We all know that the actual charging regime must be implemented by law. We know that it will involve separate legislation and regulations, all of which will be debated at length, as they always are, both in the Committee—and we know it will be referred to the Committee because it was done yesterday—and again in this chamber. For that reason, having gone over this matter for six hours in committee and knowing that we will go over the actual charging regime again next year both in committee and in the House, I conclude by thanking honourable senators for their contributions to this debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I apologise to other senators for not being in the chamber at the appropriate time. It seems as though there have been quite significant changes to the speakers list.

PARA.TAB: I begin by reflecting on the remarks of the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins). It seems as though, in dealing with areas like this one, one is damned if one does and damned if one does not. Having been forced away from the ideal of national legislation and towards a cooperative venture between the States, the Opposition is taking exception even to that.

This afternoon we are debating the National Road Transport Commission Bill 1991, which establishes the machinery to implement a national system of road laws for heavy vehicles and to recover—as the Minister has just said—the road costs which are presently accruing to the States as a result of the use of the road system by those vehicles. Specifically, the Bill sets up the National Road Transport Commission and the processes by which it has recommended the new laws and charges, and defines the Commission's relationship with the Ministerial Council to which it will give its recommendations, and Federal and State parliaments to which the Council will submit any consequential legislation.

The National Road Transport Commission Bill is the end result of a long process of research, inquiry and consultation, beginning with the report of the Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics on road cost recovery, which led to the Inter-State Commission inquiry which recommended that full cost recovery mechanisms be implemented. The report of the now defunct Inter-State Commission was refined by its former chair, Ted Butcher, and was developed further by the Commonwealth-State overarching group on land transport, under the umbrella of the Special Premiers Conference.

I interpolate, as the Minister has already done, that I find this position quite inconsistent for the Opposition which extols the virtues of market mechanisms and the extent that markets should be used for the efficient distribution and allocation of resources. The Democrats are also committed to the use of those market mechanisms. The basis of the market mechanism is that the user pays. That is what the Opposition is committed to and that is what it is now objecting to in this Bill.

I also interpolate here with respect to some of what economists call externalities, that these are not being included in this legislation. What is attempted here is simply the recovery of the road damage charges. But of course road transport also incurs considerable other expenses for the community in the form of deaths, injuries and environmental damage—both in terms of acid emissions which erode buildings and in the form of greenhouse gas emissions. None of those externalities are incorporated into this legislation. So even this legislation does not really look at full cost recovery.

The Australian Democrats support strongly the principle of road cost recovery. We believe an efficient and environmentally sound transport sector depends, amongst other things, on sending the right price signals to road users. That is why, despite our significant reservations about the detail of the Commonwealth-State agreement contained in this Bill, we have decided to support it.

Transport contributes about 40 per cent of Australia's emissions of greenhouse gases. If we do not come to grips with the challenge of reducing emissions from this sector, then there is no hope that Australia can meet its target of a 20 per cent reduction in greenhouse gas emissions; much less the ultimate goal of a 92 per cent reduction by the middle of next century. This ensures that the natural world—to say nothing of our children and our grandchildren—will have to face the impossible task of adapting to never-ending and accelerating climate change. This is a major factor in our support for full cost recovery for road vehicles and the development of an efficient and competitive rail system.

The Democrats have been lobbied intensively by representatives of the road transport industry and rural interest groups who are concerned about the impact of the proposed new charges on transport operators and regions which are heavily dependent upon road transport. They believe the new charges are inequitable because the input taxes and charges on the road transport industry are well above the average for all industry sectors and that raising the level of road charges will hit them with a double whammy. They believe many operators will be driven to the wall, particularly where foreign competition limits their ability to pass on the new charges to their customers. They believe rural communities will suffer serious economic difficulties as transport operators fold and local industries become less viable. The Democrats have not formed an opinion as to whether these claims are accurate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pity you didn't come to the hearing.

—I say to Senator Panizza that, like everyone else in this chamber, we are not transport economists. We have been confronted with conflicting advice from the industry and the Government. We have decided that there is a case to be answered. At a time of recession and great rural hardship we believe that these concerns must be addressed and any corrective measures taken as full cost recovery is set in motion. That is why we have initiated an inquiry by the Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure into the regional impacts of full cost recovery and whether the total imposts of taxes and charges on the road transport industry warrant adjustments being made as full cost recovery is implemented. This is not a six-hour inquiry involving a few selected witnesses but a lengthy inquiry involving a full range of people who may be affected by this legislation.

PARA.TAB: We do not support the call by the Opposition for us to join with it in blocking this legislation. It has taken an unnecessary, crude and counter-productive approach. To reject this legislation would be to throw the baby out with the bath water. Not only would the proposed new charges be derailed but so too would the development of uniform national road laws—in the first instance, for heavy vehicles, and probably and hopefully for light vehicles in the near future. In other words, the Opposition, which claims to be the standard bearer for micro-economic reform, is proposing to block the development of an efficient transport industry. This is sheer irresponsibility on the Opposition's part.

As I have said, the Opposition believes in the operation of the market which necessarily involves the user pays principle. That is how the market is supposed to efficiently allocate the use of resources. As the Opposition knows full well, the Senate will have every right and opportunity to reject the proposed new road charges when they are presented to us as part of the package of road transport legislation to be recommended by the Commission, a point which the Government acknowledges and accepts.

Later I will be moving an amendment to the second reading motion to make it quite clear that passage of this Bill does not imply support for the subsequent road transport legislation. There is simply no need to reject this entire Bill at this time when the charges are the major bone of contention. The Opposition dog has allowed itself to be wagged by the National Party tail.

TALK.START.PARA: —And we are very proud of it too, thank you very much.

—Senator O'Chee is very proud of that. He is pleased to be described as the National Party tail which wags the Opposition dog. The inconsistency of the Opposition's economic policy has been well canvassed by the Minister. One need only point out to Senator Boswell, who is also in the chamber, that the other day he was caught out in relation to tariff reductions in the Opposition's Fightback package as well.

PARA.TAB: Opposition speakers in this debate have expended a great deal of energy in attacking the Democrats over an inability to attend last Wednesday's meeting of the Transport, Communications and Infrastructure Committee to consider this Bill. I want to put a few facts on the record in relation to this matter. Last Wednesday's meeting was organised at very short notice, having been changed several times in the preceding few days. As should be well known to Committee members, Senator Powell, our transport spokesman, is on compassionate leave and was not able to attend. She had given the carriage of this Bill to me but I had a prior engagement which I felt was very important to honour, as many other senators have had from time to time.

Furthermore, the agreement that had been reached between ourselves and the Government to amend the Bill and establish the inquiry meant that last Wednesday's meeting had been made somewhat redundant. We were therefore concerned—and are still concerned —that the Opposition had unilaterally invited a large number of witnesses, some of whom travelled a long distance at their own expense, to a meeting which would not achieve any formal outcome. It sat for six hours to achieve what I achieved with them in 10 minutes. It should have been blindingly obvious to the Opposition from our press release of last Tuesday, the day before its meeting, that it would have been much more constructive to hear from its witnesses next year in the context of the inquiry, which has already been agreed to. It nevertheless chose to proceed with its invitations. It was a matter of great concern to me that the witnesses who attended in good faith clearly understood that the Democrats are very interested to hear from them, particularly in the context of the inquiry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not so interested as to go to the meeting. You should have attended.

—A brief meeting between 15 of those witnesses from the road transport industry representatives and myself was organised before the public hearing and a written statement was circulated to those attending to outline our position and apologise for our inability to attend. I am pleased to say that we have received a very positive response from the industry and from rural representatives to our initiative on this Bill.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Burns)—Order! Senator Coulter listened in reasonable silence to other people. I would ask honourable senators to please extend the same courtesy to him.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is talking rubbish; they were talking sense.
—I will make the decision on whether I think that.
—Give us your opinion now.
—I think it is fairly lucid actually.
—We have given an undertaking not to form a position on the new charges until the inquiry—
—We have voted against them.

—The Opposition has not voted against them because they have not been determined. Senator Boswell obviously does not understand the legislation that is before him. We have given an undertaking not to form a position on the new charges until the inquiry has reported and the Government has responded, and we will honour that commitment. Even though we support full cost recovery, we will approach the inquiry with an open mind.

PARA.TAB: The real reason we are being attacked by the Opposition is that we have come up with a position which is more constructive and sensible than its position. Our position has won general acceptance in the constituency which the National Party fervently believes is its and its alone. We have pulled the rug from under it and it does not like it. Its response is to look for any excuse to attack the Democrats and try to discredit us in the eyes of the rural community and the road transport industry. It is wasting its breath, and it knows it.

I return to the substance of the Bill. The reason I seek to insert those several paragraphs is quite simply that a lot of hot air on the part of the Opposition has been wasted this afternoon in attacking that Wednesday meeting. The overriding problem is that the Bill is the product of new federalism, something which the Opposition supports. The Democrats accept that a cooperative approach to transport micro-reform is necessary but it also creates very considerable problems. If I can interpolate here, it seems to me that there is a reasonable hope that, while this legislation may achieve a great deal in terms of substance, the working of the legislation may reveal the stupid approach which has been taken through new federalism. Before too long there will be true national legislation in this area, which is the way I believe that this matter should be handled.

One problem is that the bulk of the Bill is taken up by a schedule containing the Commonwealth-State agreement. That schedule cannot be amended by this or any State Parliament, which fairly limits parliamentary oversight, something I thought the Opposition would have been concerned about. Either we pass the Bill more or less intact or we throw it out; there is no middle course. This Bill extends the power of the Special Premiers Conference to an unacceptable extent because it is drafted in such a way that amendments to the agreement do not need to be submitted to parliament for approval. This has been identified by the Senate Standing Committee on the Scrutiny of Bills as an inappropriate delegation of power. We will be moving an amendment to remove it, which the Government has agreed to support and the Opposition has proposed independently of us.

The agreement has also pre-empted the work of the Commission by dividing the country into low cost and high cost zones for the purpose of charging. The Australian Democrats believe that those States which have demanded this concession have done so for political reasons, unrelated to cost recovery principles. The proposal for charges to be levied on vehicles travelling between zones will, in all likelihood, prove to be an administrative nightmare. We support the Minister's suggestion that the Commission take a long, hard look at the zonal system.

It has been claimed by representatives of the road transport industry that they will be paying for road construction and maintenance performed by inefficient State authorities over which they have no control. The Democrats note that this matter is the subject of a House of Representatives inquiry and that the States have a duty to tackle inefficiencies as road cost recovery is phased in. We have no doubt that the road transport industry will use its very substantial resources to keep the pressure on for reform in this area.

The Democrats do not accept the argument that the Commission is tied to a rigid formula for calculating road charges that makes it unable to develop more equitable processes. The agreement merely sets out an initial method based on the proposed work of the BTCE, the Inter-State Commission and the Special Premiers Conference. We believe that it is entirely appropriate that this be the Commission's starting point and that it not be asked to re-invent the wheel. However, the agreement will allow ample scope for the method to be refined and changed in the light of new information. We would ask the Minister to confirm this. It has been argued that the Commission's terms of reference are too narrow and that it cannot take into account the general environment of taxes and charges in which the road transport industry operates in setting charges for road cost recovery.

The Democrats do not believe that the Commission can reasonably be asked to make comparisons across industries. That is the role of relevant government departments. We have every reason to believe that the forthcoming inquiry will spur this process along. The Commission's terms of reference have also been criticised for their failure to require consideration of regional impacts of new road charges. Our reading of the agreement suggests that the Commission can examine regional impacts, an interpretation which has been confirmed to us by the Government. Nevertheless, we believe that the Senate inquiry should examine this question to ensure that our consideration of the new charges is well-informed and to allow affected parties to address their concerns directly to their elected representatives.

The Government has expressed the view to us that the inquiry is a legitimate part of the process. The Democrats believe that this Bill is, overall, an important initiative for which the Government deserves credit. We would urge the Government to take the next step and seek the agreement of the States to expand the Commission's role to include the development of a national registration scheme for light vehicles under which fixed registration and third party insurance fees are abolished and instead are recovered as an additional component of fuel excise.

The point here is that members of the Opposition are seeking to remove that excise at the precise time when Australia has a very large and rapidly increasing foreign debt. We are importing $3.11 billion worth of petroleum products, most of which are used for transport, at a time when we are recognising the need to cut down our use of fossil fuels generally, specifically petroleum.

TALK.START.PARA: —You want to raise it, though.
—Yes, go nuclear.
—You want to go back to horses and buggies.

—Those on the Opposition benches are the people who believe in the operation of a free market system: as the price is reduced, consumption is increased; as the price is increased, consumption is reduced. They are totally contradictory in their understanding of their own economic philosophy.

PARA.TAB: At the same time they are the people who will cut back public funding in areas such as public transport so that less public transport will be available. At the same time there will be a 15 per cent impost on public transport fares, further forcing up the consumption of petroleum and further disadvantaging both the individuals and industry in this country. We regard the shifting of the fixed costs from car ownership to the usage of those vehicles as sensible. It would cost less to own a vehicle —I would have thought that would be appealing to the Opposition in terms of its support for the motor vehicle industry—and it would shift those charges on to a fuel levy.

There would be an ability to own a car more cheaply but a disadvantage in using that car for non-essential purposes and in encouraging the more efficient use of public transport in this country. The Opposition has no real understanding of an efficient transport industry—none whatsoever. We regard this as an essential reform initiative which would meet environmental objectives without an inflationary impact. We would simply be replacing one cost with another.

The establishment of the National Road Transport Commission lays the foundation for this long overdue reform. As I have said, the Democrats have reserved our decision on the new charges until the inquiry into regional and taxation issues is completed and the Government has responded to it. To make this commitment clear, I now move the second reading amendment standing in the name of the Australian Democrats.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I suggest that you foreshadow your amendment at this stage as there is one amendment before the Chair at present.
—I will not move it at this stage. I simply foreshadow that I will move it at a later stage.
—by leave—I claim to have been misrepresented and wish to make a personal explanation. Senator Coulter, in his rather idiotic delivery—
—Order! That is disparaging, and I suggest that you withdraw it.

—I withdraw, Mr Acting Deputy President. In his delivery, Senator Coulter claimed that Opposition members sought witnesses from all over Australia to appear before the inquiry. My colleagues will speak for themselves. But I tell this Senate that I certainly did not convince any witnesses to come from anywhere around Australia to appear before the inquiry. My comments in the speech I made in the second reading stage were based on information I had obtained from the submissions I had read and from my experience as a continuing operator in the transport industry.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, could I just raise a point for clarification with regard to procedures? You indicated that the appropriate course of action would be for Senator Coulter to foreshadow the second reading amendment. On that basis, I am just wondering at what stage I would have an opportunity to debate that foreshadowed motion.
—Order! I suggest that we dispose of your amendment one way or another. When Senator Coulter moves his amendment, you will be able to speak to it.
—Will there be an opportunity for debate at that stage?
—Yes.

—by leave—The fact that I have been granted leave means that I will not be able to speak on the National Road Transport Commission Bill, but I will be able to speak in generalities. I support the philosophical concept of federalism. I always have, and I always will.

PARA.TAB: There have been two difficulties. The first is that the States have never assumed their proper responsibilities. They have clung desperately to their rights and have abrogated their responsibilities. I can use the trite example that here we are 90 years after Federation and we cannot get six States to agree at what age kids should start school. If we cannot get that on the board, one despairs about the more sophisticated matters that require federalism and a sense of cooperation between the great States and the Territories that make up this country.

Having said that, it would seem to me that it would have been an exercise in futility even if they had reached agreement. In the past nine years we have had—other than the aberration of Mr Whitlam—the greatest centralist government this country has ever seen. We now have a future Prime Minister who had the audacity to say, in the process of sinking the Premiers Conference of this Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), that the States could not be trusted with taxing powers, that the States would be delinquent, that the States would be irresponsible. This is a man who gave us a million unemployed.

TALK.START.PARA: —This has got nothing to do with it.

—With respect, I am certain that it is. This was seen as the great leap forward by the Prime Minister. This was his vision for the future. This was going to be a new Australia. This was his vision for a different Australia.
—Do you want to talk about the Bill?

—This is about the Bill. The Bill purports to allow the States and the Territories to participate in the process. This is the last great leap forward by the Prime Minister; it has ended up as an absolute dud. It is the last shred of the Prime Minister's concept of federalism. We all know what happened to the bigger picture. We all know that the Premiers sought to have the Special Premiers Conference to give them real powers, to give them real teeth, to give them real involvement in national matters. The honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating), the future Prime Minister, ignominiously sank the Prime Minister, simply because he could see a cheap political point to be gained by doing so.

PARA.TAB: My objection to this legislation is not that it fails to address the question of user pays; it does not do that. It ignores the enormous amount of revenue that is already raised through excise. I believe that we have heard the Treasurer and the Prime Minister say that excise—

TALK.START.PARA: —All it does is set up a commission.

—Through you, Mr Deputy President, a government does not set up authorities and commissions and bodies unless it is going to give them a function. The function will ultimately be to ensure that there is a greater raising of revenue from the road transport industry than there is presently. The self-funding is to come out of licensing fees.

PARA.TAB: This Government wonders why it is in so much trouble. At a time when the Government is taking greater revenue, the Liberal Party is offering to give it back. Quaint as it might be, it was Senator Collins who suggested that to increase the zone allowance by 25 per cent was trivial.

TALK.START.PARA: —Eleven bucks a year.

—Eleven bucks a year, 11 bucks a week, 11 bucks a minute—$34m is going back to people who live in remote and isolated areas. That is a 25 per cent increase in the present rate set by this Government for zone allowances. If the Minister is arguing that 25 per cent is a modest increase, that simply means that the base figure is modest. At a time when the Government is increasing revenue, the Liberal Party is promising to reduce the cost of fuel, to abolish excise, to reduce the cost of living in the remote and isolated areas of Australia, and to reduce fringe benefits tax by 5 per cent.

PARA.TAB: This legislation will do nothing more than load up costs for the transport industry, which will pass the costs on to consumers wherever it can. The consumers most acutely affected will be those who live in remote and isolated areas. I do not believe that the legislation has any merit; I do not believe that it has any virtue; I do not believe that it has any place on the statute books.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Burns)—Order! As two additional speakers spoke by leave, I suggest that the Minister has a right to respond to any new material.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not a hope.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Chapman's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Amendment negatived.
Amendment (by Senator Coulter) proposed:
At end of motion, add ", and the Senate:
(a)affirms that passage of this Bill in no way guarantees passage of the Road Transport Legislation foreshadowed in the Schedule; and

(b)calls on the Government to address concerns about the level of taxation on the road transport industry and the economic and social impact on regional communities of full recovery of road costs incurred by heavy vehicles, and if necessary implement corrective measures".

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will not support this amendment moved by the Australian Democrats. The amendment which we moved earlier in the debate and which has just been voted on and defeated—because the Democrats chose to support the Government—really got to the nub of the issues of concern with regard to the National Road Transport Commission Bill. The amendment that has been moved by the Democrats does not. It lacks strength and it lacks purpose. Clause (a) of that amendment—which `affirms that passage of this Bill in no way guarantees passage of the Road Transport Legislation foreshadowed in the Schedule'—is simply a statement of the obvious. This Senate should consider each and every piece of legislation on its own merits. Therefore, of course, passage of this particular Bill in no way guarantees the passage of any subsequent legislation. As I said, clause (a) simply states the obvious.

PARA.TAB: It seems strange to me that the Democrats feel the need to state the obvious in this way. Perhaps they have been in bed so often with the Government that they are now starting to feel that they are being taken for granted by the Government and that the Government thinks that it has their unbridled support on each and every piece of legislation. They therefore feel the need to back away from that impression with clause (a) of this amendment to the second reading motion.
Clause (b) is simply a very pale and poor imitation of the second reading amendment which I have already moved on behalf of the Opposition and which has just been voted on.

In conclusion, the Democrats' amendment is nothing more than a last attempt by them to salve their consciences for selling out those Australians who are so dependent on the Australian transport industry for their livelihood and their supplies by supporting this Government legislation without adequate or critical analysis of it. We heard in Senator Coulter's earlier remarks quite pathetic excuses for the Democrats not being represented on the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure which inquired into this legislation and which heard strong and solid evidence as to why this legislation should not pass. So it is quite pathetic now for the Democrats to come in here and move this meaningless second reading amendment which will do nothing for the legislation—legislation which should be defeated in this chamber. For that reason, the Opposition will not support the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will very briefly address this amendment by the Australian Democrats. Obviously, this amendment reflects the deal that the Democrats reached with the Government or the Government reached with them at the beginning before the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, that committee of inquiry, the other night.
—What a load of tripe and onions.

—The Minister can have his go next. Obviously, that was the deal that was reached. Senator Coulter chose to ignore the transport industry around Australia and to blame us for bringing these people to Canberra on a false pretext. I suppose that that is his excuse and that he is allowed to stick to it, but the point is that he still claims that five days is not enough notice for Senator Coulter to attend an inquiry; so he spent 10 lousy minutes with it.

PARA.TAB: I would like to know why the Democrats bothered to include the first clause of this amendment. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . affirms that passage of this Bill in no way guarantees passage of the Road Transport Legislation foreshadowed in the Schedule.
If the Democrats can be taken on their track record in this place, they may as well have left that part right out. I do not take one iota of notice of it, because I just do not believe it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support my colleagues in their opposition to the amendment moved by Senator Coulter. I briefly draw the attention of the Senate to a major issue which I do not think has ever been properly canvassed in this debate, and certainly it is one of the reasons why we are very suspicious of the amendment that Senator Coulter has proposed. I refer to The Achievable Vision: Alternate Budget Proposals 1991-92, brought down by Senator Spindler on behalf of the Australian Democrats. The Senate may not appreciate this, but in this budget the Australian Democrats are seeking to raise $455m by a one per cent tonne-kilometre charge to be levied on all domestic road freight movements. Senator Coulter pretends that he is a friend of people in the road transport industry and of rural industry, yet in the famous alternative budget that Senator Spindler has brought down the Democrats have a vast range of taxes that will particularly hit the freight industry.

—I take this opportunity to draw the Senate's attention to the antediluvian views that Senator Kemp has just put on the record. If he thinks that to get a fair deal for our taxpayers we need to throw money at people that damage roads, then Senator Kemp of course has a point. If he wants to continue to use fossil fuels, which are running out at a fast rate, then of course he has a point. But that is where Senator Kemp is coming from. In the trade practices inquiry, he voted against competition.
—He is coming out of the primeval slime.
—Order on my left!
—Withdraw that one! Come on!
—Order, Senator O'Chee!
—I rest my case.
—He used unparliamentary—
—Senator O'Chee! I called you to order.
—I have a point of order.
—What is your point of order?
—On a point of order: there was clearly unparliamentary language from Senator Coulter and I ask that he withdraw it.
—You do not ask him to withdraw it; you ask the Chair to ask him to withdraw it.
—In that case, I ask you to ask him to withdraw it, Mr Deputy President.
—I did not hear it. I call Senator Spindler.
—Can I tell you what it was, Mr Deputy President?
—There is no point of order. I call Senator Spindler.
—I had finished my point, Mr Deputy President.
—I call the Minister.

—Mr Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. Do I understand by what you have just said on that ruling that, should some offensive language be used in this place—I did not hear the language, and I do not know that it was—

The first amendment relates to clause 3 of the Bill 1991 and specifically to the proposed definition of `Agreement', which reads:

. . . means the agreement made on 30 July 1991 between the Commonwealth, the States and the Australian Capital Territory, a copy of which is set out in the Schedule, or, if that agreement has been amended or affected by another agreement, that agreement as so amended or affected.
The effect of our amendment is to remove all words after `Schedule', which means that we are removing the words:
. . . or, if that agreement has been amended or affected by another agreement, that agreement as so amended or affected.

The effect of this is to require any changes to the agreement to be approved by this Parliament. In other words, if our amendment is accepted by the Committee, the agreement which has already been approved will not be able to be changed without the approval of this Parliament.

PARA.TAB: The second amendment is to clause 8 and has a similar intent. Subclause 8(2) of the Bill reads:
A consent for the purposes of paragraph (1)(e) or (f) is to be given by resolution of the Ministerial Council carried in accordance with the Agreement.

SPEECH.PARA: Paragraphs (1)(e) and (1)(f) of clause 8 relate to the functions and powers of the Commission and state:
(e)functions and powers that are, with the consent of the Ministerial Council, conferred on the Commission by writing signed by the Minister;
(f)functions and powers that are, with the consent of the Ministerial Council, expressed to be conferred on the Commission by writing signed by:

PARA.TAB: (i)a Minister of the Crown of a State that is a party to the Agreement; or

TAB.TAB: (ii)a Minister of a Territory that is a party to the Agreement.

SPEECH.PARA: The effect of our amendment is to add after the word `Agreement' at the end of subclause 8(2) the following words:

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief, because I have not abandoned all hope yet that we can actually conclude this legislation by 6.30 p.m. The Government will support the first Opposition amendment, and we have indicated that to the Opposition and to the Democrats and, as Senator Coulter has pointed out, the Democrats quite independently were intending to move this way, in any case.
