PARA.TAB: We will not be supporting the second amendment. The reason is that paragraphs (e) and (f) of clause 8(1) are intended to merely facilitate the Commission in the performance of its functions, which—and this is the important point—are only advisory in nature. The functions and powers that may be conferred by Executive action are limited to those that come within the Executive power of government, such as powers to make inquiries, to form opinions about questions of policy and to make reports or non-binding recommendations.

It would be inappropriate and time-consuming for such actions to be disallowable instruments for the purposes of section 46A of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901, particularly as resultant decisions of the ministerial council will be subject to parliamentary scrutiny through the normal legislative processes. The amendment proposed is not in the spirit of the cooperative approach encompassed in the decision under the heads of government agreement to establish the Commission. I further add, simply to clarify this matter beyond dispute, and for the benefit of the Democrats who have raised this concern with us: as was explained in the Government's response to the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, the powers that can be referred by Executive action do not include power to compel people to supply information or documents or to make recommendations which have legal effect. These are powers that cannot be conferred on the Commission other than by legislative means.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts I present the 313th report of the Committee entitled Control of visitor entry. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to incorporate my tabling statement in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Introduction
This is the second and final report on the Committee's inquiry into the business migration program and control of visitor entry.

The need for two reports arose after the inquiry commenced in June 1990. The initial response to the inquiry expressed so much concern about the operation of the business migration program that the Committee decided it would examine that program before looking at matters relating to the control of visitor entry.
The Committee presented its report on the business migration program to Parliament in June of this year and then began its examination of control of visitor entry.

This inquiry arose from criticisms made by the Auditor-General of visa issue and entry operations administered in the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (or DILGEA). The Auditor-General found control weaknesses, procedural breakdowns and systems deficiencies which created a serious inherent risk that entry could be granted to people contrary to the national interest.

For this inquiry, the Committee received 57 submissions and held three public hearings. It also conducted inspections at the entry control point, international terminal, Kingsford Smith Airport, Sydney, and at the Entry Operations Centre in Canberra.

The Committee was aware that the administration of the entry of visitors to Australia is fraught with difficulties. The importance of tourism to the economy, and the legitimate expectations of all Australians that overseas family and friends should be able to enter the country easily as visitors, are important considerations. They must be balanced against the need to prevent the entry of undesirable persons, such as terrorists and criminals, and those who seek to "jump the queue" to enter and remain in Australia illegally.

The number of visitors to Australia has been steadily increasing. Since 1984/85 there has been an average increase of 20% in the number of visitor and temporary entry visas issued each year. In 1990/91 alone, more than 1.48 million visas were issued.

DILGEA has developed a range of databases which allow it not only to control entry but also to have accurate knowledge of who is in the country and whether that person is a legal or an illegal entrant. In 1990/91, over 9000 illegal entrants were located; of these, over 4000 had their departures enforced and over 700 were deported.

In April 1991, it was estimated there were 78,000 illegal entrants in Australia. Although the number of overstayers is small against the overall number of visas issued, it is a matter of concern to the Committee that some of these people, both students and other groups, are involved in serious crime in Australia.

The Committee believes that appropriate means have been and are being taken to reduce the number of people who overstay their visa period. It notes that additional resources have been provided in the 1991/92 Budget and has recommended that these resource levels be maintained in real terms to reduce even further the number of overstayers in this country.

The Committee is aware that there are legitimate reasons why a person who holds an Australian passport may wish to travel on another passport. However, the Committee believes that Australian citizens should always use their Australian passports when entering or leaving Australia. Therefore, the Committee has recommended amendment to the Migration Act 1958.
Furthermore, the Committee believes it should be an offence under the Act for Australian citizens not to use their Australian passports when entering or leaving the country.

Evidence given to the Committee highlighted problems which arise when, after the forfeiture of an Australian passport, holders of dual passports could still leave the country. The capacity exists within DILGEA's databases for information to be stored and retrieved on holders of more than one passport.
The Committee considers this information could be used more efficiently than at present.

The Committee has recommended that the databases maintained by DILGEA and the Australian Customs Service be searched for dual passport holdings, and that an emergency alert be placed on these databases to prevent the departure from Australia of the holder of a surrendered Australian passport leaving on any other passport.

When Australian citizens apply for Australian passports, they must provide details of citizenship of any other country. The Committee suggests that, before passports are issued, databases maintained by DILGEA and the Australian Customs Service be searched for information on whether applicants hold additional passports.

While the number of persons entering Australia temporarily and committing serious crimes is small against total numbers of visas issued, the Committee noted that it was not possible to establish actual numbers or the categories by which such persons gained entry. Accordingly, we have recommended the establishment of a working party to establish procedures to measure the extent of this criminal activity. This working party should examine policing problems, the type of criminal activities undertaken, any geographical concentrations and any multi-agency action which should be taken to deal with these activities.

The Immigration Records and Information System, or IRIS, is a database which creates a record of the application for a visa, checks the application against alert lists and prints a visa. IRIS has been developed in two phases and the first version has now been installed in 48 posts overseas which issue 95% of visitor visas. It is expected to be introduced in all posts by the end of 1992.

To provide an effective immigration screen, we believe the remaining high/small volume posts should be equipped with IRIS as a matter of priority. The Committee has recommended that IRIS be installed in all overseas posts as soon as possible.

We believe that the efficiency of the migrant alert list would be improved by the establishment of a two-way communications link with overseas posts and have recommended that such a link be established as soon as possible.

Passenger cards are completed by persons entering or leaving Australia and the information provided is used by a number of authorities. We believe these cards serve a useful purpose and have recommended they be retained.

Pre-visa assessment is a means of screening applicants for student visas from countries which have a high risk of overstaying those visas. Introduction of this assessment has had a major impact in controlling student entry because it acts as a bona fide test and includes an assessment of financial viability.

The Committee believes that pre-visa assessment of applicants for student entry should continue and that a test of financial viability should be one of the criteria for that assessment. We believe it is particularly important that such assessments of students enrolling in non-formal courses be rigorously maintained.

The Committee notes that pre-visa assessment is currently under review by a working party made up of DILGEA and the departments of Employment, Education and Training and Foreign Affairs and Trade. We have recommended that this working party review pre-visa assessment for short, non-formal studies, including the retention of prepayment of fees, introduction of bonds or bank guarantees as a financial viability test in the assessment.

Our final recommendation deals with the possible use of asylum provisions in the Migration Act 1958 by persons holding student visas. Statistics on asylum seekers are compiled against the applicant's country of origin, but there is no record of the category of entry by which an applicant entered Australia. The Committee has recommended that statistics on asylum seekers include an analysis of the categories under which they gained entry to Australia.

The Committee acknowledges that the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs has been working towards an effective system to control visitor entry. We believe our recommendations will make that system work more efficiently.
I commend the report to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent me moving the following motion:
`That the Senate:

(a)notes that the Australian Labor Party has rewarded the architect of the recession and the principal cause of the misery being suffered by 900,000 unemployed Australians and their families with the highest office of Government; and
(b)is of the view that, in recognition of such appalling judgement, 19 December 1991 shall be forthwith known as a national day of shame.'

SPEECH.PARA: It is incredible that the once great Australian Labor Party would reward the architect of the recession with the office of Prime Minister. This person is principally responsible for nearly one million unemployed Australians and all the misery being suffered by them and their families, of another 500,000 who have given up looking for work, and those who are underemployed. A total of 31 per cent of young Australians are unemployed and are looking for work unsuccessfully. It is amazing that the person principally responsible for this shocking state of affairs in this nation would be rewarded by this Government with the office of Prime Minister. It is important, therefore, that this motion be debated tonight because the consequences for Australia are too horrible to contemplate.

PARA.TAB: This was the man who claimed to know it all economically. This was the man who basically designed and claimed credit for the recession. He was the man who said, `This was the recession we had to have'. He was the one who gave us interest rates and inflation rates well beyond those of our competitors. He designed the J curve and all these other exotic economic expressions and basically produced an economic environment which has resulted in so much misery and suffering.

What does this man get for that achievement? Members of the Labor Party make him Prime Minister. They throw out their successful Prime Minister who won four separate elections and give him the reward of being booted out while still in office. They then put into office the principal architect of the recession, the person responsible for the horrible state of affairs that exists presently in this country.

How could that occur? How could these people be so silly? How could they not find a third party if they are sick and tired of Mr Hawke? How could they put Mr Keating before the Australian people as a credible Prime Minister in the light of his economic record and the suffering that he has caused?

As a result of this action, we are of the view that today will be known in the history of Australia as a day of shame. It will be known as the day on which the appalling state of the Labor Party was finally recognised. The consequences that Australia will suffer as a result of it are too great to contemplate.

I move this motion as a matter of regret. We do not understand how members of the Labor Party could have been so foolish. They have demonstrated tonight that they deserve to be thrown out of office. The sooner that happens the better.
Opposition senators interjecting—

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

—I am disappointed, because if the Opposition were serious about a motion such as this we would have got more than a two and a half minute speech from its leader. —He was never asked to apologise.

—I thought what he did was tantamount to that. Were it not for that, Mr Deputy President, I think you would have been justified in proceeding further under the Standing Orders. But I certainly defend the initial decision you made. Were it not for the explanation given by Senator Kemp, I think you would have been justified in seeking to take further action. I speak to the standing order raised by Senator Archer, and I suggest we get on with the business before us.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Coulter

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, when Senator Archer spoke on this point of order, he seemed to be implying that the various clauses under standing order 203(1) were connected by the word `and'. The clauses stand quite separately, and the fulfilment of any one of those clauses satisfies the requirement of standing order 203. It is made absolutely clear indeed where the word `or' appears.

PARA.TAB: I support what Senator McMullan has said. The condition has been fulfilled. Paragraph (3) goes on to say that the senator should be called upon to make an explanation or apology. We have heard an explanation; we have not heard an apology. It continues:

INTERJECT.PARA: . . . a motion may be moved that the Senator be suspended . . .

PARA.TAB: That Senator Kemp be suspended from the sitting of the Senate.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Coulter, there was a great deal of background noise. Could I ask you what you said?

—In accordance with the second part of paragraph (3) of standing order 203, I have moved that Senator Kemp be suspended from the service of the Senate. I remind you, Mr Deputy President, that no amendment, adjournment or debate shall be entered into and therefore the motion should be put forthwith.
—Mr Deputy President—
—I have a motion before the Chair and no amendment—
—I will raise a fresh point of order.

—Order! You will take a seat when the Chair is standing. No amendment, adjournment or debate is allowed on such a motion and it is to be put immediately by the person in the chair. I put the question that Senator Coulter's motion be agreed to. Those of that opinion say aye, of the contrary no—
—Point of order, Mr Deputy President—
—I am putting the question.
—Mr Deputy President, you put the question. You asked Senator Coulter when other people were on their feet.
- Order! The question is that Senator Coulter's motion be agreed to.

PARA.TAB: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Kemp is accordingly suspended from the sitting of the Senate for the remainder of this day.

TAB.EMPHASIS: Senator Kemp thereupon withdrew from the chamber.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I believe that Senator Hill's motion deserves support. Tonight is a night of infamy for the Australian Labor Party—a night of desperation where the Labor Party has tried to throw out a leader who has won it four elections on the trot. In a desperate stand to gain—
—And they are laughing.
—Those opposite are sitting there laughing and, in a desperate effort to gain popularity, they have destroyed a man who has won four elections on the trot for them.
—Mr Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. Senator Boswell has a contribution to make and it should be heard in silence.
—On a point of order, Mr Deputy President: Senator Aulich is laughing. Name him, please.
—Order! Senator O'Chee, if you try to raise frivolous points of order like that, I will deal with you as well.
—On a point of order—
—What is your point of order?

—Mr Deputy President, the people on the other side are laughing as loudly as Senator Kemp was laughing before. It is very clearly the case that the rules of this chamber, I respectfully submit to you, have to be applied fairly and equally. If we are going to have laughter from that side, I suggest that Government senators should be named as well.
—Senator Boswell.

—I was saying that this is the night that will be remembered as a disgrace to the Labor Party; the night on which it has thrown out a Prime Minister who has won four elections on the trot, in a desperate effort to regain popularity with the Australian people. I can tell Government senators now that it is an act of desperation that has no value. They have replaced a man who could lead with a man who is more unpopular than anyone in the Labor Party. They have taken this action because they think that, if they just throw Mr Hawke from the sleigh, they will win popularity again.

—Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Senator Boswell should address the issue before the Chair, which is the suspension of Standing Orders. He is attempting to address a substantive issue which is not before the chamber.
—Order! I uphold the point of order. Please continue, Senator Boswell.
—I am trying to address the motion before the Chair that Senator Hill introduced, and it needs to be debated. This man who has wrought havoc, this previous Treasurer who has—
—Order! The time for the debate has expired. I put Senator Hill's motion for the suspension of Standing Orders.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Hill's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate has no confidence in the Deputy President (Senator Colston).

SPEECH.PARA: I move this motion with regret.

TALK.START.PARA: —You shouldn't move it at all.
—Order! There will be no interjections.

—This is not the first time that the Deputy President has lost the confidence of this side of the chamber, but it is the first time that we have taken this action. We have done so because of the extraordinary action of the Deputy President tonight. I have been here for 10 years and, apart from one occasion late at night, due to an unfortunate mixture of circumstances—
—Drinks.

PARA.TAB: Government senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is offensive to Senator Walters. No person has been named.
—Senator Walsh has.

—I am talking about senators on our side. It seems that Senator Kemp was named tonight because he laughed in an environment where he was more than entitled to laugh. As Senator Kemp said, he had every reason to laugh at the presentation of Senator Richardson and he had every reason to laugh at the behaviour of the Labor Party today. How is laughing disorderly under standing order 203? Is it persistently and wilfully obstructing the business of the Senate? No-one could say that Senator Kemp did that. Is it disorderly conduct? Surely it is not disorderly conduct within the normal meaning of that expression. He certainly did not use objectionable words. He certainly did not wilfully refuse to conform with the Standing Orders. He did not wilfully disregard the authority of the Chair by laughing at Senator Richardson. He was well within what can be fairly expected in a debate of this nature in this chamber.

PARA.TAB: The truth is that the Deputy President lost control. He saw that the only way of getting himself out of that difficulty was to throw someone out. That is not the level of performance that the Senate should be entitled to expect from the Deputy President. As I have said, other circumstances have occurred in recent times where this side of the chamber has been particularly unhappy with the performance of the Deputy President, but we have not moved in this way because it is obviously not a course of action which we would desire to take. Tonight it is beyond all sense of reason. Therefore, we see no alternative but to take this action.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are entering a difficult time in the pre-Christmas period where a lot of business is to be conducted by the Senate and a lot of parties are being conducted outside, I guess.

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. I do not want to embellish the point of order I am about to make, but when we were at the old Parliament House there was an occasion where Senator Button alleged that a member of the Liberal Party was found drunk on the lawn. It took months and months for Senator Button to withdraw that statement and apologise. I hope that he is not again making an assertion of a very colourful nature which reflects improperly upon members on our side. I do not know whether the Labor Party has been imbued with a sense of disaster or ecstasy. I ask that Senator Button withdraw any imputation on senators on this side.
—And sober up before you keep going.
—Senator Macdonald would be one to talk.

—Order! I am not going to let this get out of control. I heard Senator Button make a reference to parties; he did not make a reference to a party on any particular side of the chamber. That is why I did not take offence.
—Thank you for your ruling, Mr President. I made no reference to any political party. Senator Crichton-Browne rose in a manner which reminded me of the cap fitting—
—Mr President, I rise on a point of order.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many unparliamentary remarks coming from behind Senator Crichton-Browne. I think this should be a reasonable debate.

—With respect, Mr President, it is not for me to make judgments about the unparliamentary comments being made behind me. It is always regrettable that when Senator Button is backed into a corner we have vicious, nasty little comments flowing so freely from his mouth. With respect, if Senator Button continues to reflect improperly upon the integrity and conduct of senators on this side, you will continue to get proper points of order.
—I made no reflection on members of the Opposition in the remarks that I made. For anybody who is sensitive about that, I repeat that I made no remarks which reflected exclusively on the Opposition.

PARA.TAB: We are reaching the end of this session of the Parliament and, of course, there is still business to be considered. Earlier this evening the Opposition sought to contrive, in the absence of any interest in the community outside, a motion to suspend Standing Orders. I think the community would be concerned to see that the Senate completed its business. That is what the community would be concerned about; that is what the community would expect of the Senate tonight. Tonight the Opposition moved a motion to suspend Standing Orders to enable a debate—in the interests of being seen as politically virile—concerning the new Prime Minister of this country. That was the issue which was before the Senate.

Subsequent to that, in relation to that debate and vote in respect of Senator Kemp's exclusion from the chamber, Senator Hill got up and moved that Senator Colston no longer had the confidence of the Senate. He said, `I move this motion with regret'. So he ought to move it with regret, because it is almost unprecedented in terms of the deliberations of the Senate. This almost unprecedented motion—and I am sorry that it has been moved tonight—has been moved tonight because of the failure of the previous motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is nonsense. You should withdraw that.

—Senator Crane says that is nonsense. I would have thought that his behaviour was transparent. In terms of Senator Colston's ruling, managing a chamber such as this, as Senator Colston was doing, in very difficult circumstances when there is acrimonious debate taking place, is not an easy task. Senator Colston, as Deputy President, is entitled to make judgments about these matters which, unless they are horrendously out of line with the Standing Orders, should be respected by the Senate. I believe that his judgments were and are respected by a majority of the Senate.
—You weren't here to see it.

—I said that they were respected by a majority of the Senate, and it is a majority of the Senate that is important in determining this issue. Senator Hill made all sorts of allegations about the Opposition being unhappy with Senator Colston's performance, not just tonight but on previous occasions. We have not heard about it before in terms of a motion of this kind. This is the first time that a motion of this kind has been moved by the Leader of the Opposition—and it is moved with regret!
—You were overseas again.

—Senator Macdonald says that I was overseas. That is a brilliant conclusion. He should not get too excited about that. Of course the Government will not contemplate this action by the Opposition. We have confidence in the Deputy President of this Senate. The majority of the Senate has confidence in him, and I think that the matter ought to be resolved as quickly as possible.

—I have served in this chamber now for almost six years. During that time I have had the opportunity to observe the great degree of difficulty and strain that can attach to presiding over the conduct of this chamber. Former Senator Doug McClelland, your predecessor, Mr President, performed remarkably well, and on this side there was a very high degree of support for and acceptance of his performance. For our own part, we had former Senator Hamer as Deputy President who, again, showed a great deal of sense and discretion.

PARA.TAB: I have to say that you, Mr President, have done a very good job in almost every situation that you have been placed in. There are times, of course, when difficulties arise and we will have our disagreements but, by and large, you have demonstrated the flexibility and tolerance that is an essential part of presiding over this chamber.

That is why it is with great regret that we have to say that Senator Colston has simply not measured up to that task. On the one hand, he has sought to throw his weight around in such a way that he demeans the office of Deputy President. He brings the chamber into disrepute by rising inappropriately, quite often ahead of time and, as tonight amply demonstrates, with no regard to the circumstances.

One would have thought that a person in politics would be acutely sensitive to matters of high drama and, indeed, melodrama. Surely tonight is one such occasion when, for the first time in history, the Labor Party has thrown out not only its most successful leader but also a Prime Minister that it has previously regarded very highly. I cannot imagine a more charged atmosphere. Yet Senator Colston purports to act as though this is just another debate, just another discussion amongst competing forces, and something that does not deserve even to have an exchange of views, an exchange of interjections and an exchange of laughter.

All those things are part of the give and take in this place—part and parcel of making democracy work. In almost every instance, the Chair—you, in particular, Mr President—has been flexible enough to allow that to happen. The great tragedy of Senator Colston's misrule and the way in which he has presided—not just on this occasion; it was also amply demonstrated in the way that he reacted with Senator Baume—was the fact that he overreacted in the first instance and then made a complete fool of himself by backing off. If he had any guts he would have proceeded with the sort of motion that we have been forced to tonight by the treachery of the Democrats.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not all of them.
—I agree entirely. Again, that is a double tragedy, because the way Senator Coulter performed was such that he did not even seem to understand the basis—
—That's keeping the bastards honest, is it?

—There is not much honesty at the top in the Democrats, and we have known that for quite some time. That is just part of the side tragedy. The real tragedy is that we have had in this chamber a Deputy President who is clearly incompetent. It gives us no joy to say that, because I think we are all prepared to accept that in the heat of the moment one can make mistakes and that one does need to back off from time to time. I thought that Senator Ray gave a very good example of that tonight. Quite clearly he did not want matters to go in the direction that they did, but there was no conception on the part of the Deputy President that somehow there was a need to resolve the matter.

PARA.TAB: It would have been quite permissible for him to have invited the Democrats to back off or to have somehow accepted the explanation given by Senator Kemp. But we had a succession of errors on the part of the Deputy President: not even beginning to comprehend that a senator is entitled to natural justice and is entitled to know on what basis he has been warned and then named; demanding that somehow Senator Kemp had to give an apology when clearly the Standing Orders do not require that; not really heeding the explanation given and not being prepared to accept that there were circumstances that would justify overlooking any minor misdemeanour, which is about as high as one could possibly place it; and, again, singling out someone who, from where I sat, committed no greater offence than probably half of this chamber has done tonight.

That is why it is such a sad state of affairs. The Deputy President does not have the confidence of the chamber when suddenly someone is singled out for behaviour that almost everyone else would regard as fair and reasonable in the fairly highly charged circumstances of the night. That is where judgment is required. That is where discretion is required. Senator Colston manifestly lacks both of those qualities. He has been given an opportunity over a long period to demonstrate that he can learn on the job, that he can use tact and discretion and that he can familiarise himself with Standing Orders. But what we have found time and again is that he has no understanding of Standing Orders—he constantly has to have them explained to him by the Clerk—and generally he demonstrates an inability to handle the affairs of the chamber. That is a very sad state of affairs, and that is what brings us to the position we are in tonight.

We are very much united behind Senator Kemp. We do not regard him as having committed any offence—certainly not within the terms of standing order 203(e) in relation to persistently and wilfully disregarding the Chair. If what Senator Kemp did tonight—whether or not one regards it as more than laughing—is somehow characterised as persistently and wilfully disregarding the Chair, we might as well close up shop and go home. Everyone would be guilty of an offence every five minutes.

Mr President, you know that in Question Time there is a fair bit of give and take. I do not mind that—I do not mind giving it and I do not mind taking it—and, by and large, we get by. Some people cannot keep quiet for five seconds. They come and ask, `Are you moving an amendment?' If one says, `No', they say, `I will speak for no more than 60 seconds'. The Minister went for six minutes on that occasion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have never said 60 seconds.

—The Minister said he would take one minute. That is the sort of thing that we tolerate. Senator Ray can get up and thump the table and carry on, and we accept it. Senator Richardson can go through the sort of mealy-mouthed performance we had tonight. We know that he does not believe a word of it. We know what sort of machinations have been undertaken over the last six weeks or so. Again, we cop it. Unless we are prepared to have that spirit, this place cannot work. That is why we are reluctantly driven to the position that we take tonight. Mr President, we cannot go on in this way. You brought matters to a resolution on another issue because you took the view that things simply could not go on the way they were, and we take the same view tonight.

—Often in this chamber when we come to debate Standing Orders we refer to a most important one that is not there, and that is that common sense shall prevail. A couple of phrases were used by the two Opposition spokesmen tonight. They said that today has been an extraordinary day, and certainly it has been. Senator Alston said that there should be a lot of give and take in the chamber, and I agree with that. I was here for the whole debate and I think that in my time in the Senate I have not heard so much noise coming from one side of the chamber as we did tonight.
—You are joking.

—No, I think that is a fact. I can understand why, and I do not condemn the reasons for that noise, joy and so on. It was not a question tonight of the odd interjection floating across the chamber, but of an absolute barrage.
—Of laughter.

—No, not just of laughter; a whole range of things were said. The second thing that disturbed me in the behaviour tonight was that, irrespective of what the other side of the chamber or this side of the chamber may evaluate in a Presiding Officer, it is the fact that when Presiding Officers get to their feet there should then be silence. There was not that silence tonight; the barrage continued.
—He had lost confidence.

—Senator Alston says that he has lost confidence. But if the Chairman gets to his feet because he cannot establish order, silence should prevail. Those opposite know that that is the practice. Certainly that did not happen tonight. It has been said that Senator Kemp was picked out. I heard Senator Hill warned, I heard Senator MacGibbon warned, I saw Senator Kemp warned, and later saw Senator Calvert warned.
—All on this side. Isn't that funny?
—Senator Bishop says that it was all on her side but, with respect, I would say that 95 per cent of the noise tonight, because some of us are a bit down, came from the other side.

PARA.TAB: Where this particular issue got away from us is that, immediately Senator Kemp was named, I think I made the point that we should hear an explanation. We then started to have a variety of points of order. At that point Senator McMullan intervened, made a contribution and said `Let's get on with it'. Everyone on this side of the chamber assumed that that was the end of the issue. I did not even realise that Senator Coulter was talking to the point of order and then he moved the motion. I have to say that the Deputy President had no choice but to put it. The Standing Orders gave us no chance to intervene to try to apply some common sense, or to apply some sort of interpretation to what Senator Kemp had said. I took Senator Kemp's explanation as probably being sufficient. But when the motion was put we had no alternative but to back up the Deputy President.

It will be said that at that point the Deputy President could have backed off, but he could not. Once the motion is moved, the Deputy President must put it. That again goes to the point where traditionally those sorts of motions are moved from this end of the chamber. Rarely on some occasions they are moved from about where Senator Alston sits. I must say that that tradition should continue. However, we have been through an experience before in which a Presiding Officer some years ago named a disorderly senator, and I do not comment on the circumstances—

TALK.START.PARA: —Please do. Don't spare her.
—No, I am not picking on anyone, but this chamber did not back up the Presiding Officer and I think that this chamber was at fault.
—Because they had gone home.
—Exactly, we concede that, but it is very difficult for most people in the chamber not to back up the Presiding Officer who has named someone, and that is what occurred here.

PARA.TAB: Where do we take it from here? I do not take it as far as to say that I have lost confidence in the Deputy President. The coalition does take that view; I do not. I have seen the Deputy President perform some admirable tasks in this place, for example in difficult, complex committee stages. I repeat that my experience in this chamber tonight was one of the noisiest I have gone through. On this occasion it was not one of those give and take situations.

Some reference was made to the election or non-election of Senator Crichton-Browne. I thought that he took his defeat rather well and I do not think that that should intrude on the debate or on one's judgment at all tonight.

TALK.START.PARA: —What made you raise that?

—Because a reference was made from Senator Crichton-Browne's side, saying that we made a mistake, while they were waving bogong moths away; that is the way I took it. I say in conclusion that today has been an interesting one. In contrast to my experience in this chamber today, I have seen someone who has behaved impeccably, honourably and so on. I then came into this chamber and saw some puerile performances tonight. I will remember this day of contrast. We have seen a great Australian whose career ended today, but in contrast we have seen a pack of puerile performers in this chamber. That contrast will always stay with me.

PARA.TAB: I do not believe that the Opposition has made a sufficient case to warrant a motion of this seriousness, but I believe that at some stage people from this chamber should enter into a dialogue to understand what is within the acceptable bounds of give and take in the chamber. Senator Alston was right to say that there should be a fair amount of latitude. But it does not come to the point of a total shouting down of somebody who is trying to deliver a speech in this chamber. It bordered on that. Had it been a speaker other than Senator Richardson, who has a pretty loud voice, that speaker would have had absolutely no chance of being heard in this chamber.

This is a serious motion for the Opposition to move, as Senator Hill has acknowledged. I do not believe that the case is sufficient, but I think that common sense should prevail more often in this chamber rather than a quick resort to Standing Orders. I believe that at some stage—and we are probably too tired to do so in this period—we should have some sort of discussion as to how the authority of the Chair is reinforced, especially when occupants of the Chair are on their feet calling for order.

TALK.START.PARA: —I claim to have been misrepresented and seek leave to make a brief statement.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to put something on record because the flippant manner in which the matter was put by Senator Robert Ray will not reflect in the Hansard report. I thought Senator Ray implied that there had been some motive from somebody on this side of the chamber to move this motion on the basis of Senator Colston defeating Senator Crichton-Browne for the deputy presidency. I hope Senator Ray will acknowledge for the benefit of the Hansard that no mischievous intent was in his mind. Certainly it has not been implied from this side, nor would it be. I would like to think that we all accept the decisions of this chamber with good grace and understanding. I would be deeply offended personally if I thought Senator Ray was imputing that. I would be grateful if Senator Robert Ray would acknowledge that he was not imputing that in any way.
—I so acknowledge and would like that to be on the record.

—In the contributions so far from the coalition, part of the defence that has been offered is that laughing was a natural response to the situation, or that it was a minor misdemeanour, or that it was a fair response. That description has also been turned around to offer part criticism of the Deputy President. Much of that is a matter of opinion so far. I would like to offer two facts that I think Senator Coulter and I are privy to and that so far nobody on the Government benches and nobody else in the debate has acknowledged.

PARA.TAB: Fact one: I was standing next to Senator Kemp while he was chuckling. He was not disrupting the chamber, he was simply chuckling. Fact two: I was still standing next to Senator Kemp when Senator O'Chee introduced a deliberate strategy of disruption. Senator O'Chee gave an instruction not only to Senator Kemp but also to several others. I challenge Senator O'Chee to deny that he said, `Keep laughing, they can't chuck you out for laughing'. Senator O'Chee orchestrated; he danced from one place to another in a deliberate strategy which showed disrespect to this chamber and in particular provoked Senator Kemp not to laugh but to make loud disruptive noises which mimicked laughter but which served only to disrupt this place and to interrupt the legislative process.

I submit that what we saw from Senator Kemp was part of a process orchestrated by Senator O'Chee, something which we in the Australian Democrats saw from this end of the chamber and which disgusted us to such an extent that we thought it should be stopped so that we could get on with the legislative process.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a personal explanation.
—You deny that and you lie.

—We will deal with that interjection in a minute, Senator Bell, because I take umbrage at that suggestion. Mr President, the comment I make is that Senator Bell did not hear what I said correctly. I want to put on the record what I did say. I make not one effort to resile from what I have said. It is very simply this: we cannot interject, but there is nothing to stop us from laughing. I was laughing genuinely, as were many of the members on this side of the chamber.

PARA.TAB: I find it personally offensive for Senator Bell to come in here and perform another stunt, hot on the heels of the one we have seen, and to be now accused by him of lying is even worse. If Senator Bell has a problem with his hearing then so be it, but I do not want him coming in here and trying this stunt on me. I will not tolerate it. That is why I want to put it on the record right here and now and we can then get on with this debate about a very substantive point. Senator Bell is in here to score cheap shots. We are not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The motion before the chamber is a very serious one indeed. It is a motion that suggests that the Senate has no confidence in the Deputy President. In all of the 16 years I have been here I do not think I have heard of such a motion. It is a motion that I believe should be supported by far more evidence than I have heard thus far. That is, it should reflect a continuous discontent by a majority of this chamber over the actions of the Deputy President such that would lead to such a motion. I have not heard that evidence thus far.

PARA.TAB: I do not think it is appropriate for this motion to be moved because of one incident. I must confess to the chamber that I left Parliament House at about five or ten minutes to seven this evening to attend a commitment outside, thinking that the National Road Transport Commission Bill 1991 would still be before the chamber when I got back. I arrived back at about 25 or 20 to nine—the car having picked me up at about a quarter past eight—and the bells were ringing. I just about made it to the door when I heard that the reason the bells were ringing was Senator Hill's motion to suspend Standing Orders. I was not aware of what had occurred before then. I was not in the chamber to observe what happened so far as Senator Kemp was concerned.

If there were concerns about what occurred, the clear response would be to vote against the motion that was presumably moved on that occasion, thus registering one's disagreement with the action that had been taken—whether one was registering disagreement with the action of the Deputy President or whether one was registering disagreement with the action of the person who moved the motion, thus registering disagreement with the motion itself. As I understand it, the Opposition has registered its objection to the action that has been taken either by the Deputy President or by the person who moved the motion.

There has only been one reference made about the Deputy President by the Opposition tonight. There have been general statements made about the Deputy President's efficiency or otherwise in the job, but no specific mention except about the occasion a couple of weeks ago. I thought that occasion was dealt with sensibly by the chamber; I thought it was dealt with sensibly by Senator Michael Baume; and I thought it was dealt with sensibly by the Deputy President when he was Chairman of Committees. It was a very difficult occasion. I observed it and I thought it was dealt with sensibly.

During the years I have served in this chamber, four or five senators have occupied the position of Deputy President. One of the functions of Deputy President is that of Chairman of Committees. If one has no confidence in the Deputy President then one has no confidence in him as Chairman of Committees. I want to stand here and say that his performance as Chairman of Committees is equally as good as, if not better than, any of those other Deputy Presidents. He has been an intelligent, sensitive, considerate, tolerant and efficient Chairman of Committees.

I certainly would not support the motion on the basis of the evidence that has been presented to us. I apologise for not being here earlier tonight but, even if I had been, I could not support this motion on the basis of one single incident. There has to be a pattern of virtual misbehaviour by the Deputy President for such a motion to be supported and accepted by the chamber. I certainly do not believe that pattern of behaviour is there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, regard this as a matter of considerable seriousness. You, Mr President, the Deputy President and myself, along with Senator Harradine and Senator Walters, all started in this place on the same day. We have enough experience between us to know how this place operates and what sort of give and take is necessary to make it operate. Senator Ray produced the solution for what was going on tonight, but because of ignorance, stupidity, shortsightedness and one-upmanship it was not given the opportunity to work. That is the real problem we are facing tonight. Standing order 203—`Infringement of order', which is what caused this problem tonight, is fairly simple and straightforward. It states:

PARA.TAB: A Senator who has been reported as having committed an offence—

SPEECH.PARA: and I have previously gone through the various offences—
shall attend in the Senator's place and be called upon to make an explanation or apology, and then a motion may be moved that the Senator be suspended from the sitting of the Senate.

Senator Kemp very adequately made an explanation which would have been perfectly acceptable to you, Mr President, and would have been perfectly acceptable to the Deputy President. There was never any doubt about the nature of the explanation that was given by Senator Kemp. But, here, this body tonight, through arrant stupidity, has put a plaster on Senator Kemp for the rest of his life that he got thrown out of the Senate for misconduct. That is what has happened, as a result of some stupidity from further down the line. I do object to that. I object to that far more than I object to the fact that we are dealing with a motion of no confidence at the moment.

PARA.TAB: It is a day of high emotion. I accept the fact that history has been made today and we are all part of it. We do not often fit into this place when real history is made; but today is one of those days. There is a lot of emotion, on both sides. There is a lot of emotion of conflict on both sides, particularly on the other side. But this is not the way to deal with it. I feel that we have done a terrible thing today as far as Senator Kemp is concerned—to be thrown out of the Senate for laughing. One could not get thrown out of a Senate in any place I can think of—probably in Ethiopia one would not be thrown out, or in Mongolia. Where would one get thrown out for laughing? I do not think for an instant that Senator Colston would have thrown Senator Kemp out of the Senate for laughing. Whatever else, I would not have thought that those opposite would have voted to throw out Senator Kemp, either, and that is where the problem lies. Why did you mob over there voted to throw him out? You stupid lot. Look at what you have done now.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—It is half past nine. We could have started with business at eight o'clock. But because honourable senators opposite wanted to play their games as a means of getting rid of the tensions that they had built up during the day, we now find that it is half past nine. Why can we not do something to review this stupid decision that we have suffered and get on with the business as we are supposed to?

PARA.TAB: Senator Alston was talking about a bit of give and take. That is what it is all about and that was what Senator Ray was on about. Senator Coulter wanted to be the main figure in the act today and this is where we wind up. That is what happens. Mr President, can we not do something to reverse this decision and get on with the business of the day?
Motion (by Senator McMullan) proposed:
That the question be now put.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Hill's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Senator Hill—I seek leave to move a motion of rescission of the resolution suspending Senator Kemp. I need leave, otherwise I would be bound by the notice requirements in standing order 87.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I am somewhat taken aback by the suggestion that has been made. I will speak for only one minute. I was not aware of the actual nature of the motion that Senator Hill intended to move tonight. Frankly, I do not know what Senator Colston's reaction to this would be. As to the situation tonight—and I thought Senator Ray very effectively put it—frankly, I agreed with Senator Ray, and I did so by way of interjection. I thought the senator suspended tonight in fact gave a very proper and gracious response. Senator Coulter actually moved the suspension.
—Before the Deputy President had a chance to consider it.

—Senator Baume is correct. Mr President, I would like to suggest a certain course of action, which I know the Senate is certainly capable of taking, with your advice on how we do it. I think it is appropriate—after six weeks of sitting, on the last night—that the suspension against the senator from the service of the House be rescinded and that the motion against the Deputy President be withdrawn.
—Is leave granted to Senator Hill? Senator Hill sought leave to move a motion—
—Yes, but only the first part.
—I agree.

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Collins)—by leave—proposed:

That the order of the Senate agreed to earlier this day suspending Senator Kemp from the sitting of the Senate be rescinded, and that the motion of no- confidence in the Deputy President (Senator Colston) be withdrawn.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the motion that has been moved by Senator Collins, I point out that I certainly had sought to move the motion of rescission, because I listened carefully to what Senator Ray said and I got the impression that it was his view, and therefore the view of Government senators, that the offence of laughing was not disorderly conduct or abuse of the Chair or anything that justified being thrown out. I therefore thought it sensible—particularly in the unprecedented circumstance when the motion to suspend Senator Kemp was not in fact moved by a Government senator but by a member of a third, minority party—that the Senate should give further consideration to that unusual course of action of suspending Senator Kemp for laughing in the chamber. It certainly seemed to us that a reconsideration was warranted, and that is why I was seeking leave to move that immediately. The Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) has done so by way of procedure, and we will support that part of the motion.

PARA.TAB: The withdrawal of our motion of no confidence puts us in a very difficult position, which I will try to explain. As was said on both sides of the chamber, the action to move a motion of no confidence in the Deputy President should not be taken without very serious consideration, and very serious consideration was given. We were of the view that the conduct of the Deputy President was such that he should no longer have the confidence of this chamber.

My discomfort is that, by complying with this approach and in trying to meet the spirit of Christmas and so forth, it may well appear that we now regard our action as not of that consequence. I will not take a position in this place that in any way withdraws what we believe to be the gravity of this matter and our justification in moving the motion we did.

TALK.START.PARA: —That applies to the suspension, too, with respect.
—It does not quite apply to the suspension because around the chamber people are generally and genuinely of the opinion that it was a miscarriage of justice.
—That is not what the chamber said.

—I listened to Senator Ray. In effect, he indicated that the Labor Party felt it was locked in to protect the Deputy President once Senator Coulter had taken this incredible action. I got the impression that Senator Ray was saying that it was not a hanging offence and that that course of action should not have been taken but that he did not really have any choice once Senator Coulter had taken the action that he did.

PARA.TAB: I think that Senator Ray regretted what had occurred. That is why I wanted the chamber to reconsider what it had done and I wanted Senator Coulter to reconsider the action that he had taken. I would like to think that, on further reflection, he would think that that was not a sensible course of action. It certainly was not a course of action that would result in the type of environment that is necessary to make this place function in the future. I would have liked him to have had the opportunity to consider that. The Minister has, however, asked us to also withdraw the motion that we have just lost. I am not too sure how that is done in any event; it may not be possible.

We accept that we lost that vote. The chamber has confidence in the Deputy President, notwithstanding the very serious viewpoint that we put to the chamber. We accept that. We will be in business with Senator Colston in the future and he will continue to get respect in a way that we would give respect to any President or Deputy President who has the confidence of this place.

But the more I think about it, the more I do not think the Minister can ask us to take a course of action now that would indicate that we did not hold our earlier action with the level of gravity which we did. I am not sure with this unusual procedure he has moved how we get ourselves out of that. If the Minister is waving his hand to suggest that he has a solution, I look forward to hearing it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I have to acknowledge that I am indebted to Senator McMullan for his suggestion. Mr President, I am obviously entirely in your hands. I am grateful to have heard the views of Senator Hill on this matter. Senator McMullan has suggested a procedural problem that I had not recognised—I think that Senator Hill is correct—and that is that perhaps a motion of the chamber can be moved, leaving the vote stand as it is though in a more positive way, the suspension of Senator Kemp can be withdrawn and the Senate can affirm its confidence in the Deputy President.

—Senator Collins is proposing an attempt to somehow rewrite the entire course of recent history. If we are in a spirit of compromise, I do not think it is necessary to go to that point. No-one wants to reopen wounds and traverse the same ground. All we are saying at this end of the chamber is that, in the circumstances, we are warranted in reconsidering the position we took in relation to Senator Kemp. Other than that, let bygones be bygones.

PARA.TAB: We have put our point of view in relation to the Deputy President. We have lost and we accept the consequence that there is no motion of no confidence or censure. We will continue to treat Senator Colston with all the respect that his position deserves. There is therefore no reason for resiling in the way that Senator Collins would suggest. I do not think that either side wants to go back over all that ground. We can very simply get to the point we want to reach.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is frustrating in that we are very close to agreement. I understand the sense in which Senator Hill, Senator Alston and Senator Collins have spoken. We are seeking to do two things in this discussion. If we find a formula to do both things, we will be in agreement and we can get on with the business. The Government will not agree to any motion which indicates in the slightest way that we do not have full confidence in the Deputy President.
—We have just done that.

—I thank Senator Newman, but I do understand that. There is absolutely no sense in saying to us that we will do only one thing, which is rescind the suspension of Senator Kemp. We will not do that by itself.

PARA.TAB: I understand the point. Both Senator Ray and I, in responding to the explanation offered by Senator Kemp, indicated some sympathy for the fact that, perhaps with some further action on his part, a way out might have been found. But the motion has been moved and we supported the Deputy President and continue to do so.

Senator Archer, in speaking in the debate, made some points. I did not agree with them all. When he got stuck into our side of the chamber I did not agree with that, and that is fair enough, but he made some comments about the impact of this action upon Senator Kemp. If there is a way in which something can be done that in no way reflects upon the standing and support of the Government for the Deputy President, while dealing with that perceived problem which we appreciate the Opposition side has, we are prepared to try to find a compromise.

However, the compromise needs to have two elements. The form of words in the second element is negotiable, but we need to find that form of words. I suggest to Senator Hill that perhaps we need a little more time to discuss the form of words in order to resolve this matter. If he thinks some further discussion might do that, I suggest that debate on this motion be adjourned until a later hour this day. I am prepared to deal with it. I understand what the Opposition is trying to achieve. I am happy to do that if he thinks that discussion will find a form of words that will allow both points to be achieved. If it will not, we will simply oppose the Opposition's motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the debate be adjourned to a later hour.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There has been a speaker from the Government's side. I call Senator Bishop while I find out what motion is before the Chair because I still think it is Senator Collins's.

—I am speaking to the motion that was moved in two parts by Senator Collins. Senator McMullan says that he will agree to a rescission motion provided that he gets his way and that somehow there is a vote of confidence in Senator Colston.

PARA.TAB: Quite clearly, that is unacceptable on this side for the reason that we, in all honesty and sincerity, moved that motion out of sadness and slow anger as much as anything else, with a desire to see somebody put out of his misery. It is a situation that we have experienced over time. Indeed, I am seeking to examine the Hansard at the moment and I will bring back to this place a list of the people who have been warned by Senator Colston over a period of time. I know that when that list comes to light they will virtually all be people from this side of the House and not from that side of the House.

Part and parcel of this question of confidence is the question of respect. A person in the chair earns respect by having an even-handed and reasonable approach—that is, the approach of a reasonable man. We have access to video replays in this place. Anyone who looked at the video replay would see that many of the rulings which led to the moving of the earlier motion came about out of anger on the part of the Chair. That is clearly not an acceptable way in which to manage this chamber.

In speaking to the motion moved by Senator Collins, and the one foreshadowed by Senator Hill—that is, simply to move the rescission motion—I think it is fair and reasonable that the motion be rescinded. Senator Colston rose in his place and asked Senator Coulter to repeat what he had said because he did not hear it the first time. He should have listened more attentively to what Senator Ray had to say. Senator Ray was offering him the way out, and he simply did not have the ability to accept that offer and rule that way. One will see that, in his anger—which is so obvious every time one looks at a replay of the way that these incidents arise—Senator Colston asked Senator Coulter to repeat the motion that he had moved and he really got himself into the mess.

It is quite unreasonable for Senator Collins to ask what he has asked of this side of the chamber—which, as I said, moved the motion out of both a long sense of burning anger and injustice, and a sense of sadness to see a man in a position where he is unable to cope. If Senator Collins could see his way clear to put his motion into two parts—that is, two motions—then we would be able to vote accordingly. Otherwise, we ought to have Senator Hill's motion as he has sought leave to move it and we ought to be able to vote on that.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to withdraw my motion and to make a short statement as to why I wish to do so.
—Is leave granted?
—Yes, if you will give me leave to move mine.
—Yes, we will.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I deeply regret the contribution that has just been made by Senator Bishop. The Hansard will show that she at least purported to speak on behalf of the Opposition. She said, `We will not agree' and so on. The suggestion Senator Bishop has made is about to be moved in a motion by Senator Hill, which we will oppose—I think rightly and justifiably. We are perhaps indebted to Senator Harradine—I got this third hand—for the original suggestion to try to get a peaceful resolution to this matter. I point out to all honourable senators that, with regard to the question of the suspension of the senator from the chamber, Senator Bishop seems to think there is no concession on this side of the House at all; that we are simply asking for one from the Opposition. That is absurd. The suspension of that senator was carried by a vote of this Senate; the Senate voted to suspend the senator.

PARA.TAB: I offered a solution in good faith which, frankly, I think a majority of the Senate was prepared to support. But it puts us in an impossible position if that concession from this side of the House—which I thought was a reasonable one—to withdraw the suspension of the senator was the only one agreed to by the Opposition. Senator Bishop has said it; she said, `We will not agree to withdraw any lack of confidence in the Deputy President from this side of the chamber'. So it is with great regret, and for that reason, that I withdraw the motion. For the reasons I have just given—I think reasonably—I indicate that the Government will be voting against the motion about to be moved by Senator Hill, so the suspension will stand.
Motion—by leave—withdrawn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the order of the Senate agreed to earlier this day suspending Senator Kemp from the sitting of the Senate be rescinded.

SPEECH.PARA: I move this motion, for the reasons I gave a few moments ago. With regard to the issue of the Deputy President, I also repeat what I said a few minutes ago, which is that the chamber has resolved confidence in Senator Colston. We respect the decision of the chamber and we respect the office of Deputy President. He can expect that respect from us when he returns to the chair.

PARA.TAB: I do not think the Government can ask us to do any more than that and I have put that on the record. In those circumstances, I urge those opposite to consider their view about the rescission and I urge them to recognise and accept that the decision to throw out Senator Kemp tonight was wrong. It is an exercise that should be put behind us. That is why I give those opposite this opportunity, whilst demonstrating respect for the Chair, to reconsider this issue and recognise the spirit of what Senator Ray said, that it really was not a hanging offence and was not an offence which warranted Senator Kemp being suspended. I give the Government the opportunity to reconsider, and I give Senator Coulter the opportunity to reconsider the action he has taken.

There is a chance tonight to get things right in the end. The way to get things right in the end is to rescind the motion of suspension, allow Senator Kemp to return and accept what we have said—that is, that we always show respect for the Chair and will continue to show respect for the Chair, as we will show respect for the office of Deputy President. In that light, I urge Senator Coulter to reconsider the attitude that he seems to be indicating by shaking his head.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not need to remind you, Mr President, that the conduct of business in this chamber is only possible if there is respect for the Chair— for the rulings of the Chair and the orders of the Chair—and reasonable decorum in the chamber. When Senator Bishop was speaking she simply proved the misbehaviour of her own side because she said that Senator Colston could not hear what was going on. Senator Colston could not hear what was going on because of the puerile and infantile rabble over here in the Opposition. A number of Opposition senators had been named and, clearly contrary to what Senator Hill has just said, the Opposition was showing no respect whatsoever for the Chair.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order.
—Sit down!
—Order! I will tell people when to sit down.
—Mr President, I believe that Senator Coulter used the word `rabble' with reference to us. I believe that is unparliamentary and you should ask him to withdraw it.

—Order! As I said in a letter to you the other day, Senator Panizza, I do consider it to be unparliamentary. Therefore, I will ask Senator Coulter to withdraw it. A lot has been said tonight about give and take. On my left—and I have not pulled them up because of the tenseness of the debate—I have clearly heard expressions such as `sewer rats' and `a sleazy mob' used with reference to the Party against which Senator Panizza is now taking the point of order. I will ask Senator Coulter to withdraw and I ask everybody to demonstrate better behaviour.

—Thank you, Mr President. I withdraw that remark. The Opposition was extremely rowdy and disruptive and, in my opinion, the Deputy President was entirely justified in calling to order a number of senators from the Opposition.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Democrats are fed up with these constant interjections and the disruptive behaviour that prevents the proper conduct of the operation of this chamber. I personally was driven to the action I took tonight. If the Opposition is going to continue to behave like this, I will continue to use standing order 203. It seems to me that it needs to be taught a lesson if we are going to get on with the business of this chamber. The fact that it might not have been used very often in the past seems to me to be quite irrelevant. If it is not going to be used, why have it in the Standing Orders?

Senator Collins's motion was entirely reasonable. I was attempting to uphold the proper order of this chamber and the rulings of the Deputy President, and I will continue to do that. Consequently, I am pleased to note that, in the light of what the Opposition is refusing to do, Senator Collins has withdrawn his motion. We will be guided by his action in that.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was said earlier tonight that Senator Harradine, Senator Archer and I have been here for just over 16 years. As far as I can remember, in that time we have had only two people thrown out. They were not from this side of the chamber; they were both from the Labor benches. There was a threat that I be thrown out—not for unparliamentary language, I believe—when I said that one of the Ministers was a disgrace to Her Majesty's Government. That was ruled unparliamentary. I did not believe it to be so and I refused to withdraw. At least I was first given—as has everyone else who has ever been thrown out of this place—the opportunity to explain and then the opportunity to apologise. I am sure that Senator Harradine will back me in that. Honourable senators have never been refused the opportunity to apologise.

PARA.TAB: On this occasion Senator Kemp was asked—and we will have the Hansard tomorrow—to explain. He was not asked to apologise by Senator Colston at any stage. When that was pointed out, as soon as Senator Kemp completed his explanation Senator Colston said, `I want you to apologise; I did not hear you apologise'. There was a general call from our side that it had not been sought.

Before Senator Colston had the opportunity of seeking an apology from Senator Kemp, Senator Coulter rose and usurped the position of the Government. Never before in this place has anyone but the Leader of the Government sought the suspension of a senator, be it from a Labor government or a Liberal government. Never before has some minority group usurped the position of the Leader of the Government. Because Senator Coulter chose to act so stupidly and try to usurp the position rightly taken by a government in that situation, we reached the stage where all the efforts of Senator Ray to pour oil on troubled waters were undercut and to no avail.

If the Democrats want to grandstand in the way they have tonight—except for Senator Kernot, who voted with us; she also saw that the Democrats had undercut Senator Ray in his efforts to overcome the problem—we will always get into this situation.

The Senate is only run according to the Standing Orders and tradition, and I emphasise `tradition'. Once we depart from tradition, as has occurred tonight, we will always run into trouble. I am quite sure that Senator Harradine would agree. Had he been here, I doubt that we would have lost that vote. Never before has there been a situation where a senator has been thrown out of the Senate without first being given the opportunity to apologise. That is what occurred tonight.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder whether we could come back to the mood that pervaded the chamber at the start of this matter. I understand everybody getting a bit offside, but Senator Hill put forward a proposition which I think needed discussion. It was answered by Senator Collins and Senator McMullan. I thought we were progressing fairly well along a peaceful path where we all saw ourselves as senators who wanted to get rid of a problem. We seem to have moved away from that to where we are getting a little curt with each other.

PARA.TAB: Senator Coulter has done what he thought right. Senator Colston is perhaps bruised by what has happened. The one who is suffering the most is Senator Kemp. I am beginning to wonder whether we are sacrificing those three people to the speeches we are making and the shafts we are throwing across the chamber. If a Senate with members who are all as intelligent as we are cannot come to some sort of compromise position, perhaps we should adjourn the debate or let the Whips or somebody brilliant such as Senator Baume come forward with a compromise.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is funny you should mention that.
—I take it that Senator Baume is about to do that. In those circumstances, and since we are coming to reason, I will sit down and let the reconciler come forth.

—I thank Senator Cooney for his support, which is even more strenuous and effective than on the tennis court. The problem has clearly emerged, as everyone has said, because of an unprecedented action by the Australian Democrats. I do not want to go into that matter because it has been well dealt with.

PARA.TAB: I have some feeling for Senator Colston on this matter. The problem is simply that before Senator Colston had the opportunity to consider the explanation by Senator Kemp it was snatched away by precipitate action by the Australian Democrats. Clearly, the way out of this—which seems to me to resolve all problems—is that the rescission motion, as proposed by Senator Hill, should be accepted. That would then give Senator Colston the opportunity to determine whether or not he would accept—there is no assumption either way that he would or would not—Senator Kemp's explanation. When he has made that decision—I hope Senator Collins will take this on board—having heard the manner in which Senator Colston would make his determination, and if his determination was, for example, to accept the explanation of Senator Kemp, it would be up to the Senate to move a motion supporting the decision of Senator Colston to accept Senator Kemp's explanation.

We have to recognise that to an extent the Opposition's feelings of grievance emerge from the fact that it appeared that the Deputy President had not taken into account the explanation that was asked for and very properly given and which, as Senator Ray and Senator Collins indicated, was one that was `acceptable'.

That is the thing. It is unfair that Senator Colston was not given the opportunity. He should be given that opportunity. I believe it would then be proper for the Senate, having heard whatever Senator Colston had determined—in the event that he did accept that explanation—to move a motion, which I hope would be carried unanimously, supporting the decision of the Deputy President to accept Senator Kemp's explanation. That seems to me to be an indication of support for the ultimate decision taken by the Deputy President, if that were his decision. I do not want to prejudge it. It seems to me to be ridiculous that we cannot get together on a simple issue such as this, which I hope would, firstly, resolve this waste of time and, secondly, present some evidence of goodwill at this time of the year.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—At this moment and in that particular form of words, I am not sure whether Senator Michael Baume has the exact solution we are looking for; but it puts the matter back in the spirit of the debate when Senator Hill and Senator Alston spoke. I reiterate my previous suggestion that we should adjourn this discussion so that we can talk about a form of words that will resolve the matter, so that we can get on with the business of passing legislation and come back this evening with an agreed form of words. I move:

PARA.TAB: That the debate be adjourned to a later hour this day.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Motion (by Senator McMullan)—by leave—agreed to:
That standing order 64 be suspended to enable new business to be commenced after the question for the adjournment of the Senate is first put this day.

DEBATE.TITLE: INSURANCE LAWS AMENDMENT BILL 1991LIFE INSURANCE POLICY HOLDERS' PROTECTION LEVIES BILL 1991LIFE INSURANCE POLICY HOLDERS' PROTECTION LEVIES COLLECTION BILL 1991LIFE INSURANCE SUPERVISORY LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1991GENERAL INSURANCE SUPERVISORY LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1991INSURANCE ACQUISITIONS AND TAKE OVERS BILL 1991

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 10 October, on motions by Senator Bolkus and Senator McMullan:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is tonight belatedly considering a group of six Bills concerning the life and general insurance industries. These Bills include the Insurance Laws Amendment Bill 1991, the Insurance Acquisitions and Takeovers Bill 1991, the Life Insurance Policy Holders' Protection Levies Bill 1991, the Life Insurance Policy Holders' Protection Levies Collection Bill 1991, the Life Insurance Supervisory Levy Amendment Bill 1991 and the General Insurance Supervisory Levy Amendment Bill 1991. The Bills were referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration before the second reading debate. That Committee has considered the legislation and Senator Coates has already presented the Committee's report to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: The proposals before us arose because of a financial scandal last year involving the attempted takeover of two life insurance companies, Regal and Occidental. These two insurers were, and still are, part of the Battery Group of companies. Battery decided to sell Regal and Occidental to an American investor, Mr Phillip Carver, via a company he controlled, Heath Holdings. The price was $132m payable in three instalments over 12 months. Of this, $65m was paid by the Bank of Melbourne to the Commonwealth Bank and the ANZ Bank to extinguish debts owed by Battery. This $65m had been taken from statutory funds of Regal and Occidental; that is, the statutory funds had been raided to pay for the acquisition of the life insurance companies.

As Senator Michael Baume has remarked to the Senate in the past, this unauthorised use of the statutory funds of a life insurance company is contrary to section 38 of the Life Insurance Act. Yet, more than a year later no final legal action has been taken against the people who undoubtedly contravened this provision. Some other charges, however, may be laid against Mr Carver who was recently arrested at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport whilst attempting to leave Australia on a false passport.

The recipient banks refused to return the $65m, claiming that they had received the money in good faith and that they had extinguished loan obligations of equivalent value. A judicial manager, Mr Richard Grellman, was appointed under the Life Insurance Act by the Federal Court of Australia. This is the first such appointment and resembles the appointment of a receiver or a provisional liquidator in that the directors have been temporary replaced.
