It is his responsibility to continue to run the two insurance companies which still have about 90,000 policyholders and assets of over $300m. Legal action is being taken to recover the $65m, and there is a very good chance of success. A successful action has already been achieved which entitles the judicial manager to use the companies' funds to pursue this legal action. The whole matter is currently before the courts, so I will not mention it further.

These extraordinary circumstances prompted the former Treasurer to intervene to abort any crisis which may have occurred. We can contrast this with a completely hands-off approach by him to the devastated Farrow Group crash in Victoria. After a succession of negotiations former Treasurer Keating, now Prime Minister elect, announced in January that a compulsory levy would be imposed on life insurers to make up 90 per cent of any shortfall in policyholders' funds which remained after all the relevant legal actions had been completed. Depending on the results of the various court cases there may not ever be any levy imposed under this legislation.

The earlier industry proposal for a voluntary levy could not be implemented, so a legislated response was sought and agreed to by the Government. The former Treasurer also announced proposals to allow the Treasurer to supervise all acquisitions of insurance companies in excess of 15 per cent of capital, to increase minimum capital standards for life and general insurers, to strengthen investigatory powers of the Insurance and Superannuation Commission as well as to increase duties of actuaries and to increase disclosure in the statutory returns of general insurers.

All of these proposals are contained in the six Bills before us tonight. I think the central question in this legislation is: should the Government be taxing all life insurance policies to subsidise policyholders who have incurred a loss through fraud? The pure answer is no; the risk should be borne by the policyholders because all investments carry a degree of commercial risk, including the ultimate risk of failure of the institution. This must be balanced by the question of the health of the life insurance industry and the financial system as a whole.

In this case, the Treasurer took the view that the financial system was in some danger and, as such, intervention was necessary. Given the deregulatory bent of former Treasurer Keating, clearly there must have been some genuine fear, especially after the collapse of the Farrow Group of building societies. Also the extraordinary situation which arose in the Regal and Occidental affair should never be repeated because of the new powers of the Treasurer with respect to acquisitions of insurance company equity. This package should not be viewed as a precedent for bailing out investors in the future.

On balance, the Australian Democrats support the policyholders' levies legislation. The regulation of major acquisitions of insurance company equity is comparable to the provisions which have operated for many years in the banking industry and, therefore, is supported by the Democrats. The improved minimum capital standards should also lead to greater investor protection and are also welcomed. This should also speed the expected rationalisation of both the life and general insurance industries which are widely recognised as having too many participants. The provisions strengthening the investigatory powers of the Commissioner arise because of the shortcomings discovered during the investigation of the Regal and Occidental matters.
Debate interrupted.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Giles)—Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I put the question:
That the Senate do now adjourn.
Question resolved in the negative.
Debate resumed.

DEBATE.TITLE: INSURANCE LAWS AMENDMENT BILL 1991LIFE INSURANCE POLICY HOLDERS' PROTECTION LEVIES BILL 1991LIFE INSURANCE POLICY HOLDERS' PROTECTION LEVIES COLLECTION BILL 1991LIFE INSURANCE SUPERVISORY LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1991GENERAL INSURANCE SUPERVISORY LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1991INSURANCE ACQUISITIONS AND TAKE OVERS BILL 1991

TALK.START.PARA: —Clearly, a regulator must be in a position to investigate, report and act on any aspect of legislation which he or she has a duty to enforce. The proposals pertaining to this in the legislation are absolutely reasonable, are necessary and have the support of the Australian Democrats. The related proposals to increase the supervisory levies on both the life and general insurance industries to pay for the extra administration costs which this package imposes on the ISC are also consistent with the general cost recovery nature of the existing operation of the ISC. As such, the Democrats do not oppose this increase in the supervisory levies. There are many issues in the life insurance area which have not been addressed by the Government in this legislation. The Life Insurance Act has been under review for years. Perhaps Senator McMullan could inform the Senate of the progress of that review.

PARA.TAB: General insurance in the public sector is also in a turbulent environment at the moment. Premier Greiner in New South Wales is preparing to privatise the GIO, the Victorian Opposition has stated its intention to privatise the Traffic and Accident Commission and the Commonwealth is still attempting to destroy the Housing Loan Insurance Corporation. None of these proposed privatisations is in any way driven by efficiency or by competitive considerations. Indeed, they will be anti-competitive and will generally disadvantage consumers. They are purely the result of ideological bias—the bias of the Prime Minister-designate of this country. Surely this process of deregulation and privatisation has done enough damage for those driving the process to be asked to justify their policies on the achieved gains. Any rational analysis would show us that New Zealand is not a good model to follow.

We are starting to hear some encouraging noises from Mr Crean and Senator Button about active Government policy in some areas. We await the economic statement in the new year. The biggest concern is the almost complete failure of the Australian capital markets to provide adequate development capital. The big institutions—that is, the life offices and the banks—have been unwilling to provide the development capital needed to commercialise our scientific achievements. Examples abound of real entrepreneurs—not paper shufflers—being forced to sell to foreign investors because of a lack of local interest. There are real gains to be made by Australian firms collaborating with foreign concerns with expertise and access in foreign markets, but the control should stay in Australia.

The Australian Democrats have said before and will say it again, and we know that many others are starting to agree with us, that deregulated financial markets have failed. It is time for the Government to acknowledge that specific regulation is needed and that it must act in this area. Failure to do so will continue to doom Australia to never become the cliched clever country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Due to a unique series of circumstances, described by Australian Business magazine as `one of the most botched deals in modern Australian corporate history', we have six insurance Bills before us for debate: the Insurance Laws Amendment Bill 1991, the Life Insurance Policy Holders' Protection Levies Bill 1991, the Life Insurance Policy Holders' Protection Levies Collection Bill 1991, the Life Insurance Supervisory Levy Amendment Bill 1991, the General Insurance Supervisory Levy Amendment Bill 1991 and the Insurance Acquisitions and Takeovers Bill 1991.

PARA.TAB: These insurance Bills will hopefully achieve two things. Firstly, they will prevent a repeat of the Occidental and Regal Life debacle. Secondly, they will raise funds to compensate for a maximum of $65m which was misappropriated by placing a one-off levy on other insurance companies. It is not in the Senate's best interests for me to go into the full details of the failed sale of Occidental and Regal Life Insurance companies by the Battery group to a shelf company called Heath Holdings, although for those interested I would recommend an article which appeared in the Australian Business magazine on April 24 1991.

What has not been said loudly and clearly in relation to this case, and which I wish to say today, is that we are essentially dealing with a banking problem which the then Treasurer, Mr Keating, chose to transfer to the insurance industry for it to deal with. The viability of the Bank of Melbourne was threatened as a result of their actions and the sale of Occidental and Regal. Rather than the Treasury having to bale out another failed financial institution, Mr Keating changed the focus of attention to insurance companies and put the onus on them to bale their colleagues out. What has happened in this instance is, indeed, unfortunate not only for those professionals involved but for all of the policyholders affected.

The deal which took only two months to put together and one night to stuff up has resulted in two companies being put into the deep freeze for 12 months so far, and probably another 12 months while the legalities are sorted out. The picture is not totally grim, despite neither company writing new business. Policyholders can make claims but cannot surrender their policies, although death and disability pay-outs are being met. Policy renewals are lower and those who are paying their premiums for death and disability are being fully underwritten by Mercantile Mutual, which has effectively taken over Occidental and Regal's death and disability business. The situation could have been much worse but, hopefully, the amendments that we are debating here today will prevent a repeat performance of the Occidental and Regal Life debacle.

I will deal briefly with the six Bills on an individual basis. First, the Insurance Laws Amendment Bill 1991 amends the Insurance Act 1973 and the Life Insurance Act 1945. These amendments—which concern increasing the minimum capital and solvency requirements for authorised general insurers, minor amendments to the description of accounts and statements required by the Commissioner, et cetera, as explained by other speakers—are all welcome moves with which the Opposition has no problems. However, I am concerned that the tightening of prudential standards could cause a problem for the privacy provisions. It is not possible to keep a central register of people making false insurance claims, even though a third of the payments are suspected to be fraudulent. I also wish to address the concern raised by the Insurance Council of Australia at the hearing of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration with respect to clauses 24 to 26.

The Insurance Laws Amendment Bill amends both the Insurance Act and the Life Insurance Act to introduce virtually identical provisions, disqualifying directors and certain executive officers from holding office if they have been convicted of certain offences or become bankrupt. Whilst the industry accepts the principles of the decision, it expresses concern that there is no method by which a person could apply to a court to have the disqualification lifted in circumstances where the court was satisfied that the offence or bankruptcy did not justify the disqualification either because of the lapse of time or otherwise.

The corporation law is cited by way of comparison as a law with a similar disqualification which operates for only five years but, even in that period, a court has discretion to permit a disqualified person to manage a corporation. Whilst this matter was not pursued further by the Committee, I understand that, as part of the major review of the Life Insurance Act which the Insurance and Superannuation Commission is presently conducting, this matter will be considered. I look forward to reading the report of the review early next year and discovering whether the ISC recommends further amendment to clauses 24 to 26 in accordance with the ICA's submission.

Secondly, the Life Insurance Policy Holders' Protection Levies Bill 1991 and the Life Insurance Policy Holders' Protection Levies Collection Bill 1991 formally impose a levy on life insurance companies to compensate holders of life insurance policies of Occidental and Regal Life. They also contain provisions which will limit the total amount of levy collected under the legislation to $65m. I had planned to propose an amendment to these Bills until I read the Budget papers which made an additional provision. The papers state:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has introduced legislation, as a one-off arrangement, to enable the imposition of one or more levies on registered life insurance companies to raise an amount not exceeding $65m.

That Bill has just passed the Senate. The timing and the amount of the levies, which will provide a measure of financial protection to policyholders of Occidental Life Insurance Company of Australia Ltd and Regal Life Insurance Ltd, will be dependent on the judicial management of those companies.

PARA.TAB: The levies collected will be paid into a protection fund and are to be tax deductible to life offices, relating exclusively to non-fund assessable income. Grants paid to Occidental Life and Regal Life will be exempt from income tax and will be used to meet up to 90 per cent of the liabilities under life policies issued by Occidental Life and Regal Life. Certain payments to life offices representing surplus moneys from the protection fund will be treated as non-fund assessable income. These arrangements are being imposed because of the special and unusual circumstances involving an unauthorised dealing in statutory fund moneys of the two companies. The measures will operate from the date of royal assent.

I also mention that, whilst the insurance industry considers that the imposition of an industry levy sets a dangerous precedent for similar intervention if other insurers were to fail, it is accepting of the fact that a levy needs to apply in this instance.

The industry, which has experienced explosive growth during the past decade, is dominated by two life companies which between them control 60 per cent of the market. Neither the industry nor the taxpayer could afford to support either of these giants were they ever to need help, which would be highly unlikely. Yet what would be the use of a support scheme that excluded these two?

The life companies initially objected to the imposition of a levy. However, they have accepted the need for it in this instance as a one-off levy and are happy to comply with it. They are even happier to comply with it now that the tax deductibility aspect has been addressed by this Government. The fact remains, though, that policyholders of all other groups have been disadvantaged as a result of fraud in one group. This is another instance of lack of prudential standards and the failure of the Government to move quickly during a period of explosive growth of the life insurance industry. Such payments on $65m give encouragement to those at the cheap and less ethical end of the market to write high risk business in the knowledge that major catastrophes will be picked up by government action. Imposing a levy has not been conducive to sending the right signals to encourage good practice.

There were three objections raised by participants at the Finance and Public Administration Committee's hearings on these Bills. One of the comments I wish to raise here today relates to one of several comments made by Commonwealth Life Ltd. Its concern was that there is a group of contracts in the market where the way in which the investment earnings are credited to the policyholder is very tightly controlled by the policy wording. The concern was that clause 13 does not specifically cover that particular group of business where the wording of the policy would not allow the company to pass on the cost of the levy to the policyholder.

In response to this concern, Senator McMullan stated, for the purposes of Hansard and therefore for the purposes of the Acts Interpretation Act, that it is the Government's intention that this legislation be interpreted as a tax for the contract in the terms of policies which Commonwealth Life Ltd referred to. I would like Senator McMullan to iterate that point again, as he indicated he would be willing to do when the Bill came up for debate in the Senate.

During the Committee's hearings, I also raised a point with Mr Grellman, the judicial manager, about provision for assistance to those policyholders who had elected voluntarily to discontinue payment of premiums under their policies. In response to this question I have received a fairly lengthy letter from the Insurance and Superannuation Commission. My concerns in this area have been allayed to some extent as a result of its correspondence. However, I would appreciate the Government, and any others who will be responsible for compensating policyholders, bearing my point in mind during their deliberations.

In respect of the Life Insurance Supervisory Levy Amendment Bill and the General Insurance Supervisory Levy Amendment Bill, I make several comments. The insurance industry is supervised by the Insurance and Superannuation Commission, whose job will now be expanded as a result of the changes introduced in this legislation. In anticipation of extra staff to cope with this expanded workload, these supervisory levy amendment Bills allow for an increase in life and general insurance supervisory levies from $20,000 to $28,000 and from $11,600 to $15,000 respectively.

Finally, I refer to the Insurance Acquisitions and Takeovers Bill 1991. The purpose of this Bill is to set out rules for compulsory notification to the Minister of deals that would involve the transfer of a certain interest in an Australian insurance company, their assets or directors, and to allow the Minister the right to refuse approval of such deals. If this Bill had been in force a year ago, the Occidental and Regal Life situation probably would not have arisen.

As my colleague Senator Short has indicated, the coalition will be moving amendments to this Bill. A number of concerns were raised in relation to this Bill by those attending the Committee proceedings that have been taken up by the coalition in its amendments. The first concern was raised by the AMP over clause 5, which sets out the circumstances that are deemed to be contrary to the public interest for the acquisition or takeover of an insurance company. Their particular concern was with subclause (c), which refers to a situation that is likely to unduly concentrate economic power in the general or life insurance industry or in the Australian financial system. There are two points with regard to this subclause. The first is the concern that this requirement appears to cover very similar ground to that covered by section 50 of the Trade Practices Act, but with a different and more vague criterion. The concept of `unduly concentrate economic power' is very close to the domination concept in the Trade Practices Act.

The AMP was particularly concerned that an insurance company which had a concern about the competitive effect of a proposed acquisition would need to seek the approval of both the Minister, under this legislation, and of the Trade Practices Commission. That is a situation which I describe as a double jeopardy situation. The second point is that the subclause relates to unduly concentrating economic power in the Australian financial system as well as in the insurance industry and that this type of cross-industry trade practices provision is unknown in other industries.

Opposition members are also concerned about paragraph 5(1)(d) of the Bill. The paragraph defines a matter to be contrary to the public interest if it is contrary to the national interest. `National interest' is not defined in the Bill and, thus, we are concerned that the provision, requiring as it does a highly subjective judgment, might be used to unduly restrict entry to the insurance industry.

Item (a) of clause 5 relates to situations where an acquisition or takeover is likely to adversely affect the prudential conduct of the affairs of the company. Whilst this item is supported, it was pointed out at the Committee hearing that the Life Insurance Act contains no direct obligation to conduct a company's affairs in a prudent manner, and it is thought that it should contain such a provision, both on general principles and for consistency with clause 5(a) of the Bill. When this matter was raised in the Committee, Senator McMullan responded that it was a worthwhile comment which he would take on notice. I trust that the point has not been lost and that Senator McMullan will stand by his word in this instance.

I would also like the honourable senator to reiterate for Hansard purposes the comments he made in the Committee about decisions under this clause being reviewable to the effect that, if it appeared that the Minister had made an arbitrary decision in the face of the facts, the AAT would overturn it.

I come now to clause 15 of the Bill. The Australian Bankers Association has drawn attention to the formula in clause 15(5). The intention is for a percentage to be calculated, but the formula as written does not result in a percentage. The Australian Bankers Association has suggested an easy remedy, and I would suggest that, for the sake of completeness, the alteration be made.

Still on the acquisitions and takeovers Bill, National Mutual has expressed concern in relation to what is referred to as the trigger proposal. Its specific concern is with capital raising procedures. Without a National Mutual representative present at the hearing, this matter was passed over fairly quickly. National Mutual points out that the trigger proposals will complicate its capital raising process. The company then goes on to say that the inclusion of regulations, which may result in such proposals being exempted from compliance if the Minister sees fit, is of some comfort to it. It does, however, increase its workload, and I would not be surprised to see some changes in this area in time to come. There are probably deficiencies there.

The losses of the Regal and Occidental Life companies have hastened the need for more and stronger government regulation of the life and general insurance industry. The lack of regulation has meant that too many small and inexperienced operators have entered the market. Hopefully, the legislation before us today will significantly tighten both the area of ability to enter the industry and the area of ongoing supervision so that the history books will never again record a debacle such as we have experienced with Occidental and Regal.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is not a lot to be said in summing up the second reading debate because we have had extensive and worthwhile discussion on these Bills in the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration. I appreciated it; it was informative.

PARA.TAB: This is, I think, an important package of Bills. In the pressure of debates such as this, and with the constraints of time, the positive things upon which we agree in such packages of legislation tend to get overlooked in the course of debating the points that are the highlights of contrast between us.

This package of Bills, taken together, will increase the level of prudential protection provided to life and general insurance policy holders and provide a measure of financial support to policy holders of the Occidental Life Insurance Company of Australia and Regal Life Insurance Ltd in particular. It also provides a mechanism for the prior screening of changes to the ownership and control of life and general insurance companies. It puts in place levy arrangements which will ensure that an appropriate degree of protection is provided, and allows for the recovery of costs arising from additional resources provided to the Insurance and Superannuation Commission, for the purpose of improved industry supervision through an increase in the life and general insurance supervisory levies.

I emphasise that these measures have been developed in liaison with senior representatives of the life and general insurance industry associations. The substantive point of disagreement between us now lies with the Opposition's amendment which we will deal with in the committee stage. Therefore, I will say no more at this stage, but thank the Senate for its support for the second reading of the Bill, which I commend to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: INSURANCE ACQUISITIONS AND TAKE OVERS BILL 1991
The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition has an amendment to the Insurance Acquisitions and Takeovers Bill 1991. This package of legislation has been on again and off again and has been with us for quite a few weeks. Our amendment was circulated in October, and I am not sure of the Australian Democrats' position on it. I move:

PARA.TAB: Clause 5, page 7, paragraph 5 (1)(c), lines 9 to 11, omit the paragraph.

SPEECH.PARA: The provision in Clause 5(1) reads:

PARA.TAB: For the purposes of the application of this Act to an Australian- registered insurance company, a particular matter is taken to be contrary to the public interest if it is

SPEECH.PARA: Then one sees paragraphs (a) and (b), and then comes paragraph (c) which we propose to delete and which reads:

PARA.TAB: likely to unduly concentrate economic power in the Australian general insurance industry, in the Australian life insurance industry or in the Australian financial system.

When these Bills were considered by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration in October, the report of the Committee recorded a statement by Opposition senators, namely Senator Watson, Senator Campbell and Senator Kemp, supported by me, although I was not a member of the Committee. We expressed concern about aspects of the Insurance Acquisitions and Takeovers Bill, one of which related to clause 5(1) of the Bill which defines circumstances which, for the purposes of the Bill, are deemed to be contrary to the public interest.

Paragraph (c) is of concern to us. As Senator Watson pointed out in his remarks, one of the basic reasons for that concern is that the terminology in paragraph 5 (1)(c) differs materially from the provisions of section 50 of the Trade Practices Act which addresses the same issue and which will also apply to the transactions in question.

The Opposition supports action to tighten as much as possible prudential standards in the insurance industry, but our view is that this particular paragraph is aimed at competition policy. Its inclusion in a Bill concerned with prudential matters is confusing, particularly given the established body of case law in relation to the existing trade practices legislation.

The proposed clause introduces an element of double jeopardy to the legislative environment in which the insurance industry operates and may represent an unnecessary barrier to entry to the insurance industry. I would have thought that that is a potential problem with which we would all be concerned because an open and competitive environment in the insurance industry in the interests of consumers—who comprise most Australians—is a very important requirement indeed.

Since the Bills were considered in the Standing Committee, I have noted several press articles dealing with the relationship of the Trade Practices Commission to the insurance industry. Those articles and comments in the media have raised similar sorts of concerns to those that I personally have had for some time—and I think that the coalition shares my concern—as to how the Trade Practices Act, the Commission and the ISC will work in relation to the insurance industry. The concern is as to how they interrelate and whether there is duplication and conflict, which matters require examination. Perhaps that is a topic for another occasion.

The fact that competition policy is rightly dealt with in Section 50 of the Trade Practices Act leads us to propose this amendment. I hope that the Government and the Democrats will be able to agree with it. I am not totally optimistic that that will be the case, but certainly logic is on the side of acceptance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats are aware of the statements made by the Opposition in the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration. I understand what the Opposition is seeking to do, but we are also aware of the response of the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner dated 3 October 1991. If Senator McMullan is not proposing to incorporate it, I certainly would propose to do so, but the most relevant paragraph that I would like to quote by way of explanation of our position on this amendment is contained in page 2 of the letter. We agree with the Government's view:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . that the Bill should allow the Treasurer to have regard to all aspects which could impinge on whether a proposal might be against the public interest. Consequently it would be inappropriate not to have regard to concentration/competition considerations particularly given the increasingly important role insurance and superannuation is performing in the overall financial system.
We also agree:
It would not be appropriate to rely on the provisions in the TPA for this purpose because the scope of conduct being regulated is different and there are different thresholds which apply.

We do not concur with the Opposition's concern about the anti-competitive nature here. On balance, we would have to oppose the Opposition's amendment. I seek leave to incorporate this letter in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: INSURANCE AND SUPERANNUATION COMMISSION
Mr Peter Hamburger
Secretary
Senate Standing Committee on Finance
and Public Administration
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Mr Hamburger

During the Committee hearing into the package of insurance legislation on 13 September concern was raised about the interaction between paragraph 5(1)(c) of the Insurance Acquisitions and Takeovers Bill (IA&T Bill) and section 50 of the Trade Practices Act (TPA).
There are a number of points I would like to make which may assist Committee members in understanding the reasons for including paragraph 5(1)(c) in the Bill.

The purpose of clause 5(1) is to deem a number of matters to be contrary to the public interest. Depending on the nature of the particular proposal involved, any one of matters included in clause 5(1) namely prudential conduct, unsuitable persons, undue concentration of economic power and national interest could become important from the viewpoint of assessing whether a proposal is considered to be against the public interest. For example, if a proposal is considered likely to lead to an undue concentration of economic power in the Australian general insurance industry, the Australian life insurance industry or the Australian financial system this provision makes it clear that this can be regarded as being contrary to the public interest. Similarly, if a proposal is considered to be contrary to the national interest it is deemed to be contrary to the public interest.

Furthermore, we have been advised that even if the concentration of economic power aspect was removed from clause 5(1) it is arguable that the Treasurer could still find a proposal which unduly concentrated economic power in this way to be contrary to the public interest. In those circumstances, however, there could be a risk that a court or tribunal may consider that an undue concentration of economic power was not contrary to the public interest and overturn it. Thus the Bill seeks to remove any doubt that the public interest does encompass such considerations.

The view was put in the Committee that requiring a proponent to meet both IA&T Bill and TPA tests independently placed a discriminatory burden on insurers. This situation, however, is no different to that required in some other industries. For example, an Australian resident wishing to acquire an interest in a broadcasting company must meet the requirements of both the Broadcasting Tribunal and the TPC. Similarly a foreign person wishing to acquire an interest in any trading company must meet the requirements of both the FA&T Act and the Trade Practices Commission (TPC). Simply because the Treasurer does not object to the proposal under the FA&T Act does not mean approval from the TPC is not needed or is automatic. In this regard it is important to note that the Treasurer (or as it is expressed in the Bill, the Commonwealth Government) does not approve a proposal; rather, the Bill gives scope for expressing no objections to a proposal going ahead.

We are confident that where a proposal may be subject to examination under both the IA&T Bill and the TPA, the potential for any difficulties to arise will be minimised through the consultation process which will be undertaken by the ISC while a proposal is being examined. A consultation process with other Government Departments has been specifically allowed for in clause 75(4) of the Bill. What is proposed is that consultation with the TPC will be undertaken as a matter of course on any proposal which involves an existing insurer acquiring a significant interest in another. The views of the TPC would therefore be taken into account in the Treasurer's decision on the proposal.

This proposed approach is, of course, consistent with the arrangements which have been followed in assessing foreign investment proposals under the FA&T Act and no significant problems of the type raised by the Committee have occurred in the administration of that legislation. In contrast to the position under the FA&T Act, however, where the proponent has no formal appeal avenues open, all adverse decisions (other than a temporary restraining order) under the IA&T Bill are subject to internal and AAT Review.

In summary, therefore, the Government has taken the view that the Bill should allow the Treasurer to have regard to all aspects which could impinge on whether a proposal might be against the public interest. Consequently it would be inappropriate not to have regard to concentration/competition considerations particularly given the increasingly important role insurance and superannuation is performing in the overall financial system. It would not be appropriate to rely on the provisions in the TPA for this purpose because the scope of conduct being regulated is different and there are different thresholds which apply.

I hope this information assists in clarifying some of the concerns which were raised about the interaction of paragraph 5(1)(c) of the IA&T Bill and section 50 of the TPA during the Committee's hearing.
Yours sincerely
Richard M. Beetham
Commissioner
3 October 1991

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief in light of the comments that have been made by Senators Short and Kernot, who were both admirably brief in their comments. As was clear in the deliberations of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, I am not without concern about the point that Senator Short raises. It is a question about which I have given some consideration and which I raised with relevant Ministers in the Government. Although I think competition policy is very important and we need to be very rigorous in its pursuit, I do not want us, in an ad hoc manner, to proliferate different standards in different pieces of legislation without good cause.

PARA.TAB: There are different standards in different pieces of legislation which apply due to the particular nature of industries. I wanted the Government to consider whether it believed that the circumstances of the industry we are dealing with here tonight were such that this clause was warranted as a special inclusion. After that consideration, the Government has formed the view, particularly given the increasingly important role that the insurance and superannuation industry is performing in the overall financial system, that it would be inappropriate not to have regard to concentration and competition considerations.

My view is that as long as we had the national interest element in there—I believe we should—any Minister making a decision under the legislation would give consideration to competition factors. Inevitably that would be so, but it is much better, if that is going to be the case, that it is explicitly stated in the legislation rather than subsumed into the broader national interest aspect. It would not be impossible to consider it under the national interest heading anyway, but that then means our having a more indirect statement.

Given that the Government has formed the view that that would be a criterion Ministers would be likely to take into account, it is the view of the Government that it would more appropriately be explicitly stated. Therefore, we are opposing the amendment, although, as I said before and I repeat, I am not unaware of or unsympathetic to the concerns that the Opposition raises as a matter of general principle about it.

I want to make it very explicit that what is proposed is that there be very close consultation between the Trade Practices Commission and the Insurance and Superannuation Commission as a matter of course on any proposal which involves an existing insurer acquiring an significant interest in another. The views of the Trade Practices Commission would therefore be taken account in the decision of the Treasurer on the proposal.

It has been a very legitimate debate. It has been a very important point properly considered by the Senate in its Finance and Public Administration Committee and here in the committee stage of the Bills, but on reconsideration the Government remains of the view that the paragraph should remain. The Government therefore opposes the amendment.
Amendment negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the debate I sought certain assurances from the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) arising from issues that were raised during the hearing of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration. I acknowledge that during my presentation the Parliamentary Secretary was absent and that, therefore, it would be fairly difficult for him to respond. Seeing that that lack of assurance may be seen in this parliamentary chamber to be an abrogation of those early assurances, I would hope that his advisers could give him the confidence that he will monitor those issues to which we earlier drew some attention because of concerns raised not only by the industry but also by the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to unduly delay proceedings, but it may be that we can resolve this if Senator Watson recapitulates very briefly. I do apologise for my absence because, as Senator Watson knows, in my other hat as Manager of Government Business we did have some delicate discussions to undertake which, in the interests of decorum, took place outside the chamber. But, from what I heard, the assurance which Senator Watson sought was a reiteration of an assurance which I gave to the Committee relating to the interpretation of the levy as a tax. With regard to that point at least, I am happy to give that reiteration here. If there are others, I will check the Hansard and give a considered response to Senator Watson.

PARA.TAB: Bill agreed to.

PROCTEXT.PARA: SCHEDULE OF THE AMENDMENT MADE BY THE SENATE AND DISAGREED TO BY THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES, BUT AMENDMENT MADE IN PLACE THEREOF

PARA.TAB: Clause 39, pages 24 and 25, proposed paragraphs 82BB(1) (a) and (b), omit the paragraphs, substitute the following paragraph:
"(a) if:

TAB.TAB: (i)a decision is made before the end of the current year of income to abandon the project; or
(ii)the project ends before the end of the current year of income;

PARA.TAB: the expenditure is an allowable deduction for the current year of income; or".
Motion (by Senator McMullan) proposed:
That the Committee does not insist upon its amendment No. 1 disagreed to by the House of Representatives and agrees to the amendment made by the House in place thereof.

TALK.START.PARA: —The House of Representatives has returned to the Senate an amendment which was moved by the Opposition and supported by the Australian Democrats and thus passed by the Senate. The amendment concerned the deductibility regime for environmental impact costs. The Senate amendment was actually in two parts. The first was full deductibility in circumstances where a decision is made before the end of the current year of income to abandon the project or the project ends before the end of the current year of income, and the second was in other circumstances—in other words, where the projects proceeds—where 33 1/3 per cent of expenditure was allowable in each of the three years.

PARA.TAB: The message from the House of Representatives was to accept that part of the amendment allowing full deductibility where the project does not proceed, but to reject that part of the amendment concerning the three-year deductibility write-off. The effect of that was to reinstate the original 10-year write-off, which the Opposition believed was too long. The Government does appear to be unduly concerned about the revenue implications. I regret the threat of the Government that a failure by the Senate to accede to the Government's request would result in the Government withdrawing from the Bill the whole of the deductibility provision proposed.

The Opposition has taken this threat very seriously. This is the last night on which this matter can be debated, and we are not sure what time the other House will rise. We also acknowledge that a number of companies will be balancing on 31 December. Our failure to agree tonight could result in this Bill being held over until perhaps April next year. Recognising that those companies will have to pay their first taxation instalment in January 1992, they will be severely affected. We are not prepared, under such a threat, to put them in that position.

I remind the Government that it was its timetable to delay this to the last possible minute, thus, the wrath of industry falls squarely on the Government's head. We are not prepared in these dire economic times to have industry denied an appropriate deductibility regime, even over 10 years. That is the threat that is put to us in the dying hours of this year, prior to Christmas. I certainly hope that the sorts of standover tactics that we have seen tonight with this Bill, and in the earlier debate, are not a signal of the new Keating Ministry, because it will not be in the best interests of Australia. It is regrettable that this, the first Bill that we have seen under the Keating Administration, is so dictatorial, so demanding and so demeaning of government.

I remind the Senate that the Government alleges that it is concerned about shortcomings in the Income Tax Assessment Act, particularly those shortcomings that affect the competitiveness of Australian industry vis-a-vis those operating in the international field. Our proposal would have put the legislation on a par with the world's best. What we are doing is relegating Australian industry to second-rate status, making it harder for it to compete. I find it hard to accept, in the knowledge that next year an improved deductibility regime will be introduced. It is basically pigheadedness on the part of the Government. I suppose it will be seen to be a sign of strength; but it is a sign of folly, and I do not believe it will be well taken up by industry at the present time.

The previous Prime Minister and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) referred to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet the concern about the efficiency of the taxation deductibility regime. Certainly this would be one issue that would be examined. There is some concern that there has been inadequate communication within the Government for it to come to this sort of decision. It is a decision that was probably made by Treasury, without adequate communication either with Prime Minister and Cabinet, which has this reference before it in relation to depreciation, or DITAC.

I raised this matter in a question this afternoon. I am also concerned that in this whole deductibility regime the Minister has not yet come back to parliament and told those companies that balance on 31 December how they will deal with the statement on industry depreciation. They will be disadvantaged. I think it is pretty poor legislative tactics for the Government to offer a carrot and not produce within the appropriate time schedule a legislative base that will enable companies to effect an appropriate deduction, which allegedly was promised over nine months ago.

I think that this wrath from industry will in time fall very heavily on the head of the Australian Government. I therefore regret the decision that has been made, which is certainly not in the national interest. A few moments ago we were talking about legislation that basically involved certain decisions in the national interest. I do not believe that this is in the national interest, particularly at a time of ailing investment in manufacturing and mining. These are the two industries that surely should help bring Australia out of the recession.

In many cases the environmental impact studies involve a necessary expense, incurred under legislation or as a result of Commonwealth, State or local government decree. I believe that what we proposed was not unreasonable in the circumstances. Because of the threat, the Opposition will reluctantly have to agree with the proposals as returned from the House of Representatives, but we regret the tactics that have been used.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was pretty stirring stuff from Senator Watson, but if we had stuck with him, he did not have to agree, did he? For years, Senator Watson has complained that Australia does not have a competitive business taxation structure. He knows that Senator Button has written that well publicised letter to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), saying that we do not have a competitive business tax system. He says that he has responded to a threat; he has agreed to fold on this important amendment which he himself proposed earlier.
—Purely because we haven't got the time.

—I am telling Senator Watson that it is untested, and I have said to him that we would have supported it. However, given that he has accepted the Government's threat, those numbers mean that the amended amendment will be carried.

—I support the motion I moved to agree to the amendment from the House of Representatives. The Opposition amendment was in two parts. The Government is accepting one part, and so I will not waste any time talking about that; that has now been agreed by all parties in the chamber. Regarding the other part, I made this statement during the committee stage in the principal debate and so I will reiterate it very briefly. The Government is not of the view that it is appropriate that we should use the taxation system to subsidise companies conducting environmental impact statements.

PARA.TAB: There are two basic flaws with that. I think it is appropriate that we have taken a step forward to recognise through the taxation system those expenses, but it is unrealistic to be writing them off over three years, and it is, in effect, a subsidy on the conduct of environmental impact statements. We do not believe that we should subsidise it because it is bad tax policy; also, I believe that not one jot of extra environmental activity would be undertaken as a consequence of this amendment, because the environmental impact statement requirements on companies are set down in other legislation.

It is for that reason that we were not originally disposed to agree to the amendment and it is why, I confess, we took a fairly strong line against it, although not uncompromising, because we did propose the compromise that came back from the House of Representatives, which has been accepted. Everybody would prefer that we never had to have forthright negotiations around this place. It would be nice if those things did not occur. I think there is broad agreement amongst all parties on the direction of this part of the Bill and I think of the Bill as a whole. Some might, because of their other package of policies, want to go further with bits of it, but it is not a matter where we have strong contention.

There are some fairly important questions of principle involved in the matter that was before us. That is the reason we took the stand we did. It is the reason I reiterate it now. Therefore, I welcome the fact that the message from the House of Representatives is going to be accepted. History will be our judge, but the compromise that has come back from the House of Representatives which accepts part of the Opposition's amendment may prove to be even better legislation than that which the Government introduced. This is a heresy which I should not utter, but it is very late at night and it is nearly Christmas. Perhaps the Treasurer will not see that I have done it because he will not read the Senate Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which Treasurer?

—The incumbent with whom I discussed this matter. It may also be that, as to some of the concerns that I expressed in the committee stage originally—and some officers have advised the Treasurer (Mr Willis) and me of these concerns—there is a potential for abuse here and it may prove to be justified. Our compromise may turn out to be something we have to move to remedy subsequently. We all hope not, because it would be the sort of 1980s abuse of the tax system that we hope we are growing out of, and that would not be the sort of use of investment that the people of Australia are best served by.

PARA.TAB: So there is an element of risk, but if the risk proves to be justified it will be at the very least a reasonable compromise, perhaps more. For that reason I thank honourable senators for their contribution to this debate and support the motion I have moved.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Resolution reported; report adopted.

DEBATE.TITLE: POLITICAL BROADCASTS (TASMANIA) REGULATIONSPOLITICAL BROADCASTS (AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY) REGULATIONS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Political Broadcasts (Tasmania) Regulations, as contained in Statutory Rules 1991 No. 482, and the Political Broadcasts (Australian Capital Territory) Regulations, as contained in Statutory Rules 1991 No. 483, made under the Broadcasting Act 1942, be disallowed.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to speak briefly to the motion I have moved. As everybody would know, this was one of the most outrageous pieces of legislation ever placed before this Parliament. It commenced in a way that would have banned all advertising on radio and television at all times—365 days of the year—for Federal, State and local government elections. As time went by it was somewhat amended. It was also a major reason why the Australian Democrats changed their leader. It was apparent that a deal had been made with the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) and their then leader, Senator Powell. It was genuinely thought that this legislation, having been referred to the Senate Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures—and I refer to that part relating to the ban on advertising, not that part relating to disclosure provisions—would disappear, never to be seen again.

PARA.TAB: But what did we see? We saw the new leader of the Democrats up his price on the previous agreement, the apparent back room deal, that was made. It was a low figure. We saw yet again another deal made which would give the Democrats something like $1.8m of free radio, and free television ads in particular, and another amount to all parties which totalled somewhere in the order of $8m.

We had what I could only call a ratty provision—one that will not work—whereby in an election a brochure is distributed to every householder in Australia showing the photograph, curriculum vitae and short policy of every candidate, at the taxpayers' expense. There are two reasons why this could make a mockery of the whole electoral system. One is that the straight logistics of it will make it almost impossible for this brochure to be delivered because, in the main, it is not known until nominations close, except by those who know well in advance that they have been preselected by a political party, who will nominate. From that day on it takes approximately 20 days for the Electoral Commission to get a photograph, curriculum vitae and short policy statement, put it into a brochure and have it distributed to every household in Australia. It is an incredible waste of taxpayers' money and an abuse of the taxpayer because surely it is the role of candidates and political parties to let the electorate know who they are and what they stand for.

The second aspect of that which I believe will cause incredible problems to the integrity of the electoral system is that it will encourage anyone in the community, for a simple nomination fee of $250, to be able to nominate and get a brochure distributed which describes his or her job and policies. It is not beyond the bounds of possibility that it would be an attraction to local business people to spend the $250 and get the brochure distributed. More likely, however, is that political parties will see this as a cheap opportunity to have multiple Independents stand, even though they are really fronts for political parties, and have these brochures distributed in the hope, particularly in marginal seats, that they will pick up just a few extra votes that could take them over the line.

The major reason that we are opposing these regulations that apply to the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill is a legal opinion we obtained from the Robert Garran Professor of Law at the Australian National University, Professor Synes. I am happy to quote this because in debate during the political broadcasts Bill the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) said that he had a legal opinion to say that what was in the Bill, which is now an Act, was constitutional and could not be subject to challenge.

Professor Synes is one of the most respected constitutional lawyers in this country, and it was for that reason that we sought his opinion. He made it very clear that the provisions could not validly operate in respect of State elections. That is what these regulations are about. They refer to the ACT and Tasmania because within about seven or eight weeks or so—in early February—there will be an election in the ACT. It is also anticipated that there could well be an election in Tasmania. These regulations remain in force until and if they are disallowed.

We believe that seeking leave tonight to have this matter debated is an opportunity to consider this issue. I really exhort the Australian Democrats to consider this move because the advices we have, of which I am happy to give them a copy, make this very clear. I interpolate that I am sure we all welcome Senator Kemp back into the Senate. I hope that he has not been too lonely.

These regulations seek to impose the will of a centralist Federal government upon the States. When the Bill was initially mooted and introduced by the Minister in the middle of this year, the whole hype of it concerned Federal elections, disclosure and a range of other matters. These regulations tell the States how they must operate. As pointed out by Professor Synes, the central provisions relating to State elections are those contained in section 95D as is now in the Act. He points out that:

SPEECH.PARA: It is clearly established that the Commonwealth may not discriminate against one or more States or impair their capacity to exist or function as independent units of the federation.
He goes on to say:
To date, the only ground on which federal laws have been declared invalid under this implied principle has been that they discriminated against the States generally, as compared with other persons.
He then quotes some cases and points out:
The Bill does not fall foul of this aspect of the principle.
But in his view it impairs the capacity of a State to function as an independent unit of federation. He said:

While no federal law has, as yet, been invalidated on this ground, the principle has been reasserted on a number of occasions in recent times. What it is that may not be destroyed or impaired has been variously described as `the structural integrity of the State components of the federal framework...'
He continues:

What is involved, here, is not the impairment of a State's powers or functions of government, which occurs of course, every time a federal law controls a State. The implied principle protects the State as an organisation of government, that is to say its general structure, machinery and processes by which it exercises whatever governmental powers and functions it has.

He points out that a Commonwealth law which purported, for example, to control the appointment of State Ministers, judges, the procedure of its Parliament or its relationship between its Parliament and the Executive would clearly come within the implied prohibition. Again, to quote from Professor Synes—and this is the nub of the issue:

It seems to me that the control of advertising and persuasion for purposes of State elections comes within the same category. The process of election is fundamental to the organisation and structure of State governments. It is the process which determines the composition of both its legislature and its executive, therefore, a federal law which purported to control the advertising of political matter in relation to a State election would be contrary to the implied constitutional prohibition.
I think the key to it is at the end, where he said:
At the heart of the . . . matter is the impairment of the capacity of a State to function as an independent unit of the federation.

As I have indicated, that is the major reason why we believe these regulations should be opposed. Of course, we have a deeper philosophical point of view. Right from the word go, we have been absolutely consistent in our view: a view that was shared by the Standing Committee. It said that, having looked at the banning of advertising on radio and television, it would walk away from it, even though it had some appeal, because it attacked freedom of speech and freedom of political expression in Australia. That was contained in the majority report of the Standing Committee. In my own State, the Premier, Mr Goss, stated quite categorically that he did not support the legislation because it was an attack on freedom of speech.

PARA.TAB: We have a very precious heritage of freedom in this country. This Act, as it now is, attacks those freedoms. It attacks the freedoms at a Federal level—which of course was our major cause of concern. We have made the point clear to the Democrats over and over again that as far as we were concerned there was no compromise when it came to an attack on freedom of political expression or freedom of speech. One either accepts the principle of those freedoms or one does not; there is no such thing as a half-way house.

This is the reason why I have moved this motion. I really encourage the Democrats to think seriously about it. It is not just a general attack on freedom of speech, but it is now our strong view—in the presence of considerable legal opinion from the Robert Garran law professor at ANU—that it would be unconstitutional and invalid in respect of its application to the States.

This is what these two regulations, which have been introduced tonight, do. They seek to impose on the States this ban on paid advertising on radio and television during election campaigns. We have an ex-Prime Minister who talked about federalism and cooperation with the States; yet the Government not only has an Act that is the most outrageous attack on freedom of speech in federal elections that this country has ever seen, but also it is now applicable, under the regulations, to the States. The first two cabs off the rank are the Australian Capital Territory and Tasmania.

I raise a point of interest. The Democrats went along with this legislation and, curiously, as well as the coming ACT elections, a referendum is to be held. I do not know whether the Democrats received a letter, but I certainly received one from the group of people who are supporting the Hare-Clarke proportional representation system within the ACT. That group has written to the ex-Prime Minister and asked, `Do you know what you have done?'. A large slab of those people who are supporting the Hare-Clarke system in the ACT referendum are Democrats. There is a sort of union of people—in fact, it comprises everyone except the ALP which is pushing single member electorates—which wants to promote the Hare-Clarke system because these people believe it is more appropriate to the ACT and it will bring about a fair result.

These people have written to the ex-Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, and they have said, `Do you know what you have done? You have prevented us from taking out advertisements to promote the Hare-Clarke system within the ACT'. This is only the beginning of the sorts of things we will find. I would not hesitate one bit—in view of my earlier remarks about the unworkable aspects of the silly brochure and the constitutional requirements—to say that this Act will not survive. It should not survive; it is atrocious. It is an attack on freedom of political expression the like of which this country has never seen before. It is totally and utterly un-Australian.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats do not support the disallowance of these regulations. We have heard the arguments; we have heard them all night. The substance of Senator Parer's arguments goes to the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Act and not to the regulations. However, it is dishonest to keep trotting out this hoary chestnut about freedom of speech when it can be argued just as validly that the sort of advertising the Opposition is seeking to protect—the sort of advertising which is trivial, which focuses on personalities and not on issues, and which has as its very aim the inhibition and obstruction of rational and detailed analysis of election policies—is a threat to democracy. It is not simply an argument about freedom of speech—as appealing as that slogan might sound.

PARA.TAB: Senator Parer has one legal opinion about the constitutional invalidity of free time. The Government can have another. The Democrats are satisfied that these regulations give effect, in a fair way, to the intention of the Bill which has been passed. That is why, having been through that marathon debate and having canvassed all of those arguments, it would be ridiculous for us to accept disallowance at this stage.
Debate (on motion by Senator Hill) adjourned.
Debate resumed from 14 November, on motion by Senator Tate:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bankruptcy Amendment Bill 1991 relates to a direct consequence of the Hawke Government's disastrous economic policies—that is, the number of bankruptcies which are spiralling and out of control. In 1989-90 there were 8,552 bankruptcies in Australia, which was then the highest figure ever. In 1990-91 the figure leapt dramatically by more than 50 per cent to 13,091. The quarterly bankruptcy statistics for the September quarter this year show a 72 per cent increase in comparison with the same quarter last year. Australian people and businesses are going to the wall at an absolutely unprecedented rate. In fact, in the present economic climate, it is not so much surprising that there are so many bankruptcies but rather that the figure is not even higher.

PARA.TAB: Most of these bankruptcies happen to ordinary Australians. However, there has been a great deal of community outrage at the disgraceful way in which some of the high profile erstwhile mates of this Government have managed to avoid the law. For too many of these failed entrepreneurs bankruptcy has not even amounted to a minor interruption to their opulent lifestyles. The coalition is therefore pleased that the Government has taken some action to tighten up the law relating to bankruptcy through the introduction of this Bill. The Minister conceded in his second reading speech that this Bill is a response to a feeling in the community that the mechanisms in the Bankruptcy Act for obtaining income contributions from bankrupts who can afford it have been less effective than they should be.

The Bill introduces a range of amendments to bankruptcy law principally in relation to discharge from bankruptcy, contributions by bankrupts to the bankrupt estate from their income, and procedures for meetings of creditors. The Bill replaces the court ordered discharge system with an administrative system based on clearly specified eligibility and disqualification criteria; clarifies the grounds on which a bankruptcy can be prolonged by objection and provides for objections in certain circumstances to extend bankruptcies to eight years; prohibits overseas travel without court approval by bankrupts liable to make contributions to income; sets up a compulsory income contributions regime which applies to bankrupts who have an income above the specified threshold amount; puts in place new administrative enforcement mechanisms to facilitate the recovery of property into bankrupt estates and to enable efficient collection of contributions; expands the powers of the official receivers to obtain information and to undertake inquiries in relation to the financial affairs of bankrupts, including inquiries overseas; clarifies creditors meeting procedures to ensure that creditors are fully informed before making decisions relating to the future course of a bankruptcy administration; provides for regular indexation of money amounts specified in the legislation; and gives jurisdiction to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal to review decisions of trustees and officials of the bankruptcy administration in connection with the proposed new discharge and income distribution arrangements.

Section 131 of the Bankruptcy Act provides that a bankrupt is able to retain income for his or her own benefit subject to any court order to the contrary. Such court orders are, however, expensive to obtain and in many cases the trustee in bankruptcy will simply not have sufficient funds to go to court. In any event, the only sanction for non-compliance with the contribution order is imprisonment for contempt of court, which is hardly a suitable remedy and is very unlikely to be applied.

Many bankrupts—I am sure that we are all familiar with some of the more high profile examples—consequently manage to earn large incomes after bankruptcy and also manage to avoid paying anything to their creditors from that income. It is regrettably easy to hide assets and income out of the reach of creditors, often through the use of associated entities, even though the bankrupt is still deriving benefit from that income. Under the provisions in this Bill, income is defined to include benefits which, if they were provided by an employer to an employee, would be taxable as fringe benefits under the fringe benefits legislation. It would also include the amount of any money or the value of any other consideration received by a person other than the bankrupt from another person or associated entity as a result of work done or services performed by the bankrupt.

The trustee in bankruptcy will be able to make an assessment of the income likely to be derived by the bankrupt during the contribution and assessment period, which will be an annual period beginning at the commencement of bankruptcy. The trustee, in making the assessment, will be able to take into account any information about the bankrupt's employment or income. If the bankrupt claims not to be receiving income or to be unemployed but is engaged in activities which resemble employment and are capable of generating income, the trustee will be able to treat the bankrupt as being employed or in receipt of income.

The base threshold amount is 3.5 times that which at any time is the maximum basic rate of pension. At present, this would be an annual income of about $23,000 for a person without dependants. The bankrupt will be able to contribute half of the assessed income above the actual income threshold amount. If a bankrupt's income is below the actual income threshold amount, they will not have to make contributions, although they can do so if they choose.

Pursuant to new section 139T, the official receiver will be able to authorise departure from the relevant contribution level in cases of hardship for medical reasons, work related expenses or child-care. Decisions by trustees in relation to income assessment will be reviewable by the Inspector-General in Bankruptcy and by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Under proposed sections 139ZK and 139ZL, the official receiver will be empowered to collect moneys owing by way of contribution from third parties through garnishment or a charge over property. These provisions are based on section 218 of the Income Tax Assessment Act.

In relation to early discharges of bankruptcy, section 150 of the Bankruptcy Act currently provides that a person may apply to the court for an order of discharge at any time after the date of bankruptcy. Making an application to the court is an expensive procedure and therefore little used. When it is used it is almost always by persons who have become bankrupt through failed business activities who wish to be discharged so that they can resume those activities. Low income earners can rarely afford to apply for discharge. The eligibility and disqualification criteria introduced in this Bill are designed to ensure that a person who has become a bankrupt because of commercial culpability is disqualified from early discharge.

It is proposed that a bankrupt will be able to apply for discharge after six months have passed since filing a statement of affairs with the registrar. The trustee then assesses the application to determine whether the applicant is eligible for and is not disqualified from early discharge. The eligibility criteria are that the bankrupt has no or insufficient money to pay the trustee or to pay a dividend to the creditors, has not entered into a transaction that is void against the trustee, and earns an income which is less than the actual income threshold amount applicable to him or her at the time the early discharge application is made.

The bankrupt will be disqualified if he or she has previously been a bankrupt, if more than 50 per cent of his or her unsecured liabilities were incurred as a result of the bankrupt carrying on business activities, if he or she has unsecured liabilities which exceed 150 per cent of his or her income in the year immediately before the date of bankruptcy, or if he or she has given false or misleading information about his or her beneficial interests in any property or his or her liabilities or income. Decisions by trustees in relation to early discharge will be subject to review by the Inspector-General in Bankruptcy and by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

Automatic discharge from bankruptcy normally after three years can at present be objected to on the grounds set out in section 149 and include unsatisfactory conduct on the part of the bankrupt and failure to cooperate in the administration of his or her estate. In proposed section 149D, the Government sets out new more detailed grounds for objection which include the bankrupt continuing to manage a corporation contrary to the corporations law, failing to provide information about assets liabilities and income where required to do so by the trustee, departing Australia without permission or failing to return when requested to do so, and failing to attend a meeting of creditors. Some of these grounds will extend the bankruptcy for up to eight years, others for five years. In order to encourage bankrupts to file statements of affairs, which often happens when the bankruptcy is by creditors' petition, the period of bankruptcy will run for three years from the date of filing.

In relation to overseas travel restrictions, the Bill also contains provisions that are designed to restrict such travel by bankrupts. Bankrupts who are assessed as liable to make contributions to the estate from their income will not be allowed to undertake overseas travel except with the permission of the court. This permission will only be granted where the travel is necessary on compassionate grounds or where it is necessary for the bankrupt to travel in order to derive income. It will not be granted if the bankrupt has been guilty of conduct that would found an objection to discharge under proposed section 149D.

Under the provisions of this Bill, the official receiver and registered trustee will be able to recover property disposed of by a bankrupt in a transaction designed to defeat creditors which is void against the trustee by administrative means. Presently, this can be done only through the courts and it is expected that the new procedure based on similar provisions in the Income Tax Assessment Act will be more cost effective.

Difficulties can arise particularly in the context of complex bankruptcies in the conduct of creditors' meetings. This Bill sets out detailed meeting procedures so that creditors are aware of their rights and trustees are aware of their responsibilities. It provides that creditors will be able to remove a trustee by resolution, not only by special resolution. Bankruptcy law, in what is necessarily a difficult balance, aims to help the bankrupts get back on their feet, while at the same time obtaining the best possible result for creditors. While this Bill will make it more difficult for bankrupts to avoid the law, the coalition does have serious concerns that it singles out business owners and operators for special punishment by disqualifying them from the early discharge procedure under Part VII, Division 3 of the Bill.

The coalition sees no reason to treat all business bankrupts, the majority of whom are victims of the recession we had to have, in this discriminatory way when the fault lies with a few of the Hawke Government's big business mates. I therefore take this opportunity to foreshadow that I will be moving a second reading amendment which reflects this concern, and that in the committee stage I will be moving for the deletion of proposed section 149Y which provides that a bankrupt is disqualified from early discharge if involved in business activities before the bankruptcy and more than 50 per cent of his unsecured liabilities were incurred as a result of carrying on business activities.

I will also be moving for the deletion of proposed section 149Z which provides that a bankrupt is disqualified from early discharge if his unsecured liabilities exceed 150 per cent of his income during the year prior to the date of the bankruptcy. Once again, it seems to be punishing many for the transgressions of a few. I foreshadow some additional amendments I will be moving on behalf of the Opposition which aim to clarify the drafting of proposed subsection 64H(1) concerning the use of telephone conference facilities for creditors' meetings and the power of the official receiver to enter premises in proposed section 77AA(1). I also foreshadow that I will not be proceeding with Opposition amendment No. 3 which allows the Official Receiver to obtain information and evidence in proposed section 77C(1).

In conclusion, whilst not opposing the Bill, as I said at the outset, the coalition deplores what has been the Hawke-Keating Government's blind determination to pursue economic policies which are sending Australians bankrupt in such appalling numbers. Therefore, I move:
At the end of motion, add ", but the Senate:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)deplores the fact that Australia's bankruptcy levels are the worst for 60 years, and
(b)condemns the Government for its proposal to single out business owners and operators for special punishment by disqualifying them from early discharge from bankruptcy".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is discussing the Bankruptcy Amendment Bill 1991. This Bill is directed at four main areas: the movement of bankrupts out of Australia; voting procedures at creditors' meetings; repayment of creditors from income; and the period of bankruptcy. Like Senator Hill, I observe that this Bill is being brought in at a time when we have an unprecedented increase in bankruptcies in Australia due to the current depression. It is not before time that amendments are introduced to tighten up the provisions governing the administration of bankrupt estates because some of the current provisions have enabled high flying bankrupts to leave Australia and at least for a time, and sometimes all together, to escape their responsibilities.

PARA.TAB: On the question of movement of bankrupts out of Australia, it should be observed that currently there are relevant provisions in the current legislation. Section 77(a) of the Bankruptcy Act requires a bankrupt forthwith after becoming a bankrupt to furnish the trustee with the bankrupt's passport, if any. Section 272 of the Act is also relevant, providing that it is an offence to leave Australia with the intent to defeat creditors. This Bill provides that a bankrupt who is assessed as liable to make contributions to the estate from his or her income will not be able to travel overseas except by permission of the court, although permission will be able to be granted for compassionate reasons: for instance, the death of or serious injury to a close relative or where travel is necessary to enable the bankrupt to continue to derive income. Therefore, these amendments clarify and strengthen the provisions currently in the Act.

They have been criticised on the basis that, with regard to travel restrictions, it may be more beneficial to provide trustees with clearer guidelines rather than making it necessary for bankrupts to apply to the courts. Further, the example is given that in a recent case a bankrupt requested the return of her passport to visit a dying relative, the trip being paid for by members of the family. Had court approval been required at that stage, this would only have added more cost and grief.

However, the rationale between the tougher restrictions on overseas travel by bankrupts is the basic assumption that, as a general rule, bankrupts should remain in Australia during the bankruptcy and that the instances of overseas travel by bankrupts genuinely justified by employment or compassionate grounds would be very rare indeed. The absence of the bankrupt from Australia potentially is so disruptive of the proper administration of the estate that it is advisable for it to be a matter appropriate for consideration by a court rather than by the trustee. The Australian Democrats believe that the proposed amendment will strengthen the legislation in this area.
