It is clearly more sensible to assess an application for travel prior to departure rather than to attempt to impose a penalty after the event. It is also worth emphasising again that the requirement will only apply to bankrupts above the income threshold.

The voting procedures of creditors' meetings are largely uncontroversial. One of the aims of the Bill in this area is to reform voting procedures so that trustees may be removed by majority in value rather than number, and at least three-quarters in value of creditors are required. I refer briefly to clause 64H which provides for telephone conferences and foreshadow that the Australian Democrats will support the Opposition's amendment in this area.

In the area of repayment of creditors from income, criticism has focused on the fact that once again there is already provision in the Act for payment from income and that bankrupts will be reduced to a subsistence level. At present, section 131 of the Act provides that a bankrupt is able to retain income for his or her own benefit, subject to any order of the court to the contrary. In the second reading speech, the Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: Section 131 has not been a particularly useful instrument for trustees in bankruptcy to employ. The court process is costly to invoke and, frequently, neither has the trustee funds available to initiate the process nor are creditors willing to advance funds to the trustee to enable the trustee to take action. Frequently, once made, orders are not complied with by the bankrupt. The only sanction for non-compliance with a contribution order is imprisonment for contempt of court. This is a severe sanction, and not particularly useful—an imprisoned bankrupt cannot earn income to contribute to the estate.

Hence, the Australian Democrats are favourably disposed to the proposed amendments in clause 25 of the Bill, which would make the contribution from a bankrupt's income compulsory where the income is above a minimum threshold which `will be set well above the level of pensions and related benefits'. The Bill provides for a basic income threshold amount equal to three and a half times what at any time is the maximum basic rate of pension. As at 1 July 1991, this would reflect a gross annual income of $22,886.50 for a person with no dependants.

PARA.TAB: The Bill makes allowances for changes in liability to reflect amounts actually earned during an assessment period, and for variation by the Official Receiver where the bankrupt suffers hardship. Clause 139T(2) sets out reasons on which an application may be based, and more may be prescribed later by regulation. There is a right of appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

The Australian Democrats have some concern about a particular provision in clause 139T(5). This subclause provides that where the Official Receiver does not respond to an application on the basis of hardship within 30 days, the application is deemed to have been refused. This procedure appears to unnecessarily disadvantage the applicant on the basis of hardship. In effect, he or she will be penalised if the officers working in the Official Receiver's office do not perform their duty as they should within 30 days. Accordingly, I will be moving an amendment which will seek to reverse this situation and deem the decision to have been positive, in favour of the applicant, if the Official Receiver has not responded to the application within 30 days.

If it is later found that the decision is, in substance, unsatisfactory, the Official Receiver has no possibility of appeal under current legislation. I have been advised that it would be a relatively easy matter to insert a further amendment to the effect that such a right of appeal would be available to the Official Receiver. Shortage of time has prevented me providing that amendment. I advise the Government and the Opposition that this avenue remains open. On balance, the proposed amendment in this area represents an improvement over current procedures.

I turn now to the period of bankruptcy. I note that the changes in this area are substantial. At present, under section 149, bankruptcy usually lasts for three years and early discharge can be obtained only on application by the court under section 150. The Government suggests that only a very small percentage of bankrupts can presently avail themselves of this right because of the great costs involved. Under the new regime proposed in the Bill, the three-year period will continue to apply in the ordinary course of events.

Early discharge under an administrative system will be introduced and will be available automatically to bankrupts who repay their creditors in full, or where the bankrupt has neither significant property nor significant income to make contributions. Clearly, this will contribute substantially to the swift rehabilitation of a significant proportion of bankrupts who currently remain in the bankruptcy system for three years to no purpose.

The Bill proposes that bankrupts be ineligible for an early discharge where their liabilities exceed a specified percentage of pre-bankruptcy income; where the bankrupt has failed to disclose assets, liabilities or income; where the bankrupt has incurred credit after bankruptcy without disclosing it; or where the bankrupt continues to manage a corporation unlawfully once bankrupt. Additionally, in a small number of cases, bankruptcy will be prolonged administratively for up to eight years where, for instance, the bankrupt fails to make the required contributions from income, incurs substantial further credit or fails to account adequately for the disposal of income or property.

The Australian Democrats share the Opposition's concern about clause 149Y, which penalises people carrying on business and includes them under the disqualification provisions against early discharge from bankruptcy. In this current climate in particular, but even in general terms, we can see no reason why this should be so. However, we believe that clause 149Z should be retained, as it covers the area where people incur debts without having the reasonable expectation of being able to repay. This clause, being general, covers both personal debts and debts incurred during the conduct of a business. We believe that this adequately covers the objectives which the Government might have had in introducing this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is appropriate that the Bankruptcy Amendment Bill 1991 is being dealt with on the same evening that Mr Keating was elected by the Australian Labor Party as the Prime Minister of Australia. It should really be called the Keating Amendment Bill because `Keating' and `bankruptcy' are synonymous. Today, this man who created the worst recession in Australia's history was elected to the top job by the people of the Labor Party. It is a disgrace that this man should be rewarded for bankruptcy. Madam Acting Deputy President, you will be aware, as will all members of the Government, that bankruptcies were up 53.1 per cent in 1990-91 from what they were in 1989-90; up 72.2 per cent in the September quarter of 1991-92; and up 154 per cent between 1982-83—the last year of the Liberal Government—and the present time.

PARA.TAB: All of this was done by the same man who brought us these new pieces of the English language: `scumbag', `sleazebag' and `spew'. That is the man who has brought this sort of bankruptcy. Mr Keating is the man who said, `I think loyalty is the stuff of politics; political parties are built on loyalty'. Unfortunately, Bob Hawke did not believe Mr Keating when he said that. These bankruptcies are brought to us by the man who, on 30 May, said, `It is not true that this is the worst recession in 60 years'. Fortunately, Australia does not believe Mr Keating either. These bankruptcies are brought to us by the man who said, `We won't let there be a recession'. No-one believed him when he said that. These bankruptcies are brought to us by the man who said, `I am not sitting here desperate to be Prime Minister'. Who would believe him when he said that?

These bankruptcies are brought to us by the man who, in March 1991, said, `The worst is now behind us; the Government established the strategy'. We are still suffering and, if it were funny, we would be laughing, that someone could be so base as to make those sorts of claims. These bankruptcies are brought to us by the man who, in February, said, `We won't destroy business activity; we won't destroy employment'. We now have one million of our fellow Australians unemployed. These bankruptcies are brought to us by the man who said, `We are well on the way to prosperity'. Mr Keating might be, but what about the rest of us?

These bankruptcies are brought to us by the man who said, `I think a lot of the lay-offs are behind us; I think they laid them off last year'. How can typical and traditional Labor voters possibly believe Mr Keating when he says that? These bankruptcies are brought to us by the man who, in August 1991, said, `I have never committed myself to a policy or a decision I was ashamed of'. On the night that this man has been elected to the top position in our political system, we are debating this Bill. I think it is most appropriate that the welcome to Mr Keating as Prime Minister is recognised by the Senate dealing with this Bankruptcy Amendment Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I fully endorse the remarks of my colleagues Senator Hill and Senator Macdonald. Senator Macdonald pointed out the exquisite irony of this Bill being brought before this chamber tonight. After all, who was the friend of the rich corporate cowboys? Who were the friends of the spivs? Who were the people who made the Labor Party break from its traditional support and become close to the rich and powerful and the corporate cowboys? In some ways, this Bill seeks to address some of those problems which occurred in that period.
—Do you have a mirror on your desk, Senator?

—The honourable senator was one of the 56 who scabbed on Bob Hawke. I say to Senator Button that there were 900,060 people today who, if they were represented in the Labor Party Caucus, would have voted against Mr Keating and against Mr Hawke and for a new leader who could have some program and some vision to rebuild Australia and employment.
—That is not an original comment.

—That is not an original comment. As the honourable senator correctly reminds me, that was a comment by Senator McKiernan. This is a sorry day for Australia. I believe it is a sorry day for Senator Button, because of the role that people such as him have played in undermining Mr Hawke. I am not a supporter of Mr Hawke but we have seen Senator Button in this chamber day after day refusing to give any sense of commitment and loyalty to the man who was the Prime Minister of this country, who was thrown from office and who was politically killed by a thousand stabs from his closest colleagues. I think that what we have seen is a sorry day in Australian history.

PARA.TAB: I wish briefly to make some comments on particular aspects of this Bill. As many people have observed, this Bill comes to us on the heels of the corporate cowboys of the 1980s. Perhaps the one who has received the greatest press in recent days is Mr Christopher Skase. There would be very few Australians who would not share the view that the massive debts run up by Mr Skase and his Qintex company in his greedy splurge in the 1980s were nothing short of appalling. The demise of these corporate cowboys affected many innocent people. The effects of these empire failures took jobs from many Australians and placed losses and costs on banks, which will ultimately be borne by average Australians. They left, in short, a ruinous trail in their wake.

This Bill goes some way to addressing the problems that we have seen in recent months. One measure in the Bill before us today imposes a prohibition on travel without prior approval by bankrupts liable to make contributions from income. However, in our view, this Bill clearly does not go far enough. Given the short time available, I do not plan to proceed at length on that point, but I just draw attention to the fact that in 1988 the Government commissioned a report into the insolvency laws known as the Harmer report. The reforms within the Harmer report were welcomed by the insolvency industry as providing real and substantial suggestions as to how the current regulatory framework could be improved. However, since the Harmer report was handed down, the Government has allowed it to gather dust. I think that that is a pity.

It should not be concluded from any of my remarks today that the aim of any new legislation should be to penalise all bankrupts in the way that most Australians would believe that the corporate cowboys should be dealt with. It is a sad fact that, as a direct result of the Hawke-Keating Labor Government induced recession, the rate of bankruptcies has soared in recent times. It is a shocking fact that, in the last financial year, one in 1,000 adult Australians were declared bankrupt. Personal bankruptcies soared to over 13,000 in the last year to June, up from 8,600 just one year earlier.

In my home State—also the home State of Senator Button—the figures are just as devastating. In fact, in Victoria we had the double whammy, as you know, Madam Acting Deputy President—a Labor government in Canberra and a Labor government in Victoria. The joint results of those two disastrous governments have seriously affected the capacity of business to remain viable and, in fact, many people in Victoria have been forced to file for bankruptcy. In the last three months to the end of September 1991, some 1,146 people filed for bankruptcy in Victoria. This constitutes a 75 per cent increase over the same quarter in 1990.

Finally, the Government stands condemned for placing before the chamber today a Bill which, while seeking to achieve a positive end in relation to corporate cowboys, has ignored many of the reforms contained in the 1988 Harmer report. Such reforms would have the effect, in many ways, of assisting those average Australians who have fallen victim to the Government's self-induced savage recession. The Bill before us today does not go far enough in this regard.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank those senators from the Opposition and the Australian Democrats who have contributed to this debate on a very important Bill which will stop bankrupts leaving Australia unless satisfactory arrangements to meet obligations are made; which will reform voting procedures at meetings of creditors; which will compel bankrupts with the capacity to repay creditors from income to do so; and which will deal with a period of bankruptcy in various situations. It is a most important Bill, and I thank those honourable senators who have indicated their support.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.
Original question, as amended, resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Clauses 1 to 11—by leave—taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 12.
Motion (by Senator Hill) proposed:

PROCTEXT.PARA: 1.Clause 12, page 10, proposed subsection 64H(1), lines 3 to 10, omit the subsection, substitute the following subsection:

PARA.TAB: "'64H.(1) If a trustee has considered it appropriate that telephone conference facilities may be used for a meeting of creditors pursuant to section 64C and if a creditor, or the proxy or attorney of the creditor, who wishes to participate by telephone in the meeting has satisfied the requirements of paragraph 64C(b), in so far as they are applicable, the trustee must take all reasonable steps to ensure that the creditor, or the proxy or attorney of the creditor, is contacted on the telephone number provided by that person before the start of the meeting, and if such a person is so contacted the trustee must take all reasonable steps to ensure that that person can hear the proceedings, and can be heard, by means of those facilities, so that that person can participate in the meeting.".

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will be supporting the amendment, largely for the reasons enunciated by Senator Hill.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will not support this particular amendment, but I can see that the Opposition and the Democrats are determined to press the matter, so I will not take the matter to a vote.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 13 to 18—by leave—taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 19.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 2.Clause 19, page 22, after proposed subsection 77AA(1), insert the following subsection:

PARA.TAB: "`(1A) A trustee may by application in writing request the Official Receiver, or an officer authorised in writing by the Official Receiver, to enter premises on behalf of the trustee to seek information for any purposes of this Act and, if the Official Receiver, or an officer authorised in writing by the Official Receiver, acts on behalf of a trustee pursuant to such an application, the provisions of subsections (1),(2) and (3) of this section apply in respect of such actions provided that:

TAB.TAB: (a)the application by a trustee shall contain reasonable details of the information or the type of information sought and the reasons the trustee requires the information; and

(b)if the Official Receiver acts on behalf of a trustee as provided by this subsection, on presentation by the Official Receiver of documentary evidence to support the claim, the trustee shall reimburse, out of the proceeds of the property of the bankrupt estate, the Official Receiver for costs and expenses incurred by the Official Receiver in so acting.".

SPEECH.PARA: Under proposed subsection 77AA, as presently drafted, the Official Receiver has the power to enter premises to seek information. The Opposition is of the view that a trustee should also have the right to ask the Official Receiver to enter premises in these circumstances. This seems to us to be a sensible amendment as it is most often the trustee who would be aware of the need to seek information for purposes under the Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats will not be supporting this amendment. We have examined the legislation and are satisfied that the amendment is unnecessary as the provisions are covered elsewhere in the legislation.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that to be the case. In fact, there are other provisions in the Bill which render this amendment unnecessary. Therefore I oppose it.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.
Clause agreed to.
Clause 20 agreed to.
Clauses 21 to 24—by leave—taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 25.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move amendment No. 1 and additional amendment No. 1:

PARA.TAB: Clause 25, page 34, proposed subsection 139T(5), line 20, omit "refusing", substitute "granting".
Clause 25, page 35, after proposed subsection 139T(13), insert the following subsection:

" `(13A) An application may be made by the Official Receiver to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal for the review of a decision taken to have been made to grant an application under subsection (5).".

SPEECH.PARA: In the second reading debate I indicated that I thought it might be too late to attempt an amendment to cover this point. However, it is a tribute to the superb service we are getting from our support staff in the Senate that at very short notice this amendment has been prepared for us.

PARA.TAB: On the substance of the amendment, the provision in clause 139T(5) provides that where a person makes an application to be given relief from the obligation to provide income under the provisions of the legislation on the grounds of hardship, there is the prospect of them being fixed with a deemed refusal of the application if the Official Receiver does not respond within 30 days. The Australian Democrats believe that this is not satisfactory. In this provision we are causing the applicant to suffer a refusal simply because the public servants in the Official Receiver's office have not done their job in time. We believe that it should be reversed. Instead of such a matter ending up in a deemed refusal, it should end up in a deemed granting. That covers my amendment to clause 25, page 34, line 20.

It has been pointed out to me that should it be found later that in substance the wrong decision has resulted, the Official Receiver would not be able to appeal under the present legislation. This is the purpose of the additional amendment No. 1 which provides such an avenue of appeal. Accordingly, I commend both amendments to the Government and the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although the Opposition joins the Democrats in applauding the staff of the Senate in making this further change at short notice, we are still not varying the previous position that we determined and of which we advised the Democrats, and that is that we would not be supporting this amendment.

PARA.TAB: We accept that it is a laudable aim to encourage the Official Receiver to make a decision within 30 days. If the Official Receiver is taken to have granted an application to vary contributions rather than the current position, which is that it would be refused if no decision were made, it is the creditors standing behind the Official Receiver who will suffer. We regard that as unsatisfactory.

I also intended to argue that it would tend to override the current existing appeal mechanism. I think that is what Senator Spindler sought to bring to our attention by means of his additional amendment No. 1. Therefore, I will not press that argument. Nevertheless, our position remains that by the Official Receiver not making a decision, as Senator Spindler wishes to amend the Bill the creditors would suffer, and we do not think that that is satisfactory.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not support this amendment. I am advised that if there were a deemed allowance of a decision, the trustee could make a new assessment of the income of the bankrupt and continue to collect contributions regardless of whether hardship was involved or not. The bankrupt would then need to go through the review process before the Official Receiver again, and if the matter were again aborted it would have to go to the AAT.

PARA.TAB: Liability to pay contribution is not affected by the making of an application for a review under section 139ZG, nor is the person making contributions entitled to a refund where an excess amount is paid under section 139ZH. Therefore, the proposed amendment is pointless and will have a detrimental effect on the contributions scheme.

The whole aim of the Official Receiver review provision is to enable speedy administrative review of assessments by trustees so that genuine cases of hardship are dealt with expeditiously without the need for court or AAT involvement, where delays are problematic and which involve expense. The Government does not support this amendment.
Amendments negatived.
Clause agreed to.
Clause 26 agreed to.
Clause 27.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 4.Clause 27, page 63, proposed section 149Y, lines 7 to 26, omit the section.

The coalition is of the view that proposed new section 149Y should be deleted. It provides that a bankrupt is disqualified from early discharge if they were involved in business activities before the bankruptcy and more than 50 per cent of their unsecured liabilities were incurred as a result of carrying on business activities. As I foreshadowed in my speech on the second reading, we believe that this unfairly singles out business bankrupts and for that reason should be omitted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will be supporting this amendment, which is identical to our amendment No. 2.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not support this amendment. The early discharge provisions were inserted in order to help primarily ordinary wage and salary consumer debtors, in respect of which there is no significant administration of bankrupt estates. It is not appropriate that the provisions apply to bankrupt business persons whose affairs will invariably require some period of time for administration before they can be satisfactorily settled. I believe it is necessary to ensure that persons who have pursued unsuccessful business activities using the funds of investors and credit providers, a matter that was pointed out by Senator Kemp, undergo some significant period of restriction on future activities. We do not believe that the early discharge provisions should be available for them.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 5.Clause 27, page 63, proposed section 149Z, lines 27 to 41, omit the section.

Our final amendment is to delete proposed section 149Z, which provides that a bankrupt is disqualified from early discharge if the bankrupt's unsecured liabilities exceeded 150 per cent of income during the year prior to the date of bankruptcy.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will not be supporting this Opposition amendment. We believe that the proposed section should remain as printed. It is essential to ensure that people who have recklessly or negligently entered into commitments which they have no reasonable expectation of meeting should not be allowed to take advantage of the provisions which give them an early release from bankruptcy.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government strongly believes that this proposed section should still be supported. It would disqualify from early discharge a person who incurred unsecured liabilities amounting to more than 150 per cent of his or her income in the year preceding the bankruptcy. It is important to have a provision in the law which provides a sanction for those reckless individuals who engage in profligate financial dealings and who enter into an unsecured debt situation exceeding 150 per cent of their earnings in the year preceding their bankruptcy. Those persons who wish to spend so freely, using money advanced by others, without having proper, prudent regard to the question of whether they really have the capacity to repay, ought not be entitled to be discharged from bankruptcy after six months but should remain bankrupt for the ordinary three-year period. The Government presses this particular provision.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Remainder of Bill—by leave—taken as a whole, and agreed to.
Title agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.
Bill (on motion by Senator Tate) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: POLITICAL BROADCASTS AND POLITICAL DISCLOSURES LEGISLATION

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to ask a question and make a short statement in relation to the regulations under the political broadcasts and political disclosures legislation dealt with earlier tonight. The matter came in in somewhat of a hurry and the regulations were not before us. We are looking at a situation where two elections—the ACT election and a Tasmanian State election—may be held before we come back next year. I seek Senator Button's advice on just where we stand with these things in view of certain undertakings given by Senator Bolkus at the time of the debate on the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill 1991.

PARA.TAB: I have just been going through the Hansard to refresh my memory because I was quite sure that some comments were made. Senator Kernot made a lot of them. I am very concerned that many of the matters in that debate on the Political Broadcasts Bill were to be dealt with in the regulations. During the debate there were a lot of amendments and a lot of uncertainty, and Senator Bolkus kept telling us that they would be dealt with in the regulations. Senator Kernot was saying that we would have plenty of time to look at the regulations and make sure they are right. I realise that I have not been granted leave yet, so I will not quote what Senator Kernot said without getting that leave, but there are quotes in the Hansard. I am a little concerned that all of these things were brought in very quickly. I have not even seen them yet—they may be quite appropriate.

TALK.START.PARA: —They haven't been available.

—They have not been available. The Clerk attempted to get us some photocopies and a limited number of copies were made available. It may be that they are quite okay. I just do not know. I have a real fear that we are going to have two elections before we next sit. When it comes to the Tasmanian election I do not know whether Senator Harradine has a group in the State Parliament, but I do not know what is going to be done with him and what is going to be done with the Democrats in the State parliament. I think this was all to be in the regulations. Maybe they are; maybe they have been worked out. I know that Senator Parer, our shadow Minister, received the regulations only a very short time before they were brought into the Parliament. I have not had a chance to speak to Senator Parer—he may have been able to go through them.

PARA.TAB: It concerns me—and it should concern Senator Kernot—that, when we raised problems and queries, they were amended on the run and we were told they would be looked after in the regulations. I suppose that I have made my statement. My question was: what effect do the regulations have? Is there going to be an opportunity for us to study them and put a point of view across, as was undertaken that we would be allowed to do in the debate by the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus)? Are we going to be given that opportunity before they are put into effect for the Tasmania and ACT elections?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Macdonald, you have been able to make a speech but you have not had leave yet.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Senator Macdonald had finished before I had an opportunity to tell him whether leave was granted or not. The regulations are available. It is clear from what Senator Macdonald had to say that he wants to study them. It is also clear that he wants to talk to Senator Parer about them. The most appropriate way to handle this would be for Senator Macdonald to have those discussions, make that study and, if he so desires, write to the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) about it, and I will see that the Minister provides him with an answer.
—The question was: are they in effect until they are disallowed?
—Of course they are. Obviously the regulations are in effect until they are disallowed.
—We were given undertakings that we would be allowed to look at them, debate them and ask questions before the two elections.
—I understand that. I do not see how we can resolve the issue at this stage but I have made an offer.

—by leave—I ask Senator Button a question in relation to an answer that he promised to give the Senate before it rises today on the problems that companies would face in relation to depreciation charges in legislation that was about to be introduced into the House of Representatives. There are certain problems in respect of companies that have a substituted accounting period that balance at 31 December. These companies will be required to make their first income tax instalment in January. Basically, they are at a loss to know how to deal with the proposed changes in relation to their accounts for the year ending 30 December 1991.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Senator Watson has pursued me about this issue. I have sought an answer from the Treasurer (Mr Willis) which I will try to chase up tomorrow morning. I know the Senate will not be sitting but I will try to provide Senator Watson with an answer as quickly as possible.

DEBATE.TITLE: POLITICAL BROADCASTS AND POLITICAL DISCLOSURES LEGISLATION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I wish to speak for only one minute. I would like to quote one sentence from the Hansard of 5 December where Senator Bolkus said:

SPEECH.PARA: I think we are coming back on 18 or 19 December and they —
that is, the regulations—

should be available for the Parliament to consider before then. Were the regulations to apply also to any Tasmanian election, we would give the Senate the opportunity to scrutinise those regulations also by having them before us for those sittings.
That has not occurred. They came before the Senate late tonight. We have not seen them—

TALK.START.PARA: —Lunchtime.

—I appeal to the Clerks—because I asked for a draft tonight after 8 o'clock and was told one was not yet available. They said that they would try to get the regulations photocopied for us, and that was after the time when we started, and I think it was 10.30 tonight before we started debate on the legislation, after all the debacle. That was the first opportunity we had, because they were tabled then. I asked for a copy and was told one was not yet available. We had an undertaking by the Minister on 5 December.
—There were many more.

—That is just an example, as Senator Macdonald says. We had an undertaking from the Minister that they would be available to us. That was given on 5 December. It has not been carried out. It is easy to overcome—
—Senator, you are well over time.
—It is easy to overcome; don't just say that it is all too hard.
—You asked for a courtesy. You got it and you have abused it.

—Well, the Minister has the gist of what I am saying. Please do not say it is too difficult; it can be overcome. All the Government has to do is withdraw the regulations and bring them in when we come back. Is there a response from the Minister, Mr President?
—Apparently not.

—On a point of order, Mr President: I have asked the Minister for a response. Is the Minister not going to respond to a request of mine that one of his Minister's undertakings to the Senate has been completely reversed and has been denied to us?
—I am sorry, there is no point of order; if the Minister wants to answer he can and if he does not there is nothing I can do about it.
—It is in fact the case that they were given to the Australian Democrats but not to us.
—That makes it worse, Mr President; if they were given to the Democrats but not to us, as the Leader says, that is a disgrace.
—I object to this. Senator Hill provided that little piece of information. The Opposition was provided with these regulations at lunchtime today—as Senator Parer says, at half past one.
—Are you arguing that that is reasonable?
—It is not reasonable for you as the so- called Leader of the Opposition to say that these things were given to the Democrats and then for Senator Walters to set off again on that basis.
—I think that is a disgrace, if the Democrats got them the day before. We will never take notice of what the Minister says again.
—Order! The honourable senator has had leave three times.

—I realise it is now very late at night, but I would like to express my appreciation to all of those people who have worked so hard to keep this chamber and Parliament House running. I think it would be an understatement to say that this has been an interesting year, culminating in what has been a momentous day, particularly for those of us on the government side.

PARA.TAB: The 1991 sittings have been some of the most relentless since Federation, with the Senate sitting part of every month except July. We have had a lot of late night sittings, including the first all night sitting in a quarter of a century.

From my own perspective the year's rulings have been more difficult and complex than I have previously experienced. In addition to matters arising from the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill, and notably the rulings concerning contingent notices when a Bill is under guillotine, rulings have been required in relation to the Westpac documents; Question Time, and Ministers remaining after Question Time; content of notices of motion, particularly in the light of changes to standing order 76; unparliamentary language; and, of course, numerous points of order.

I think the Senate would be disappointed if I did not mention the conduct of Question Time. For the record, I would like to note that this year the average number of questions per day was 22.8. This was the best since 1984. In addition, I would also like to note that until about one month ago we were heading for an average of over 23.5 questions per day, which would have been the best since 1982. I do not want to lay any blame on either side of the chamber, but it is a pity that the events of the last month have spoilt this record.

Another notable feature of the year has been the televising of the Senate and its committees. Honourable senators now seem to regard this as a normal part of the proceedings of both the Senate and the committees.

In 1991 we have also seen the publication of the sixth edition of Australian Senate Practice, which was launched by the President of the Administrative Review Council, Professor Cheryl Saunders, and I was pleased to be there and to take part in that ceremony. It was subsequently tabled in the Senate by Senator Durack. We also saw the passage of unique resolutions through both Houses concerning the proposed joint meeting of the Houses to hear an address by Mr George Bush, President of the United States. We also saw the tenth anniversary of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, which was marked by a very successful seminar on the Committee, which was attended also by Lord Thurlow.

The parliamentary departments have played their usual valuable role. Hansard in particular has improved substantially. For example: in-house publishing commenced in October; daily Hansards are available by 9.30 the morning after each sitting day; weekly Hansards are generally available two weeks after the end of the sitting week; the electronic Hansard is available earlier on the parliamentary database system; and committee transcript delivery times have now shortened significantly.

On a personal note, can I say that in October, on the invitation of the Commonwealth Secretary-General, I was an observer on the Commonwealth team to the first multi-party elections that had been held in Zambia for some time. Without going into this in any detail, as I realise it is late, I only want to say that witnessing the peaceful transition through the ballot box of a country from a one-party state to a multi-party democracy was one of the most stimulating and exhilarating experiences of my political life. I greatly appreciated the opportunity to participate in this process, and I thank the Senate for allowing me this privilege, by giving me three days off.

I also had the privilege of leading a delegation to eastern Europe, and I am pleased to see Senator Panizza and Senator Spindler, who were both members of that delegation, here tonight. I am sure that they realised that we were visiting these areas at a time of momentous change, and particularly for Senator Spindler it was a very moving occasion when we were able to visit the city where he was born and actually find the original documents of his family and of his birth that he had never been able to see.

As is customary, and absolutely essential, I would like to thank most sincerely all those who make this place work as a parliament. Over the last couple of weeks I have been fortunate enough to be able to thank personally a lot of the people who have done this, for example, all the support staff. Also I would like to thank the Clerks and Clerks Assistant, upon whose guidance I rely, the Deputy President, the Temporary Chairmen of Committees and, of course, all the Whips.

I know that there are many others who keep this building going and I wish to thank all of them, on behalf of all honourable senators. Finally, I would like to wish all honourable senators and staff a happy and restful Christmas with family and friends, and I hope that I will see you all again here safely next year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, thank you for providing us with the details of the very lengthy sittings in the Senate this year. I was going to refer to those numbers, but I shall not do so. It is late, or rather should I say early in the morning of 20 December. The 19th of December was an extraordinary day, of course, for the Australian Labor Party and the Government, with the retirement of Bob Hawke as Prime Minister of this country, and, on behalf of all Labor senators, and I would hope some other senators, I would like to pay a tribute to his great role as Prime Minister of this country and his great service to this country in many aspects of public life. I would also like to mention Mrs Hawke who I think, if the expression is appropriate, has been a great first lady for Australia during the period of Bob Hawke's prime ministership. On behalf of the Government senators I wish them well in their future life and careers. Bob Hawke, of course, will be regarded by history as an icon of Australian politics during the 1980s. I say that 19 December was both a traumatic day and in some ways an emotional day for the Australian Labor Party.

PARA.TAB: I understand this to be the last sitting day for Senator Jo Vallentine, who has served as an Independent for Western Australia since July 1985. I am sure that all honourable senators will join with me in wishing Senator Vallentine well for the future. The year was also marked by the resignation of Senator Paul McLean as the Democrat senator for New South Wales and his replacement by Senator Karen Sowada. I have already welcomed Senator Sowada to the Senate. I just hope that now she is as enthusiastic about the workings of democracy in this place as she was on the day she arrived here in September. This was also the first year in the Senate for Senator John Tierney, who replaced Senator Peter Baume as Liberal Party senator for New South Wales.

Mr President, it remains for me to join with you in thanking the Deputy Presidents, the Clerks, and all the officers of the Senate for the contributions which they have made to our welfare and wisdom during the course of this year. I also thank the Manager of Government Business, Senator McMullan, who took over the stewardship of that role from Senator Ray in June, and the Parliamentary Liaison Officer, John Croswell, in each case for their attention to the Government program and to the interests of the Opposition, the Democrats and independent senators.

Finally, Mr President, I would like to thank you for the way in which you have fulfilled your role in continuing—with perhaps some minor exceptions in the last day or so—to manage smoothly the operations and proceedings of the Senate. I wish all honourable senators in this place a happy Christmas and new year and thank them on behalf of the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the motion, there are a few matters that I also wish to touch upon. I agree with the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) that 19 December was certainly an extraordinary day. We perhaps thought it was extraordinary in different terms from those in which the Government considered it. We think it is absolutely incredible that the Government would elect Paul Keating as its leader and as Prime Minister, but we have had that debate earlier tonight and we will not canvass that ground again.

PARA.TAB: On behalf of the coalition, I join with the Leader of the Government in acknowledging and recognising the work and contribution to public life of Prime Minister Hawke. We wish him and Mrs Hawke all the best for the future.

Mr President, you made mention of Odgers. I also recognise the unique contribution of the Australian Senate Practice, the sixth edition of which seems to have come in for a great deal of usage in the short time it has been here. It is interesting to observe that it is already being used by Government senators when it serves their purposes.

Mr President, you also mentioned the television coverage of Parliament. I give credit to the ABC for being prepared to televise the Parliament, which I think is an important contribution to the Australian community. I mention the ABC radio program Ring the Bells, and the new television program Order in the House, which has done a great deal to bring to the public of Australia, in a new way and in much greater detail, the workings of Parliament. How the public will react to that is for the public to determine. Nevertheless, it has an opportunity to experience the practice of democracy in a way it has not previously experienced, and I think that is to be commended.

Mr President, you mentioned the long sitting. Certainly, it has been a long and arduous sitting. In fact, I understand that there have been only three occasions since 1970 when the Senate has sat for a similar period or longer. Of course, the sitting started early with the most important debate on the Gulf war, in which there were many significant contributions made by honourable senators.

I take this opportunity to join with the Leader of the Government in the Senate in thanking a number of people. I thank my colleagues on this side of the chamber—Senator Boswell and members of the National Party, and my colleagues in the Liberal Party—for the contribution they have made, for the teamwork that they have provided and, if I might say so with respect, for the very effective opposition we have provided in the Senate.

I thank you, Mr President, for your contribution. We thank the Deputy President for his work, particularly the Estimates committee work. We thank the Clerks, who have been helpful to all of us, for continuing their high standards of objectivity and learning. We appreciate their work. We thank the Hansard staff and all the staff of the Department of the Senate, whether they be in the Table Office, senators' services, secretarial services, transport, printing office, attendants, committee staff and so forth. Without them, this Senate cannot function. We appreciate the work they do for us and the work they do for Australia. I thank the people in the Parliamentary Library who provide a fine service, the Parliamentary Information Systems Office and the Comcar drivers—even if we are going to abolish their usage for senators when we get into Government. I thank our Whips, the Parliamentary Liaison Officer and many others who have made our work, I would hope, effective in the course of this last year.

Despite the fact that it is late, Mr President, there are a few comments I wish to make about the operations of the Senate during the last year. I mention the reference of Bills procedure which has very much enhanced the procedural operations of the Senate. It is contributing in a very significant way to improving the quality of legislation. It is interesting that, generally speaking, throughout the Senate it has been used in a cooperative way. The legislative process has been improved as a result of this new system. As I recall, it comes up for review in the new year. It is my view that, whereas it may still be in need of some further refinement, it is a reform that is well justified. It is in its early days and I hope that it will continue and be further developed.

Mr President, you mentioned Question Time. Notwithstanding your comments—I think you thought the Senate was doing pretty well with the number of questions that were being asked—from an Opposition perspective, we are still of the view that insufficient questions are being asked and answered. That caused us to put down a new contingent motion in the course of this year that gave us the right to debate the issue that at least 28 questions should be asked and answered. We hope that, with or without the use of that contingent motion in the course of the next Parliamentary session, we can get to the situation where 28 questions are in fact asked and answered during Question Time.

We sought to cooperate with the Government to produce a program that would enable us to get home to our families last week. Unfortunately, it did not work. The only lesson that I hope the Government has learned is how unwise it is unnecessarily to use the guillotine in this place. It was unnecessary and unwise in relation to the ad bans Bill—a Bill that was designed to curtail freedom of speech. It was a demonstration of very poor judgment by the new Manager of Government Business (Senator McMullan). I hope that we will not see the Government, in the time that it remains in office, try that tactic again. It was counterproductive to its objectives and an unwise exercise of power on behalf of the Government, in conspiracy with the Australian Democrats.
The tabling of reports continues to cause us concern. We are most unhappy with the large number of reports that have been tabled in the last couple of days.

TALK.START.PARA: —Eighty in the last two days.

—As my colleague says, there have been 80 tabled in the last two days. That does not enable us to fulfil our function in relation to the scrutiny of those reports. We have started to use the procedures to call for an explanation and, hopefully, in the future persuade those who are responsible for these reports that it would be in their best interests to get them in earlier in the year.

PARA.TAB: One concern I should put on the record relates to this new practice of the Government of introducing Bills into the Senate by representative Ministers—in other words, Bills that are not the subject of ministerial control in this chamber. We have seen this as an attempt to avoid the cut-off date procedures, which have been working fairly well and which are designed to avoid a build-up of legislation in this place at the end of session. Again, therefore, there is an inability to properly scrutinise that legislation. We hope the Government, having tried that tactic this time, will not continue it in the future; otherwise we will have to look to further procedural methods to avoid it.

The new procedures we have adopted in relation to debating the appropriations in the Committee of the Whole still do not seem to be working all that well. The Deputy President is to put down a report from the Procedure Committee with a number of new options. I am not sure whether it has already been put down. If it has not, it will be soon. I look forward to the Senate giving further attention to ways in which we can improve that procedure.

I want to mention two important anniversaries. One that was mentioned was the tenth anniversary of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. It was also the twentieth anniversary of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. Both committees, particularly through the work of their staff but also their senators, have made and are making a significant contribution to the legislative process. I commend the work of all those who have contributed to those committees in the years preceding the anniversaries I have mentioned.

As Senator Button said, Senator McLean left us during the year. We wish him well. We have been joined by a couple of new senators. Senator Vallentine is leaving us. She came here with a mission, she pursued her mission, and we wish her well in the future.

Bearing in mind the time, that is really all I wish to say. The years in opposition are never much fun, but I am proud to say that the coalition parties are now demonstrating a unity that ought to be a lesson to this Government. We have fine leadership under John Hewson and Tim Fischer. Most important of all, we now have before the Australian people a policy program that can give them a clear alternative that can produce jobs, jobs, jobs, some vision for Australia at last and some hope for Australians, which is more than they have been able to get from this Government.
I wish everyone a happy Christmas. I hope they return rested for another year of the contest.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that everyone will be very pleased to hear at this hour that I will not take up much of the Senate's time. As we all know, Senator Jo Vallentine is leaving us today. She is one of the most charming and hard-working members of Federal Parliament that I have ever known, and I have known her for a long time—since she started in the old House. I thank her for her friendship and for maintaining a point of view which is quite separate from that of the majority of members of both these chambers. She has done it with dedication. I know that it has not been easy for her. We all wish her the very best in her new life.

PARA.TAB: Senator Paul McLean also left this place this year, somewhat suddenly. I have known Paul for 15 years. He contributed enormously to the Australian Democrats and carried out his duties as Whip for the Democrats with great vigour. We also wish him well in his new life as a constituent of Senator Bell and Senator Harradine, amongst others.

We would like to thank those support staff without whom we all know that we could not carry on in here. I thank you, Mr President, for your sensible running of this chamber. I thank the long-suffering Clerks whom I know have a very hard time. They all had to stay up all night last week while we were getting 40 minutes sleep. I thank the other Whips and the Managers of Government and Opposition Business, as well as the Parliamentary Liaison Officer, John Croswell, whom we have always found to be helpful, efficient and cooperative. I understand that John will also be leaving us soon.
Merry Christmas to our colleagues on all sides and to all Australians. I know that none of us in here will drink and drive, so I expect to see everyone back here whole and hearty in the new year.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to associate myself with the sentiments expressed by all parties in this Senate. After nearly eight weeks straight in the Parliament, the time we have waited for has arrived. We are going home later today to share Christmas with our families and loved ones. We will have three or four weeks off and live a relaxed and normal life for that short time. I am looking forward to that time, which I will share with my family, including my son and daughter. Senator Harradine told me that he is going to have his Christmas dinner with 27 children and grandchildren. I am sure that will be a very happy and joyous occasion for him.

PARA.TAB: It will then be back to the grind after three or four weeks. It has been a tough year for the Opposition, but it has been a lot tougher for the Government, which has had to face the problems.

We saw a momentous occasion today—namely, a Prime Minister stepping down, or being removed from office. While I do not want to get involved in other people's politics, I have to say that Mr Hawke was magnificent in defeat. It seems that politics works under the law of diminishing returns. The longer one stays, the bigger the target one becomes and the more likely one is to get hurt. I have seen it not only with the Australian Labor Party but also with my own Party. It seems to be a fact of life. I take this opportunity to wish Mr Hawke and his wife all the best for the future.

I also take the opportunity of saying goodbye to Jo Vallentine, who came here in 1985. I do not think we share anything in common in politics, but Jo is a very nice person. We wish her all the best. Perhaps if she straightens up and flies right and is prepared to do the right thing, we might even take her back into the Country Party. But she will have to improve.

I thank my colleagues in the National Party for their contributions, and I pay a very special compliment to Senator Bjelke-Petersen, who is not here at the moment. She had a very rough year this year, but she came down and did her duty as a Queensland senator, and she did it with dedication. I thank her for that.

I thank my staff and the National Party support staff, who always work as a team, and all those people who make this place run so well: the transport officers; the attendants; the Hansard staff; the Clerks, who will always run you up a quick amendment in 10 minutes; the printing staff; and all the other people who keep this place ticking over. Requests are always met with a willingness to help.

I would like to thank Senator Hill. I know that we have had a few rough trots as we have gone through the year, but we have managed to do our best and stick together. We will always have these differences, but we will work our way through them.
Mr President, I wish you a very happy Christmas. Christmas is a time for peace and forgiving. I wish every member of this Senate peace and a happy and blessed Christmas.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be only a minute or two. This has been a momentous day; it was the culmination of a rather momentous year. Like Senator Boswell, I wish Mr and Mrs Hawke the very best for the future. Little did Bob Hawke know that 25 years after he decided, in a particular hotel in Melbourne, if my memory serves me correctly, to go for the top job ultimately he would be removed from that job.

PARA.TAB: My congratulations go to the new Prime Minister, Mr Keating. I wish him well, not only for his own sake but also for the sake of our country. I would also like to wish Senator Jo Vallentine all the very best for her future. I endorse the remarks that have been made that she is a very friendly and affable person with a mission, and she has pursued it. I would also like to wish all the best to Paul McLean, a new constituent of ours. It is good to see and to welcome Senator Sowada and also Senator Tierney. Their presence in here has enhanced this chamber. Both of them have made their mark in the very short time that they have been here.

One of the problems, as I have said, is that we have been negativing the adjournment. Mr President, you made an order that if the adjournment is negatived, free toasted raisin bread would be available in the lobbies. I have noticed that since you made that decision there has been a very distinct tendency to negate the adjournment. I do not know whether that is the reason for it, but if it is, I would withdraw the toasted raisin bread.

Finally, I would like to thank the support staff, the PLO and all of the other people. I suppose the best way of thanking them would be for me to sit down immediately. Before I do that, I wish them and all honourable senators the very best for Christmas and the new year. We have a lot of work to do in the new year to get this country going again and I hope we will all pull together to do that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is seven years and three months since I was first chosen by a group of people in Western Australia to be a candidate for the Nuclear Disarmament Party in the 1984 election. A lot has happened in the seven years since—it feels like 15 years—and honourable senators will be glad to know that I am not going to go through all the ups and downs of that time. It has been a great responsibility and a great privilege to represent people in Western Australia following that 1984 election, again following the 1987 election and following the 1990 election. It has been a somewhat unusual career in that I was first elected to represent the Nuclear Disarmament Party which, unfortunately, had a very difficult time at its first annual conference in early 1985, so I came in here as an independent. Most of the time I have been in here as an independent and, latterly, I have represented the Greens, WA.

PARA.TAB: It has been quite a lonely time on this back bench. I have been by myself for most of the time, except for when Robert Wood was here representing the Nuclear Disarmament Party in New South Wales, followed by Senator Irina Dunn. It was good to have some company, and after the last election one of my great disappointments was that there were not more Green senators here to support me and to continue with this work. I am sure that in the future more Greens will be elected from different States who will work very closely with our closest ideological counterparts—the Australian Democrats across the aisle.

During my time here it has been very much a team effort. For one individual—I am sure this would be the same for Senator Harradine—on one's own as an independent it is very difficult indeed to function in here without strong team support. I have had that very strong support and I am very grateful to the people who have worked consistently with me. In particular, I thank Annabelle Newbury, who has been with me nearly the whole time, and Peter Jones, who would be better known to more people around the Parliament because he has been stationed here in Canberra.

These two people have the particular quality which I call `stickability'—they are prepared to stay there and really work. They are totally committed to the issues and they will be working on the issues until they drop dead, as I will be until I drop dead. I do not know too many people who have such commitment that they will continue to work on issues. I am very grateful to both Annabelle and Peter Jones for their support.

I have to mention particularly my spouse, Peter Fry. I mentioned him in my first speech; he is still there doing a wonderful job in parenting and taking primary responsibility for our daughters. He has done a truly amazing job and I am very grateful for his support, without which I could not have continued in this job.

I would like to thank all of the people who make this building work. They have been mentioned by other people here tonight. I would like to thank you, Mr President, and the Deputy President for conducting proceedings in the Senate as best as you are able to under sometimes very trying circumstances. I thank you for your fairness which I, in particular, have really appreciated. I have also appreciated the amazing help I have received from members of the Parliamentary Library research staff in various departments who have been very assiduous and forthcoming with their help on many different occasions.

I thank the Hansard reporters, for whom I think I have been quite a difficult person to report because I do tend to speak rather fast. I thank the drivers who get us to and fro, the Clerks and the people in the Table Office and the Procedure Office. I must make special mention here of Cleaver Elliott whose assistance is, I think, outstanding. I would also like to mention the catering staff and the corridor staff who are always very polite and very helpful indeed. I thank, particularly, the people who have to withstand the very long sittings and keep us going in here—the Senate attendants.

As I alluded to before, I would also like to mention the support that I have had from the community. I could not have done this job on my own. I thank not only the people who have worked with me in a paid capacity, but also the many community groups—environmental groups, social justice groups and human rights groups—around the country which have supported me, given me a lot of feedback, a lot of ideas and input and whom I have been able to help too through the offices of the Senate. It has been wonderful having close working relationships with so many groups in the community.

On another level, I have also had a lot of support from the Quaker community around Australia. I am very grateful indeed for that spiritual support which has been wonderful and, more latterly, for the support of a group of people who have been coming into the building regularly to meditate. They have been coming in here not only to support me, but also to support all honourable senators—little did they know it—in the hope that we would have more harmony in this building. I will return to that subject a little later.

It is very important for someone like me to be here. I am very aware of the fact that our parliamentary system of democracy—which is about as good as one can get, I think, although it has its shortcomings—does allow for people like me to get in here through our system of proportional representation. I think the major parties, generally, seem to have failed the electorate so dismally in the last few years—and that goes for both major party groupings—that there will be a greater interest in independents, as has been seen in various State parliaments around the country which are now dependent on independents. Local government elections also reveal that independents have a very important role to play. I think the third force, which will probably comprise Greens, independents and the Australian Democrats, will have a very important role to play in the future of Australian politics.

Unfortunately, in this Senate a lot of time is wasted on party game playing. That is one of the reasons for the great disillusionment in the community. Of course, we have seen an enormous amount of this in just the last few weeks, and other people have already alluded to that. I believe that far too much time is wasted in here by playing party political games and not getting on with the issues that are of importance to people in the community. I sometimes think that politicians are so far removed from their constituents that they do not really know how hard people in the community are hurting, or what issues are of real concern to people, because we spend hours and hours in here wasting time on pointless point scoring.

Much of my very first speech in this place is still highly relevant, although at that time I was focusing on the question of disarmament because that is the issue that I was elected to represent. Much of that is still relevant. I could still say, looking at my first speech, that we are spending far too much on defence and far too little on foreign aid, and that the United States bases on Australian soil are for war fighting. That has finally been admitted in the wake of the Gulf war. What we have been saying in the peace movement for years and years the Government finally had to admit—that is, that the American bases on Australian soil make a considerable contribution to the war fighting operations of the United States Government.

To my great shame and horror—it was the most difficult time of all for me in these seven years—Australia was involved in the Gulf war. The same comments that I made about lack of sovereignty in my first speech are relevant today. The fact that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), without consultation with the Australian people, his Cabinet or the Parliament, could decide that Australia would go to war in that crisis was very difficult to take. I never thought that I would be a senator in the Australian Parliament with Australia at war. I think it is to our great shame that that war was entered into with such great gusto by the Prime Minister and most people in these two chambers.

When we had the special sitting in January there was uproar in the galleries. That was because so many people who did not support Australia going to war felt unrepresented by the people sitting down here on the red and green leather. They felt that their voices were not heard, so they made sure that their voices were heard from the galleries. I give them full credit for that.

The problems still continue because in Iraq at the moment there is a dreadful crisis looming that has been vastly exacerbated by that bombing and the war in January. It did a couple of things the United States might have wanted, such as getting the Iraqis to withdraw from Kuwait, but it has created so many more problems. I call on the Government to work assiduously for the embargoes against Iraq to be lifted. Children in their thousands are dying in Iraq as a result of the Gulf war. The problems are manifestly worse than they were this time last year, before that war occurred.

Fortunately, a lot has changed in seven years. Some of the changes have been good. It has been amazing to see the transformation of eastern Europe from one-state dictatorships to relative democracies. That has been wonderful to see. The breaking down of the Berlin Wall, which happened relatively quickly and relatively peacefully, was something more than most of us could have hoped for seven years ago. That has been a major change for the good. Unfortunately, with the disintegration of the Soviet Union, we have domination by the power of one. This is a very dangerous situation for the world, where the United States thinks that it has the mandate to go wherever it will, in whatever part of the world its interests will be served by intervention. That is still consistent with what I said in my first speech seven years ago; that has not changed.

One thing the Labor Party has not changed is the uranium mining industry—that is the good thing—which has not been expanded in this country. I am very glad to have been part of the ongoing campaign since 1978 to ensure that uranium mining is phased out in this country. We know that the end result of uranium mining is radioactive waste. Despite the best efforts of the Synroc team in Australia, still there has been no breakthrough in the disposal of radioactive waste. It is an enormous negative legacy that we are leaving future generations.

Fortunately, there have been a few wins on environmental issues. Since 1987, when I took on board a lot more environmental issues, it has been very pleasing to participate in campaigns that have resulted in some success, such as Antarctica being left free from the ravages of mining. That is something I should compliment both the Opposition and the Government for—the Opposition for coming to that realisation sooner than the Government. Once it was decided, the Australian Government pushed quite hard in international fora for Antarctica to be declared a wilderness area.

Another significant win was the inclusion of stage 3 of Kakadu on the World Heritage listing. Again, I must complement the former Prime Minister for having made a good decision on the grounds of Aboriginal spirituality. It could equally have been made on environmental grounds. Nevertheless, the right decision was made, despite all the flak that that caused.

Some outstanding issues that remain include Aboriginal issues. We still have not come to terms with the original dispossession of the indigenous people of this country. Until we do that we will not have peace and justice in this land. It is an outstanding issue that must be addressed. I am pleased to say that my successor, Senator-elect Christabel Chamarette, will be following that issue assiduously. Having worked in the prison system, she is particularly concerned about the lack of justice for Aboriginal people. I would like to refer honourable senators to the deaths in custody reports, which should be taken note of, not only because of the deaths themselves but also because of all the surrounding circumstances that have caused so many of those deaths. It is an absolute shame and disgrace to our nation and it must be addressed.

I think we have to admit that the economic system—we seem to have a Tweedledum and Tweedledee situation—in this country is not working. When I hear the Prime Minister-elect talking about growth and what we must do, I can share only one aspect of that, and that is that we want more Australians in jobs. Obviously, unemployment is a huge problem in this country at the moment. When we look at the GST package the Opposition is offering, I think the Labor Party has not used its best argument against the GST—that is, that it would be an absolute disaster for unemployed people. Obviously, Labor has not used that argument because it has presided over this growth of unemployment and I suppose it is a bit too embarrassing. But that is what the GST would mean—absolute disaster for people who do not have jobs and for people at the low end of the scale. It would do very nicely indeed for people at the upper end of the scale who can see some short term benefits. It is a very selfish kind of analysis and not one that is sustainable in the long run.

The already overstuffed are swimming in money while the poor get poorer. The trickle-down theory has become a cruel hoax. Money is the only commodity that flows uphill. It pours from the South to the North at the rate of billions of dollars annually. Something else that we have seen happen regularly in the seven years I have been here is the cut in the foreign aid budget. We are part of the problem of that money flow going from the South to the North instead of the other way around.

Grass roots movements worldwide are increasingly focusing attention on economic matters because of the obvious connection with the accelerating deterioration of the biosphere and concern for the plight of the impoverished. Thus far, governments have reacted to these concerns with jargon-filled rhetoric and ineffectual knob-twiddling. There are no signs at all that anyone involved in traditional politics has the ideas or the will to make the necessary modifications to the economic system itself—a system which, as presently structured, demands that we rip the planks off the life raft at an ever increasing rate. I am talking here about sustainability. The present economic system is not sustainable in the long run.

Perhaps the strongest argument for an urgent reappraisal of the way in which we go about our business arises from recent findings about the way the earth behaves like a living organism. I refer to James Lovelock's Gaia theory, which strongly suggests that as a consequence the implications of the chaos theory must be taken into account before all other considerations. This is because Gaia, that is, our whole planet, is not a steady-state system which, simply due to its size, is able to accommodate huge quantities of pollutants, but is a far-from-equilibrium system which maintains the biosphere in a way that makes it a place that nurtures life by means of a staggeringly complex range of bio-feedback loops working cooperatively—the same type of control employed by the human body known as homeostasis, or wisdom of the body.

When overload occurs in the systems that function in this dynamic far-from-equilibrium way, the systems suddenly collapse chaotically, tripping into a new dynamically stable state, which in the case of Gaia may be one that is antagonistic to life. As Lovelock points out, the present steady-state increase in the rate of global warming due to the rising levels of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere may suddenly flick into a life-threatening rise in mean temperature which would persist for aeons.

It is conceivable that, if the perturbation was large enough, it may well cause Gaia to trip from the present oxygen-carbon cycle to, say, a methane-based system. The criticality of this homeostatic balance cannot be overstated. Take, for instance, the percentage of oxygen in the atmosphere. For each one per cent rise in the oxygen content above the present 21 per cent, the probability of forest fires being started by lightning increases by 70 per cent. At a 25 per cent oxygen level, even the damp twigs and grass of a rainforest would ignite. That is only 4 per cent higher than the present oxygen content.

The Gaian principles of cooperation, diversity and adaptability would seem to offer the most favourable basis for economics that will best serve the needs of both the person and the planet. In nature, small highly adaptable units interact cooperatively within themselves and as a collective whole to maintain the integrity of the system, in contrast to today's anti-ecological exploitative model. What has to change is the exploitative model of planet Earth and its people.

The essentially nurturing aspect of Gaian dynamics is central to the ethos of the rising Green culture which stresses the necessity of a socio-economic model that places the rights of the person and the planet above the interests of the corporate state. As Elisabet Sahtouris says:

Our technology has ravaged nature and continues to do so, but the ravages of technology are based on our unnatural greed, our profit motive. There is no intrinsic reason that we humans cannot develop a benign technology once we agree that our desire to maximize profits is completely at odds with nature's dynamic balance—that greed prevents health and welfare for all. No other creatures take more than they need, and this must be our first lesson.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is very important that we come back to this. It is a challenge to the whole system. I realise that many people have left the chamber because they do not want to hear something that is creative and futuristic in thinking; they just want business as usual to continue. It is not good enough. It is not sustainable. It cannot continue.

PARA.TAB: I shall finish by talking about the spiritual renewal globally, which is part of the Gaian dynamic, where there is a nurturing of people and the resources of the planet Earth. It is happening. Of course, people here would probably be the last to know about that. It is largely dependent on women's spirituality. For far too long—for five millennia—women have not been accorded a proper place in society. They have not been heard. They will be heard. They must be heard.
I would like to read a poem written by Dorothy Cameron, one of the people who has been coming into this building to meditate. The poem is entitled The Singing Hill:

SPEECH.PARA: The men in dark suits
With endless disputes
Sit in the marble temple,
In the shining edifice
Built upon the hill.
They are the elders
Of the present-day tribe,
Quite unaware that aeons ago
The Hill was sacred
And magic was there.
For once it was the Singing Hill,
The hill which sang the Earth Song
At the meeting of the ley-lines
And the crossing of the song-lines
In the centre of the Hills of the Circling.
The Song of the Earth was the women's song.
They were the tribal elders then
Who knew of the Mysteries,
Who drew down the moon
And nurtured the Earth and its singing.
Unknown to the dark suits
Shouting within,
The women are returning
To the Centre of the Circling,
Reclaiming their own.
Circling the fountain in the shining edifice,
Circling the pyramid of the thrusting dome,
They return to their own
And the chanting is beginning,
The humming has begun.
With the passing of the seasons
Music from the Singing Hill
Will transcend the voices
Of the dark suits
Shouting their abuse.
New tribal elders,
The re-emerging Daughters,
Will awaken Gaia
And the shouting will be stilled.
The healing of the planet will begin.
Gaia's woman-energy
Will link the endless Cosmos
With the light of inner knowledge
And a reverence for the Earth.
And the Daughters of a different Dreaming
Will recover the mystery,
Rediscover the harmony,
Of the Centre of the Circling
Around the Singing Hill.

Finally, I would like to quote a great friend of mine who is a wonderful woman activist, who first used the term `heart politics'. I think this is really the guts of what I want to go out of this Senate saying:
