The earth gives us everything we have, everything we are, everything we love. We are utterly dependent on it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I would like to seek your indulgence and the indulgence of the Senate for a few moments to talk about an important issue. Yesterday in Question Time I addressed a question to Senator Collins with regard to Aboriginal investments and specifically those of the Gagudju Association of western Arnhem Land. Very obviously, he has not been able to fully answer my question at this time as he needs to seek further advice from the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. I look forward to receiving, hopefully during the parliamentary recess, the answer to the question I put specifically to Senator Collins yesterday in this regard.

PARA.TAB: However, I noted earlier today that Mr Clyde Holding made a personal explanation in the House of Representatives. I must comment on some of the points he made. In his opening remarks, Mr Holding said:

Yesterday in the Senate by way of a question, Senator Tambling made serious allegations against me and allegations against members of the Gagudju Association, an Aboriginal organisation, and misled the Senate as to the position of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commercial Development Corporation.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Holding went on to explain various personal matters that arose as a result of his statement. I certainly did include in my question a number of issues that required the attention of Senator Collins; the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Mr Tickner; and ATSIC with regard to activities by Mr Clyde Holding. I make no apology for raising those issues appropriately as questions.

PARA.TAB: However, Mr Holding did not go on in his comments today in the House of Representatives to outline any of the—what he calls—allegations against the members of the Gagudju Association. He does not go on in any way to outline how I supposedly misled the Senate with regard to the position of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commercial Development Corporation. I contend that anyone who takes the time to read my question in the Hansard of yesterday will see that I did not make any allegations against members of the Gagudju Association and I did not mislead the Senate in any way with regard to the activities of the Commercial Development Corporation.

The question I raised with regard to Mr Holding related to his activities in what I allege was an unauthorised consultant of the Gagudju Association. In his comments today in the House of Representatives, Mr Holding said:

The facts are, of course, that for some years I and my family have `had skin' with two Aboriginal organisations, Gagudju being one of them. `Having skin' simply means that one has been asked to become part of a clan. One becomes part of what is a broad Aboriginal community and family group. This carries considerable obligations. It is an honour which I was asked to take when I was Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I was proud and pleased to accept that honour. It is not a token relationship.

SPEECH.PARA: I accept that Mr Holding has developed a very special relationship with the people of western Arnhem Land. But it is important not to confuse those special relationships with patronage and, particularly, with issues where conflict of interest situations could arise.

PARA.TAB: Whilst Mr Holding went on to outline how he had taken up an honorary consultation as a result of approaches from Ms Jessie Alderson, the Chairperson of Gagudju, he did not answer the question which I raised about his particular involvement in that regard—whether it was approved by the full association and the other people of Arnhem Land. Mr Holding did not answer the question I raised as to whether he was to be appointed a director of an operating and management company. He did not answer the question I raised as to whether he was travelling to that area at government expense. He did not answer the question I raised as to whether he is to become a director, under the contract that has been put forward, of an organisation that I believe he has pushed as a successful group with the Gagudju Association, a company by the name of Spirit Resorts Group Pty Ltd of Brisbane, which was formed on 26 June 1991.

Mr Holding also did not address the issue I raised as to whether the ATSIC Commercial Development Corporation had in fact proffered advice to the same Gagudju Association that other companies, principally the Australian Frontier Group and the present managers of the Crocodile Hotel, Vista, which also operates under the name of Four Seasons, had offered particular proposals with guaranteed financial returns to the Aboriginal people.
Finally, Mr Holding said at the end of his comments today:

SPEECH.PARA: I leave it to Senator Tambling to explain, if he can, his public relationships with Aboriginal groups in the Territory.

I am pleased to do so. I am a senator for the Northern Territory; I represent all of the constituents of the Northern Territory, including some 30 per cent of whom have direct Aboriginal involvement. I am also related through marriage to people of the same Aboriginal groups with which Mr Holding has obviously developed a special relationship. Many of those people have contact through the Gagudju Association and the other associations of western Arnhem Land.

PARA.TAB: I have had constituent representations on this issue from members of the Gagudju Association, from other Aboriginal people in Jabiru, in Arnhem Land and in Darwin. I have had representations from various commercial interests which are connected with these very serious commercial operations. I asked yesterday whether Mr Holding had in fact written the various minutes of these meetings. That is an issue which needs to be addressed.

I noted in the returns to the Parliament in 1986 and 1990 with respect to Mr Holding's specific interests that he makes no declaration of any interest or association with these groups of western Arnhem Land.

I am sorry to have detained the Senate, but I felt that it was important to put these comments on the record as Mr Holding raised them today in the House of Representatives. I felt that it was most important that I address them this evening and have them on the record. Hopefully, with the information that will be made available by ATSIC, Mr Tickner and Senator Collins will answer the comments in much more detail during the parliamentary recess.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 8 October 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Does Australia presently export weapons, or any parts of weapons, to third world countries; if so, which countries receive weapons, or components of weapons, from this country?
(2) What legislation is in place, if any, to prevent such weapons from being used in civil war where innocent civilians are killed or injured?

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The short answer to the honourable senator's question is yes, but it is an answer which needs to be understood against the background of the stringent controls on such exports which the Government imposes. Statistics on exports of defence and defence related goods from Australia, including the destination of these exports, have been published in Hansard: for example, a table of "Defence export applications approved by financial year and country with equipment values" for 1989-90 was provided in the answer to House of Representatives question No.559 (Hansard, 9 April 1991, pages 2233 and 2234). A similar table for 1990-91 was provided in the answer to Senate question No.1226 (Hansard, 15 October 1991, pages 2097 and 2098).

(2) While there is no specific legislation in place which could control actual use of these weapons once exported, the Government does seek to determine the potential end use of these exports through the requirement for end user and non- transfer certification.

Persons wishing to export defence or defence related goods specified on Schedule 13 of the Customs (Prohibited Exports) Regulations from Australia require approval for export from the Minister for Defence (or his/her delegate). The criteria covering the export of such goods are detailed in the Guidelines for Exporters published in 1989. These Guidelines identify a range of strategic, foreign policy and human rights issues which are taken into account by the Standing Interdepartmental Committee on Defence Exports in considering applications to export defence and related goods. Situations where these criteria might apply include those in which:
Australia's foreign policy and trade interests could be adversely affected by the reactions of third countries
the proposed country of destination is involved in internal or external conflicts or there is a state of tension which indicates conflict is likely
the exports could potentially contribute to destabilisation in the region concerned
the country is acquiring non-conventional weaponry in contravention of Australia's non- proliferation interests.

The Government will generally only approve the overseas sale of controlled goods listed under Parts 1 and 2 of Schedule 13 of the Customs (Prohibited Exports) Regulations to recognised governments who are required to provide an End Use and Non Transfer Certificate, which entails an undertaking that the goods will only be used for the purposes indicated.

In addition, depending on the circumstances, activities such as the use of weapons in civil war, where innocent civilians are killed or injured, or undertaking preparations for such use, could constitute an offence against the Crimes (Foreign Incursions and Recruitment) Act 1978. Possible offences include a person engaging in a hostile act in a foreign state, or accumulating or stockpiling weapons or giving goods or performing services in support of any person or body, for the purpose of assisting a person engaging in a hostile act in a foreign state.

asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 5 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: With reference to recent press reports concerning the evolution of trading arrangements in the successor States to the Soviet Union and the changing role of Vnesh Ekonom.
(1) What will be Australia's attitude to trade with the emergent republics.
(2) Is there a policy, with strategy guidelines, to capitalise on trading opportunities which abound in these republics.
(3) Will such a strategy incorporate concessional finance components, for example, the current EFIC commodity trade facility with the USSR.
(4) Will such facilities be extended to the smaller republics and not just Russia.

(5) Is the Government prepared to offer these concessional finance facilities now, since Australia's competitors in Europe and the Americas are doing so and are likely to capture these markets ahead of Australia unless we act immediately.
(6) Is the Government prepared to finance technical assistance to the Soviets, to be provided by Australian companies, as an additional strategy to open up and expand markets in the former USSR.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Political developments in the Soviet Union have resulted in marked changes to the trading environment now facing Australian companies. A clear conclusion from discussions during my recent visit to the Soviet Union was that much of the power and authority, particularly in the economic area, has moved to the Republics. This process has meant that Republican Governments and individual enterprises within Republics are now making many of the key purchasing decisions affecting Australian products. It is therefore essential that Australia strives to enhance contacts both at official and business level with the republics. During my visit, I used every opportunity to emphasise to republican authorities the merits of Australian commercial proposals in a number of key areas including oil and gas development, minerals and telecommunications.

(2) The Government continues to encourage Australian companies to explore trading opportunities in the Soviet Union. The uncertain trading environment, however, requires innovative approaches and sound entrepreneurial skills. The recent G7 Accord on Soviet debt provides some respite for the pressures on the Soviet external account, but there is a complex process of economic reform in prospect. The short term outlook is for dislocation, hopefully followed by economic recovery.

The vastness of the opportunities in the emerging Soviet markets will however be matched by similar levels of risk. Not only is there the major impediment of a nonconvertible currency, but major gaps in legislation and physical difficulties created by decayed infrastructure make successful business in the Soviet Union a challenge to the most experienced exporter.

Notwithstanding this environment, opportunities for traditional Australian exports remain. Moreover, an essential element of the transition to a market economy is rapid improvement of infrastructure eg. telecommunications, food processing and storage facilities. Australian companies are already benefiting from this process, but will require substantial motivation to profitably manage and exploit these opportunities.
Legislative evolution currently underway should also facilitate Australian involvement in areas where we have a comparative advantage, specifically minerals exploration and downstream processing.

The Australian Trade Commission (Austrade) and the Australian Embassy generally are devoting considerable resources to assisting Australian companies interested in trade and investment with the Soviet Union. Austrade has focused considerable effort in establishing contact with enterprises and Ministries in the key individual republics, and in the Soviet Far East, which is developing as a natural trading partner for Australia.

Proximity to Western Europe and the existing level of activity by West European and North American companies in the European part of Russia and Ukraine reduces Australia's competitiveness in those regions.

(3) Concessional finance is not used to support Australia's trade with the Soviet Union. However, the Government has underwritten two credit facilities to support traditional commodity trade with the Soviet Union through the National Interest provisions of the EFIC Act - The first provides $A 100 million in credit cover for the sale of wheat and barley on two-year terms. The second is a $A 400 million 240 day rollover facility established to support exports of wool and other commodities.

These credit arrangements are currently guaranteed on the Soviet side by Vnesheconombank. How these arrangements might work in the future and what responsibilities Central or Republican authorities will have in credit arrangements involving the Australian Government are currently under consideration and almost certainly will require further negotiation. Much depends upon the future administrative arrangements that develop in this area, and the future role of Vnesheconombank and its ability to act on behalf of the various Republics.
(4) See 3 above
(5) See 3 above

(6) The Government's assistance to the Soviet Union includes a program of business and management training to facilitate the transition to market economies. The Government has allocated $4.5 million over a three year period for this program, which is an extension of the existing Australian Program of Training for Eastern Europe (APTEE). ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: DSTO: Professional Officers and Research Scientists

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 7 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Why has the department chosen to debar DSTO Professional Officer Technologists (Engineers and Experimental Officers) from SES equivalent positions under the unilateral salary and conditions determination for the DSTO Research Scientists.
(2) Why were the Professional Officer Technologists not accorded equal treatment with the Research Scientists.
(3) Will the career prospects of Professional Officer Technologists working in the DSTO be reduced as a result of the Government's actions.
(4) Will the debarring of Professional Officer Technologists from SES and equivalent positions subsequently affect the calibre of employees within DSTO.
(5) Will the working arrangements between Professional Officers and Research Scientists be less flexible as a result of new determinations.

(6) Are Professional Officers performing the same work and carrying the same responsibility at the same level as Research Scientists; if so, why should they receive a lesser level of recognition and remuneration.

(7) What consideration has been given to the re- establishment of a Professional Officer senior management structure aligned with its own field of responsibility to give proper credence to the term ``technology'' in the organisation's title.

(8) How does the department justify this action, which will undoubtedly diminish the technology component of the DSTO, in respect of the report of the Prime Minister's Science Council which recently considered the state of engineering in this country and decided that development of a strong engineering base is crucial to the return of a prosperous economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: Before responding to the specific questions, some background might help put my answers in perspective.
There are three quite independent issues which have a bearing on the questions raised:

Firstly, in December 1987, a restructuring of the DSTO was announced to enable DSTO to respond to Government strategies announced in the policy information paper "The Defence of Australia 1987". The identification in the Paper of key capabilities and technologies required for Australia's strategic situation, together with the demand for an enhanced Australian defence industry sector were the key factors driving structural changes in DSTO. Reprofiling of staff to increase the number of scientists and research engineers and the transfer to industry of advanced development and full scale engineering were features of restructuring strategies. The new structure consisted of five mission oriented laboratories with integrated scientific and engineering functions. The Advanced Engineering Laboratory was abolished.

Secondly, in June 1989, DSTO made application to the Department of Industrial Relations to reclassify the 23 SES positions in its five Laboratories to Chief of Division. Chief of Division classifications fall within the Research Scientist structure which has a mandatory entry requirement of a Ph.D degree, or other comparable qualification—which may include significant research experience and achievement. The reclassification was sought in order to better align the classification of positions with their functional responsibilities. Senior man- agers in DSTO laboratories are primarily concerned with the management of research and must possess the appropriate technical qualifications to fulfil their functions. SES officers, on the other hand, are generalists with greater flexibility to perform a wider range of tasks not limited to individual Departments. The Chief of Division structure has recently been implemented in DSTO. It exists in the BMR and has for many years in the CSIRO.

Thirdly, under the Structural Efficiency Principles, revised Professional Officer and Research Scientist structures have been endorsed by the Industrial Relations Commission. These reflect increased pay outcomes flowing from structural efficiencies and work value increases. Separate structures have continued to be maintained for Research Scientists and other professionals although, as far as possible, common pay points have been introduced. For example, Senior Research Scientists were aligned with Senior Professional Officer Grades B and A. Beyond the level of Senior Research Scientist, pay rates in the new Research Scientist structure align with those in CSIRO.
Turning now to the specific questions:

(1) DSTO Professional Officer Technologists have never been, nor will they be, debarred from senior management positions within the organisation. Bearing in mind that the function of a senior manager in DSTO is the management of research, Professional Officers who consider they meet relevant job selection standards may apply for Chief of Division positions. If selected, they would then be assessed for category transfer to the Research Scientist structure. Apart from those positions which existed in the former Advanced Engineering Laboratory, senior management positions in DSTO have historically nearly always been occupied by officers from the Research Scientist stream.

(2) It is presumed that the question implies a perceived inequality in Structural Efficiency Principle outcomes. Under the Structural Efficiency Principles there was a requirement that all increases had to be based on demonstrated productivity changes, including any changes in work value. Increases for different categories were negotiated in the Industrial Relations Commission and granted on a case by case basis depending on the merits of the particular case. Professional Officer outcomes ranged from 6.1% to 21.3% compared with 6.1% to 19% in the case of Research Scientists.

(3) No, in the context of SEP outcomes. However, it has to be acknowledged that the loss of the Advanced Engineering Laboratory in 1987 did reduce opportunities. Three SES jobs, which were engineering managers, were abolished.
(4) As indicated in my response to Question 1, Professional Officers are not debarred from senior management positions within DSTO.

(5) No. A feature of the 1987 restructuring of DSTO was the integration of scientific and engineering functions within each laboratory and these working arrangements will not change nor will any flexibility be lost by virtue of new salary determinations.

(6) No. Professional Officers do not perform the same work as Research Scientists. The classification of a position depends on a number of factors including the job of work required, work value and level of responsibility. Comparison of positions across different structures can therefore be misleading because of the number of variables involved and weighting given those variables in determining the correct classification of the position.

(7) The 1987 restructuring of DSTO placed greater emphasis on research with a transfer to industry of advanced development and full scale engineering. There has been no change in this emphasis and re-establishment of a senior management structure for Professional Officers as existed in the now abolished Advanced Engineering Laboratory is not required. As stated earlier, Professional Officers may still compete on merit for senior management positions.

(8) The technology component will not diminish per se. DSTO will still work to the point of production of concept demonstrators; follow on full scale engineering development will be done in industry. Therefore, the products of DSTO research will continue to provide opportunities for development of the national engineering base. Within DSTO itself, since the 1987 restructuring, there has been considerable enhancement of the professional officer base within the organisation. Total Professional Officer numbers have increased by around 18%, much the same as for Research Scientists. Within the professional group, increases have mainly occurred at the upper levels, thus increasing career opportunities. Further, many officers are professionally qualified in engineering and the DSTO commitment to engineering is reflected in the significant increase (around 70%) in Engineer numbers since the 1987 restructuring.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 7 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the Minister read reports in the Guardian Weekly of 3 November 1991, detailing statistics relating to malnourishment and deaths of children in Iraq, claiming "more than 100 000 starving and at risk of dying in the near future".
(2) Is the Australian Government trying to initiate through the United Nations a humanitarian solution, so that aid can reach these children.
(3) Is the Minister prepared to commit Australia to a review of the narrow oil sale limit, which is cited as fundamental to effective food distribution in Iraq.
(4) How can the anticipated billion dollar Gulf War profit, to be paid to the United States by its allies, be re-directed to assist in rebuilding Kuwait and Iraq.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) I have seen the Guardian Weekly report of 3 November 1991. It is based on the findings of the 87-member International Study Team which visited Iraq in August and September 1991 (known as the second "Harvard" report, released on 29 October 1991). The Harvard report, which has been examined by officers of my Department, makes clear the full scope of the tragedy which Iraq has brought upon itself as a result of its invasion of Kuwait, its rejection of international demands to withdraw peacefully, and its continuing prevarication over the acceptance of and compliance with UN Security Council Resolutions. The implementation of these Resolutions would enable the importation into Iraq of greater supplies of food and medicine to help relieve the undoubted plight of the Iraqi people.

(2) Earlier this year, the UN Secretary General appointed an Executive Delegate, Prince Sadruddin Aga Khan, to initiate and oversee the humanitarian relief program in countries affected by the Gulf War, including Iraq. This program, which has a funding target of US$460 million, has been well- supported by the international community which has so far (to the end of October 1991) contributed US$285 million towards it. Since the onset of the Gulf crisis, Australia has contributed a total of $8.1 million in humanitarian assistance to the UN and international relief agencies assisting victims of the conflict and those displaced in its aftermath. We have also directly supported the Kurdish people in Iraq by sending 75 ADF personnel to provide them with basic health care for one month, at a cost of $4.4 million. We will, in addition, be assisting children in Iraq through programs run by CARE Australia. My colleague, the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development, recently announced an Australian Government contribution of $400,000 for two CARE projects specifically designed to counter malnutrition among young children near Najaf in southern Iraq.

(3) The UN Security Council adopted Resolutions 706 and 712 (in August and September 1991) to enable Iraq to export oil up to the value of US$1.6 billion over a six-month period in order to pay for foodstuffs and other approved items. A part of the revenue would be deducted to pay compensation (through a Compensation Commission established by the United Nations) to victims of Iraq's aggression, and to meet expenses associated with UN operations in Iraq. Iraq has not accepted these Resolutions, claiming them to be an infringement of its sovereignty. Australia is not a member of the Security Council. We do, however, fully support the action of the Security Council in adopting these Resolutions, and we would urge the Iraqi Government to accept them in order to alleviate the suffering of Iraq's civilian population.

(4) The claim of a "billion dollar Gulf War profit" is presumably derived from a partial reading of a statement made by a Pentagon spokesman on 29 October 1991. While the spokesman said that the United States had so far received US$48.2 billion in contributions to the coalition war effort, against an estimated cost (to that point) of US$47.1 billion, he also said that expenses were still being submitted and that the total could reach US$50 billion. As to the rebuilding of Kuwait, the Kuwaiti Government is making good progress in restoring infrastructure. All of the oil fires, for example, have been extinguished well ahead of the original schedule. As stated in (3) above, the intention of the UN is that part of the damage caused to Kuwait as a result of the Iraqi invasion should be paid for by Iraq through the Compensation Commission. As to Iraq, its reconstruction would almost certainly be hastened if it accepted the UN Security Council Resolutions and got on with implementing and complying with them.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 11 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the position of the Australian Government in relation to the declaration of independence by the Ukrainian Supreme Soviet.
(2) Does the Australian Government intend to open a diplomatic mission in the Ukraine.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Australian Government has welcomed the 1 December referendum as a decisive and unequivocal expression of the will for independence on the part of the Ukrainian people. Ukraine is now entering a new era in its history.

Recognition of Ukraine by the great bulk of the international community seems inevitable. The Government sees Australian recognition of Ukraine, within a comparatively short period of time, also as inevitable. The Australian Government's only concern at the moment is the timing of the act of recognition. This will take into account Ukraine's intentions on a range of issues which are relevant to the wider international community's consideration of recognition and the related issue of establishment of diplomatic relations with Ukraine. These include:
security and central control of nuclear weapons, given Ukraine's stated commitment to become a non-nuclear state
acceptance and compliance with existing soviet arms control commitments, such as START, CFE, and the biological weapons convention
commitment to internationally accepted agreements governing standards for observance of human rights and to protect minority rights; and
arrangements for meeting the Soviet Union's international obligations, particularly Ukraine's share of the Union's debt.

The Australian Government is engaged in consultations with the Ukrainian Government on how it proposes to address these issues. It is likely that a satisfactory resolution may be achieved within a short space of time.

(2) As you would be aware, I visited the Soviet Union from 14 to 23 November, and had discussions with Ukrainian leaders in Kiev on 22 November. During my visit, I announced that Australia would appoint an Honorary Consul in Kiev, reflecting the political and economic importance of the Ukraine, and its significant links with Australia.

The establishment of an Australian Consulate, headed by an Honorary Consul, will give a major impetus to Australia/Ukraine relations, and is a practical demonstration of the Government's commitment in this regard.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 26 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Was the listing of the Port Kennedy area in Western Australia on the Register of the National Estate deferred at the meeting of the Australian Heritage Commission on 21 November 1991; if so, what information was advanced to the Australian Heritage Commission to justify the deferral.

(2) For what reason was deferral of the listing chosen rather than placing Port Kennedy on the Interim List of the Register of the National Estate, followed by advertising and calling for public comment on listing.

(3) Has any other nomination of an area for listing on the Register of the National Estate been delayed or deferred as a result of representations by the Western Australian Government or its agencies.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) At its meeting on 21 November 1991, the Australian Heritage Commission agreed to defer a final decision on the listing of the Port Kennedy area to its next meeting, on 9-13 February 1992. The information provided by the Western Australian Government indicated that some development activity had occurred within the boundary agreed to by the Commission at its June 1991 meeting. This development may affect some of the values for which it is proposed to list the area. This information, and any other submitted by the Western Australian Government by 31 December 1991, will be assessed by the Commission before its meeting in February 1992. The Commission's final decision will be based entirely on the national estate significance of the area.

(2) The Commission has a long history of referring decisions on proposed entries in the Interim List of Register of the National Estate to the relevant State or Territory for comment prior to the publication of the listing. This procedure provides a final check on the effects that recent changes may have had on places so that any necessary amendments can be made prior to publication. Once a place is entered in the Interim List anyone may then object or provide any comment on the place. The Commission must consider those objections, giving upmost consideration to the significance of the place in national estate terms.

(3) The Commission has deferred consideration of nominations and the listing of places on several occasions following requests based on sound reasons from State and Territory governments. In the case of Western Australia, the Commission deferred consideration of nominations in the Karri Forest region in order to obtain information on the whole region. This deferral led to the reassessment of that region in co-operation with the State Department of Conservation and Land Management, the results of which will be announced shortly. Similarly, consideration of the Hepburn Heights area, near Perth, was deferred to obtain regional information on local remnant bush areas. The Commission has also deferred listing a marine region to avoid public confusion with state conservation processes.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 27 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) What provisions are laid down in existing departmental regulations, guidelines or instructions governing mid-term reviews of common-user contracts.

(2) Can the outcomes of mid-term reviews result in unilateral variation in the terms of common-user contracts, in particular in cases where the variation may result in terms that are less favourable than before to existing contractors.

(3) In the case of mid-term reviews of existing common-user contracts what provision is made, or is required to be made, for consultation with existing contractors before action is taken arising from the mid-term review.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Common-use contracts are not contracts in the strict legal sense. They are standing offers by the supplier to supply goods or services at the price agreed and on specified terms and conditions if they are ordered by the Commonwealth.
The terms and conditions usually provide for periodic review of pricing, either six-monthly or annually.

In accordance with the "Commonwealth Purchasing Manual", Chapter 13, Section 13 titled "Review of Orders Placed and Tender Specification", reviews of all orders placed against particular common-use contracts over a period may be undertaken "to determine whether:

(a) the range of requirements obtainable under the PCC (Period Contract Circulars, the former name for Buyers' Guides covering common use contracts) and/or the number of suppliers should be maintained/increased/decreased or defined in more precise terms;
(b) the estimated requirements are appropriate or require amendment; and/or
(c) fixed quantity contracts rather than PCCs should be used for particular users or requirements."
My Department also conducts reviews of common-use contracts at its own discretion to check the efficiency and effectiveness of its arrangements.
(2) The terms and conditions of the continuing offers cannot be varied unilaterally. Variations must be agreed between the parties, the Commonwealth and the supplier.

(3) There are no requirements for consultation with existing suppliers concerning actions arising from mid-term reviews unless that action involves formal variation of the terms and conditions of the continuing offer which can only occur with the agreement of the supplier.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 27 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the answer to Question on Notice No 1316 (Senate Hansard, p2987) relating to the adverse impact of World Heritage Listing of the Wet Tropics on the mining company, Stannum Pty Ltd:
(1) What was the itemised value of Stannum Pty Ltd's China Camp project, as estimated by Price Waterhouse in its assessment of the company's compensation claim.

(2) Following the receipt of advice from Price Waterhouse that Stannum Pty Ltd's compensation claim was inappropriate, was the company: (a) provided with any explanation as to why its claim had been rejected; if so, were the reasons given those which Price Waterhouse had used to justify its advice to the Government that the claim was inappropriate; and (b) invited to resubmit a revised claim; if not, why not.
(3) Did Price Waterhouse advise the Government at any stage that the compensation claim was inappropriate for any reason, aside from the amount claimed.
(4) Did Price Waterhouse make any comment on whether Stannum Pty Ltd should be allowed to resubmit a revised compensation claim based on their assessment of the value of the project.

(5) Given that Price Waterhouse's advice was based on the amount claimed, and given that Price Waterhouse did not advise the Government that the principle behind the claim was inappropriate, why was Stannum Pty Ltd not offered the opportunity to resubmit a revised claim.
(6) Would the Government consider a revised claim now if the liquidators of the company submitted one; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Price Waterhouse did not provide an estimate of the itemised value of the China Camp project.
(2) Stannum Pty Ltd was advised by me on 28 May 1990 in the following terms:

"I refer to your letter of 12 April 1990 regarding the status of your leases within the Wet Tropics of Queensland World Heritage Area. I have considered this situation with concern for your company and for Australia's World Heritage obligations for which I am responsible.

I understand that you have no new proposals for environmentally compatible uses of your leases. Regretfully, I cannot permit your proposed mining activities to proceed to the detriment of the World Heritage values of the Wet Tropics.

I have not regulated to prevent your proposed activities as I will be taking up the issue of such proscriptions in the context of Commonwealth/Queensland cooperative management arrangements for the Area.

However I shall not hesitate to prevent you from undertaking any activity which could damage the World Heritage values of the Wet Tropics of Queensland World Heritage Area, in accordance with Australia's international obligations under the World Heritage Convention, should I find it necessary.

As you are aware Price Waterhouse has prepared an independent report on your claim for compensation. Notwithstanding the assessed worth of your company, as reported by Price Waterhouse, your company remains ineligible for compensation from the Commonwealth Government in this case.

It should be understood that the Structural Adjustment Package was established to compensate for the `blanket' effects upon the whole North Queensland timber industry of the cessation of logging within the Wet Tropics.
It is the Government's policy that mining in the Wet Tropics will not be the subject of a blanket prohibition and individual proposals will be assessed on a case by case basis.
It is not Commonwealth policy to compensate mining companies where their activities are found to be incompatible with Australia's natural or cultural heritage."
(3) See answer provided in the Senate on 12 November 1991 in response to the honourable senator's question, Question No 1316, Part (5).
(5) See answer to (3) above.
(6) No. The Government's view remains that the company is ineligible for compensation from the Commonwealth Government.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 28 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Was the firm of Sinclair, Knight and Partners of South Perth employed as consultants by the Department of Defence to produce a report on the Marine Support Facility at Fremantle; if so (a) when did the consultancy begin; (b) what were the terms of reference for the consultancy; (c) what section of the department commissioned the work; (d) when was, or when will, the report be completed and handed to the department; (e) who has

QUESTION.PARA: been or who will be, given access to the report; and (f) what was the total cost of the report.

PARA.TAB: (2) Why was this study commissioned.
(3) What were the main findings of the report.
(4) Will a copy of the consultant's report be provided; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes; (a) the consultants were engaged on 26 August 1991; (b) the terms of reference were for Sinclair, Knight to independently value the capital investment by Australian Shipbuilding Industries (WA) Pty Ltd (ASI) in the WA Marine Support Facility; (c) the report was commissioned by Deputy Secretary Acquisition and Logistics; (d) the report was completed and handed to the department on 12 September 1991; (e) circulation of the report is restricted to those departmental officers involved in discussions with ASI; and (f) the total cost of the report to the department was $22,000.

(2) and (3) The study was commissioned to obtain an independent assessment of the level of investment by ASI in the Marine Support Facility, which is a factor in the pricing of ASI work for Navy at the Facility.
(4) No, the report is commercial-in-confidence.
